vgc2024.overview:
• Smeargle is a Pokemon with access to a strong supportive movepool, allowing it to function as a niche supportive option with great role compression.

  • Smeargle works well alongside Urshifu-S, especially Choice Band variants. Along with Follow Me support, Wide Guard can protect Urshifu from common super effective spread moves like Dazzling Gleam and Bleakwind Storm.

  • Smeargle's biggest weakness is its abysmal stats, necessitating the use of Focus Sash in order to give it any survivability. Due to its dreadful Attack stat, it cannot provide any offensive pressure outside of Endeavor, and so it is almost completely reliant on its partner to deal damage.

Support.description:
• Burning Bulwark can be used to dissuade Fake Out and potentially burn physical attackers; however, Spiky Shield can be considered to block certain status effects and bypass opposing Focus Sashes.

  • Decorate can punish passive play in front of Fake Out pressure and should be used alongside Pokemon slower than Smeargle in order to immediately threaten +2 attacks.

  • The invested bulk allows Smeargle to survive a Tachyon Cutter from Iron Crown and almost always survive a Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R after Terastallizing into Grass.

  • Tera Grass is generally preferred to be immune to Spore, though Tera Ghost can be used for a Fake Out immunity.

Sticky Web.description: Smeargle functions incredibly as an entry hazard lead on hyper offense teams thanks to its ability to lay Sticky Web and Stealth Rock via Stone Axe. Taunt can prevent hazards from Deoxys-D and Skarmory and sweepers such as Ogerpon-W and Dragonite from setting up, while Memento can allow safe switch-ins for other frail Pokemon like Gengar and Chien-Pao. Smeargle is exclusively used on hyper offense teams due to it more or less being a suicide lead. Some notable partners include frail attackers such as Swords Dance Iron Boulder and Sheer Force Gengar, which benefit greatly from Sticky Web and the safe switch-in Memento provides. Some counters to Smeargle include Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao, since they are both immune to Taunt and Memento, enabling them to use it as setup fodder; as a result, Fighting-types such as offensive Bulk Up Great Tusk and Iron Hands are good partners. Another Pokemon that annoys Smeargle is Great Tusk due to its hazard removal capabilities, making threats such as Swords Dance Ceruledge, Ogerpon-C, and Tail Glow Manaphy much appreciated.

Pink Blob (Specially Defensive).description:
• Blissey functions as an blanket check to special attackers on balance and stall teams, being especially useful against hard-to-check special threats such as Calm Mind Miraidon, Chi-Yu, Iron Bundle, and Walking Wake.
  • Seismic Toss is Blissey's only way to reliably deal damage to most opposing Pokemon, while Shadow Ball is able to do decent damage to Flutter Mane.
  • Thunder Wave is extremely useful to cripple common switch-ins such as Koraidon and can also find use against Flutter Mane and Terastallized Miraidon.
  • Blissey is a reliable setter of Stealth Rock, which can free up moveslots on Great Tusk and Iron Treads, but you should note that opposing Great Tusk and Iron Treads as well as Corviknight have little difficulty clearing entry hazards on Blissey.
  • The Tera Type is quite flexible. Tera Ground is very useful against Calm Mind + Parabolic Charge Miraidon sets, as it completely negates their recovery and allows Blissey to force out them out.
  • Tera Fire gives Blissey the ability to better take on Chi-Yu, with Heavy-Duty Boots negating the Stealth Rock weakness.
  • Tera Ghost provides a Fighting-type immunity and allows Blissey to switch out of Dugtrio and Gothitelle.
  • Solid defensive walls such as Skeledirge, Great Tusk, Dondozo, Scream Tail, and Dachsbun are good teammates to take on physical attackers like Koraidon that commonly come in on Blissey.
  • Blissey is not capable of handling all Miraidon sets on its own, so Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Iron Treads are heavily recommended teammates. In turn, these Ground-types have less pressure on them to stay healthy and can focus more on setting entry hazards.
  • Care should be taken against Miraidon and Iron Bundle, which often use pivoting moves or Taunt to gain momentum on Blissey. Proper prediction with Blissey's teammates may be required to handle this.
  • As a result, Rocky Helmet is an option, as it does damage to U-turn, Flip Turn, and Electro Drift users, making Miraidon and Iron Bundle unable to pivot on Blissey for free. If running Rocky Helmet, make sure you have plenty of Pokemon that can deal with entry hazards, such as Corviknight, Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Hatterene.
  • Flutter Mane is difficult for Blissey to reliably check due to Taunt and Psyshock sets, so Corviknight and Garganacl can help pick up the slack. In return, both appreciate Blissey being a safe switch-in to Iron Bundle.

Utility Wall.description:
Blissey's incredible special bulk allows it to check the tier's most dangerous special attackers such as Mesprit, Rotom, and Magneton along with setting Stealth Rock and being the only viable cleric. Stealth Rock is Blissey's most popular utility move because it lets other Stealth Rock setters run different sets alongside Blissey. Thunder Wave gives Blissey a way of punishing physical attackers such as Toxicroak, Paldean Tauros, and Scyther for switching in. However, this leaves you vulnerable to Pokemon such as Rotom and Haunter, so Shadow Ball can be used to threaten them instead. Heal Bell allows Blissey to relieve its team of status, helping against bulkier teams that may use Toxic. Any two-move combination of Stealth Rock, Thunder Wave, Shadow Ball, and Heal Bell can work depending on your team structure. Tera Ghost helps Blissey against many physical attackers, including Toxicroak, Hisuian Sneasel, and Tauros, and makes it easy to paralyze them on the following turn. Alternatively, Tera Fairy gives Blissey an incredible generalist typing that still helps it tank Fighting-type attacks.

Pairing Blissey with physical walls such as Sandaconda, Avalugg, and Sableye can help Blissey circumvent its low physical bulk. Stealth Rock Blissey also opens up frees up Sandaconda to run Coil sets instead. Additionally, Taunt users such as Froslass and Hisuian Qwilfish can beat Blissey by shutting down its recovery and utility moves. Having additional Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Bombirdier and Eelektross that can check these Pokemon helps Blissey substantially. Lastly, item disruption from Knock Off and Trick can be troubling for Blissey; without Heavy-Duty Boots, it's liable to being chipped down overtime by entry hazards, while Trick from Choice item users such as Rotom completely cripples Blissey. As a result, having a Knock Off absorber like Sandaconda or a Trick absorber like Sticky Hold Muk is great to support Blissey.

Calm Mind.description:
Blissey is able to run Calm Mind to set up against the tier's setup sweepers and wallbreakers such as Oricorio-P and Magneton, forcing them out while threatening common switch-ins such as Toxicroak and Rotom. Shadow Ball is Blissey's main offensive tool, threatening out Ghost-types like Rotom and Haunter. On the other hand, Dazzling Gleam and Stored Power can be used together for more overall damage output, allowing it to beat opposing Blissey and Braviary. Thunderbolt and Ice Beam can be used as well thanks to their useful coverage against Pokemon like Sandaconda and Bruxish, but they don't synergize well with Blissey's common Tera types. Tera Ghost ensures that Shadow Ball OHKOes non-Eviolite Haunter while also giving Blissey more opportunities to set up against Fighting-types it would otherwise be weak to, such as Hisuian Sneasel, Medicham, and Toxicroak. Tera Fairy also gives Blissey defensive traits such as resisting Fighting- and Dark-type attacks while boosting the power of Dazzling Gleam.

Blissey appreciates help from physical walls such as Qwilfish, Sableye, and Sandaconda, which are able to punish common Fighting-types that threaten Blissey like Hisuian Sneasel, Medicham, and Paldean Tauros. Blissey always wants to keep its item, so Knock Off absorbers like Sandaconda and Sticky Hold Muk and Trick absorbers like Choice Scarf Rotom pair well with it. Blissey also enjoys item displacement support, so Knock Off users like Bombirdier and Sableye make for good teammates. If you are running Tera Fairy with Dazzling Gleam and Stored Power, you will lack power against Magneton and Tera Steel Appletun. This opens up room for your own Fighting-types like Hisuian Sneasel and Toxicroak, which also threaten Appletun before Terastallizing.

Specially Defensive (Normal).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Pink Blob.description: Blissey's immense special bulk, useful utility moves, and reliable recovery allow it to function as a niche specially defensive pivot, as it checks threats such as Choice Specs Dragapult and Mega Charizard Y. Seismic Toss allows Blissey to pressure anything that isn't a Ghost-type with meaningful damage. Toxic is the preferred option to cripple Pokemon like Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona. Thunder Wave can also be used to annoy fast threats like Tornadus-T and Iron Valiant. It also allows Blissey to status Steel-types like Kingambit, Heatran, and Kartana. Teleport allows Blissey to safely pivot in teammates like Dragapult, Zamazenta, and Mega Medicham. However, Blissey is an acceptable Stealth Rock user if no other fits on your team. Shadow Ball can be considered as a niche option to break Dragapult's Substitutes and chip offensive Gholdengo, but it usually isn't worth dropping other moves. Tera Fairy gives Blissey a Fighting resistance in exchange for negligible Poison and Steel weaknesses, and it reduces the damage it takes from Pursuit users like Kingambit, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar. This should be used if Blissey absolutely has to take on a Fighting- or Dark-type like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, or Weavile. Blissey's defensive profile makes it a liability into certain Ghost-types, specifically Dragon Dance Dragapult and Gholdengo. Kingambit is a great option that deals with the former two threats while also benefitting from Blissey bringing it in safely with Teleport. Other wallbreakers like Tapu Lele, Dragapult, Mega Charizard Y, and Mega Medicham also appreciate pivot support and benefit from Blissey spreading Thunder Wave. A switch-in to powerful physical attackers, like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, Mega Medicham, and Kingambit, is necessary. Options like Toxapex, Slowbro, Skarmory, and Great Tusk can help out on this front. Knock Off is irritating for Blissey, as losing its Heavy-Duty Boots is quite detrimental to its pivoting efforts. Options such as Flyinium Z Tornadus-T and Gliscor can help out in this regard.

Defensive.description:
With the highest HP stat in all of Pokemon, an extremely impressive Special Defense stat, and access to important utility moves, Blissey is one of the best special walls in the entire tier, as well as being Normal's best Stealth Rock setter. Seismic Toss is the best move for Blissey to deal consistent damage and not be a completely passive Pokemon despite being ineffective against Ghost-types. Shadow Ball can be used over Seismic Toss in order to not be completely useless against Ghost-types. Stealth Rock helps Blissey's offensive teammates like Ursaluna and Maushold have an easier time getting KOs. Thunder Wave is used to slow down opposing Pokemon so that Blissey's slower, wallbreaking teammates, such as Ursaluna, have an easier time making progress. Alternatively, Healing Wish can be used over Thunder Wave in order to heal one of Blissey's teammates to full health, gaining momentum and making an end-game sweep easier.

Wallbreakers like Ursaluna and Choice Specs Hisuian Zoroark are great teammates for Blissey, as they are capable of dealing with the defensive Pokemon that Blissey is unable to beat, such as Sableye, Toxapex, and Dondozo. In return, Blissey can switch into attacks to keep the wallbreakers safe. Ditto and Blissey make a great pair, as, thanks to Natural Cure, Blissey is able to switch in to status moves that would otherwise cripple Ditto, such as Will-O-Wisp from Sableye, Skeledirge, and Rotom-W, as well as Thunder Wave from Gholdengo, then get rid of the status via Natural Cure. Ditto is also capable of dealing with setup sweepers that would otherwise threaten Blissey such as Baxcalibur and Dragonite. Thunder Wave is also a great option to use on opposing Choice Scarf users like Iron Valiant and Meowscarada so Ditto will not have to worry about Speed ties. Hisuian Zoroark is a great teammate for Blissey, as the immunity to Fighting-type moves is extremely valuable. Hisuian Zoroark is also able to burn opposing physical threats like Urshifu-R and Dragonite, which would otherwise make quick work of Blissey, as well as dealing with Ghost-type Pokemon which Blissey cannot damage without Shadow Ball. Hisuian Zoroark's Knock Off can also help Blissey wear down targets by making them vulnerable to entry hazards and removing Leftovers and Black Sludge recovery. Moreover, Hisuian Zoroark can disguise itself as Blissey and catch foes such as Iron Hands, Zamazenta and Sneasler off guard. Cyclizar is a good teammate for Blissey, as Blissey can switch into the fast special attackers that would otherwise threaten Cyclizar such as Flutter Mane and Choice Scarf Walking Wake. Cyclizar also carries Knock Off, which, as mentioned previously, works well with Blissey. Choice Specs Cyclizar outspeeds and threatens to OHKO non-Choice Scarf Iron Valiant, which would otherwise threaten Blissey, with Hyper Voice. Finally, Braviary and Staraptor can function as alternative switch-ins to Fighting-type Pokemon like Quaquaval and Great Tusk and retaliate with their STAB-boosted Brave Bird. Braviary uses Defog to keep Blissey and teammates safe from hazards, while Staraptor is a more offensive Choice Scarf user able to threaten Fighting-type Pokemon.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Calm Mind Support.description:
• The old reliable special wall is still viable, but it now takes a more active role through the use of Calm Mind.

  • Shadow Ball: Ghost-types like Nasty Plot Gholdengo and Swords Dance Mimikyu are still common options used against Blissey. This makes Shadow Ball a consistently strong option, particularly after a couple of Calm Mind boosts.

  • Tera Blast: Tera Blast is a very flexible attacking option, giving reliable STAB before Terastallizing and providing new offensive coverage thereafter.

  • Fling with Flame Orb: This is a surprising option to burn common Blissey switch-ins like Great Tusk, though failing to use it right away will force switching out to get rid of the burn. Fling also gets rid of Choice items from Trick users.

  • Stealth Rock: Stealth Rock remains a trusty support move for Blissey, punishing teams that are forced to switch around Blissey and its teammates.

Other Options

  • Fling with Toxic Orb: This is as close as it gets to Blissey regaining Toxic, though getting badly poisoned is devestating if Blissey is the last Pokemon around, making it a risky option.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Blissey is known for shrugging off big special hits with ease. However, its presence at team preview often attracts hard counters, and Tera is one way of dealing with that.

  • Dark: Dark Tera ruins Espathra's attempts to break through Blissey with Stored Power, at least forcing a Calm Mind war instead of a total loss. Blocking the occasional Psyshock from foes like Nasty Plot Gholdengo is also a plus.

  • Ghost: The Fighting-type immunity comes in handy for Blissey and prevents it from being trapped, though it does become more vulnerable to Gholdengo.

  • Fire: Tera Fire puts the brakes on Choice Specs Tera Fire Chi-Yu’s wallbreaking parade, ruining its ability to reliably 2HKO Blissey.

  • Flying: With the Flying Tera type, Blissey gains a handy resistance to Fighting and no longer has to worry about Fissure from Dondozo.

Items

  • Leftovers: As is the case with most walls, Leftovers’ passive recovery is a great supplement to Softboiled and helps Blissey be less passive itself.

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak lets Blissey set up against Garganacls that lack Body Press. It also blocks flinches from Chi-Yu’s Dark Pulse as well as the Special Defense drop from Espathra’s Lumina Crash.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 Def / 252 SpD with Calm or Bold: Beyond making Tera Blissey that much harder to break by foes like Espathra and Chi-Yu, going all-in on Special Defense means less frequent Softboiled uses against special attackers, especially with Leftovers.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spd with Bold: Maximizing both HP and Defense gives Blissey a little extra boost in physical bulk.

Bulky Offense.description: • This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

Special Wall.description: Blissey is a decent, albeit niche, wall and utility Pokemon in AAA with its ability to check most special attackers and extremely diverse movepool. Seismic Toss allows Blissey to not be completely passive and gives it consistent damage. Blissey's last two moveslots are flexible. Calm Mind + Shadow Ball is enough to beat the few special attackers that can otherwise defeat Blissey one-on-one such as Sheer Force Gengar and Gholdengo. Stealth Rock provides entry hazard support to free up a moveslot for a teammate, while Thunder Wave spreads status, crippling Pokemon like Azelf and Manaphy, and Heal Bell allows Blissey to operate as a cleric. Unaware allows Blissey to check special attackers attempting to set up on it like Gholdengo, Tail Glow Manaphy, and Iron Moth, while Well-Baked Body allows it to check Iron Moth while also giving it a more favorable matchup into Volcarona and Heatran. Magic Guard allows Blissey to avoid chip damage from entry hazards, letting it function as a better wall. Blissey most commonly runs Leftovers, as the extra healing can be extremely helpful, although on teams with more shaky hazard control, Heavy-Duty Boots can be opted for instead. A Calm nature is used to make Blissey function better as a special wall, notiably allowing it to always avoid the 2HKO from Sheer Force Gengar's Focus Blast. Blissey is most notably a special wall that does not require the use of Regenerator, which allows physical walls such as Great Tusk to run it instead. Blissey is most commonly seen on stall and fat team structures. Physically defensive walls like Corviknight and Deoxys-D are a must, as they help deal with Blissey's weakness to physical attackers and make a potent defensive core with it.

Magic Guard.description: With naturally high Special Defense and HP along with a decent neutral typing against most attacks, Blissey is an effective special wall capable of checking various special threats like Eternatus and Miraidon. Magic Guard also gives Blissey an immunity to residual damage from sources such as Salt Cure and Thunder Cage, with the protection from the latter and its low Attack limiting healing from Strength Sap letting it check most Take Heart Arceus formes. Ruination is a way to make near-guaranteed progress barring a miss, and its consistent damage mitigates Blissey's otherwise-crippling passivity. Topsy-Turvy deters setup attempts from Take Heart and Nasty Plot users by inverting their boosts and likely forcing a switch, in which case Blissey can then pivot out with Teleport or Parting Shot. Blissey's ability to deny Strength Sap healing makes it a great pick on balance teams carrying physical attackers such as Mega Lucario, as Fur Coat walls with Strength Sap usually can't get past Blissey, and physical attackers can force Imposter users out if they switch in while Blissey is pivoting. Blissey's immense frailty means that reliable physical walls, such as Mega Slowbro, are mandatory to cover for it; Arceus-Ghost can also bypass Blissey with either Secret Sword or Triple Arrows, so Yveltal makes for a good teammate. Imposter-proof Blissey with any Regenerator user.

vgc2024.overview:
• Entei is a strong offensive threat thanks to its amazing movepool, and access to Sacred Fire and Extreme Speed. Its great defensive stats combined with the immunity to Fake Out and Intimidate given by Inner Focus make it difficult to slow down. When next to Chien-Pao, It can threaten to OHKO metagame staples Kingambit, Rillaboom, and frailer Flutter Mane sets.

  • As mentioned above, Chien-Pao is a great partner for Entei as Its Sword of Ruin ability helps Entei get KOs more easily. Chien-Pao can also remove Indeedee-F's Psychic Terrain with Ice Spinner, allowing Entei to click Extreme Speed. Another great partner for Entei is Raging Bolt, which, with its powerful Electric-type moves, especially Thunderclap, can pressure foes resistant to Sacred Fire such as Urshifu-R. Ogerpon-W is also a great partner that can redirect Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes or threaten it with a strong Horn Leech.

  • Despite its strengths, Entei struggles against bulky Water- and Fire- types like Urshifu-R, Terastallized Ogerpon-W, Incineroar, and Gouging Fire, which resist Sacred Fire. All of them also either resist Chien-Pao's Ice-type STAB move or can mitigate it and Entei's damage output. Entei also faces issues against Farigiraf, which blocks Extreme Speed.

Bulky Attacker.description:
• Snarl slows down strong special attackers such as Flutter Mane, Raging Bolt, and Iron Crown. Tera Blast can be used instead when using Tera Grass to hit Water-types.

  • Assault Vest helps increase Entei's longevity against special attackers such as Flutter Mane, making Entei even harder to remove taking into account Sacred Fire's burn chance.

  • The EV spread allows Entei to survive a 116 Special Attack Modest Earth Power from Landorus and, when Terastallized, almost always survive Mystic Water Urshifu-R's Tera Water-boosted Surging Strikes, the rest of the EVs are used to maximize its damage output.

  • Tera Grass provides resistances to Water- and Ground- types like Urshifu-R and Landorus, as well as granting a Spore immunity. Tera Normal boosts Entei's Extreme Speed power while also removing its original weaknesses.

  • 252 HP / 36 Def / 220 SpD with Bold: This spread avoids a 2HKO from Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast after Leftovers recovery.

Rest.description:
• This set's write-up has not started yet, but here's some basic info to get you started!

  • Chesto Berry: This transforms Suicune into more of a late-game bulky sweeper, making Rest safe only once but giving it extra coverage against Dragonite and Roaring Moon.

  • Tera Type: Fairy is the best choice for avoiding getting torn apart by Choice Band Chien-Pao's Crunch and Swords Dance Urshifu-R's Wicked Blow.

Stealth Rock.description: Mega Tyranitar’s excellent defensive stats, typing, and Pursuit enable it to carve a niche as a reliable entry hazard setter and Pursuit trapper. Stone Edge is a strong STAB option that OHKOes Iron Moth while denting neutral targets such as Celesteela and Tapu Fini. Pursuit enables Mega Tyranitar to trap Psychic- and Ghost-types like Latios and Blacephalon. Knock Off offers a strong STAB move to OHKO bulky Ghost- and Psychic-types like Hisuian Zoroark and Latios. It is also the strongest move Mega Tyranitar has to hit Slowbro. Superpower is an option to snipe opposing Tyranitar and severely damage would-be switch-ins such as Excadrill. 176 Speed EVs enable Mega Tyranitar to outspeed Celesteela. Offensive Fighting-types such as Buzzwole, Iron Hands, and Keldeo appreciate Mega Tyranitar removing bulky Ghost- and Psychic-types. In exchange, Buzzwole covers Mega Tyranitar’s weaknesses to Fighting- and Ground-type attacks, while Keldeo can bring Mega Tyranitar in safely with Flip Turn. Other teammates such as Iron Moth and Tapu Bulu offer some defensive synergy and appreciate Mega Tyranitar’s ability to remove Psychic- and Fire-types, respectively. Mega Tyranitar’s typing gives its weaknesses to prominent attacking types such as Fighting, Water, and Ground, so Pokemon such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss can provide switch-ins to these types. The Future Sight support provided by the latter meshes well with Pursuit and dissuades Buzzwole and Iron Hands from switching in. Celesteela and Skarmory can help check Excadrill and Buzzwole, with Skarmory providing Spikes as a bonus. Clefable and Tapu Fini can check Fighting-types for Mega Tyranitar to some degree. Due to its lack of reliable recovery, Mega Tyranitar is vulnerable to being chipped down, so partners such as Choice Scarf Latias and Choice Band Scizor can ease the burden against frail sweepers such as Polteageist and Nihilego. Finally, Sand Rush Excadrill benefits from Mega Tyranitar’s Sand Stream and its ability to wear down Skarmory and Hippowdon.

Dragon Dance.description: Dragon Dance Mega Tyranitar utilizes its solid bulk and versatile offensive coverage to act as a threatening late-game cleaner. Ice Punch synergizes well with Stone Edge, as it chunks physically defensive Ground-types like Hippowdon and physically defensive Tangrowth. Earthquake is a valuable coverage option to hit Excadrill. Knock Off is an alternative STAB option that hits Gastrodon and Slowbro hard. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature is preferred to outspeed Alakazam with a single Dragon Dance. Dragon Dance Mega Tyranitar is usually found on bulky offense or hyper offense since these structures provide adequate tools to facilitate setup. The main hindrances for Mega Tyranitar are physically defensive walls like Hippowdon, Skarmory, and Clefable. Teammates like Mewoscarada, Tapu Fini, Swords Dance Scizor, and Meteor Beam Celesteela can take advantage of these Pokemon. Mega Tyranitar can also be revenge killed by common Fighting-types like Buzzwole, Keldeo, and Iron Hands even after a boost. Teammates such as Polteageist and Latios offer valuable typings and can soft-check Fighting-types. In return, they appreciate Mega Tyranitar’s ability to take advantage of specially defensive walls such as Blissey. Offensive Steel-types such as Sand Rush Excadrill and Scizor can cut a Mega Tyranitar sweep short, and thus Fire-types like Victini and Iron Moth are excellent partners. Magnezone deserves a special mention, as it traps Scizor and Skarmory. Sand Rush Excadrill appreciates Mega Tyranitar’s Sand Stream ability and in exchange offers insurance against Unaware Clefable. Mega Tyranitar is vulnerable to chip damage and thus appreciates pivoting support from Victini, Magnezone and Scizor. Slowbro and Slowking can bring in Mega Tyranitar safely with Teleport and offer Future Sight support for Buzzwole. Finally, Spikes from Skarmory and Mew can wear down walls.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Tyranitar is a brutally powerful wallbreaker capable of ripping through common defensive staples such as Clefable, Tapu Fini, and Celesteela. Its absurdly powerful Knock Off and Pursuit combined with its excellent special bulk also make it a premier Pursuit trapper capable of dominating common Psychic-types such as Choice Specs Latios and Slowking as well as physically frail foes like Iron Moth and Blissey. Earthquake targets Rock- and Steel-types such as opposing Tyranitar formes and Excadrill. Aerial Ace is an alternative to hit Fighting-types, notably 2HKOing Buzzwole. Assurance is another option, with it becoming a near-unwallable force when paired with entry hazards and synergizing well with Knock Off removing Heavy-Duty Boots. Tyranitar best fits on offense teams looking for a wallbreaker and Pursuit trapper. It is especially effective at removing special walls such as Blissey, making specially attacking teammates such as Choice Specs Latios and Iron Moth great partners. Pivots, notably specially attacking ones such as Slowbro and the aforementioned Iron Moth, can force in special walls and safely bring in Tyranitar. Entry hazard setters such as Excadrill and Skarmory enjoy Tyranitar's ability to break through most hazard removal options, and it greatly appreciates the chip damage they provide in return, especially if it's running Assurance. Tyranitar is dominated by Fighting-types such as Buzzwole and Iron Hands, making checks to them such as Clefable and Latios mandatory teammates. Sand Stream can notably support Sand Rush variants of Excadrill, and as physical wallbreakers, Tyranitar and Excadrill can weaken their shared physically defensive checks like Skarmory, Buzzwole, and Tangrowth. While Tyranitar matches up well against many special attackers, it falters against a good deal of them such as Alakazam and Thundurus-T due to its weaknesses, making specially defensive tanks such as Assault Vest Tangrowth useful partners.

Stealth Rock.description: Mega Tyranitar is an excellent option on a myriad of team compositions, sporting great utility with Knock Off and Stealth Rock and providing crucial resistances against many common offensive threats like Volcarona, Iron Moth, and Zapdos. Knock Off allows Mega Tyranitar to remove items from switch-ins such as Ferrothorn, Landorus-T, and Great Tusk, greatly impeding their longevity. Pursuit lets Mega Tyranitar threaten to trap and remove foes such as Tapu Lele Choice locked into Psychic, Iron Moth, and Heatran. Additionally, the threat of Pursuit forces foes like the Tapu Lele to play quite predictably, easing the burden for teammates such as Galarian Slowking not having to fear Psychic-type attacks lest they be trapped by Mega Tyranitar. A solid matchup into common Defoggers like Zapdos and Moltres allows Mega Tyranitar to proficiently set up Stealth Rock, while Knock Off removing Heavy-Duty Boots allows its own entry hazards to incur damage easier. The given Speed EVs allow Mega Tyranitar to outspeed Rotom-W. Iron Valiant is an incredible teammate for Mega Tyranitar, as Mega Tyranitar can trap and inflict heavy damage or outright remove Clodsire and Galarian Slowking, which are two of the biggest roadblocks for Iron Valiant. Defensively, Alomomola is very common teammate, as it can keep Mega Tyranitar healthy with Wish + Flip Turn and sponge attacks from Fighting-types it fears such as Mega Lopunny and Great Tusk. Gliscor can give Mega Tyranitar trouble, as once its Toxic Orb has been activated, it can switch in consistently without fearing the item loss of Knock Off while clearing Stealth Rock with Defog, so Ferrothorn, Urshifu-R, and Ogerpon-W are good teammates to assist combatting it.

Sand Stream (Rock).description:
The given EV spread lets Tyranitat outspeed Kingambit and not get 2HKO'ed by Flutter Mane.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Specially Defensive (Dark).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Salt Cure.description: With Ceaseless Edge and Stone Axe, Tyranitar becomes a potent entry hazard setter. Salt Cure pressures entry hazard removers like Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Toxapex while discouraging Pokemon that threaten Tyranitar like Iron Valiant and Gholdengo from switching in. Tyranitar also has the option of running Parting Shot to pivot on its would be switch-ins. Knock Off removes items like Covert Cloak from Pokemon like Toxapex and Gholdengo, which would otherwise block Salt Cure. The listed EV spread lets Tyranitar outrun most variants of Corviknight while having enough special bulk to survive +2 Make It Rain from defensive Gholdengo under Sand, and avoid a 2HKO from Never-Melt Ice Glacial Lance Kyurem on top of checking other special attackers like Skeledirge, Indeedee, and Rotom-H. Threats to Tyranitar include Annihilape, Iron Valiant, Palafin, Gholdengo, and Great Tusk. Tera Water checks Palafin and Gholdengo, while Tera Flying and Fairy check Great Tusk and Iron Valiant. Heavy-Duty Boots avoids entry hazard damage, which can be useful with Tera Flying, while Leftovers increases Tyranitar’s longevity. Tyranitar prefers bulky teammates like Corviknight, Rotom-W, and Rotom-C to patch up its Ground weakness. Physically defensive Toxapex is appreciated to handle the likes of Palafin and Iron Valiant and covers for Tyranitar's Fighting, Water, and Fairy weaknesses while also providing entry removal with Mortal Spin. Offensive Gholdengo is a good teammate, as it blocks entry hazard removal while also being able to throw off powerful attacks and spread status with Infernal Parade and Thunder Wave. Powerful offensive Pokemon like Iron Valiant, and Palafin can more easily break holes with the chip damage provided by Tyranitar.

Choice Band (Rock).description: Choice Band Tyranitar is the premier physical wallbreaker on Rock teams with its massive base 134 Attack stat and its access to Pursuit allowing it to revenge kill Gholdengo, Latias, and Hisuian Zoroark. Stone Edge deals huge damage to key Pokemon that Rock-types struggle with such as Corviknight, Celesteela, and Mega Venusaur. Knock Off means that Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Slowbro have to be careful when facing Tyranitar, along with removing valuable items from Toxapex and Empoleon. Fire Punch OHKOes the likes of Mega Scizor and Ferrothorn, both of which are threats to Rock teams. Earthquake helps with the Steel, Poison, and Rock mirror matchups by hitting Heatran, Clodsire, and Garganacl with a lot of power. Heavy Slam is also worth mentioning, as it can OHKO the likes of Tapu Bulu and Clefable and helps the Fairy matchup a tremendous amount. Ice Punch is an alternative as well, as it threatens to OHKO foes such as Landorus and Gliscor. Additionally, Tyranitar is able to set up sand, aiding teammates such as Garganacl, Cradilly, and Nihilego with a Special Defense boost. A Jolly nature allows Tyranitar to outspeed Choice Specs Iron Valiant outside of Electric Terrain and Mega Diancie while Sticky Web is up and OHKO both with Heavy Slam. This does, however, cause a loss of power, making the Steel and Poison matchups much harder by not 2HKOing Corviknight and Mega Venusaur with Stone Edge. Shuckle can set up Sticky Web, which allows Tyranitar to outspeed threats such as Gholdengo and Nidoking. Mega Diancie is a great special wallbreaker that Tyranitar needs on its team to deal with the Fighting-types that threaten it such as Kommo-o and Great Tusk. Cradily gives Tyranitar a switch-in to Ground-type moves that can reliably take hits and proceed to use Recover to maintain its health while also setting up Stealth Rock. Choice Scarf Terrakion pairs amazingly with Tyranitar by taking the physical wallbreaking load off of Tyranitar and splitting it between the two powerhouses. Terrakion is able to revenge kill Mega Lopunny while also benefitting from Tyranitar's Pursuit trapping ability. As a wall, Garganacl appreciates Tyranitar removing Leftovers from Pokemon such as Hippowdon and Ting-Lu. Ogerpon-C creates additional pressure in the Ground and Water matchups, complementing Tyranitar's power with great coverage. Nihilego helps with Tyranitar's weakness to Fairy-types, providing great Special Defense in sand, as well as Poison coverage. Although Tyranitar has great bulk, Rhyperior and Omastar are better checks to Scizor, a huge threat to the Rock type. Rhyperior's great bulk and ability allow it to beat Scizor, while Omastar's neutrality to Steel-type moves allows it to beat Scizor one-on-one.

Offensive.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Magic Guard.description: Magic Guard Ho-Oh is a strong, resilient wallbreaker that can also provide valuable support through entry hazard removal. Flare Blitz and Brave Bird are reliable STAB moves that deal great damage against the majority of the tier. Magic Guard negates recoil from these moves in addition to various forms of passive damage, such as Stealth Rock and poison. V-create is an option that allows Ho-Oh to have more immediate power over Flare Blitz, notably 2HKOing non-Fur Coat neutral Arceus formes, at the cost of lowering Ho-Oh's defenses and Speed after use. Also, V-create only has 8 PP compared to Flare Blitz's 24, which can cause issues in longer games. Fire Lash is another alternative that allows Ho-Oh to pressure passive walls like Dondozo more easily though consecutive Defense drops, eventually forcing these foes out. Tidy Up and Mortal Spin both serve as hazard removal, and each come with their own advantages. Tidy Up allows Ho-Oh to set up and potentially sweep, and it also somewhat mitigates the stat drops from V-create if it is used. Meanwhile, Mortal Spin applies more pressure to opposing walls, with poison helping to wear them down over the course of a game. Alternatively, Head Smash can be used to nearly OHKO Imposter users that lack Eviolite; otherwise, Ho-Oh risks being walled by its Imposter. Furthermore, Head Smash is Ho-Oh's best move to hit Mega Diancie, cleanly 2HKOing it. Strength Sap pairs well with Magic Guard to give Ho-Oh incredible longevity, ensuring that it can serve as a long-term check to opposing Fire- and Fairy-Types like Arceus-Fire, Arceus-Fairy, and Choice Specs Mega Diancie locked into Boomburst. Ho-Oh can struggle to defeat bulky Dragon- and Water-types such as Fur Coat Miraidon and Dondozo, so offensive teammates such as Mega Diancie and Kartana are appreciated. Ho-Oh also enjoys entry hazard and Knock Off support to push checks into 2HKO range, as well as allowing Head Smash variants to defeat Imposter users more easily. Ho-Oh can be Imposter-proofed by the aforementioned Fur Coat Miraidon and Dondozo, as well as by Fur Coat Arceus formes, although they should all ideally have some move to punish the Imposter user from simply staying in and setting up.

Ice Scales.description: Ice Scales Ho-Oh serves as an effective specially defensive wall capable of checking dangerous threats such as No Retreat Arceus-Ghost and Mega Gardevoir. V-create's high Base Power coming from Ho-Oh's respectable Attack helps reduce Ho-Oh's passivity and forces switches, while Lava Plume provides a high-PP alternative that can cripple Pokemon like Mega Mewtwo X with burns. Haze clears stat boosts from setup sweepers like No Retreat users and Arceus formes. Ho-Oh serves as a good user of Mortal Spin with its STAB moves threatening out Steel-types. Glare cripples Magic Guard Mega Mewtwo X on V-create sets. Knock Off removes important items like Covert Cloak and Eviolite from switch-ins like Miraidon and Imposter users, respectively. Teleport is an option to generate momentum and allow Ho-Oh to safely bring in allies against threats it cannot take on, such as certain Take Heart Arceus formes. Ho-Oh is threatened by certain special attackers such as Mega Diancie with a Rock-type move, Palkia-O, and Primal Kyogre; as a result, teammates such as Arceus-Poison and RegenVest Primal Kyogre make good partners. Ho-Oh also can have trouble against bulky setup Pokemon such as Miraidon and Take Heart Arceus formes, making Pokemon like Dialga-O, Salt Cure users, and Covert Cloak Imposter users good teammates. Fur Coat Dialga-O, Arceus-Poison, and Arceus-Ghost help check physical wallbreakers that break past Ho-Oh and can also absorb Knock Off, which is useful considering that Ho-Oh ceases functioning as a wall without its item. Ho-Oh can be Imposter-proofed by Pokemon like Fur Coat + Take Heart Arceus-Poison and Arceus-Ghost, though a Fire-immune Steel-type like Primordial Sea Registeel can be used to block the Imposter user's Mortal Spin.

Swords Dance.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Defensive Pivot.description: Swampert's good matchups against entry hazard removers like Excadrill, Rotom-W, and Salamence and access to Flip Turn make it a solid option for offensive teams as a Stealth Rock setter. Its typing allows it to check important threats like Mega Aerodactyl, Victini, and Excadrill, and utility options like Toxic and Yawn are useful to pressure Defoggers or force switches, respectively. Flip Turn allows Swampert to function as a slow pivot and bring another teammate in safely against Pokemon like Mega Venusaur, Clefable, and Slowbro. Toxic cripples Defoggers like Rotom-W and Salamence and walls like Slowbro, Tangrowth, and Gastrodon. Yawn is an alternative that can discourage setup sweepers like Calm Mind Latias or Clefable from taking advantage of Swampert, and it synergizes well with Flip Turn and entry hazards by forcing the opposing Pokemon to switch out and surrender momentum. A Relaxed nature with 0 Speed IVs is used to ensure Swampert is as slow as possible, letting it use Flip Turn after the opposing Pokemon attacks. Swampert fits best on offensive teams looking for a pivot that can set up Stealth Rock and safely bring in frail wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Latios against walls like Slowbro. Pivots like Victini and Thundurus-T can create VoltTurn cores and enjoy Swampert bringing them in against Pokemon like Mega Venusaur and Celesteela. Celesteela in particular appreciates Swampert's Electric immunity and ability to check Victini, Rotom-W, and Zeraora; in return, Celesteela deals with Grass-types that annoy Swampert like Tangrowth, Amoonguss, and Tapu Bulu. Slow wallbreakers like Iron Hands, Choice Band Tyranitar, and Choice Band Bisharp can pressure Pokemon that Swampert invites in like Slowbro, Salamence, and Clefable. The latter two are especially notable since they can Pursuit trap Slowbro, and all of them enjoy Swampert's ability to keep entry hazards up and maximize their wallbreaking potential. Finally, Swampert is very reliant on Leftovers to check threats like Excadrill as it lacks other forms of recovery, making Knock Off absorbers like Mega Tyranitar, Mega Venusaur, and Z-Move Hydreigon great partners.

Rain Sweeper.description: Mega Swampert is a staple on rain teams thanks to its great typing and Swift Swim allowing it to outspeed a majority of the metagame. Its immunity to Electric-type moves is greatly appreciated for rain teams, which can struggle with common Electric-types in the tier such as Raging Bolt and Tapu Koko. Flip Turn allows it to maintain momentum against checks like Rotom-W and Alomomola while wearing them down. Ice Punch hits Pokemon such as Dragonite, Serperior, and Mega Latias that would check Mega Swampert otherwise. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be used to take advantage of forced switches on Pokemon such as Garganacl and Galarian Slowking, as well as free up a slot for a teammate like Ferrothorn to run Spikes over Stealth Rock. Superpower is another option, which hits checks such as Kartana, Ferrothorn, and Ogerpon-W. As the premier rain setter in the tier, Pelipper is a mandatory teammate for Mega Swampert, being able to grant it free switches with its ability to act as a slow pivot with U-turn. Ferrothorn is another especially good teammate for Mega Swampert for its ability to switch into the defensive Water-types Mega Swampert has trouble dealing with such as Alomomola, Slowbro, and Rotom-W as well as Ogerpon-W lacking Superpower, and it can also make progress by setting hazards and forcing switches against these foes. Ferrothorn is also able to remove items like Rocky Helmet from Pokemon such as Skarmory, letting Mega Swampert attack more freely, and Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon such as Zapdos and Alomomola, making them more easily worn down by hazards. Mega Swampert can also struggle against Grass-types such as Kartana and Rillaboom, which makes Pokemon like Zapdos and Tornadus-T great teammates for their ability to check the aforementioned Pokemon. Mega Swampert also appreciates other Swift Swim users such as Barraskewda as teammates, being able to wear down each others' shared checks such as Ferrothorn and Rotom-W. Archaludon is a good partner, being able to check Grass- and Water-types Mega Swampert has trouble with such as Alomomola, Ogerpon-W, and Serperior. In return, Mega Swampert threatens Ground-types that Archaludon struggles with like Landorus-T and Gliscor.

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Water

Yawn lets Swampert threaten to put foes to sleep while forcing switches, a rarity for Water teams aside from fringe options like Politoed. Ice Punch can surprise Ground-resistant switch-ins with super effective damage, notably 2HKOing Latios after Stealth Rock, but finding a moveslot for it is difficult. Mirror Coat can grab a surprise OHKO on problematic targets like Flutter Mane, but its reliance on prediction makes it inconsistent. Heavy-Duty Boots can be worthwhile on some teams, since Swampert struggles against some Spikes-stacking teams like Flying and Poison, but this leaves it without any recovery and thus more easily worn down by direct damage.

Defensive Pivot (Water).description:
Swampert is the best offensive Stealth Rock setter available to Water teams thanks to its great bulk and access to Flip Turn. Its partial Ground typing is also excellent, granting it an Electric immunity which notably lets it block Volt Switch from common threats such as Zapdos, Iron Treads, and Iron Hands. STAB Earthquake strikes fear into the heart of bulky Pokemon that often annoy Water such as Clodsire, Alolan Muk, and Gouging Fire while boasting decent neutral damage even with low investment. Alternatively, Earth Power deals less neutral damage but allows Swampert to lure annoying physical tanks like Archaludon, Torkoal, and Pecharunt and surprise them with a 2HKO. Flip Turn allows Swampert to pivot out of common switch-ins like Amoonguss, Skarmory, and Latios and act as a pivot for frailer teammates. Flip Turn's damage also shouldn't be underestimated; boosts from it being a STAB move, rain, and potentially Torrent can make it a nasty parting gift. As an example, a Flip Turn with all of those multipliers active has a chance to OHKO Gliscor after Stealth Rock. Swampert can set up Stealth Rock itself, providing critical entry hazard support for a type with somewhat limited options for the role; this also lets it break Focus Sash on major threats that use it such as Breloom. Since its STAB combination is excellent on its own, Swampert is free to run a utility move of choice in the last moveslot: Roar lets it rack up passive damage against the opposing team after setting up Stealth Rock and phaze some setup sweepers that it can't threaten to KO, such as Calm Mind Primarina and IronPress Skarmory. Protect lets Swampert make the most of Leftovers recovery while scouting Choice item users such as Choice Band Chien-Pao and Choice Specs Flutter Mane, making them easier to play around. Knock Off gives Swampert extra coverage against foes like Latios and lets it remove Heavy-Duty Boots from its switch-ins, forcing them to take Stealth Rock damage and thus making them easier to outlast. The given EV spread maximizes Swampert's ability to take special hits, achieving such feats as avoiding a 2HKO from Choice Specs Iron Valiant's Moonblast after Stealth Rock and surviving 4x super effective hits like Hydrapple's Giga Drain. 24 Attack EVs guarantee that Earthquake will always 2HKO Garganacl after Stealth Rock damage, as well as OHKO Excadrill, and 2HKO bulky Gouging Fire. On Earth Power sets, use a Calm nature and move the Attack EVs into Special Attack.

Since its typing and Stealth Rock make it universally useful to Water, Swampert is highly flexible in what teams it can fit on. Swords Dance Ogerpon-W is a quintessential teammate that enjoys entry hazard support to wear down its checks before a sweep. Empoleon is great for checking Grass-type attackers that threaten Swampert, like Amoonguss and Abomasnow, and discouraging Freeze-Dry spam from Kyurem and Alolan Ninetales; its STAB Flash Cannon also threatens Hatterene and Galarian Weezing, both of which can frustrate Swampert's attempts to set up Stealth Rock. Toxapex is an even sturdier Grass-type check that can deal with Meowscarada and Ogerpon formes, and it stacks hazards with Swampert in the form of Toxic Spikes. Choice Scarf Hisuian Samurott can check some threats that annoy Swampert like Slowbro, Latios, and Air Balloon Gholdengo while also contributing Spikes. Calm Mind Primarina is a potent wincon that can deal with offensive Dark- and Dragon-types like Chien-Pao and Dragonite, which tend to overwhelm Swampert, and it enjoys Swampert pressuring common special walls, most notably Clodsire. Choice Specs Greninja especially can tear massive holes in the opposing team with help from Swampert's Stealth Rock, and its coverage threatens common hazard-control options like Hatterene, Great Tusk, and Brambleghast. Keldeo can threaten some Rapid Spin users that Swampert has trouble with like Great Tusk, Avalugg, and Alolan Sandslash, and it enjoys Flip Turn support to hit the field safely; other frail offensive threats like Greninja, Barraskewda, and Cloyster love Swampert's reliable ability to pivot as well. Other pivots like Rotom-W, Pelipper, Barraskewda, and Urshifu-R can form an oppressive VoltTurn core with Swampert, continuously wearing down foes in conjunction with entry hazards. Volcanion can punish Grass- and Ice-types similarly to Empoleon while discouraging Corviknight and Forretress from spending a turn on hazard removal with its Fire-type STAB move.

Support Pivot.description:
• This set's write-up has not started yet, but here's some basic info to get you started!

  • 244 HP / 252 Def / 12 SpD with Impish or Relaxed: Maximizing Defense lets Swampert preform the best against foes like Chien-Pao and Urshifu-R. The Special Defense investment avoids a OHKO from Silk Scarf Ursaluna-B's Blood Moon.

  • 252 HP / 20 Def / 236 SpD with Sassy or Careful: With Sitrus Berry, this spread ensures Choice Specs Latios will faill to 2HKO Swampert with Draco Meteor.

  • 0 Speed IV: A Speed IV of 0 can be perfect for getting in teammates unharmed, but this can be risky against powerful foes like Ursaluna-B.

RegenVest.description: With an excellent defensive typing, solid bulk, Flip Turn, and good utility with Knock Off, Swampert is a premier RegenVest pivot that checks notable special attackers such as Gholdengo, Zapdos, and Iron Moth while also getting in offensive teammates with its slow pivoting. Stone Edge hits Zapdos, Volcarona, and Dragonite, while Mirror Coat can be used against setup attackers like Enamorus-T and strong special attackers such as Walking Wake and Latios. Flying-types like Corviknight and Mandibuzz appreciate Swampert's Electric immunity, letting them reliably check physical attackers and remove entry hazards. Frail offensive Pokemon like Azelf, Chien-Pao, and Barraskewda benefit from Swampert, as its slow pivoting lets them come in more safely, and they can also take advantage of its Knock Off removing items from their common checks such as Deoxys-D and Corviknight. Swampert maintains much of its special bulk through its Assault Vest, so it's vital to have Knock Off absorbers such as Corviknight and Great Tusk for Swampert to more reliably check special attackers. Grass-resistant Pokemon like Heatran and Well-Baked Body Gholdengo are also good teammates for Swampert, as special attackers such as Iron Moth and Deoxys-S frequently run Grass-type coverage predominantly for it.

Rain Sweeper (Water).description: Mega Swampert is a mainstay on rain-based Water teams due to its ability Swift Swim, part-Ground typing, great role compression, and fearsome wallbreaking ability, heavily improving the Electric, Poison, and Dragon matchups. Earthquake nails Water-resistant foes like Toxapex, Hisuian Goodra, and Water Absorb Clodsire as well as Electric-types such as Tapu Koko, Iron Hands, and Zeraora. Furthermore, with sufficient chip damage, it's capable of overwhelming Ferrothorn and Gastrodon. Waterfall is nicely complemented by rain as it outdamages Ice Punch when combatting Flying-types like Zapdos and Corviknight. Waterfall is notably preferred over Liquidation due to its higher PP and potential to break through walls, such as the aforementioned Corviknight, via flinching. Ice Punch targets Dragon- and Grass-types like Dragonite, Latias, and Tapu Bulu due to their resistances to Mega Swampert's STAB combination. Flip Turn allows Mega Swampert to escape unfavorable situations and form pivoting cores with teammates like Pelipper, Greninja, and Barraskewda. Alternatively, Stealth Rock may be used to take advantage of Mega Swampert's ability to force switches, while other options such as Stone Edge and Toxic may be used to threaten Mantine, Pelipper, and Rotom-W which wall it otherwise. A Jolly nature is preferred to outpace Choice Scarf Thundurus-T, Volcarona after one Quiver Dance, and opposing Mega Swampert. However, an Adamant nature may be used for higher damage rolls against Kommo-o, Mega Venusaur, and Gastrodon. Pelipper is a perfect teammate, as it provides rain with Drizzle, slowly pivots into Mega Swampert with U-turn, and removes entry hazards with Defog. In return, Mega Swampert provides an immunity against the aforementioned Electric-type moves and threatens Rock-types such as Terrakion and Mega Diancie. Toxapex provides a buffer against Grass-types like Rillaboom and Meowscarada as well as Kommo-o while also providing Toxic Spikes to enhance Mega Swampert's wallbreaking capabilities. Furthermore, Toxapex appreciates Mega Swampert forcing out Heatran and Gholdengo, as they easily take advantage of Toxapex's passivity. Urshifu-R and Barraskewda deal with threats like Ferrothorn, Hydreigon, and Kyurem, while Mega Swampert removes Toxapex and Water Absorb Clodsire. Other Swift Swim users like Basculegion-F and Barraskewda take on threats like Slowbro and Tapu Koko outside of rain, respectively. Greninja provides speed control outside of rain and beats Fairy-types such as Tapu Bulu and Alolan Ninetales with Gunk Shot as well as overloads shared Water-resistant foes like Ferrothorn and Mega Venusaur with a Choice Specs set. Empoleon is a good teammate as it can free up Mega Swampert's Stealth Rock moveslot and switch into Freeze-Dry users like Kyurem and Alolan Ninetales.

Specially Defensive (Water).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

RegenVest.description: Mega Swampert is a premier special wall thanks to its great typing and decent bulk. It has a good matchup against common special attackers like Miraidon, Eternatus, and Blacephalon. Knock Off is a useful utility move, removing items like Imposter Chansey's Eviolite, Miraidon's Covert Cloak, and Primal Kyogre's Assault Vest. Stone Axe can be used to set up Stealth Rock, and threaten physically frail Pokemon like Mega Beedrill and Blacephalon, while Mortal Spin can be used for entry hazard removal, and in conjunction with Knock Off, poison walls that would otherwise be immune thanks to Covert Cloak, like Miraidon and Ice Scales Primal Kyogre. Mega Swampert is a particularly good user of this Mortal Spin thanks to hitting Steel-types like Mega Steelix and Dialga-O with its Ground-type STAB move. Mega Swampert is mainly used as a special wall and slow pivot, making teammates such as Mega Mewtwo X and Mega Diancie suitable partners. Despite its good special bulk being further boosted by Assault Vest, its physical bulk is middling at best, meaning common mixed attackers like Mega Mewtwo X and Deoxys-A largely don't have trouble with it. Therefore, Fur Coat Miraidon and Ice Scales Arceus-Fairy are nice defensive options. Since Mega Swampert's Mortal Spin + Ground-type STAB move threatens most Pokemon, a Take Heart Arceus forme with a held Plate is the easiest Imposter-proofing option.

Rain Sweeper.description:
Surf is reliable due to its perfect accuracy, Weather Ball is stronger but reliant on rain being up, and Hydro Pump is even stronger but has lower accuracy. Ice Beam nails Appletun and Trevenant, but Focus Blast hits Arboliva harder. Using a Modest nature maximizes Ludicolo’s damage output, but opting for a Timid nature lets it outspeed foes like +1 Morpeko, +2 Adamant Veluza, and Choice Scarf Swanna under rain.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Rain Setter.description:
Pelipper is OU's premier rain setter thanks to Drizzle and reliable recovery in Roost. Surf threatens a number of common Stealth Rock setters such as Gliscor, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T with OHKOs in rain, while Hurricane covers Grass-types like Meowscarada and Serperior while also dealing more damage to Hisuian Samurott. Knock Off can be run instead of Hurricane to cripple foes like Galarian Slowking, making them easier for its teammates to break through. A Speed-reducing nature in conjunction with 0 Speed IVs gives Pelipper its slowest possible U-turn, allowing it to safely bring in teammates to make use of its rain. A physically defensive EV spread lets Pelipper easily handle physical threats like Hisuian Samurott and Zamazenta, running enough Special Defense EVs to guarantee take on Enamorus's Moonblast after Stealth Rock. On the other hand, a specially defensive spread can be used to take less damage from special attackers that would otherwise take advantage of Pelipper's poor Special Defense, such as Gholdengo and Enamorus, as well as avoiding an OHKO from Choice Specs Dragapult's Draco Meteor, while running enough Defense EVs to survive two Hisuian Samurott's Ceaseless Edge from full. The corresponding negative nature alongside 0 Speed IVs give Pelipper the slowest possible U-turn to bring its teammate in safely, and underspeeding uninvested Tyranitar and the niche Hippowdon allow its rain to override their sand when leading against them. Though Pelipper is rarely Terastallized, Tera Ground can be used to remove its 4x weakness to Electric-type moves from Raging Bolt and Zapdos and safely pivot out of them.

Pelipper should be used exclusively on rain teams where it is commonly partnered with powerful wallbreakers like Barraskewda, which is greatly enabled by Swift Swim activation, and Raging Bolt, which benefits from Water-type Weather Ball to break through Ground-types. Due to Pelipper's weakness to Stealth Rock and that it can't afford to run Heavy-Duty Boots, it benefits greatly from Rapid Spin support from Iron Treads to allow it to repeatedly set rain. Because Damp Rock is needed to maximize the number of rain turns, Pelipper appreciates having a teammate that can switch into Knock Off, such as Kingambit, especially if its Air Balloon has been popped. Due to its 4x weakness to Electric-type moves, Pelipper enjoys Ground-type teammates like Iron Treads that can easily switch into the likes of Raging Bolt. Pokemon like Air Balloon Kingambit that can help against Kyurem are also appreciated, as Pelipper is unable to defensively check it and rain teams tend to struggle against it.

Rain Setter (Flying).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Rain Setter (Water).description:
Pelipper provides rain for Water teams, which enables Barraskewda and wallbreakers like Azumarill and Walking Wake. Hurricane is the STAB move of choice, bypassing the accuracy check in rain while nailing Water-resistant Grass-types, such as Amoonguss, Meowscarada, and Breloom. Roost allows Pelipper to come in multiple times throughout the match to re-set rain if need be. U-turn let's it slow pivot into threats such as Quaquaval and Barraskewda. Knock Off cripples foes, while Surf gives a secondary STAB move boosted by rain, allowing Pelipper to wear down Pokemon like Gholdengo and Kingambit. Heavy-Duty Boots allows it to switch in and set rain even if Stealth Rock is up. An alternative EV spread of 248 HP / 48 Def / 212 Spe with a Timid nature can be used to outspeed Adamant Breloom.

Barraskewda is the obvious partner choice thanks to its ridiculous Speed with Swift Swim in rain. It also appreciates Pelipper's slow pivoting with U-turn due to its lack of bulk. Walking Wake is another great rain attacker, since its STAB Dragon-type moves hit most Water-resistant and immune foes, such as opposing Gastrodon and Amoonguss, hard. Quaquaval appreciates Pelipper's slow pivoting to come in safely and can potentially snowball through teams with rain-boosted Aqua Step and Moxie. Quaquaval can also get rid of entry hazards should Pelipper get hit by Knock Off, provided it has Rapid Spin. Gastrodon and Quagsire are also really good partners thanks to their Electric immunities. Both also provide entry hazards, pressuring opponents, and Pelipper can use hazard removal turns to pivot out with U-turn or heal with Roost. Rotom-W can form a VoltTurn core with Pelipper, allowing the team to gain momentum easily and bring in Pokemon fairly safely. Rotom-W can also switch into opposing Electric-types like Magnezone, Iron Hands, and Sandy Shocks if necessary. Toxapex provides a Fighting resistance, a Grass neutrality, and another pivot thanks to its ability, Regenerator. Slowking checks threats such as Indeedee and Walking Wake, and it's another slow pivot thanks to Chilly Reception and Regenerator, bringing Pelipper in safely to set the rain. Both Toxapex and Slowking can also easily pivot into Pelipper with Eject Button, since Regenerator means they won't lose too much health from an attack. Azumarill can take advantage of rain with priority in Aqua Jet, as well as bringing a very strong Water-type STAB move.

Choice Specs (Water).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

vgc2024.overview:
• Pelipper's Drizzle ability, STAB Hurricane for Pokemon like Amoonguss and Ogerpon-W, and access to Tailwind, make it the premier rain setter.

  • Pelipper is best paired with partners who benefit from like Archaludon and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R, both having incredibly hard-hitting moves in Rain being Electro Shot and Surging Strikes, respectively.

  • Pelipper's mediocre bulk and Speed leave it especially vulnerable to fast threats like Flutter Mane and Chien-Pao. These, combined with Fake Out pressure, can prevent Pelipper from getting up Tailwind and minimize its impact on the game. Drizzle boosting opposing Water-types like Urshifu-R and Ogerpon-W's STAB moves can also make Pelipper disadvantageous long-term.

Rain Setter.description:
• Pelipper can use Wide Guard over Protect to block spread move, most notably Iron Crown's Expanding Force. Pelipper utilizes Weather Ball to obtain strong boosted STAB, threatening Incineroar and Landorus.

  • Pelipper utilizes Rocky Helmet to provide useful chip damage against Fake Out users, Ice Spinner Chien-Pao, and Urshifu-R, but can use Focus Sash for survivability or Damp Rock to extend rain for slower teams.

  • When using Focus Sash, Pelipper should use an alternative spread of 4 Hp / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with a Modest or Timid nature instead, foregoing bulk.

  • The EV spread helps Pelipper survive a Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast and almost always a Miracle Seed Rillaboom's Wood Hammer. The Speed investment allows Pelipper to outspeed Ogerpon when in Tailwind.

  • Tera Steel helps Pelipper gain resistances to strong threats like Rillaboom and Flutter Mane, giving it a turn to set Tailwind or click Hurricane. Tera Flying can be used to boost Pelipper's damage output and, when fully invested in Special Attack, threaten Amoonguss for an OHKO. Tera Ghost makes Pelipper immune to common moves, being Fake Out and Extreme Speed.

Pelipper.description:
• Hurricane's full accuracy in Rain makes it mandatory on Pelipper. It provides consistent damage and threatens the Grass-type Pokemon that resist Water.

  • Hydro Pump is Pelipper's best Water-type attack but can be forgone if accuracy is a concern. Helping Hand paired with a fast Water-type Pokemon can compensate for the lack of reliable Water-type damage.

  • Wide Guard can be used over Protect to answer ubiquitous spread moves such as Gholdengo's Make it Rain and Sylveon's Hyper Voice.

  • Focus Sash ensures Pelipper survives attacks from Pokemon that might otherwise outspeed and OHKO it, such as Hydreigon and Annihilape. Damp Rock extends the uptime of Pelipper's rain-reliant teammates, allowing them to beat bulkier teams without requiring repeat switch-ins.

  • 252 Speed EVs with a Timid nature allow Pelipper to outspeed the entire metagame with Tailwind, as well as some notable Choice Scarf threats such as Annihilape.

  • A Ground Tera type grants Pelipper an immunity to Electric and a resistance to Rock, which are its main concerns. With a Grass Tera type, it instead resists Electric, but this grants an immunity to Spore and Rage Powder.

Rain Setter.description: The ability Drizzle and access to U-turn allow Pelipper to be the best rain setter in the tier, thus a staple on rain teams. 0 Speed IVs and a Relaxed nature allow Pelipper to pivot teammates in safely with the slowest possible U-turn. Its decent physical bulk alongside Scald lets Pelipper check and threaten to cripple popular offensive presences like Urshifu-R and Mega Lopunny, as well as Stealth Rock setters like Landorus-T and Heatran. Roost keeps Pelipper healthy throughout the course of the game, enabling consistent rain and better longevity against threats such as Urshifu-R. Hurricane can be used to hit foes such as Urshifu-R, Tera Grass Heatran, and most notably, Ogerpon-W, for super effective damage, while Defog is an alternative that removes entry hazards if common partners in Tornadus-T or Zapdos lack it. Tera Ground is used to change Pelipper's 4x weakness to Electric into an immunity to potentially absorb Volt Switch from Tapu Koko or Rotom-W and pivot out. Pokemon that need rain to boost their strength and Speed such as Mega Swampert, Barrsekwda, Battle Bond Greninja, and Urshifu-R are great partners for Pelipper. They particularly appreciate Pelipper being able to bring them onto the field safely and often into a winning position via a slow U-turn. Mega Swampert also serves as a bulky Electric-immune Pokemon that can check Tapu Koko for Pelipper. Other Pokemon like Zapdos and Tornadus-T also benefit from the rain Pelipper sets up and can act both as excellent wallbreakers or entry hazard removers. Furthermore, Ferrothorn and Archaludon can take advantage of Pelipper's typing defensively, with the latter's signature move in Electro Shot pairing especially well with rain.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to Battle Stadium Singles Regulation F! This Pokemon has been updated to reflect the new Pokemon that The Indigo Disk has brought!

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Bulky Drizzle.description:
• Pelipper is the best rain summoner around, letting dangerous teammates like Urshifu-R, Swift Swim Basculegion, or Electro Shot Archaludon run wild!

  • Ice Beam: This lets Pelipper do huge damage to Dragonite, who otherwise takes most of this set on fine.

  • Tailwind: Tailwind gives Pelipper even more team support props, making it an especially scary option with Urshifu-R sets.

  • Roost; Roost takes advantage of its decent physical bulk, increasing its staying power. This is particularly useful in weather wars against Torkoal and Hippowdon.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Pelipper is all about rain support, so only Terastallize if if its needed to win certain match-ups.

  • Steel: Tera Steel prevents total annihilation from Freeze-Dry users like Iron Bundle and Alolan Ninetales.

Ground: Tera Ground gives Pelipper an immunity to Volt Switch, which is often used against it early-game. This wastes a turn for the opponent and gives Pelipper the chance to safely U-turn or deal massive damage with a rain-boosted Hydro Pump.

Grass: Tera Grass is a viable way to gain an Electric resistances without being revenge killed by Urshifu-R.

Alternate EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA with Quiet: With 0 Speed IVs, this is used to underspeed uninvested Hippowdon, giving Pelipper the initial advantage in weather wars.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpA with Bold or Relaxed: This spread gives Pelipper a better matchup against dominant, powerful physical attackers like Urshifu-R and Dragonite.

Fast Drizzle.description:
• This set's write-up has not started yet, but here's some basic info to get you started!

  • Quick Attack: Quick Attack may seem silly, but it allows Pelipper to snipe opposing Focus Sash foes like Iron Bundle and Urshifu-R.

Drizzle Bird.description:
• Hydro Pump versus Surf: Hydro Pump significantly weakens opponents when rain-boosted, often picking up surprise KOs. Surf is the far more reliable option.

  • Hurricane versus Roost; The choice between Hurricane and Roost is a matter of coverage versus longevity. Hurricane gives Pelipper a powerful secondary STAB move, while Roost takes advantage of its decent physical bulk, increasing its staying power. This is particularly useful in weather wars against Torkoal

Tera Types

Ground: Tera Ground gives Pelipper an immunity to Volt Switch, which is often used against it early-game. This wastes a turn for the opponent and gives Pelipper the chance to safely U-turn or deal massive damage with a rain-boosted Hydro Pump.

Grass: Tera Grass is a viable option for Rotom-W, which primarily uses Hydro Pump on lead while providing a Volt Switch resistance.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA with Quiet: With 0 Speed IVs, this is used to underspeed uninvested Hippowdon, giving Pelipper the initial advantage in weather wars.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpA with Relaxed: This spread gives Pelipper a better matchup against dominant, powerful physical attackers like Choice Band Dragpault and Extreme Speed Dragonite.

  • 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Modest: This offensive spread can be used to outspeed uninvested Corviknight and others in that Speed tier.

Items

  • Eject Button: This extra method of pivoting makes it much easier to switch Pelipper in just for getting rain up.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs can be used to take advantage of Pelipper's powerful STAB moves.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry provides longevity on defensive sets.

Rain Setter.description: • This EV Spread survives Choice Specs Flutter Mane Moonblast and outspeeds Iron Bundle in Tailwind.

Rain Setter (Water).description:
Underspeeds Hippowdon, allowing Rain to be set last.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Specs (Psychic).description:
A Modest nature lets Gardevoir OHKO Kingambit with Vacuum Wave after Stealth Rock damage.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Bulky Offense.description:
• Between using Trace to cancel Ruin abilities and burning foes with Will-O-Wisp, Gardevoir can overwhelm some of the meta's strongest physical sweepers.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Beyond crippling physical attackers for the remainder of the match, the passive burn damage breaks Focus Sash on Chien-Pao and Multiscale on Dragonite.

  • Psyshock versus Psychic: The choice of Psychic-type STAB comes down to what you need to hit hardest. Psyshock is the best option into Flutter Mane, Iron Moth, and Clodsire, while Psychic puts more pressure on Toxapex and many variants of Bulk Up Annihilape.

Other Options

  • Sitrus Berry versus Pinch Berry: Sitrus Berry is normally the preferred recovery item for bulky Gardevoir sets, but it is a highly sought-after item. If needed elsewhere, Gardevoir's bulk profile is strong enough that running a pinch Berry can work.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Using Tera usually improves common matchups like Flutter Mane and is certainly an option if a target is deemed high enough priority. Otherwise, Gardevor's impressive suite of defensive attributes combined with excellent STAB coverage are great as is.

  • Fire: Tera Fire’s resistances to Ice, Steel, and Fairy are all excellent, greatly improving the matchups against Flutter Mane, Scizor, and Kingambit. Tera boosted Mystical Fire will also 2HKO maximum HP Kingambit without Assault Vest.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy can patch up this set's lacking power by boosting Moonblast, and the removal of Gardevoir's Psychic typing makes dealing with opposing Ghost-types like Flutter Mane and Mimikyu more manageable.

  • Normal: Tera Normal's defensive attributes are lacking overall, but nullifying a key Ghost-type attack from the likes of Flutter Mane and Mimikyu can give an opening to deal extra damage or inflict a crucial burn.

EV Spreads

  • The spreads listed below all have an even HP stat to guarantee that Sitrus Berry activates after getting hit by Ruination. All spreads are also capable of surviving one unboosted Shadow Ball from Flutter Mane.

  • 244 HP / 244 Def / 20 Spe: Near maximum HP and Defense gives Gardevoir fantastic defensive calcs; after Sitrus Berry recovery and inflicting a turn 1 burn, Gardevoir has a strong chance of avoiding the 3HKO from Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash and Assault Vest Ting-Lu's Heavy Slam. The Speed investment outspeeds maximum Speed Adamant Kingambit.

  • 244 HP / 204 Def / 60 Spe: A little extra Speed investment lets Gardevoir outspeed defensive Gholdengo with 20 Speed EVs, but Gardevoir is much less likely to avoid the 3HKOs mentioned in the main spread.

Offensive.description: • EV Spread: This spread allows Assault Vest Gardevoir to survive Modest Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball from full health, while outspeeding Adamant Breloom.

Pixilate.description: Pixilate Mega Gardevoir distinguishes itself from Mega Diancie through its higher damage output and STAB-boosted Psystrike, allowing it to heavily pressure Poison-types and RegenVest Primal Kyogre. Volt Switch eases prediction and helps chip targets like Primal Kyogre and Ho-Oh into 2HKO range from Boomburst. Armor Cannon provides the strongest general coverage against Steel-types like Mega Steelix, while Steam Eruption hits Ho-Oh for super effective damage while also dealing respectable damage against Primordial Sea Steel-types. Mega Gardevoir is capable of applying pressure onto common specially defensive walls such as Ice Scales Arceus formes, but it can need help taking down walls like Ice Scales Ho-Oh. Thus, partners like Eternatus and Palkia-O are helpful to assist in pressuring opposing Ice Scales users, while they appreciate Mega Gardevoir helping deal with RegenVest Primal Kyogre. Mega Gardevoir also appreciates paralysis support, such as from RegenVest Nuzzle users like Celesteela, to help with its middling Speed. Depending on coverage, Mega Gardevoir can be Imposter-proofed by teammates such as Victini, Ferrothorn, and Ice Scales Arceus formes.

Quiver Dance.description:
Masquerain functions as a threatening Quiver Dance sweeper thanks to its high-powered STAB attacks and extensive coverage, including rare access to Hydro Pump, which allow it to pressure opposing teams without being overreliant on Terastallization. Hydro Pump hits Charizard, Pyroar, and Carbink and, together with Hurricane, provides neutral coverage for the entire metagame. Tera Blast Steel lets Masquerain beat targets such as Carbink and Articuno reliably, as well as set up more easily on targets like Gogoat and Misdreavus that can otherwise threaten it with coverage. Alternatively, Tera Water boosts Hydro Pump's damage output further and improves its matchup against Fire-types like Charizard. Other coverage options include Ice Beam, which helps Masquerain reliably beat Gabite, and Bug Buzz, which gives Masquerain a more reliable STAB move that can threaten Dark- and Psychic-types like Alolan Persian and Indeedee-F and deal neutral damage to threats like Raichu.

Masquerain appreciates teammates like Raichu, Electrode, Alolan Persian, and Lumineon that can bring it in safely with pivoting moves. Raichu can also notably use Tera Water or Tera Ice to check fast Electric-types like Choice Scarf Rotom-F and generate free switch-in and setup opportunities for Masquerain with Encore. Ground-types like Whiscash, Alolan Dugtrio, and Gabite can reliably switch into and threaten Tinkatuff, which can cripple Masquerain with Thunder Wave or Encore; Whiscash also greatly helps against Choice Scarf Lycanroc-N, which outspeeds and can revenge kill Masquerain after one boost, and facilitates wallbreaking with Spikes, while Masquerain and Alolan Dugtrio can set up on each other's checks. Grass-types like Gogoat can switch into some Electric-types like Electrode and Pokemon like Whiscash that may threaten Masquerain with Rock-type coverage; they also pressure Pokemon like Carbink better alongside Masquerain. In return, Masquerain can pressure targets like Charizard and Articuno depending on its Tera type. Indeedee-F can provide Masquerain with Healing Wish support, allowing it to attempt setup more than once in a game, as well as Psychic Terrain to prevent priority users like Skuntank and Honchkrow from revenge killing Masquerain if it has already Terastallized.

Sticky Web Lead.description:
With its combination of a good Speed tier, Intimidate, and solid offensive capability after setting Sticky Web, Masquerain is PU's premier Sticky Web lead. Hurricane is Masquerain's normal STAB move of choice, allowing it to hit Pokemon such as Gogoat and opposing Masquerain for good damage. However, Bug Buzz can be used instead, hitting mostly the same targets as Hurricane and being more accurate at the cost of power. Hydro Pump is coverage for Fire-types such as Charizard and Carkol, as well as Carbink and Alolan-Dugtrio, although Surf can be used instead of Hydro Pump, trading off power for accuracy. Masquerain's fourth moveslot is very flexible; U-turn can be used to pivot into a partner Pokemon after setting up Sticky Web and Quiver Dance can make Masquerain more offensively threatening after setting up Sticky Web. Ice Beam can OHKO Dartrix and Gabite, but it is hard to fit, as Masquerain normally finds more usage out of U-turn and Quiver Dance. Masquerain can Terastallize into the Ghost type to prevent spinners such as Quaxwell and Carkol from removing its Sticky Web. Masquerain can also run Heavy-Duty Boots to ease Sticky Web setup later in the game at the cost of being a less effective lead, as well as run Tera Steel for easier setup with Quiver Dance if spinblocking is not a concern.

Masquerain's most common teammates are ones that take advantage of Sticky Web slowing down their grounded offensive checks, so wallbreakers such as Swords Dance Zangoose, Squawkabilly, and Choice Band Basculin-B are great partners. Ghost-types such as Misdreavus and Banette spinblock for Masquerain to keep Sticky Web on the field, and Sticky Web allows them to spread status more easily to normally faster threats such as opposing Basculin-B. Electric- and Rock-types such as Raichu and Choice Scarf Lycanroc-N help deal with the Flying-types that annoy Masquerain and its teammates, such as Rotom-S, as they are immune to Sticky Web.

Focus Sash (Fighting).description:
