Based on its choice of coverage, Mega Latios is either walled by Psychic-types like Latios and Latias or certain Water- and Flying-types like Calm Mind Tapu Fini and Celesteela. The aforementioned Pursuit trappers are excellent at removing the former. Ghost-types like Hisuian Zoroark can also work well at KOing these foes. Against the latter group, Electric-types such as Iron Hands and Zeraora can eliminate them. Given that many of Mega Latios's checks lack recovery and don't hold Heavy-Duty Boots, entry hazard setters like Mew, Excadrill, and Mega Tyranitar can help it break through them.

Wallbreaker.description: Wielding its signature move Luster Purge, powerful coverage to complement it, and a good typing that gives it a favorable matchup against common threats like Ogerpon-W and Zamazenta, Mega Latios is a powerful wallbreaker in the metagame. Aura Sphere is important coverage to hit Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn as well as to KO chipped Mega Tyranitar. Mystical Fire hits the aforementioned Ferrothorn along with Mega Scizor and Iron Crown. Draco Meteor is a powerful nuke to threaten foes like Galarian Slowking after a Luster Purge drop while also immediately threatening other Pokemon like Raging Bolt, Gouging Fire, and Mega Latias. Psychic Noise lets Mega Latios pressure checks that rely on recovery to deal with it, like Heatran and Mega Scizor, while also being a backup STAB attack with sufficient PP compared to Luster Purge. Mega Latios finds itself on many team archetypes including bulky offense and balance due to its versatility. However, it is outsped and revenge killed by Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Darkrai, and Weavile. Thus, teammates that can help with this like fast threats including your own Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant or defensive walls including Heatran and Clefable can help aid Mega Latios. In return, Mega Latios can pressure defensive checks like Heatran and Galarian Slowking for them. Good entry hazard control from allies like Great Tusk and Landorus-T helps, since Mega Latios is somewhat vulnerable to Stealth Rock due to its tendency to switch in and out very often.

Stored Power.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Psychic

Latios can use Flip Turn to keep up momentum against the many switches it forces and bring in teammates to better answer the incoming threat. Psychic Noise is an option to better counter defensive walls such as specially defensive Articuno and RestTalk Dondozo, denying their recovery and decreasing their longevity overtime. Psychic Noise also has the added benefit of shutting down Draining Kiss Primarina completely. Energy Ball can be used to more easily counter Water/Ground types such as Gastrodon and Swampert.

Special Attacker (Dragon).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Calm Mind (Psychic).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Specs (Psychic).description:
Boasting amazing offenses, Latios cements itself as a formidable threat on Psychic teams. With Choice Specs, Latios can drop powerful Draco Meteors and pulverize foes such as Gliscor and Gouging Fire that may otherwise trouble Psychic teams. Luster Purge can punish any switch-ins to Draco Meteor and plow through the likes of defensive Articuno and Gholdengo after a Special Defense drop. Latios has a plethora of coverage options, Ice Beam lets it threaten common Ground- and Flying-type threats like specially defensive Gliscor, while Thunderbolt lets it threaten Water-types like Empoleon. Latios can utilize Aura Sphere to counter Steel-types like Kingambit and Heatran without help from teammates. Latios can also hamper the opposition with Trick, being able to cripple foes like Hisuian Goodra, Kingambit and Ting-Lu.

Latios appreciates support from Deoxys-S, being able to easily spread entry hazards and help Latios OHKO foes more easily. Alternatively, offensive Deoxys-S appreciates Latios punching holes in the opposition so that it can clean up later with its massive Speed tier. Galarian Slowking and Jirachi are great partners that can pivot Latios in with Chilly Reception and U-Turn, respectively, and take care of Fairy-types such as Iron Valiant and Hatterene that Latios is weak to. Specially defensive Jirachi can also set up Stealth Rock and pressure Ice-types such as Alolan Ninetales and Baxcalibur, as well as spread paralysis against the likes of Zamazenta and Greninja, allowing Latios to outspeed them. Choice Scarf Iron Boulder is a great partner that can clean up after Latios has been KOed and outspeed and threaten to OHKO other Choice Scarf users such as Meowscarada, Greninja, and Iron Valiant as well as Dragon Dance +1 Gouging Fire. Choice Scarf Hoopa-U is a good partner to beat Ghost-types such as Skeledirge, Gholdengo, and Dragapult. Assault Vest Hoopa-U can also deal with bulky Gholdengo and break apart defensive cores alongside Latios. Stored Power Espathra can act as a wincon once Latios has weakened the opposition. Gallade and Hatterene are good choices for countering Dark-types that are extremely threatening to Psychic teams such as Chien-Pao and Kingambit. Indeedee-M also notably provides a Ghost immunity alongside Healing Wish, giving Latios a second chance late-game. Eject Button Slowbro can provide a safe switch-in against Ceruledge and spread paralysis against or finish off weakened Chien-Pao and Kingambit, easing the burden on Latios.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to Battle Stadium Singles Regulation F! This Pokemon is a new addition from the Indigo Disk that happens to be relevant!

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Offensive.description:
• Latios's useful array of resistances, fantastic use of Terastallization, and good offenses make it a strong choice for either a wallbreaker with Choice Specs or revenge killer with Choice Scarf!

  • Luster Purge: Despite its low PP and poor offensive coverage, Luster Purge's high chance of dropping Special Defense still makes it a great wallbreaking tool.

  • Flip Turn: While Flip Turn is weak, Latios forces enough switches to make it a reasonable offensive pivot.

  • Trick: Trick gives Choice Scarf Latios an option to nearly shut down defensive Pokemon like Porygon2 and Ting-Lu and situationally lock offensive foes like Dragonite and Chien-Pao into more manageable moves. Choice Specs Latios isn't quite as effective with this, but its it's still worth considering for crippling defensive foes.

  • Shadow Ball VS. Aura Sphere: Shadow Ball is Latios's best move against Gholdengo and will 2HKO most Flutter Mane sets as well. Aura Sphere leaves Latios reliant on Special Defense drops to deal with Gholdengo, but it is a more direct option against common Tera Steel foes like Dragonite and opposing Latios.

Other Options

  • Calm Mind: While not a defensive set, Calm Mind is a reasonable option for boosting Draco Meteor and Luster Purge to dangerous power levels.

  • Ice Beam: Ice Beam is handy for letting Choice Specs Latios OHKO Assault Vest Landorus-T and deal massive damage to Ting-Lu, though Draco Meteor has more general utility in many cases.

  • Grass Knot: If using Choice Specs, Grass Knot pulls a 2HKO even on Sitrus Berry Ting-Lu, though it being resisted by so many popular Pokemon like Dragonite makes it a risky move to be locked into.

  • Surf: If using Tera Water, Surf is a reasonable coverage option against Steel-types.

  • Thunderbolt: Thunderbolt offers good coverage against most Steel-types, but it is a very risky move to be locked into due to Ground-types like Landorus-T and Excadrill.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Latios's typing isn't amazing defensively, but the very useful resistances to Urshifu-R's and Ogerpon-H's STAB moves mean Terastallization isn't always an upgrade. Still, thanks to Levitate, Latios has some effective defensive options to consider.

  • Steel: Tera Steel has superb synergy with Levitate, making Latios an effective offensive check against common foes like Landorus-T and Dragonite while giving Latios great counterplay against Fairy-types like Flutter Mane defensively and offensively with Tera Blast. This also lets Latios tank a Blood Moon from Ursaluna-B, though the Vacuum Wave weakness can be bothersome afterwards.

  • Fire: Tera Fire also gives Latios a vital resistance to Fairy-types while maintaining the resistances against Ogerpon-H's STAB moves and providing a powerful Tera Blast against most Steel-types.

  • Water: Tera Water covers Latios's issue with Ice-type attacks, which can save it in a pinch against Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle, while still retaining an important resistance to Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes.

  • Electric: Tera Electric removes all of Latios's weaknesses except from Mold Breaker users with Earthquake like Excadrill and provides a useful paralysis immunity against common status spreaders like Porygon2, Flutter Mane, and Serperior.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy is a decent alternative to Tera Steel, giving Latios a good option against Dragon-types while still retaining a Fighting-type resistance.

Items

  • Choice Specs VS. Choice Scarf: Choice Specs is preferred on Latios for the excellent wallbreaking potential. Choice Scarf Latios is a reasonable revenge killer, but it still doesn't deal well with Chien-Pao due to the Sucker Punch weakness, making it more reliant on unique qualities like Trick and Levitate to separate itself from other Choice Scarf revenge killers.

  • Soul Dew: While not as effective at breaking walls as Choice Specs, Soul Dew is a reasonable alternative to still take advantage of Luster Purge's Special Defense drops, and it is a great way of getting around Item Clause issues if Latios still needs a power boost.

  • Focus Sash: Latios isn't frail, but Focus Sash lets it threaten offensive threats it normally has no bussiness with, such as Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle.

Minor Optimizations

  • Neutral Nature: It's best to use a neutral nature with a Timid Mint to ensure that Latios can eat any berry without getting confused after using Trick.

Bulky Stall Breaker.description:
• This set's write-up has not started yet, but here's some basic info to get you started!

  • 204 HP / 124 Def / 180 Spe: This outspeeds Timid Chi-Yu while avoiding a 2HKO from Adamant Choice Scarf Urshifu-R's Tera Water Surging Strikes

  • 252 HP / 84 Def / 4 SpA / 4 SpD / 164 Spe: This slightly slower spread outspeeds Timid Iron Crown, avoids a 2HKO from Adamant Choice Scarf Tera Water Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R, and survives Timid Flutter Mane's Choice Specs Moonblast after Latios has used Calm Mind.

Wallbreaker.description: Choice Specs Latios is a fearsome wallbreaker that can force progress in almost every matchup with its combination of powerful STAB attacks, effectively mixed coverage with Psyshock, and ability to finesse poor matchups with Flip Turn and Trick. Adaptability Luster Purge consistently OHKOes common slower offensive Pokemon like Zapdos and Walking Wake without dropping Latios's Special Attack, but Trick can cripple an opposing Chansey or Deoxys-D or disrupt a setup sweeper like Cresselia. Adaptability provides the most overall power to the set, letting it reliably 2HKO common RegenVest pivots like Swampert and Manaphy with Psyshock, while Tinted Lens lets it 2HKO Meloetta and Heatran with Psyshock and have a good chance to OHKO Corviknight and Gholdengo with Draco Meteor. Latios pairs well with fast cleaners like Deoxys-S and Hisuian Electrode, as they can readily take advantage of the opposing RegenVest user being removed from the match. Strong physical wallbreakers like Iron Boulder and the Ogerpon formes appreciate Latios bringing them in safely with Flip Turn and even chunking their checks like Corviknight that may try to eat a predicted Psyshock. Latios invites in powerful Dark-type revenge killers like Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao, making robust checks to these such as Fluffy Corviknight and Regenerator Primarina mandatory. Latios functions best with frequent entry to the field, making entry hazard removers like Corviknight and Great Tusk excellent partners. Slow pivots like Corviknight and Deoxys-D can help get it onto the field safely.

Speed Control.description: Choice Scarf Latios is a reliable source of speed control and offensive pivot that sets itself apart from Azelf with its powerful Draco Meteor. Psyshock allows Latios to effectively have mixed coverage and 2HKO common RegenVest pivots like Swampert and Manaphy after Spikes, while Luster Purge is notably stronger against common offensive Pokemon like Hisuian Electrode, Cinderace, and Barraskewda and is more spammable than Draco Meteor. Adaptability is more consistent, as it is always active and does not announce itself, while Hadron Engine can support Electric-types and Surge Surf users, disrupt opposing terrain from the likes of Azelf and Deoxys-S, and let Latios OHKO Corviknight with Thunderbolt. Trick is an option in the last slot to shut down bulky setup sweepers like Cresselia and cripple walls like Deoxys-D. Latios works best with slow pivots like Corviknight and Swampert that can get it onto the field in advantageous positions; similarly, Latios often provides easy entry to slow, wallbreaking teammates like Galarian Zapdos and Ceruledge with Flip Turn. Latios is heavily threatened by Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon, as they discourage it from using its Psychic-type moves and can even threaten it thanks to priority moves and Choice Scarf, respectively. Physically defensive Manaphy and Fluffy Corviknight, respectively, can provide insurance against these threats.

Choice Scarf.description:
• Choice Scarf Kyogre is a solid form of speed control found on bulky offense teams. Its ability to outspeed Zacian-C and pressure common Pokemon found on bulky archetypes, like Ting-Lu, Corviknight, Skeledirge, and Groudon, gives it a decent offensive presence. Choice Scarf Kyogre can also pressure hyper offense teams because those teams don't run Pokemon naturally faster than it. However, Choice Scarf Kyogre is prediction reliant, as there are a lot of Pokemon that resist Water-type attacks in Ubers, mainly metagame staples like Koraidon, Miraidon, and other defensive Pokemon like Water Absorb Clodsire and Eternatus. Choice Scarf Kyogre is also relatively weak, which means that it'll often be forced to use Tera to power up its attacks; even then, Pokemon like Eternatus and Clodsire will still wall Kyogre.
  • Koraidon is the biggest threat to Kyogre, as it commonly switches into it, takes little damage from its Water-type attacks, and sets sun. Catching Koraidon with Ice Beam is extremely important, as it can make the difference between Kyogre sweeping in the late-game or not. This makes Choice Scarf Kyogre extremely prediction reliant, as one single bad move can mean the entire momentum of the battle is lost.
  • Tera Water boosts Kyogre's Water-type moves to insane levels. For instance, Water Spout now OHKOes max HP Arceus formes that are neutral to Water and 2HKOes Arceus formes that resist Water. It also has a good chance to OHKO Groudon even if sun is active.
  • Kyogre should be brought onto the field via pivoting moves like U-turn from the likes of Koraidon, Miraidon, and Landorus-T. Unless there are Water Absorb Pokemon on the enemy team, Water Spout is a relatively free move to spam; however, hitting Koraidon on the switch with a well-timed Ice Beam can be game-changing.
  • Choice Scarf Kyogre appreciates Pokemon that can wallbreak by themselves. A good teammate for this reason is Miraidon, which shares a common check in Clodsire. Taunt Miraidon in particular can shut down Clodsire completely, as Clodsire will be at half HP after switching into Draco Meteor. Miraidon can also bring Kyogre onto the field via U-turn. Arceus-Ground is another great teammate for Kyogre, as it can keep Pokemon like Eternatus, Clodsire, and Miraidon in check.
  • Pokemon that can check Koraidon, like Arceus-Fairy, Groudon, and Skeledirge, are a must, as Koraidon is one of the most annoying Pokemon in Ubers for Kyogre to deal with: it replaces rain with sun, weakening Kyogre's main attacking moves. They can also set entry hazards and, in Landorus-T's case, bring Kyogre onto the field with U-turn.
  • Entry hazard removers like Giratina-O and Corviknight are appreciated, as Kyogre loses a lot of power when its HP is lowered. Both Pokemon also check threats like Extreme Killer Arceus, which can revenge kill Kyogre with Extreme Speed.

Choice Specs.description:
• Choice Specs Kyogre is a devastating wallbreaker that can OHKO or 2HKO the entire metagame. However, the ever-present sun set by Koraidon and its relatively low Speed make it harder to use than it may appear, even with its incredible power.
  • Water Spout gives Kyogre the power to OHKO even resistant Pokemon such as Miraidon and Eternatus when paired with Tera Water, and it lets Kyogre claim KOs with ease early on. Ice Beam lets Kyogre hit Koraidon and Clodsire super effectively, cleanly OHKOing the former lacking bulk EVs and 2HKOing the latter. Thunder is Kyogre's strongest option for breaking through bulky Water-types such as Toxapex, Arceus-Water, and opposing Kyogre.
  • Tera Water lets Kyogre perform feats such as OHKOing Miraidon, Toxapex, Arceus-Water, and Eternatus with Water Spout or Origin Pulse with a layer of Spikes up.
  • An alternate EV spread of 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 Def can be used to take on Arceus formes and switch into defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Landorus-T better.
  • Kyogre fits well on bulky offense. It has trouble getting onto the field and loses a significant part of its power if it takes a hit, so it should be paired with pivots such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and Landorus-T. They can bring Kyogre in on their incoming checks such as Arceus-Fairy and Skeledirge, Arceus-Ground, and Ting-Lu, respectively.
  • Kyogre also greatly appreciates entry hazard removal, such as Defog support from Giratina-O and Corviknight, which keeps Water Spout at full power. Speed control options help Kyogre to wallbreak to its fullest, as it tends to have to take a hit before attacking thanks to its lower Speed, such as Thunder Wave from Arceus, Miraidon, Giratina-O, and Groudon, and Sticky Web from Masquerain.
  • Entry hazards support from Ting-Lu and Clodsire is also appreciated to make sure Kyogre's attacks can cleanly OHKO most of their switch-ins. The aforementioned two Pokemon are also able to check Miraidon and Eternatus, both of which can come in on Kyogre and revenge-kill it. Koraidon can force Kyogre out and can switch into its Water-type attacks, so checks to Koraidon such as Skeledirge, Landorus-T, Great Tusk, and Arceus-Fairy are also appreciated. That said, Kyogre can also predict Koraidon coming in and catch it with an Ice Beam, which is a clean OHKO on all Koraidon without bulk EVs.
  • Kyogre can also be used as a solid offensive check to Arceus formes, as it can pivot into a Taunt or a Calm Mind and force them out with a strong Origin Pulse or Water Spout. Kyogre can also pivot into opposing Calm Mind Kyogre, forcing it out with Thunder.

Bulky Calm Mind.description:
• Thanks to Kyogre's naturally high bulk, it can use Calm Mind to set up on defensive Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, as well as Pokemon it forces out through its typing, such as Zacian-C and Koraidon.
  • Surf is the move of choice thanks to its higher PP as well as accuracy over Origin Pulse. Ice Beam lets Kyogre hit Miraidon, Koraidon, Eternatus, and Clodsire super effectively, which would otherwise freely switch into Kyogre. Tera Blast can be used if paired with Tera Ground to break through Clodsire, regardless of whether it has used Tera.
  • Substitute can be used to set up on Clodsire, which cannot break it with Earthquake, and avoid status in general. Rest lets Kyogre repeatedly come in and absorb status, though it must be wary of Miraidon's Hadron Engine setting Electric Terrain.
  • Tera Fairy flips Kyogre's matchup against Eternatus and Koraidon, letting Kyogre freely come in on Dragon-type moves and resist Koraidon's STAB attacks. Tera Ground lets Kyogre set up on Miraidon's Electro Drift, although it cannot take Draco Meteor well without previously having set up. Tera Poison is another option for becoming immune to Toxic from Clodsire, Toxapex, and Eternatus while also resisting Koraidon's Fighting-type attacks.
  • Leftovers provides Kyogre with a form of recovery and gives it more chances to enter the field.
  • The given EV spread lets Kyogre take on physical attackers like Groudon and Koraidon better while outspeeding some paralyzed +1 Arceus formes and paralyzed Zacian-C.
  • Kyogre fits best on balance and bulky offense teams thanks to the defensive utility it provides as well as being a solid late-game wincon.
  • Miraidon is a great partner for non-Rest variants of Kyogre, as it can break through Taunt and Calm Mind Arceus formes and pressure bulky Water-types such as Toxapex and Arceus-Water. Miraidon can also use U-turn to bring Kyogre in on Ground-types that it can set up on, such as Ting-Lu and Clodsire. Ting-Lu and Groudon are solid partners for Kyogre, since they can set up Spikes to weaken Kyogre's checks, while also being able to switch into Electric-type attacks that threaten Kyogre. Physical attackers such as Groudon, Arceus-Ground, Chien-Pao, and Koraidon pair well with Kyogre, as they can use Kyogre's checks as an entry for them to start breaking, and Kyogre pressures all of their checks apart from Arceus-Water.
  • Kyogre needs Koraidon eliminated before it can start setting up, as Kyogre is generally forced out by it and its STAB moves are weakened. As such, defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge, Great Tusk, and Arceus-Fairy are solid partners that check Koraidon effectively. Finally, Kyogre has trouble coming in against faster offense teams, so partners that can pressure these teams such as Choice Scarf Koraidon and Miraidon, Extreme Killer Arceus, and Zacian-C are preferred.

Offensive Calm Mind.description:
• Offensive Calm Mind Kyogre is a decent setup sweeper on offensive and balance teams for its ability to punch big holes in defensive cores for its team to exploit.
  • Ice Beam allows Kyogre to threaten Dragon-types like Koraidon, Miraidon, and Eternatus, which can withstand Kyogre's STAB attacks. Koraidon is a noteworthy target, because it can otherwise easily oppose Kyogre’s rain with its sun. Ice Beam also hits Clodsire, which otherwise completely walls this Kyogre set without Tera Ground Tera Blast.
  • Kyogre can easily spread paralysis with Thunder Wave thanks to it naturally forcing out Ground-types, which is appreciated by slower teams.
  • Thunder lets Kyogre smack defensive Water-types that resist Surf and Ice Beam, like Toxapex and Dondozo, as well as lays waste to opposing Kyogre. It also hits Pokemon that may Terastallize into a Water-type, like Eternatus and Zacian-C.
  • With Tera Ground, Tera Blast can 2HKO Clodsire without setting up, even if it is Terastallized into a Steel-type, while also hitting Toxapex. However, it has very little practical use outside of this.
  • Kyogre has no reliable recovery, so Heavy-Duty Boots is the preferred item so it doesn’t get worn down by entry hazards. Leftovers can be used on teams that have reliably hazard control like Giratina-O.
  • Tera Fairy gives Kyogre a Fighting resistance and Dragon immunity, making it impossible for Koraidon to threaten Kyogre in rain.
  • Tera Poison gives Kyogre a Fighting resistance and immunity to Toxic, and also allows it to absorb Toxic Spikes from Eternatus, Toxapex, and Clodsire.
  • Tera Ground gives Kyogre an Electric immunity, letting it avoid Electro Drift from Miraidon and Thunder from opposing Kyogre.
  • Tera Grass, on the other hand, gives Kyogre Ground and Electric resistances, letting it set up on Pokemon it otherwise cannot, like Groudon, Arceus-Ground, and Miraidon.
  • This Kyogre set is a good fit on balance teams that struggle against defensive teams, as it is a bulky setup sweeper that can take advantage of common defensive Pokemon like Skeledirge and Ting-Lu to spread paralysis with Thunder Wave.
  • Zacian-C is a fantastic partner, able to threaten many Pokemon commonly used to threaten Kyogre without a Substitute, like Koraidon and Miraidon. Zacian-C also loves Kyogre’s rain neutering its Fire weakness.
  • Koraidon can pivot into Kyogre with U-turn while taking attacks used against Kyogre, like opposing Koraidon’s Flare Blitz when Kyogre is Terastallized and Miraidon’s Electro Drift. Koraidon also loves Kyogre threatening physical checks like Skeledirge, Toxapex, and Groudon.
  • Clodsire lures like Choice Specs Miraidon are great for Kyogre, as Kyogre is completely walled by Clodsire that has Terastallized into a Steel-type if it doesn't have Tera Ground Tera Blast.

RegenVest.description: RegenVest Primal Kyogre is a useful special wall, pivot, and utility Pokemon, notably checking foes like Flutter Mane, Palkia-O, and Eternatus. Flip Turn allows Primal Kyogre to safely scout moves from opposing threats like Choice Specs Flutter Mane and then swap into the appropriate answer, be it an Imposter Pokemon or an Ice Scales user. Scald is typically preferred over Steam Eruption thanks to its higher PP, but some teams may appreciate the extra power of Steam Eruption. Knock Off cripples item-reliant Pokemon like Chansey, RegenVest Dialga, and RegenVest Celesteela along with removing Covert Cloak to let it status Pokemon it otherwise couldn't, such as Mega Audino. Mortal Spin's entry hazard removal and poison-inflicting capabilities make it a good all-around utility choice, especially since Primal Kyogre has an excellent matchup against many of the metagame's Steel-types, like Mega Steelix and Celesteela. Nuzzle can slow down wallbreakers like Eternatus and Choice Specs Flutter Mane, and Stone Axe can help wear down foes for allies. Primal Kyogre's fear of physical wallbreakers like Mega Garchomp, Ash-Greninja, and Ultra Necrozma makes reliable checks to them, like Fur Coat Mega Audino and Ice Scales Arceus-Ground, useful teammates. Special wallbreakers like Flutter Mane, Eternatus, and Miraidon appreciate Knock Off removing items from opposing RegenVest users and Ability Shields from Pokemon like Ice Scales Arceus-Ground. Imposter-proof Primal Kyogre with a Take Heart Arceus forme holding a Plate.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Kyogre is a decent revenge killer and wallbreaker, most notably on bulky offense teams, that threatens Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Skeledirge, and most defensive Arceus formes. Ice Beam is Kyogre's best move to hit Koraidon and Miraidon, weakening them to potentially let it clean up late-game. Thunder is used for Toxapex and Arceus-Water. Tera Water boosts Water Spout considerably, allowing it to 2HKO Pokemon such as Eternatus and Tera Poison or Steel Ting-Lu, while Tera Ghost prevents Kyogre from being revenge killed by Extreme Killer Arceus. As Kyogre is slower than other Choice Scarf users such as Calyrex-S, Koraidon, Miraidon, and Extreme Speed Arceus, solid checks to them, such as Ting-Lu, Landorus-T and Toxapex for the latter two, are appreciated. Giratina-O checks Arceus too, and it can remove entry hazards for Kyogre to maintain its powerful Water Spout. Offensive teammates such as Calyrex-S and Miraidon can pressure Kyogre's checks such as Eternatus, Toxapex, and Arceus-Water, and they appreciate Kyogre threatening Ting-Lu for them. Partners such as Miraidon and Koraidon, whose checks are pressured by Kyogre can safely pivot it in with U-turn.

Defensive.description:
• Thanks to Groudon's excellent physical bulk, it soft checks numerous physical threats in the tier such as Arceus, physical variants of Arceus-Ground, Koraidon, and Zacian-C.
  • 16 EVs in Speed allow Groudon to outspeed uninvested Kyogre, Giratina-O, and Landorus-T. Alternatively, a spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD can be used to maximize Groudon's bulk.
  • Precipice Blades is a powerful STAB option that OHKOes Zacian-C and Miraidon and has a chance to OHKO Eternatus, whereas Earthquake is a weaker STAB option that offers greater accuracy.
  • Will-O-Wisp cripples physical threats Groudon switches into such as Arceus, Koraidon, and physical variants of Arceus-Ground.
  • Spikes helps chip down switch-ins for the rest of the game due to the limited distribution of hazard removal in the tier. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be used for the same purpose but Spikes is recommended as it hits all targets neutrally.
  • Groudon tends to struggle against special wallbreakers such as Miraidon and Flutter Mane, so Protect is a great option to scout for a potential Choice item and increase its Leftovers recovery. Alternatively, Bulk Up can be used to beat physical setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Arceus formes and Koraidon.
  • Leftovers is mandatory on Groudon, since it does not have any reliable recovery.
  • Tera Fairy gives Groudon an immunity to Dragon-type attacks from the likes of Miraidon, Eternatus, and Koraidon.
  • Tera Water lets Groudon resist Zacian-C's STAB Behemoth Blade, Calyrex-I's STAB Glacial Lance, and Koraidon's sun-boosted Fire-type attacks.
  • Due to Groudon being unable to reliably check physical threats long-term, it’s best to have some form of speed control such as Choice Scarf Koraidon or a reliable wall such as Skeledirge alongside it.
  • Breakers such as Miraidon and Flutter Mane really appreciate Groudon's ability to reliably set both sun, which boosts their Fire-type attacks, and Spikes, which allows them to wallbreak more effectively. Koraidon also has great synergy with Groudon as they both set sun. It also appreciates Spikes support from Groudon.

Swords Dance.description:
• Swords Dance Groudon is a threatening wallbreaker that is able to pressure defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu.
  • Crunch is chosen as the primary coverage move to hit Giratina-O super effectively and also hit Corviknight neutrally. Spikes and Stealth Rock make progress against the switches Groudon forces, but Fire Punch is another option that breaks through Corviknight while also synergizing with Drought and Tera Fire.
  • The given EV spread outspeeds uninvested Giratina-O, Kyogre, and Landorus-T while maximizing bulk and damage output. An alternate spread with 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe and a Jolly nature can be used on Sticky Web teams as a sweeper.
  • Lum Berry can be used to get past Will-O-Wisp users like Arceus and Giratina-O, though this cuts into Groudon's longevity.
  • Tera Ground boosts Groudon's Precipice Blades to absurd levels, letting it OHKO even bulkier variants of Arceus at +2. Tera Fire lets Groudon avoid Will-O-Wisp entirely and powers up Fire Punch but makes it susceptible to being revenge killed by Arceus-Ground and opposing Groudon. Tera Fairy is an option to become immune to Miraidon's and Giratina's Draco Meteor, but the other Tera types are generally preferred thanks to their offensive power.
  • Groudon is best used on bulky offense as an offensive entry hazard setter that can come in on slower Pokemon such as Clodsire, Skeledirge, and Ting-Lu and use them as setup fodder. Groudon forces switches thanks to its power, so use these chances to aggressively set hazards or use Swords Dance.
  • Miraidon is a great partner for being able to pivot Groudon into Clodsire and Ting-Lu while also being able to pressure Groudon's checks like Giratina-O and Corviknight. The two Pokemon also share a check in Arceus-Ground, which they can overwhelm. Koraidon is a similarly good partner for sharing a check in defensive Arceus-Fairy, which they can overwhelm together. Koraidon also can U-turn into Groudon on incoming Skeledirge, which Groudon can use as an opportunity to set hazards or force a defensive Terastallization. Utility Arceus-Fairy can form a hazard stacking core with Groudon while also helping check Giratina-O, Koraidon, and Miraidon. Finally, Arceus-Water, Clodsire, and Eternatus are solid partners, as they all check Kyogre, which cannot switch into Groudon repeatedly but can threaten it out.

Setup Attacker.description: Groudon's base stats and STAB on Precipice Blades make it a premier choice for a bulky attacker. Fur Coat allows Groudon to wall many common threats, such as Koraidon and opposing Groudon, while Mold Breaker ignores Fur Coat and Levitate on walls like Eternatus, Arceus-Ghost, and Zamazenta-C. Victory Dance lets it reliably set up on opposing physical attackers like Groudon and Koraidon, whereas Tidy Up removes entry hazards and makes it harder for Imposter users to safely switch in thanks to the lack of a Defense boost. Toxic heavily cripples Precipice Blades switch-ins like Arceus formes and Dondozo, and it works especially well with Mold Breaker, which lets Groudon bait and punish Prankster users. Alternatively, Knock Off removes Heavy-Duty Boots, Leftovers, and Ability Shield from bulkier targets like Dondozo, Eternatus, and opposing Groudon. Earth Plate boosts Precipice Blades's damage, whereas Heavy-Duty Boots leaves Groudon less susceptible to chip damage from Spikes, and Rocky Helmet provides extra security against Population Bomb users like Ursaluna. Groudon's best fit is on balance and offense teams that want to compress a bulky attacker, non-passive wall, and possibly an entry hazard remover into a single teamslot. Teammates like Dondozo and Eternatus are recommended to shore up Groudon's weakness to Palafin-H, with the latter also helping out against Solar Beam Arceus-Fire. Use Corviknight to Imposter-proof Toxic and Mold Breaker Groudon variants, and a Fur Coat user that doesn't mind Knock Off for other variants.

Defensive.description: Groudon is a decent pick for bulky offense teams thanks to its ability to check Zacian-C, Extreme Killer Arceus, Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground, and Koraidon due to its solid bulk. Access to moves such as Will-O-Wisp and Spikes differentiate it from Landorus-T. Will-O-Wisp allows Groudon to cripple Pokemon that switch into it such as Koraidon and physical variants of Arceus-Ground. Roar is used to phaze foes such as Swords Dance Zacian-C, Swords Dance Koraidon, Extreme Killer Arceus, and Arceus-Ground that may try to set up on it while also racking up chip damage from entry hazards. Protect is an alternative move that can be used to scout moves from the likes of Choice Specs Miraidon and Kyogre and Choice Scarf Koraidon as well as maximize Leftovers recovery. Tera Water allows Groudon to resist Behemoth Blade from Zacian-C, Flare Blitz from Koraidon, and Water Spout and Ice Beam from Kyogre, whereas Tera Fairy makes it immune or resistant to Scale Shot and Low Kick from Koraidon and Draco Meteor from Miraidon. Offensive teammates that benefit from the hazards set up by Groudon such as Calyrex-S, Calm Mind Arceus formes, Miraidon, Koraidon, Zacian-C, and Extreme Killer Arceus are appreciated. As Groudon lacks recovery, revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Koraidon and other physical walls with access to recovery such as defensive Arceus formes are mandatory partners. As Groudon is unable to check special attackers such as Calyrex-S, Miraidon, and Kyogre, checks to them such as Ting-Lu and Clodsire are appreciated; they can set up hazards as well to form a hazard stacking core with it.

Dragon Dance.description:
• With Dragon Dance, Rayquaza serves as a threatening late-game sweeper with the ability to boost its already sky-high Attack and fix its issue with Speed.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots is generally the preferred item thanks to nullifying Rayquaza's otherwise bad weakness to Stealth Rock, but Life Orb enables Rayquaza to perform ridiculous feats like guaranteeing an OHKO on Zacian-C after a single boost.
  • Tera Flying further strengthens Rayquaza's already spammable Dragon Ascent, letting Life Orb Rayquaza crush bulky teams. At +1, Life Orb Tera Flying Dragon Ascent has good odds to 2HKO even the most physically defensive Corviknight.
  • Tera Fire gives Rayquaza a valuable resistance to Fairy, letting it set up on Zacian-C, Arceus-Fairy, and Flutter Mane, while also letting it become immune to Will-O-Wisp from Groudon and Skeledirge.
  • Extreme Speed allows Rayquaza to revenge kill weakened foes in a pinch, most notably Scale Shot Koraidon, Miraidon, and Extreme Killer Arceus.
  • Substitute allows Rayquaza to block status-inducing moves like Will-O-Wisp from Skeledirge and Toxic from Clodsire, Toxapex, and Gliscor. It is generally not worth using with Life Orb because the combination cuts too much into Rayquaza's already awful longevity.
  • Draco Meteor allows Rayquaza to beat Skeledirge and the rare Dondozo solo without Terastallizing. However, it has little practical use outside of this.
  • A Naive nature should only ever be run when Rayquaza runs Draco Meteor. Jolly is the preferred nature in all other scenarios.
  • Dragon Dance Rayquaza is best used on hyper offense teams that love its ability to punch big holes into bulky teams for its teammates to exploit late-game. Rayquaza is not much of a defensive presence, but it can be used to check dangerous Ground-types like Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground without sacrificing offensive output.
  • Zacian-C forces out or baits Terastallization from Fairy- and Dragon-types that threaten Rayquaza, like Koraidon, Miraidon, and Arceus-Fairy, while being a ferocious offensive threat in its own right. Thus, it is an invaluable partner for Rayquaza.
  • As Dragon Dance Rayquaza fits mainly on hyper offense teams, it should be paired with hyper offense leads like Glimmora and Meowscarada.
  • Physical attackers that appreciate Rayquaza's ability to punch great holes into their checks are good partners for it, as they are made more dangerous late-game with their checks weakened. These include Extreme Killer Arceus, Scale Shot Koraidon, and Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground.

Swords Dance.description:
• Swords Dance Rayquaza functions as a strong wallbreaker and a potential revenge killer or late-game cleaner thanks to Extreme Speed. Dragon Ascent is Rayquaza's go-to move with which it can 2HKO Skeledirge, Giratina-O, and most Arceus formes.
  • Earthquake is a valuable coverage move that allows Rayquaza to hit Flying-resistant foes like Zacian-C and Miraidon for massive damage.
  • Swords Dance allows Rayquaza to turn the aforementioned 2HKOs into OHKOs and 2HKO Corviknight with Dragon Ascent.
  • Extreme Speed allows Rayquaza to pick off weakened targets or even sweep with the combination of Tera Normal and Swords Dance. After a Swords Dance, Tera Normal Extreme Speed can OHKO even Koraidon and Miraidon.
  • Life Orb is crucial for this set because it gives Rayquaza the necessary power boost to score OHKOs and 2HKOs that it needs to.
  • Jolly is necessary because it allows Rayquaza to get the jump on foes like the plethora of base 90 Speed Pokemon such as Kyogre as well as suicide leads such as Glimmora. On Sticky Web teams it's even more important because Adamant Rayquaza can't outrun -1 Speed Zacian-C.
  • Swords Dance Rayquaza fits on more offensive teams where it can switch in on defensive Ground-types such as Landorus-T, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire. Rayquaza pairs exceptionally well with Sticky Web setters such as Ribombee, as they let it outspeed Zacian-C, previously faster Arceus formes, and non-Choice Scarf Koraidon and Miraidon, which can all be OHKOed after a Swords Dance.
  • Rayquaza also pairs well with Extreme Killer Arceus and Kingambit because together they form a priority core that gives their team a very reliable safety net against common sweepers like Koraidon and Miraidon. Rayquaza also appreciates Taunt users like Miraidon and Arceus because they can prevent foes from setting up hazards or healing to try to stay out of range of Rayquaza's attacks.

Suicide Lead.description:
• Rayquaza has a niche as a suicide lead over other Pokemon like Glimmora thanks to its base 150 Attack and Special Attack stats. This allows it to beat other common leads like the aforementioned Glimmora, as Draco Meteor ignores Toxic Debris, and Ribombee while also threatening other Pokemon, mainly physically bulky Pokemon like Landorus-T that are annoying to its teammates.
  • Unfortunately for Rayquaza, the prevalence of Taunt Arceus hinders its ability to consistently lay down entry hazards. Furthermore, Scale Shot Koraidon is very common and is an effective anti-lead that beats Rayquaza. Other Pokemon like Zacian-C also take advantage of Rayquaza not being able to hit it with a super effective move and heavily threaten the opposing team. Lastly, Calm Mind variants of Arceus are bulky enough to utilize Rayquaza as setup fodder and freely boost themselves without much threat.
  • Draco Meteor with maximum Special Attack investment allows Rayquaza to lure in and 2HKO common physical walls, such as Landorus-T, Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Groudon.
  • Tera Fairy allows Rayquaza to be immune to Dragon-type attacks, with the most notable example being Scale Shot from Koraidon; this gives Rayquaza an opportunity to deal huge damage on Koraidon without sacrificing HP or abilities on important teammates like Zacian-C's Intrepid Sword. However, it's not entirely advised to Terastallize immediately, as it must be saved as an emergency option only.
  • Rayquaza is a suicide lead that must prioritize setting entry hazards while dealing damage if the situation presents it. Other common hyper offense leads, like Ribombee and Glimmora, lose the one-on-one against Rayquaza, which means that only dedicated teams with Pokemon like Taunt Arceus and dual screens Grimmsnarl can beat and annoy Rayquaza.
  • Rayquaza fits best on hyper offense teams with teammates that appreciate Stealth Rock being set and physically bulky Pokemon being heavily damaged. As a result, Koraidon, Zacian-C, and physical Arceus formes are good teammates. Zacian-C in particular helps Rayquaza against Scale Shot Koraidon, one Pokemon that can outright OHKO Rayquaza even through Focus Sash. Flutter Mane is another Fairy-type Pokemon that can help with Scale Shot Koraidon while also dealing with the Taunt Arceus formes that annoy Rayquaza and its team. Rayquaza cannot prevent Pokemon like Ribombee and Glimmora from getting their own entry hazards up; therefore, Pokemon that can remove them, like Great Tusk and Iron Treads, are good partners.

Aerilate.description: Rayquaza is a dangerous mixed attacker with very few consistent long-term answers. Tera Flying Boomburst deals absurd damage, OHKOing everything that isn't a special wall or Flying-resistant target and 2HKOing many resistant foes like Corviknight and Dialga-O, provided the latter's Assault Vest has been removed. Extreme Speed helps chase out opposing offensive threats like Flutter Mane and Koraidon; Tera Flying Extreme Speed also 2HKOes Arceus and Zacian. Both coverage moves nuke Steel-types; Collision Course beats Chansey and is easier to Imposter-proof, while Headlong Rush beats Arceus-Electric and Zacian-C and makes offensive Imposter-proofing easier thanks to lowered defenses. Strength Sap helps offset Life Orb recoil and takes advantage of the switches Rayquaza forces, while Jungle Healing allows it to completely nullify Toxic Groudon at the cost of lower healing per use. Rash is used to maximize damage output, while Naive allows Rayquaza to outrun Jolly Groudon and most opposing Rayquaza. Rayquaza offers basically no defensive utility and hates taking status or Knock Off, meaning slow pivoting support from Dondozo and RegenVest users like Dialga-O is mandatory. Entry hazard setters like Zacian and RegenVest users are recommended, as hazards help remove Rayquaza's need to predict and allow it to safely spam Boomburst. Imposter-proof Rayquaza with Ice Scales Arceus formes, Soundproof users, or Zacian-C.

Specially Defensive.description: Specially Defensive Jirachi utilizes its solid bulk and useful resistances to check numerous special attackers such as Alakazam, Latios, and Clefable. Iron Head is chosen as Jirachi’s STAB move thanks to its decent power and high flinch chance, bolstered further by Serene Grace. Stealth Rock provides the team with valuable entry hazard support. Though, if that role has already been covered on the team, Jirachi can also run Fire Punch to hit common checks like Scizor and Aegislash, or Body Slam to paralyze foes like Hippowdon and Celesteela. U-turn allows Jirachi to maintain momentum and bring its teammates in safely. Healing Wish can fully heal whichever one of Jirachi’s worn down teammates is needed the most late-game. Alternatively, the combination of Wish and Protect can be used to vastly increase the Jirachi’s longevity, though it diminishes its support capabilities and renders it more passive. 16 Speed EVs allow Jirachi to outspeed Adamant Bisharp. The remaining EVs are used to maximize Jirachi’s special bulk. Jirachi can instead run 120 Speed EVs to outspeed Jolly Mega Tyranitar, though it will significantly hamper Jirachi’s ability to check special attackers like Alakazam. Jirachi is prone to getting Pursuit trapped by Dark-type Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar and Bisharp and thus needs to be positioned carefully to not be taken out too early. It also pairs well with Pokemon that can switch into these threats such as Keldeo and Iron Hands. Jirachi is also weak to common Ground-types like Excadrill and Hippowdon and thus pairs well with Pokemon like Celesteela or Rotom-W that can handle them. Jirachi also quickly gets overwhelmed by strong Fire- and Ghost-types and therefore appreciates teammates that handle those Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar and Ting-Lu.

Happy Hour.description: Happy Hour Jirachi functions as a potent late-game sweeper. Z-Happy Hour gives Jirachi a +1 boost to all its stats, heightening its damage output and increasing the base power of Stored Power. After a Z-Happy Hour boost, Stored Power is a powerful STAB move that allows Jirachi to OHKO Pokemon like Toxapex and physically defensive Tangrowth while 2HKOing common walls like Hippowdon and Tapu Fini. Iron Head is a powerful STAB move that hits Dark-type Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar and Hydreigon; as it is a physical move, it allows Jirachi to beat Blissey and Chansey, which otherwise beat most special attackers. Iron Head’s high Serene Grace-boosted flinch chance also allows Jirachi to chip its checks into range for its other moves to KO. Shadow Ball hits Pokemon like Aegislash and Slowking for super effective damage, though Thunderbolt can be used instead to hit Celesteela and Mandibuzz while maintaining super effective coverage for Slowking. Jirachi struggles to do meaningful damage to walls like Ting-Lu and Hisuian Goodra and thus pairs well with Pokemon like Keldeo and Iron Hands that can threaten these Pokemon. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar and Ting-Lu will further wear these checks down to facilitate its sweep. Jirachi can also be overwhelmed prior to setting up by offensive threats like Victini, Excadrill, and Galarian Moltres. Thus, Jirachi appreciates checks to these Pokemon like Rotom-W, Celesteela, and Mega Tyranitar.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Jirachi is a potent form of speed control, able to check fast threats like Enamorus, Latios, and Alakazam while also effectively serving as a pivot with U-turn. Iron Head lets Jirachi exert high pressure thanks to its decent power and Serene Grace-boosted flinch chance. Trick allows Jirachi to cripple defensive checks like Slowbro and Skarmory that would otherwise switch in for free. Alternatively, Jirachi can use Fire Punch to hit Steel-type Pokemon like Aegislash and Scizor for super effective damage. U-turn allows Jirachi to maintain momentum for its team. Healing Wish lets Jirachi fully heal any of its worn down teammates. Jirachi struggles to deal meaningful damage to defensive Pokemon like Celesteela, Tangrowth, and Ting-Lu. It therefore pairs well with wallbreakers like Iron Moth and Enamorus that can threaten these switch-ins. Pokemon like Aegislash, Excadrill, and Bisharp also threaten Jirachi with super effective STAB moves while taking negligible damage from Jirachi in return. Switch-ins to these threats like Mandibuzz and Skarmory are therefore invaluable. Due to Jirachi’s middling damage output, it appreciates entry hazard support from Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar and Skarmory to apply more pressure to Jirachi’s switch-ins. Jirachi can also get worn down quickly by Spikes and Rocky Helmet chip damage and thus pairs nicely with hazard removers, such as Rotom-W and Excadrill, and Knock Off support from Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar and Clefable.

Specially Defensive (Psychic).description:
20 Spe EVs lets it outspeed Breloom and Pokemon around that speed tier

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Z-Happy Hour (Psychic).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Z-Happy Hour.description: With its 100/100/100 bulk, good defensive typing, and passable offensive stats, Jirachi can function as a Z-Happy Hour sweeper, utilizing the omniboost to its full potential. Stored Power is Jirachi's main attacking move, nailing most foes that do not resist Psychic&emdash;this also allows Jirachi to match up favorably against Toxapex and Clodsire, the two biggest setup stoppers in the tier. Aura Sphere allows Jirachi to deal with Dark- and Steel-types; these include Hisuian Samurott, Mega Tyranitar, and Ferrothorn. Drain Punch is an alternative to 2HKO Blissey, which otherwise walls Jirachi, and keep itself healthy with recovery when fighting foes like Heatran. Iron Head serves as a secondary STAB move that can also flinch down foes like Galarian Slowking and Dragonite. A Naive nature should be run when using Drain Punch over Aura Sphere. Jirachi pairs well with allies that can take out its main checks, since it can only set up once and thus has to make it count. Magnezone and Heatran are stellar partners, trapping foes like Ferrothorn and Garganacl that may stand in the way of a Jirachi sweep. Offensive Pokemon like Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, and Garchomp that may struggle against Fairy-types like Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant pair well with Jirachi, as it acts as a soft check to these foes and can use them as setup fodder. Tapu Lele is also notable for providing Psychic Terrain that blocks priority such as Sucker Punch from Hisuian Samurott and powers up Stored Power. Finally, dual screens support from Tapu Koko or Grimmsnarl is beneficial to ease Jirachi's setup, as the damage reduction affords Jirachi more opportunities to successfully use Z-Happy Hour.

Choice Scarf.description: Sporting its infamous Serene Grace-boosted Iron Head in conjunction with a good defensive profile, decent Speed, and a wide utility movepool, Jirachi carves itself a niche as a Choice Scarf user. Iron Head allows Jirachi to easily revenge kill Fairy- and Ice-types, such as Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Weavile, and has good odds to flinch down any foe that does not resist Steel, as long as they are sufficiently chipped. U-turn allows Jirachi to pivot out into teammates upon forcing out foes, allowing free points of entry for allies such as Ogerpon-W and Zapdos that capitalize on Jirachi's switch-ins in Heatran and Toxapex. Trick cripples most foes that try to switch into Iron Head; foes like Toxapex, Zapdos, Ferrothorn, and Alomomola dislike being locked into a move. Healing Wish gives weakened allies another chance to sweep, additionally curing status like burn and paralysis and offering a point of entry; it is best used on offensive Pokemon, such that they can be used more recklessly early-game and come back later to sweep. Ice Punch alternatively allows Jirachi to hit Landorus-T, Gliscor, Zapdos, and Garchomp particularly hard. Jirachi is best used on offensive playstyles that appreciate its one-off heal and ability to cripple defensive switch-ins. Since Jirachi acts as a soft check to the tier's premier Fairy-types in Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele, allies like Zamazenta and Weavile that dislike them pair well with it, as they can threaten Jirachi's checks in Heatran, Ferrothorn, Landorus-T, and Slowbro. Jirachi also struggles to revenge kill Mega Gyarados, Ogerpon-W, and Mega Scizor, especially once they set up, so allies like Ferrothorn and Corviknight are needed to act as sturdier checks. Finally, Jirachi is easily exploited by foes like Mega Charizard Y, Mega Scizor, and Garchomp, as all of them can switch into Iron Head and can ignore Trick provided the latter has a Z-Crystal. Allies that can take advantage of them such as Tapu Koko, Iron Moth, and Weavile make for good partners.

Specially Defensive (Psychic).description:
96 Speed EVs lets it outspeed Adamant Mamoswine.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

All-out Attacker.description: Deoxys is one of Ubers UU's best wallbreakers thanks to its great mixed attacking and Speed stats and deep coverage movepool that allows it to threaten most of the tier. Superpower deals good damage to Pokemon that resist Psycho Boost such as Arceus-Dark, Dialga, and Magearna. Shadow Ball hits Giratina and Psychic-types like Mewtwo, Hatterene, opposing Deoxys, and Solgaleo. Extreme Speed allows Deoxys to pick off low health priority and Choice Scarf users or such as Palafin, Kyurem-W, and Chi-Yu. Alternatively, Knock Off allows Deoxys to secure KOs on Pokemon like Spectrier and specially defensive Solgaleo. Tera Psychic is generally preferred to boost the power of Deoxys's Psycho Boost, although Tera Ghost and Tera Fighting can be viable options, with the former boosting the power of Shadow Ball and providing a nifty immunity to Extreme Speed and the latter allowing Deoxys to beat Kingambit and Arceus-Dark. Deoxys fits best on offensive teams looking for a strong and reliable revenge killer and wallbreaker. Bulkier walls like Magearna, Giratina, and Solgaleo can take an attack from Deoxys and OHKO it or chip away at it by setting up entry hazards and letting it take Life Orb damage, so Pokemon like Chi-Yu, Arceus-Dark, and Landorus that can deal with these threats are nice. Great Tusk is a notable partner; Deoxys deals with Pokemon like Mewtwo, Kyurem-W, and Clefable that Great Tusk potentially struggles with, and in return, Great Tusk deals with Pokemon like Kingambit and Arceus-Fire. Deoxys also appreciates having a teammate that can pivot it into the game safely; thus, Magearna, Solgaleo, Landorus-T, and Palafin all make excellent partners.

Lead.description: Deoxys is one of the best leads in Ubers UU thanks to its solid offensive stats and good movepool allowing it to act as an offensive threat after setting up entry hazards. Psycho Boost is an amazing one-time nuke, dealing serious damage to most Pokemon that don't resist it. Superpower allows Deoxys to target Pokemon like Arceus-Dark, Dialga, and Kyurem-W. Generally, Deoxys prefers Stealth Rock in the final moveslot, allowing it to nearly guarantee it sets up both Stealth Rock and a layer of Spikes, although Taunt can be run instead allowing it to stop Pokemon from setting up or laying their own entry hazards. Focus Sash allows Deoxys to guarantee at least one layer of entry hazards. Tera Psychic boosts Deoxys's Psycho Boost, although Tera Ghost can be run instead, allowing it to spinblock Pokemon like Great Tusk and Cyclizar and block Extreme Speed from Arceus-Fire, which otherwise troubles it. Deoxys fits best on offense and hyper offense teams looking for a dedicated lead that can set up hazards consistently. Offensive threats like Mewtwo, Zacian, and Ogerpon-H appreciate the entry hazards Deoxys sets up to wear down their switch-ins like Arceus-Dark, Solgaleo, and Giratina. Pokemon like Spectrier and Gholdengo that can spinblock are also nice to have. If Deoxys is not running Taunt threats like Arceus-Fire, Arceus-Dark, and Mewtwo may try to use it as set-up fodder, so Pokemon like Zamazenta-C, Palafin, and Magearna that can counter these threats are helpful to have.

Expanding Force.description:
Deoxys-A is one of the most powerful special attackers in the metagame due to its monstrous Special Attack stat and blazing Speed stat. Expanding Force is the other Psychic-type move that should be used when Deoxys-A is in Psychic Terrain. Focus Blast is for Dark-types like Chien-Pao, Incineroar, and Kingambit. Due to Deoxys-A's abysmal bulk, Focus Sash ensures it can get a guaranteed move off. A Hasty nature prevents Porygon2 from getting a Special Attack boost while allowing Deoxys-A to use physical moves from partners like Incineroar and Chien-Pao. Despite Deoxys-A's high Special Attack and powerful STAB moves, it struggles to hit Gholdengo meaningfully, so Pokemon that can actively threaten it, like Incineroar, Landorus-T, and Ogerpon-H, are beneficial. Incineroar and Landorus-T also provide Deoxys-A with pivoting, while Ogerpon-H can redirect in a pinch. Tera Psychic is recommended to make Psycho Boost and Expanding Force as powerful as possible.

Notable Partners

Indeedee-F: Indeedee-F is mandatory for this Deoxys-A set to shine, as it provides Psychic Terrain support, preventing priority moves such as Incineroar's Fake Out, Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch, and Dragonite's Extreme Speed from functioning, as well as boosting Deoxys-A's Expanding Force. It can also prevent Trick Room with Imprison. Bulky Support Pokemon: Fake Out users like Incineroar, and redirectors like Amoongus and Ogerpon-W are good partners, as they allow Deoxys-A to stay on the field for longer Haze Users: Haze users such as Chien-Pao and Volcanion are useful teammates due to their ability to clear stat changes, allowing Deoxys-A to function properly as a breaker. Pivoting: Due to Deoxys-A terrible bulk, it cannot switch into anything. Therefore, pivoting from the likes of bulky Landorus-T and Incineroar are appreciated.

Extreme Speed.description:
Deoxys-A becomes a terrifying revenge killer and mixed attacker with its ability to chip at weakened foes with Extreme Speed. Extreme Speed in conjunction with its ridiculous Attack makes it an attacker that can avoid priority attacks like Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch and Raging Bolt's Thunderclap. Superpower can be used to cover Dark-type threats like Chien-Pao and Kingambit. Focus Sash is required due to Deoxys-A's horrible bulk,and a Hasty nature prevents Porygon2's Download from giving it a Special Attack boost. Tera Stellar is the recommended Tera type, due to the plethora of coverage moves this set runs. Deoxys-A cannot damage Gholdengo very well, so Pokemon like Incineroar and Chien-Pao are recommended.

Notable Partners

Priority Attackers: Pokemon that commonly use priority moves, such as Dragonite, Rillaboom, and Raging Bolt are good teammates, as they can form a priority spam core that can clean up foes very easily. Rillaboom deserves a special mention due to Grassy Surge removing Psychic Terrain from Indeedee. Haze Users: Haze users like Volcanion and Chien-Pao are good teammates since they can erase the stat drops from Psycho Boost, Superpower, and Incineroar and Landorus-T's Intimidate. Chien-Pao also forms a priority spam core with Deoxys-A. Bulky Support Pokemon: Fake Out users like Incineroar and redirectors like Sinistcha and Ogerpon-W are good partners, as they can circumvent Deoxys-A's frailty. Pivoting: Due to Deoxys-A's terrible bulk, it cannot switch into anything. Therefore, it appeciates pivoting from bulky Landorus-T and Incineroar.

Mixed Attacker.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Unaware.description: Boasting high defensive stats and a plethora of utility moves, Deoxys-D makes for an excellent Unaware wall that can check Iron Hands and setup Great Tusk while also providing additional utility like setting entry hazards and pivoting. Spikes is the preferred hazard, as Deoxys-D can usually set multiple layers, but Stealth Rock is an alternative for teams that lack a Stealth Rock setter otherwise, and Knock Off can be used to limit opposing setup threats like Iron Boulder and Quaquaval while also debilitating walls like Corviknight and Swampert. Teleport can be used in conjunction with Deoxys-D's low Speed to safely switch Pokemon in, while Thunder Wave can be used to cripple Iron Boulder and Dragonite. Leftovers is the preferred item for extra longevity, but Heavy-Duty Boots is an option on Teleport sets to enable easier pivoting. On teams that do not need setup control, Fluffy and Intimidate dramatically increase its physical bulk versus key targets like Iron Boulder. Defensive Pokemon like Corviknight and Mandibuzz appreciate Deoxys-D being able to take on setup threats such as Iron Hands and Iron Boulder, allowing them to better handle Dark-types like Roaring Moon. Offensive Pokemon like Galarian Zapdos, Chien-Pao, and Ceruledge appreciate Deoxys-D being able to weaken opposing walls with hazards or Knock Off, as well as potentially getting them in safely if it's running Teleport. Deoxys-D narrowly avoids 2HKOs from stronger wallbreakers like Iron Boulder, so hazard control options like Scrappy Great Tusk and Corviknight are highly recommended so that Deoxys-D can have more longevity.

Lead.description:
16 Speed EVs allow Deoxys-S to outspeed Zacian-C, Miraidon, and Koraidon.

These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Offensive.description:
Thanks to its monstrous Speed, decent attacking stats, and amazing coverage, Deoxys-S can function as a great revenge killer and late-game cleaner. It outspeeds every unboosted Pokemon in OU and outspeeds plenty of boosted Pokemon as well, such as +1 Great Tusk, +1 Volcarona. and +1 Gouging Fire. Fighting-type coverage is required to hit Dark- and Steel-types that switch into Psycho Boost, like Kingambit, Ting-Lu, and Heatran. Superpower can be run to hit special walls like Blissey, but Focus Blast doesn't have any stat drops and also benefits from boosts from Nasty Plot. Knock Off removes items, helping it break down walls like Galarian Slowking and Ting-Lu by removing Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers. Shadow Ball can be used instead if it's running Nasty Plot and to avoid being walled by Hatterene. In its last move slot, it can run Ice Beam for even greater coverage, letting it destroy Dragonite, Gliscor, and Landorus-T. However, Psycho Boost hits the latter two hard anyway, so Nasty Plot can be ran instead to drastically increase its killing power if it’s running only special moves. For example, +2 Psycho Boost can OHKO Volcarona, +2 Focus Blast can OHKO specially defensive Heatran, and +2 Shadow Ball can OHKO Galarian Slowking, Hatterene, and Gholdengo. Finally, Taunt can be used as utility, denying hazards, setup, and keeping Deoxys-S free from status like Gliscor's Toxic and Clefable's Thunder Wave, and also stopping Galarian Slowking from gaining momentum with Chilly Reception. Other moves Deoxys-S can run include Expanding Force over Psycho Boost if it's used with Psychic Terrain and Stealth Rock or Spikes in its last slot to take advantage of switches. A Timid nature should be ran if using Nasty Plot, but a Naive nature should be used if running a mixed set. A Hasty nature is an alternative to better take special moves like Raging Bolt's Thunderclap, but it makes Deoxys-S weaker into common priority like Extreme Speed and Grassy Glide. Tera Fighting is its premier Tera type, giving it STAB on its Fighting-type coverage, letting it hit Psycho Boost switch-ins harder. It guarantees that Superpower will 2HKO Heatran and Iron Treads and lets +2 Focus Blast OHKO Ting-Lu. It also has defensive utility, like giving it a resistance to Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Tera Ghost can be useful on Shadow Ball sets to break past its Psychic-type switch-ins, letting it get a 2HKO on Galarian Slowking and Latias. It also gives Deoxys-S an immunity to Dragonite's Extreme Speed. Finally, Tera Psychic further boosts its Psycho Boosts, which lets it guarantee an OHKO into Walking Wake and Ogerpon-W and gives it a good chance to OKHO Gouging Fire. Life Orb boosts its damage output, but Expert Belt can be used instead to avoid recoil damage. However, missing out on Life Orb can cost Deoxys-S some KOs like missing a 2HKO on Clefable with Psycho Boost and losing the ability to do substantial damage to Corviknight.

Deoxys-S is best on hyper offense and bulky offense teams. Offensive teammates such as Volcarona, Roaring Moon, and Gouging Fire like the holes Deoxys-S pokes into opposing teams. It can damage walls like Ting-Lu, Blissey, and Galarian Slowking for these teammates or check other offensive Pokemon that outspeed them like +1 Kyurem and Dragapult. Its Fighting-type coverage takes care of Kingambit, Ting-Lu, and Heatran, removing checks for other teammates like its own Kingambit, Dragapult, and Volcarona. Similarly, its Ghost- or Dark-type coverage lets it take out Hatterene and Gholdengo, opening up opportunities for teammates like Iron Valiant and Iron Boulder to clean up late-game. Thanks to its perfect coverage, it is able to deal decent damage to any opponent, further opening holes for its teammates. This includes Pokemon like Dondozo, Roaring Moon, and Corviknight. Offensive teammates also appreciate its fast Knock Off removing items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers from walls like Galarian Slowking and Ting-Lu. Entry hazard support from teammates like Hisuian Samurott, Ting-Lu, and Glimmora help with breaking as well. Similarly, if it runs Taunt, teammates such as Kyurem and Gouging Fire like its fast Taunt denying hazards, stopping setup from opponents, and limiting recovery. While Deoxys-S has great coverage, its base 95 attacking stats are relatively low, and Psycho Boost lowering its Special Attack is less than ideal. As such, it can struggle to break past certain walls it can't hit super effectively like Corviknight and Assault Vest Primarina. Volcarona invites in Primarina and can damage it with Giga Drain. This chip damage can allow Deoxys-S to KO Primarina later in the game, while the chip Deoxys-S does to Primarina can allow Volcarona to sweep. Raging Bolt can freely switch into Corviknight and set up free Calm Minds as it switches out. Despite its massive natural Speed stat, Deoxys-S is still outsped by a lot of prominent boosted Pokemon like +1 Roaring Moon, +1 Iron Boulder, +1 Walking Wake, and Barraskewda in rain. These can be covered by carrying offensive checks to these mons like Kingambit, Air Balloon Gholdengo, and Ogerpon-W. Deoxys-S is also horribly weak to priority. It doesn't have many ways to work around Sucker Punch, and other priority like Grassy Glide and Extreme Speed hit it hard. A way around this is having teammates that can easily take common priority like Kingambit, Great Tusk, or Dragonite. Additionally, dual screen setters, like Alolan Ninetales, can help against priority and assist Deoxys-S in setting up Nasty Plots. Psychic Terrain from Indeedee is another option due to it blocking priority, and it also boosts Deoxys-S’s Psychic-type STAB moves.

Dual Screens.description:
Thanks to its unparalleled Speed tier and access to an array of solid utility options, Deoxys-S is one of the best dual screens setters in OU. Taunt is key in preventing Pokemon like Glimmora, Skarmory, Ting-Lu, and Landorus-T from laying entry hazards, setup threats such as Swords Dance Ogerpon-W and Dragon Dance Kyurem from boosting, and Cinderace from using Court Change. Psycho Boost lets Deoxys-S have some sort of offensive presence; it can obliterate lead Glimmora while overwhelming neutral targets like Dondozo and physically defensive Skeledirge. Deoxys-S generally should not Terastallize, as being unable to Terastallize a wallbreaker later in the match could be game ending. However, in a pinch, Tera Steel can let it more easily set dual screens against priority users like Weavile, Dragonite, and Rillaboom.

Deoxys-S is a fixture on dual screens hyper offense teams thanks to its absolutely blazing Speed that surpasses every unboosted Pokemon in the tier, letting it ensure at least one of Reflect or Light Screen go up. Setup sweepers like Dragon Dance Roaring Moon, Iron Boulder, Volcarona, Iron Valiant, and Serperior are amazing at making use of Deoxys-S's screens support, taking a hit from Deoxys-S's potential revenge killers such as Kingambit and Cinderace with it and being able to strike back strong. In particular, Volcarona's solid natural bulk and ability to switch in on Pokemon that would otherwise break Deoxys-S like Weavile and Kingambit make it an excellent partner. Cleaners such as Dragon Dance Kyurem, Kingambit, and Choice Scarf Enamorus are similarly potent behind dual screens. Due to Ceaseless Edge, Hisuian Samurott's Spikes cannot be denied by Deoxys-S, so Pokemon that can take advantage of Hisuian Samurott such as Iron Valiant and Enamorus are good teammates. Entry hazard control options like Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Hatterene also make for good partners in the event that Deoxys-S is unable to prevent hazards being set. Great Tusk and Hatterene in particular can double as potent bulky setup sweepers with Bulk Up and Calm Mind, respectively. Other bulky setup Pokemon like Latias and Iron Crown benefit similarly from screens.

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Deoxys-S is an incredible wallbreaker, boasting powerful Psychic Terrain-boosted Expanding Force alongside the highest relevant base Speed stat in the tier. Ice Beam hits Roaring Moon, Mandibuzz, and Dragonite for massive damage, while Knock Off debilitates foes, especially RegenVest users like Manaphy, Swampert, and Meloetta. Energy Ball hits Swampert and Iron Boulder; alternatively, Dark Pulse OHKOes Azelf and 2HKOes Gholdengo and Deoxys-D while still hitting Iron Boulder. Trick can debilitate defensive Pokemon, but it comes with the cost of weakening Deoxys-S. A Timid nature allows Deoxys-S to outspeed +1 Volcarona and Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks, while a Modest nature gives it more power, allowing it to always 2HKO defensive Gholdengo after slight chip damage. Other special wallbreakers like Iron Moth, Walking Wake, and Latios are appreciated, as they can break down shared checks such as RegenVest users like Manaphy, Swampert, Meloetta, and Hisuian Goodra with Deoxys-S. Deoxys-S is very frail, so slow pivots like Corviknight, Swampert, and Manaphy are very helpful. Additionally, entry hazard support from allies such as Great Tusk and Heatran can help chip would-be checks into range of a KO.

Sheer Force.description: With its sky-high Speed stat and fantastic coverage, Deoxys-S is able to outspeed a significant portion of the metagame and threaten many common metagame threats with huge damage thanks to Sheer Force. Ice Beam OHKOes Zapdos and offensive Roaring Moon after some chip damage and 2HKOes Mandibuzz. Energy Ball 2HKOes RegenVest Swampert, while Thunderbolt can be run instead to threaten Corviknight. Focus Blast lets Deoxys-S damage Steel-types like Heatran and Hisuian Goodra, while Dark Pulse can be used instead to 2HKO Deoxys-D and Gholdengo. Knock Off is another option that can be used to debilitate opposing Pokemon like Swampert and Manaphy by removing their held items, making them easier for Deoxys-S and its teammates to deal with. Deoxys-S struggles against specially defensive Pokemon like Meloetta and Manaphy, so it pairs well with physically offensive partners like Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Galarian Zapdos that can effectively force them out. Due to its relative frailty and lack of recovery, Deoxys-S benefits from pivots like Corviknight and entry hazard removers like Great Tusk that allow it to come in safely. Entry hazard setters like Skarmory, Scream Tail, and Smeargle can also help weaken foes, making them easier for Deoxys-S to handle.

Lead.description: Deoxys-S is one of the best hyper offense leads due to its high base Speed and access to dual screens, Taunt, and Stealth Rock. Taunt shuts down entry hazard setters like Deoxys-D and Smeargle; setup sweepers such as Thundurus-T, Manaphy, and Iron Boulder; and Defoggers like Corviknight. Pokemon such as Iron Moth and Chien-Pao that threaten Defog users pair well with Deoxys-S, since Defog threatens to remove dual screens after Deoxys-S has left the field. Mandibuzz is the biggest threat to Deoxys-S's dual screens, since its Defog cannot be blocked by Prankster Taunt. Since Deoxys-S is usually used as a suicide lead, it should only be used on hyper offense teams. Deoxys-S pairs well with setup sweepers like Manaphy, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao, since it's able to reliably get up dual screens, which allow them set up more easily and make harder to revenge kill. Pokemon weak to entry hazards such as Volcarona appreciate Deoxys-S's ability to block them from being set with Taunt. Dark-types, such as Dragon Dance Roaring Moon, are able to set up in front of Deoxys-S due to being immune to Prankster Taunt, so switch-ins like Great Tusk are required.

Protean.description: Protean Deoxys-S is a fast mixed wallbreaker and late-game cleaner, using its wide list of coverage to its advantage. Thunderbolt is Deoxys-S's most spammable move, as it hits a majority of the metagame for solid damage such as Primarina, Manaphy, non-Volt Absorb Corviknight, and Gholdengo. Ice Beam is used to hit Ground- and Dragon-types hard, such as Great Tusk, Dragonite, and Roaring Moon. Energy Ball can be used to beat Swampert while also pressuring Water- and Ground-types instead of being forced to predict. Superpower acts as Deoxys-S's main physical attack, being able to hit specially defensive walls such as Hisuian Goodra, Blissey, and Meloetta. Knock Off helps Deoxys-S and its teammates by crippling RegenVest users to be taken on better later in the game. Entry hazards like Stealth Rock and Spikes let Deoxys-S potentially weaken defensive checks for itself and its teammates. Life Orb is used to more easily use Deoxys-S's mixed potential but can reduce how many times how many times its able to switch in. Choice Specs can be used instead as an easier way for Deoxys-S to hit 2HKO damage rolls on RegenVest Pokemon and give it more switch-in opportunities, but this gives it less flexibility and physical power. With 236 Speed EVs and a Naive nature, Deoxys-S is able to outrun +1 Jolly Garchomp as well as neutral Regieleki. Setup sweepers and Choice-locked Pokemon like Roaring Moon, Chien-Pao, and Manaphy appreciate Deoxys-S's presence, as it can help with weakening or taking out any of their checks such as Great Tusk, Primarina, and RegenVest users. Teams containing slower attackers also appreciate Deoxys-S, as it can act as a form of speed control. Deoxys-S does struggle with making it onto the field safely due to both hazards and having minimal bulk, so having a defensive pivot or a hazard remover would help it, like Great Tusk, Corviknight, or Mandibuzz.

Nasty Plot (Psychic).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned

Shell Smash (Grass).description:
Torterra finds its place on Grass teams as a Shell Smash sweeper with a great STAB combination and convenient Speed tier, being able to outpace most of the unboosted metagame after a Shell Smash and break through Pokemon that trouble Grass teams such as Toxapex and Clodsire. Bullet Seed, alongside Loaded Dice, gives Torterra an incredibly strong STAB combination when paired with Headlong Rush and hits things Seed Bomb cannot KO such as Walking Wake and Air Balloon Glimmora. Seed Bomb is a less powerful alternative but comes with the upside of not having to run Loaded Dice for reliability. Headlong Rush allows Torterra to hit Steel- and Poison-types such as Heatran and Amoonguss. Rock Blast is also boosted by Loaded Dice and hits Flying-types, such as Talonflame, Dragonite, and Zapdos, that can ignore Torterra's STAB moves as well as hitting Bug-types such as Volcarona. Alternatively, Heavy Slam provides Torterra with a way to hit Galarian Weezing to secure the Poison matchup alongside being a good option into Fairy teams as a whole. An Adamant nature is preferred to gain as much extra power as possible, but a Jolly nature can outspeed slower Choice Scarf users such as Great Tusk and Hisuian Samurott. Soft Sand is an alternative to Loaded Dice if Seed Bomb and Heavy Slam are run, which lets Torterra's Headlong Rush have a favorable roll to OHKO Amoonguss with a Shell Smash boost.

Ogerpon-H is a great teammate for Torterra, as it can remove Corviknight, an otherwise large barrier for Torterra's sweeping attempts. In return, Torterra breaks through Toxapex, which inhibits Ogerpon-H's sweeping attempts. Choice Scarf Meowscarada provides speed control for Torterra while removing crucial defensive items such as Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots from Corviknight and Amoonguss respectively in order to wear them down faster. Additionally, Meowscarada can threaten Dragon-types, such as Choice Scarf Roaring Moon and Walking Wake, that can halt Torterra's sweep by outspeeding it. In return, Torterra easily destroys bulkier team compositions, such as Poison, that Meowscarada struggles to make meaningful progress against. Amoonguss provides opportunities for Torterra to set up thanks to Spore, which Torterra can struggle with finding otherwise. Abomasnow provides Aurora Veil support to aid Torterra in its sweeping efforts, offers a way to beat Dragon teams, and provides an Ice neutrality, allowing it to take a few hits from Chien-Pao, while Brambleghast can remove entry hazards to let Torterra switch in and take advantage of passive switch-ins more readily. Breloom can also put foes to sleep with Spore, while using Mach Punch to remove Choice Scarf users such as Roaring Moon and threaten Baxcalibur, which can each end Torterra's sweeping attempts quickly. Hisuian Lilligant and Rotom-C can also help in the Flying matchup, where Torterra struggles thanks to Ice Spinner and Electric-type STAB moves, respectively, while also being able to scare out Corviknight. Sinistcha is another good teammate for Torterra thanks to Heatproof.

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Fire

Thunder Punch and Knock Off are other options Infernape can choose to run over Close Combat or Flare Blitz. Thunder Punch allows Infernape to threaten several bulky Water-types. It can 2HKO mixed defensive Toxapex most of the time and OHKO Pelipper and Gyarados. With Knock Off, Infernape can not only threaten Ghost-types, such as Skeledirge, but it can also remove key items, such as Heavy-Duty Boots, from the likes of Pelipper, Ninetales, and Baxcalibur to make them susceptible to entry hazards.
