Alolan Sandslash can neutralize Toxic from foes such as Toxapex aimed at Mamoswine, threaten Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant, and use Knock Off to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from foes such as Amoonguss and Toxapex and open them up to being chipped by Stealth Rock. Moreover, both Alolan Sandslash and Avalugg can help prevent Mamoswine from being worn down by entry hazards by spinning them away. Cetitan and Cloyster are other sweepers on Ice to accompany Baxcalibur that benefit from the offensive pressure that Mamoswine's Stealth Rock creates. Cloyster greatly appreciates Mamoswine's Electric immunity, and Cetitan can only OHKO Corviknight at +6 after Stealth Rock.

Choice Band (Ground).description:
Mamoswine is a great offensive option for Ground teams thanks to its huge Attack stat, access to priority, and unique STAB combination. Mamoswine's ability, Thick Fat, also allows for it to act as an extremely valuable resistance to Ice, meaning it can switch into foes like Articuno. Icicle Crash shreds Grass-type Pokemon, such as Amoonguss and Sinistcha, and Flying-type Pokemon, such as Mandibuzz and Gliscor, that would otherwise resist or be immune to Ground-type moves. Icicle Crash is extremely threatening to Flying-type teams in particular, as most Flying-type Pokemon are 2HKOed by Icicle Crash, meaning there are no safe switchins. Ice Shard is a fantastic priority move that allows Mamoswine to stand its ground against faster Pokemon such as both Landorus formes, Cyclizar, Meowscarada, and Dragapult. Knock Off is a good final option to help deal with walls that may take a bit more time to whittle down, such as Dondozo and Corviknight, as well as create permanent progress against Pokemon such as Baxcalibur and Articuno, which both rely heavily on their items, whether it be offensively or defensively.

Mamoswine greatly appreciates entry hazard support from Pokemon like Quagsire, as the extra damage could be the difference between a 2HKO or an opportunity for an OHKO on lots of Pokemon such as Flutter Mane and Meowscarada with Ice Shard, Icicle Crash on Corviknight, and Earthquake on Toxapex and Amoonguss. Clodsire is a good teammate for Mamoswine, as it can switch in to Water- and Fighting-type attacks from Pokemon like Urshifu-R, Sneasler, and Walking Wake that would otherwise make quick work of Mamoswine, as well as provide Toxic and entry hazard support. Iron Treads is another good teammate for Mamoswine, as it keeps hazards off the field in order to prevent Mamoswine from being chipped down, as well as setts up hazards of its own. Alternatively, Choice Scarf Iron Treads outspeeds and hits Iron Valiant and Flutter Mane, which both threaten Mamoswine, for super effective damage. Choice Scarf Great Tusk is another teammate that pairs well with Mamoswine. Great Tusk is able to outspeed and OHKO Pokemon that check Mamoswine such as Choice Specs Greninja and Cinderace. Once faster threats have been taken care of, Mamoswine will have an easy time breaking the opposing team with its extremely powerful attacks. Ursaluna-B is a great teammate for Mamoswine, as it can absorb status conditions from Pokemon like Rotom-W and Sableye, as well as threatening them back with its extremely powerful Blood Moon. Ursaluna-B is also capable of using Vacuum wave to snipe Chien-Pao. Gliscor can also absorb status moves, as well as absorbing status moves and Fighting-type attacks that Mamoswine does not want to deal with. Gliscor is also able to support Mamoswine with Spikes and Toxic. Landorus forms a potent offensive core with Mamoswine, destroying Physical walls such as Quagsire and Slowbro, while Mamoswine deals with special walls such as Gliscor and Gastrodon. Additionally, Landorus can set Gravity for Mamoswine so that it can freely spam Earthquake. Lastly, Sandy Shocks is capable of dealing with Pokemon such as Pelipper and Corviknight, as well as providing hazard and Gravity support. Mamoswine easily takes care of the Ground-types that would wall Sandy Shocks.
This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description:
Gallade is the premier Choice Scarf user on Psychic teams due to its great coverage options and incredible ability, Sharpness. Being able to fire off Sharpness-boosted Sacred Sword is incredibly valuable, as it hits the Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon that give Psychic teams trouble for super effective damage, such as Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and Hisuian Goodra. Knock Off is a great way to make progress against bulkier teams, as well as dissuade Ghost-type Pokemon from switching in on a potential Sacred Sword. Night Slash is also an option to deal more consistent damage to Skeledirge and Gholdengo. Leaf Blade is used to threaten bulky Water-type Pokemon like Quagsire and Rotom-W, as well as OHKO Belly Drum Azumarill. Aqua Cutter is an option over Leaf Blade to hit Pokemon like Landorus, Volcarona and Moltres for super effective damage, but Leaf Blade is often better due to the amount of targets it hits. A Jolly nature is preferred over Adamant, as it allows Gallade to outspeed and still OHKO Greninja, Flutter Mane, and Sneasler, while the extra attack from Adamant is not necessary as most of the moves Gallade uses receive a Sharpness boost.

Espathra is a nice compliment to Gallade, as it appreciates Gallade's ability to deal with Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon like Gholdengo, Hisuian Goodra, Kingambit, and Ting-Lu, which Espathra has little way of hitting for even neutral damage, as well as its ability to remove special walls such as Galarian Slowking and Alolan Muk. Hoopa-U is also a great teammate for Gallade, as the speed of Gallade and sheer power of Hoopa-U synergize nicely to deal with both bulky and fast teams. Hoopa-U is able to threaten an OHKO on defensive staples such as Amoonguss, Toxapex, and Rotom-W with entry hazard support, while Gallade outspeeds Pokemon that would otherwise shut Hoopa-U down, such as Sneasler and Greninja. Armarouge is a strong partner for Gallade, as it provides a nice resistance to Fairy-type attacks and complementary coverage to Gallade's. Armarouge appreciates the removal of special walls such as Hisuian Goodra and Galarian Slowking, allowing it to set up and apply pressure to the opposing team, and it returns the favor by taking out physically bulky foes such as Dondozo, Zamazenta, and Corviknight. Hatterene is Psychic teams' best form of hazard control, which Gallade appreciates as it tends to switch in frequently and can otherwise get chipped. Hatterene also lures in Steel- and Poison-type Pokemon like Iron Treads and Sneasler, which Gallade can take care of. Indeedee is another good teammate for Gallade, as it sets up Psychic Terrain, further strengthening Gallade's Psycho Cut and protecting it from priority moves like Shadow Sneak and Sucker Punch. Indeedee also provides a valuable Ghost immunity, which prevents foes like Flutter Mane and Gholdengo from freely spamming Shadow Ball. Scream Tail is a great defensive teammate for Gallade, as its incredible bulk allows it to switch in to common Choice Scarf users such as Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Meowscarada, which would otherwise outspeed and OHKO Gallade. Scream Tail's access to a myriad of utility moves, such as Thunder Wave and Wish, allows it to support Gallade nicely by slowing down the aforementioned threats and increasing its longevity. Mew is a good teammate for Gallade on more offense-oriented teams, as lead Mew is the premier hazard setter for Psychic teams, and Gallade greatly appreciates the support. Galarian Slowking is a great teammate for Gallade as well, as it is able to safely switch into special attacks, as well as Fairy-type attacks that would otherwise give Gallade trouble. Galarian Slowking can also utilize Chilly Reception to give Gallade a free switch in.

Choice Scarf (Fighting).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

vgc2024.overview:
• Gallade is a strong option on Trick Room teams thanks to its high physical damage output, unique coverage and utility movepool. It can deal with many problematic matchups for Trick Room, such as set up sweepers via Sacred Sword and spread moves via Wide Guard.

  • Gallade is used on teams with Indeedee-F, as the Fighting-type coverage it provides is crucial in dealing with Incineroar, Ting-Lu and other Dark-types that give Trick Room sweepers such as Hatterene trouble. Sharpness-boosted Sacred Sword does massive damage, putting pressure on opponents from turn one, as well as checking several problematic matchups, such as Dondozo. Wide Guard removes the most common way to bypass Indeedee-F's Follow Me, spread moves, and presents mind games on opponents on whether Gallade will use Wide Guard or set up Trick Room.

  • Gallade's typing is amazing offensively, but defensively leaves much to be desired. Its Defense and HP are low, making it vulnerable to attackers like Rillaboom and Urshifu that can take one attack from Gallade while OHKOing it back. While its Special Defense is high, it is made moot by relevant special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Tornadus, which both resist Sacred Sword and hit it for super effective damage. However, it should be noted that Wide Guard blocks both Bleakwind Storm and Dazzling Gleam.

Trick Room Abuser.description:
• Psycho Cut and Sacred Sword are the highest base power moves that take advantage of Sharpness.

  • The Defense EVs allow Gallade to survive a Wicked Blow and Surging Strikes from Urshifu-S and Urshifu-R, respectively.

  • Tera Grass allows Gallade to ignore powder moves from Amoonguss, a common Trick Room counter, and resist common physical attackers such as Rillaboom. Alternatively, Tera Fire can be used to resist common anti-Trick Room leads such as Chi-Yu and Flutter Mane, as well as giving Gallade a Fairy resist.

All-out Attacker.description:
• With its wide range of moveset options and its offense-boosting ability Sharpness, Gallade is excellent at dueling a wide variety of threats.

  • Shadow Sneak versus Feint: Shadow Sneak is far more consistent as a priority move and deals good damage to targets like Flutter Mane and Gholdengo. Feint is used mostly for winning Focus Sash duels against Chien-Pao's Ice Shard and Sucker Punch.

  • Night Slash versus Knock Off: Night Slash's consistent power is best for pure offense, potentially 2HKOing targets like Bold Gholdengo, assuming they can't stall with Recover and Rocky Helmet. If more utility is desired, Knock Off can be used for removing opposing items.

  • Leaf Blade: Fully invested Sharpness Leaf Blade has a 75% chance of OHKOing 252 HP Azumarill and is Gallade's best hope of muscling past Dondozo.

Other Options

  • Aqua Cutter: Aqua Cutter benefits from Sharpness, but it doesn't add a lot of extra coverage.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Gallade uses Focus Sash or Assault Vest as its main tool for cushioning a big hit and has great natural coverage. Therefore, Tera is reserved mostly for emergency situations.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost's immunity to Normal- and Fighting-type moves can thwart revenge kill attempts from Mach Punch users and Extreme Speed Dragonite, giving Gallade an opportunity to break Multiscale on the latter.

  • Grass: Tera Grass improves the lead matchup versus Breloom; if Gallade successfully baits a Spore, most sets can beat Breloom without losing Focus Sash. Leaf Blade also becomes an easy 2HKO on Dondozo.

  • Steel: Tera Steel flips Gallade's weakness to Fairy-type attacks to a resistance. The Ice resistance can also be used in a pinch to keep Baxcalibur's Icicle Spear from OHKOing Gallade through Focus Sash.

Items

  • Focus Sash: With Focus Sash, Gallade duels opposing Focus Sash users with its hard-hitting STAB attacks and priority moves.

  • Assault Vest: Gallade has enough Special Defense to make good use of Assault Vest if Focus Sash is already taken, comfortably surviving unboosted hits from targets like Chi-Yu. Furthermore, Assault Vest isn't rendered useless by Stealth Rock chip, making Gallade a safer mid- or late-game option.

  • Scope Lens: While Scope Lens is risky due to Gallade's average bulk and Speed, it pairs well with the increased critical hit ratio many of Gallade's attacks have.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Adamant: A maximum offense spread is standard for Focus Sash and Speed ties with offensive Adamant Dragonite.

  • 196 HP / 252 Atk / 60 Spe with Adamant: For sets that run Assault Vest over Focus Sash, this slower spread avoids the OHKO from Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash after Stealth Rock damage. The Speed investment gets the jump on 4 Speed Rotom formes, letting Gallade deal as much damage as possible before getting hit with a burn.

Choice Scarf.description:
• With both Trick and Knock Off, Gallade is a decent anti-lead against several early-game setups.

  • Trick: Trick with Choice Scarf lets Gallade permanently cripple setup Pokemon like Annihilape and Garganacl.

  • Knock Off versus Night Slash: Knock Off remains a strong disruption move with or without Trick, provided you exercise caution if you've already used Trick. Night Slash has more offensive presence than Knock Off and is a good choice if you really need to hit Gholdengo with consistent damage.

  • Leaf Blade: Leaf Blade is a great coverage option and, if Trick isn't available, your best move against Dondozo.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Choice Scarf Gallade normally isn't a strong user of Tera. It is best used in situations where Gallade already has momentum and needs to preserve it.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost grants immunity to Mach Punch and Extreme Speed, letting Gallade keep its speed advantage against several targets.

  • Grass: Tera Grass can surprise Spore users like Breloom, letting Gallade score an easy KO or cripple them with Trick. Leaf Blade also becomes a 2HKO against Dondozo.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting is a no-nonsense option for making Sacred Sword hit harder.

  • Psychic: Tera Psychic boosts Psycho Cut while removing Gallade's Fairy weakness.

Swords Dance.description: With a sky-high Attack stat and a powerful STAB Close Combat, Mega Gallade serves as a potent wallbreaker in the tier, able to pressure common defensive cores featuring Pokemon such as Skarmory, Ting-Lu, and Mega Venusaur. Mega Gallade's good Speed tier also allows it to notably get the jump on threats like non-Choice Scarf Enamorus, Keldeo, and Galarian Zapdos. After a Swords Dance boost, Mega Gallade can OHKO a majority of the tier, including bulky Pokemon like Iron Hands, Hippowdon, and Mega Latias. Close Combat OHKOes threats like Mega Tyranitar, Excadrill, and Hydreigon while 2HKOing bulkier Pokemon like Celesteela and Gastrodon. Zen Headbutt threatens Mega Venusaur, Amoonguss, and Iron Moth while also being its strongest move against Fairy-types like Tapu Fini and Clefable. Triple Axel threatens Flying-types like both Thundurus formes and Enamorus as well as Dragon-types like Salamence, Mega Latias, Mega Latios, and Mega Altaria while also being its strongest move against Mega Sableye. Knock Off threatens switch-ins like Skeledirge, Slowking, and Slowbro while also hindering foes that Mega Gallade struggles to break through like Unaware Clefable. Physical cleaners like Zeraora and Scizor appreciate Mega Gallade being able to threaten or weaken their switch-ins such as Mega Venusaur and Skarmory, respectively, potentially allowing them to sweep late-game. Mega Gallade's frailty means it's OHKOed by faster threats like Mega Aerodactyl and Choice Scarf Galarian Zapdos, so teammates that can handle them like Celesteela and Slowbro are appreciated. Mega Gallade struggles to break through Pokemon like Mega Sableye, Skeledirge, and Unaware Clefable, meaning it can struggle versus bulkier teams as a whole. Therefore, teammates that can assist in these matchups while threatening the aforementioned walls such as Enamorus and Bisharp are appreciated.

Swords Dance (Fighting).description: For Fighting teams, Mega Gallade is one of the best choices, courtesy of its incredible offensive power, typing, and Speed, being the best counter to Fighting's biggest roadblock, Toxapex. Swords Dance increases Mega Gallade's power to the maximum, letting it freely overpower the likes of Mandibuzz and Celesteela. Zen Headbutt beautifully complements a Fighting-type STAB move, as it lets Mega Gallade easily break through any opposing Poison-types that may be annoying walls such as Mega Venusaur, Toxapex, and Clodsire. Knock Off is another tool in Mega Gallade's arsenal, which lets it take care of Psychic- and Ghost-types—such as Gholdengo, Slowbro, and Aegislash—and wears down Celesteela into range of Close Combat finishing it off. Triple Axel is another option to easily take care of Flying-types such as Landorus-T, Dragonite, and Enamorus. Shadow Sneak can also be considered to pick off faster weakened threats such as Gengar, Choice Scarf Blacephalon, and Mega Alakazam. With all its benefits, Mega Gallade has a few checks in Skeledirge and defensive Gholdengo; hence, offensive Great Tusk and Urshifu-R are great partners in helping take these down. Defensive Great Tusk also helps in setting and removing entry hazards, which is appreciated by Mega Gallade. Mega Gallade is also easily revenge killed by faster offensive threats such as Tornadus-T and Choice Scarf Blacephalon, so Assault Vest Iron Hands is a good check to stop these in their tracks and deal good damage back while also being able to pivot in Mega Gallade with Volt Switch. Breloom and Lilligant-H also helps significantly in the Water matchup against the likes of Mega Swampert and Barraskewda; they can also put opposing foes to sleep to make Gallade's setup easier. Choice Scarf Sneasler helps in the Fairy matchup against the likes of Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Tapu Koko while also being able to set and absorb Toxic Spikes and can U-Turn to pivot in Mega Gallade safely. Iron Valiant is also an amazing partner in the form of a specially offensive threat, complementing Mega Gallade, as it can easily take care of Mega Sableye. Choice Scarf Iron Valiant also outspeeds Mega Swampert under rain and Regieleki under Electric Terrain, making it a great revenge killer if Mega Gallade gets knocked out.

Swords Dance (Psychic).description: Mega Gallade is a potent wallbreaker on Psychic teams thanks to its greatly appreciated Dark neutrality and good coverage in Knock Off and Triple Axel. Swords Dance allows Mega Gallade to grab a boost on a forced switch and potentially win the game with its high base Speed and astronomical Attack after one boost. Knock Off is crucial to hit opposing Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Slowbro and Gholdengo that would otherwise wall this set, and its item removal is always handy in breaking defensive teams reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots down with Stealth Rock damage and removing key items from Celesteela and Toxapex. Finally, Zen Headbutt does massive work against Poison teams after a single Swords Dance and deals high amounts of damage to Fighting-resistant Pokemon such as Buzzwole and Toxapex. Triple Axel is another alternative, allowing Mega Gallade to hit Flying- and Dragon-types such as Landorus-T and Garchomp. Shadow Sneak can allow Mega Gallade to outspeed and take out Ghost-types such as Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Choice Scarf Blacephalon that could otherwise beat it. Tapu Lele forms a wallbreaking core with Mega Gallade, as they both threaten common checks to each other. Tapu Lele beats Mega Sableye with Moonblast, while Mega Gallade crushes Steel-types such as Heatran and Celesteela that trouble Tapu Lele with Close Combat. Jirachi can take Fairy-type attacks such as Tapu Lele's Moonblast aimed for Mega Gallade, as well as paralyze threats and beat them down with Thunder Wave and Serene Grace-boosted Iron Head, letting Mega Gallade break through them with a timely paralysis. Finally, Jirachi provides Stealth Rock support and a safe pivot in with U-turn. Victini provides speed control with Choice Scarf and defeats Steel-types such as Choice Scarf Gholdengo that Mega Gallade is forced out by while appreciating Mega Gallade's ability to pound Heatran to dust. Deoxys-S provides entry hazard and dual screens support, which Mega Gallade can take advantage of with Knock Off and Swords Dance to break through bulkier teams. Slowbro provides crucial momentum with Teleport while also being able to annoy teams with Scald burns and Future Sight and switch in repeatedly through Regenerator. Celebi can break through troubling physical walls such as Hippowdon and Dondozo that Mega Gallade struggles to make progress against. Finally, Choice Scarf Latias can both remove entry hazards with Defog and use Healing Wish to give Mega Gallade a second chance to break through the opposing team.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

Spikes Utility.description:
With excellent Speed, a diverse utility movepool, and Spikes, Froslass is an elite Spikes setter and spinblocker. Taunt shuts down opposing entry hazard setters like Qwilfish, Blissey, and Sandaconda while also preventing Defog from the likes of Braviary and Lurantis. Ice Beam puts additional pressure on the aforementioned Defoggers and targets other walls like Sandaconda and Appletun. Shadow Ball provides higher damage on targets like Mesprit and Ghost-types like Rotom and opposing Froslass. Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers like Coil Dudunsparce, Hisuian Sneasel, and Scyther. While Tera Dark is situational, it can become a Knock Off sponge and wall Sableye while inverting its Dark and Ghost weaknesses.

Stealth Rock setters like Bombirdier and Sandaconda contribute to the hazard stacking Froslass provides, with the former removing opposing Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off. Wallbreakers like Bruxish and Pyroar can put foes into KO range faster thanks to the extra chip damage. VoltTurn users such as Scyther, Jolteon, and Magneton can not only help bring Froslass in safely, but also wear down other walls like Muk, Appletun, and Umbreon. Defensive walls like Blissey and Sandaconda can circumvent Froslass's low bulk with their reliable recovery and can sponge status moves.

Entry Hazard Lead (Ice).description:
Froslass is a great addition to Ice-type teams as it not only provides an immunity to Fighting-type moves and Rapid Spin, but also serves as a fantastic lead that is able to both set up its own entry hazards and prevent the opponent from doing the same. Taunt prevents hazards and status from foes such as Toxapex, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire, and is also used to deny Defog from Corviknight or Talonflame. However, it must be careful as most Corviknight and Talonflame can simply attack Froslass for super effective damage. When paired with Focus Sash, Taunt increases the chances of Froslass taking an opponent down with Destiny Bond, but it can also be used in tandem with Mental Herb to punish opponents like Sableye, Grimmsnarl, and opposing Froslass that attempt to Taunt Froslass, Taunting them in return. Spikes serves to punish switches on the opponent's side and weaken their team, allowing for Froslass's teammates to clean late-game. Shadow Ball is Froslass's answer to Hatterene, 2HKOing it as it comes in to bounce Spikes back, and it's Froslass's main source of damage to prevent it from being too passive. Froslass's last moveslot can utilize Destiny Bond to take an opponent down with it, but Will-O-Wisp and Thunder Wave are also options to consider as they allow you to status Pokemon that like to play around Destiny Bond, such as Kingambit and Volcarona. Focus Sash is the preferred item as it ensures that Froslass will always get at least one layer of Spikes up, but Mental Herb can also be used to ignore Taunt from faster leads while Heavy Duty-Boots allows Froslass to safely switch back in to block spinners such as Cyclizar and Quaquaval.

All of Froslass's teammates appreciate it spreading Spikes on the opposing field and preventing hazards from going up on theirs. After Spikes, Choice Band Chien Pao 2HKOes Iron Hands, while Shell Smash Cloyster and Belly Drum Cetitan can attempt to set up and sweep without fear of getting stopped by an opposing Focus Sash. Baxcalibur benefits from Froslass paralyzing faster threats like Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant, enabling it to outspeed and take them out, though Froslass needs an intact Focus Sash for this. Similarily, Dragon Dance Baxcalibur and Iron Defense Avalugg also benefit from the opportunities to set up against foes that have been burned by Froslass and no longer pose much of a threat to it. Avalugg can also support Froslass by switching into strong physical attacks to scout. Abomasnow's Snow Warning increases Froslass's physical bulk and makes it less wary of other attacks coming from spinners, such as Great Tusk's Knock Off.

Entry Hazard Lead (Ghost).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf.description:
Thunderbolt is stronger than Volt Switch and doesn’t force Rotom out. Nasty Plot lets Rotom bolster its offensive presence after using Trick. Will-O-Wisp punishes foes like Arboliva and Morpeko for trying to switch in on Rotom and also slows down physical attackers like Hisuian Sneasel. Tera Electric and Tera Ghost both boost Rotom’s STAB moves, but Tera Fairy helps out against Dark-types like Morpeko and Skuntank.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Utility.description:
Tera Steel offers Rotom several useful resistances, including to Stealth Rock, and makes it neutral to Dark and immune to Poison, which lets it trade with threats like Passimian and +2 Hisuian Sneasel.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Nasty Plot.description:
Discharge is weaker than Thunderbolt but has a higher chance of paralyzing foes, which can support both Rotom and slower teammates. Volt Switch lets Rotom wear down its checks while also generating momentum for its team. Substitute shuts down passive foes like Naclstack. Protect lets Rotom scout for moves and gain extra Leftovers recovery. Tera Electric and Tera Ghost both boost Rotom’s STAB moves, but Tera Fairy helps out against Dark-types like Morpeko and Skuntank.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Choice Scarf.description: Rotom stands out as a fantastic user of Choice Scarf thanks to its nearly unresisted STAB combination, high Speed tier, and three immunities. Will-O-Wisp lets Rotom cripple opposing physical sweepers such as Passimian, Medicham, and Scyther on top of Toxicroak using Sucker Punch. Trick is very useful to dismantle walls that rely on their item like Sandaconda, Eelektross, and Chansey. Tera Electric and Tera Ghost boost Rotom's STAB attacks even further with no drawbacks, though note that Tera Ghost exposes Rotom to Sandaconda's Glare. Tera Dark is useful for beating Sucker Punch Toxicroak and making Rotom a good lure for Zoroark. Thanks to Rotom's ease switching into opposing Sandaconda, teammates weak to it like Toxicroak, Lycanroc, Perrserker, and Scyther make for great partners; the latter two can even form a VoltTurn core with it. Bruxish, Medicham, and Mabosstiff help Rotom get around common special walls like Umbreon, Muk, and Chansey. Some walls that Rotom benefits from teaming up with include Umbreon, Vaporeon, and Muk thanks to their ability to take on common wallbreakers that can revenge kill Rotom such as Mabosstiff, Bruxish, and Pyroar.

Nasty Plot.description:
Rotom takes advantage of common Pokemon such as Sandaconda and Chansey that typically can't threaten it to set up. Will-O-Wisp eases setup and helps weaken checks such as Eelektross and Appletun. Tera Ghost helps Rotom get by Eelektross and Muk while retaining its Fighting immunity, whereas Tera Fairy can catch Dark-type revenge killers like Zoroark and Choice Scarf Mabosstiff off guard.

Rotom's quite customizable: Substitute / Nasty Plot / Thunderbolt or Discharge / Shadow Ball limits revenge killers and makes it easier to choose an offensive Tera type. Protect can be used instead of Will-O-Wisp to scout Choice item revenge killers like Zoroark, Passimian, and Bruxish. These options lack the same consistency as the listed set, though.

Pivots like Passimian, Scyther, and Oricorio formes are great to bring Rotom in against Sandaconda and Chansey, affording it easy setup opportunities. If Rotom is running Volt Switch, pair it with physical wallbreakers such as Bruxish and Toxicroak that can take on blanket special walls like Muk and Umbreon that commonly try to check it.

Utility.description: Rotom is an excellent bulky pivot, forcing out common staples like Scyther and Qwilfish with Volt Switch while having a positive matchup against Sandaconda, the most common Volt Switch absorber in the tier. Will-O-Wisp neuters physical attackers such as Passimian and Toxicroak and powers up Hex to chunk special walls like Eelektross and Muk. Protect racks up Leftovers recovery and burn damage while scouting moves from Choice item users such as Zoroark, Bruxish, and Passimian. Tera Electric powers up Volt Switch and removes Rotom's weaknesses to Dark and Ghost, improving its matchup against Mabosstiff, Umbreon, Haunter, and opposing Rotom. Tera Steel gives Rotom a great defensive typing with Levitate, which allows it to shrug off Sandaconda's Ground- and Rock-type coverage as well as take resisted damage from common moves like Lurantis's Leaf Storm and Lycanroc's Stone Edge. Because of Rotom's vulnerability to chip damage, it benefits greatly from reliable entry hazard removal from Pokemon such as Scyther and Lurantis. Powerful wallbreakers such as Ursaring and Medicham appreciate Rotom pivoting them safely into play. Rotom is quite vulnerable to faster attackers such as Zoroark and Bruxish, so it appreciates being paired with defensive stops to these threats, such as Muk and Umbreon. Passimian is a fantastic partner that forms a VoltTurn core with Rotom and revenge kills its offensive checks; it also appreciates Rotom weakening Sandaconda.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Choice Attacker.description:
• Rotom-H sets itself apart from other Fire-types, with its Ground immunity and Volt Switch pivoting. When compared to Rotom-W, it is also much more effective at pressuring Flutter Mane, Gholdengo and Wo-Chien.

  • Trick: Trick gives Rotom-H an excellent tool against defensive foes, such as Dondozo and Skeledirge.

  • Using a neutral nature with a Timid mint: Make sure to get a Rotom-H with a neutral nature and then use a Timid Mint on it. This way, it can't be confused by any Berries given with Trick.

Other Options

  • Discharge: While weaker than Thunderbolt, the 30% paralysis chance can be devastating for some of Rotom-H's more troublesome matchups, such as Chi-Yu. Do note though that Choice Scarf Rotom-H will have a much harder time 2HKOing Assault Vest Azumarill and certain variants of Dondozo.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low / Medium: If not running Tera Blast, Rotom-H normally wants to keep its unique typing for defensive purposes, allowing it to switch into several key threats. The most common exception to this is sets that run Tera Fairy for Dragon-type matchups.

  • Electric: Electric is an easy Tera type to recommend, as it increases damage output and removes all of Rotom-H's weaknesses.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera typing with Tera Blast makes Rotom-H much better equipped to handle normally problematic Dragon-types, such as Garchomp, Roaring Moon, and Dragapult.

  • Fire: When paired with Tera Blast, Rotom-H now has a much more reliable Fire-type STAB move than Overheat, but at the cost of retaining all of its normal weaknesses.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf lets Rotom-H outspeed normally problematic threats such as Iron Bundle.

  • Choice Specs: The extra power makes Rotom-H far more difficult to wall, with defensive Skeledirge getting 2HKOed by Thunderbolt.

Defensive Pivot.description:
• Rotom-W's defensive set might be the more known one, but Rotom-H's key resistances to Fairy-type attacks and U-turn, plus its ability to put serious pressure on Gholdengo, make it a good alternative as a bulky pivot.

  • Foul Play: Foul Play is a must-have, as otherwise, Rotom-H is extremely passive against Baxcalibur, which is likely to switch in for an Attack boost from Overheat.

  • Will-O-Wisp versus Thunder Wave: Will-O-Wisp is the preferred status move, potentially shutting down major physical threats such as Dragonite, Mimikyu, and Iron Hands. Thunder Wave is still a reasonable choice, though, stopping special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Iron Moth in their tracks.

  • Trick and Flame Orb: This one-use method of burning may seem silly, but taking away important items can be devastating against certain Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, and Rotom-H can use this to get rid of troublesome Choice items if it's taken a Trick as well. Note that Rotom-H will burn itself if it Terastallizes while holding Flame Orb, which is generally not good outside of blocking sleep or Toxic poison.

  • Using a Neutral Nature with a Bold Mint: If using Trick, it's best to run a neutral nature such as Serious and change the stat boosts with a Bold Mint. This way, Rotom-H won't get confused by any Berry it receives.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Rotom-H's defensive typing is very valuable, so Tera is normally reserved for very specific situations.

  • Steel: Tera Steel with Levitate is a sublime defensive typing, letting Rotom-H better handle huge threats like Dragonite, Garchomp, and Baxcalibur.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy is an alternative option to soak up Dragon-type attacks, and it also gives Rotom-H a better matchup against Great Tusk and Iron Hands.

  • Ghost: While this unfortunately makes Gholdengo a much bigger issue, Tera Ghost is still worth considering for making Rotom-H immune to Dragonite's Extreme Speed and Iron Valiant's Close Combat. It also lets Rotom-H switch out of trapping moves without using Volt Switch.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry is Rotom-H's ticket to staying around the longest, usually avoiding 2HKOs from powerful unboosted attacks such as Dragonite's Outrage and Iron Valiant's Close Combat.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rotom-H's typing makes it a good user of Rocky Helmet, passively punishing physical Fairy-types such as Mimikyu and Iron Valiant and making it a good response to expected uses of U-turn.

Offensive Pivot.description: 44 Defense EVs as a benchmark to avoid the 2HKO from Adamant Life Orb Mamoswine whilst maintaining speed.

Physically Defensive (Electric).description:
Rotom-W is the premier physical wall for Electric teams due to Levitate and its bulk, which make it a great help in the Ground matchup, its ability to spread burns, and its resistance to Ice and Water, which is great against Mamoswine. Will-O-Wisp is an excellent move for significantly weakening physical threats such as Barraskewda, Chien-Pao, Great Tusk, and Kingambit. Hydro Pump threatens Ground-type Pokemon that Electric teams would otherwise struggle against, such as Great Tusk, Gliscor, and Mamoswine. Volt Switch allows Rotom-W's more threatening wallbreaking teammates to come in more easily. Foul Play enables Rotom-W to hit Baxcalibur, which cannot be burned, Dragonite, and physically oriented Dragapult. It also prevents Rotom-W from becoming setup fodder. Protect is a solid option to give Rotom-W an extra turn to recover some HP, inflict more burn damage on foes, and potentially scout what set the opponent may be running, which is especially valuable versus Choice-locked enemies such as Chien-Pao and Meowscarada. The given EV spread maximizes Rotom-W's physical bulk while also allowing it to outspeed and burn Jolly Azumarill.

Assault Vest Magnezone forms a nice defensive core with Rotom-W, where Magnezone is able to act as a special wall, while Rotom-W is able to act as a physical wall, as well as switch in on Ground-type attacks that would otherwise make quick work of Magnezone. Magnezone can also switch into attacks from Pokemon like Hatterene, Gholdengo, and Flutter Mane and Toxic from the likes of Amoonguss, Mandibuzz, and Toxapex, as well as forming a nice Volt Switch pivot core. Iron Hands is another great teammate for Rotom-W. Not only is Iron Hands able to come in for free after a Volt Switch from Rotom-W, but Rotom-W is also able to burn opposing Pokemon to bolster Iron Hands's Longevity. Iron Hands is also capable of taking care of Meowscarada, Hisuian Goodra, and Ogerpon-W. Defensive Zapdos is able to make quick work of pesky Grass-type Pokemon that stop Rotom-W in its tracks, such as Ogerpon-H, Ogerpon-W, Amoonguss, and Sinistcha. Sandy Shocks is the best entry hazard setter for Electric teams, and it pairs nicely with Rotom-W, which can force uncomfortable switches thanks to the looming threat of Will-O-Wisp. The revolving door of Volt Switches can force a lot of damage on opposing teams, thus making games easier to close out. Thundurus-T's array of coverage makes it a great teammate for Rotom-W. Thundurus-T can use Grass Knot to deal with Pokemon such as Quagsire and Gastrodon, as well as Psychic to deal with Pokemon like Amoonguss and Clodsire. Pawmot can use Seed Bomb to threaten Quagsire, Gastrodon, and opposing Rotom-W while also hitting Hydreigon, Baxcalibur and Ursaluna-B with STAB Close Combat. Regieleki can use its blistering Speed tier to take care of Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant, while also using Rapid Spin to remove Stealth Rock to keep Rotom-W alive for a longer period of time.

Nasty Plot (Electric).description:
Rotom-W is a great Nasty Plot sweeper for Electric teams due to Levitate and its bulk, which lets it greatly ease the Ground matchup. Stored Power deals with Unaware and Water Absorb users such as Quagsire and Clodsire, letting it threaten the entirety of Ground teams in conjunction with Hydro Pump. Substitute lets it avoid status and take advantage of passive Pokemon such as Klefki and Toxapex, eases prediction, and forces its checks such as Greninja and Ting-Lu to take damage. The given EV spread prevents Rotom-W's Substitute from breaking to Clodsire's Poison Jab while outspeeding threats such as Gholdengo and Kleavor.

Teammates such as Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks and Iron Hands love Rotom-W's ability to deal with or wear down bulky Pokemon such as Clodsire and Gastrodon, allowing them to clean up types like Poison and Water late-game. In return, Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks deals with fast threats such as Choice Specs Greninja, Flutter Mane, and Scovillain, while Iron Hands pressures matchups such as Dark and Dragon due to its sheer bulk and coverage in Ice Punch. Pawmot can revive Rotom-W with Revival Blessing, which allows it to take more risks. Additionally, Pawmot has good coverage moves in Seed Bomb and Ice Punch, which lets it break down types such as Water, Flying, and Ground alongside Rotom-W. Choice Specs Kilowattrel deals with fast threats such as Choice Specs Iron Valiant, Choice Specs Greninja, and Volcarona, removes Grass-types like Amoonguss and Breloom, and pivots Rotom-W in with Volt Switch or U-turn. Assault Vest users such as Magnezone and Eelektross deal with special attackers such as Flutter Mane, Hatterene, and Greninja for Rotom-W. They also tend to invite in passive Pokemon, which provides Rotom-W with more setup opportunities.

Nasty Plot (Water).description:
Outspeeds Adamant Scizor, 144 HP alongside 112 Def lets its Substitute not be broken by Clodsire's Poison Jab.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Other Options

Electric

Thunder Wave is a nice option to slow down enemies and give Pokemon like Zapdos and Iron Hands an easier time taking them down. 192 HP / 108 Def / 208 Spe with a Bold nature is an alternative spread, outspeeding Choice Band Dragonite, which can be problematic for Electric teams. 248 HP / 180 Def / 68 SpD / 12 Spe with a Calm nature gets the jump on uninvested Great Tusk, avoids the 2HKO from Sheer Force Life Orb Landorus's Psychic, and allows Rotom-W to switch into mixed Iron Valiant and Greninja in a pinch. This spread also leaves Rotom-W capable of surviving a Blood Moon from Ursaluna-B.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Offensive.description:
• Rotom-W's Speed access to Volt Switch and great typing make it an excellent pivot and revenge killer.

  • Trick and Neutral Natures: If using a Choice item, Trick is seriously worth considering for its ability to cripple defensive Pokemon such as Garganacl and Dondozo. Make sure Rotom-W is a neutral nature that has had a Timid Mint used on it. This way, Rotom-W can eat any Berry without getting confused.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Rotom-W's excellent typing means its fully functional without Terastallizing, but thanks to Levitate, it's still a powerful user of it.

  • Fairy: When combined with Tera Blast, a Fairy Tera type lets Rotom-W take on Chien-Pao Dragon-types such as Dragapult and Roaring Moon far more effectively.

  • Electric: Not only does the damage boost from Tera Electric come in handy, but it also removes any weaknesses Rotom-W has.

  • Ghost: Terastallizing back to its Ghost-type roots gives Rotom-W a vast array of immunities, helping against Dragonite and Great Tusk in particular. It also makes Shadow Ball viable for picking off Ghost-types with Choice Scarf.

Items

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs tends to be safer to Trick than Choice Scarf, and it gives a big power boost.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf lets Rotom-W outspeed major threats such as Iron Bundle, Chi-Yu, and Chien-Pao.

  • Assault Vest: Increasing Rotom-W's special bulk gives it a far better matchup against foes like Flutter Mane, Chi-Yu, Iron Bundle, and Gholdengo.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with Modest: This spread sacrifices Rotom-W's revenge killing potential, but, in exchange, it makes it a better pivot, and the better bulk makes Rotom-W more suited to finding the right time to cripple a wall with Trick.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Maximizing Rotom-W's Special Attack is part of what makes it an effective revenge killer if using a Choice Scarf.

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 108 SpA / 140 SpD / 4 Spe with Calm: This spread is meant for Assault Vest, letting Rotom-W avoid a 3HKO from Modest Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry.

Defensive Pivot.description:
• Levitate and excellent status moves make Rotom-W a clean choice for a bulky pivot!

  • Foul Play: Foul Play is essential for hitting Baxcalibur hard, since it's immunity to burns would otherwise let it set up on Rotom-W.

  • Will-O-Wisp versus Thunder Wave: Will-O-Wisp's ability to cripple top-tier physically offensive threats such as Dragonite, Chien-Pao, and Scizor as well as punish the otherwise problematic Iron Hands makes it the best support option. However, Thunder Wave does provide additional insurance against Baxcalibur and punishes special attackers such as Flutter Mane.

  • Hydro Pump: Hydro Pump gives Rotom-W offensive presence against foes that don't care about the rest of the moveset, like Garganacl, Chi-Yu, Volcarona, and Skeledirge.

Other Options

  • Discharge: Giving Rotom-W an Electric STAB attack to better deal with Flying-types like Corviknight and Tera Flying Roaring Moon is useful, but it can be tricky to fit into the set.

  • Hex: If using Tera Ghost, Hex gives Rotom-W a much fiercer offensive kick than usual after inflicting status.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Defensive Rotom-W works fine without Terastallizing, but some Tera types do make it harder to break through.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Rotom-W an incredible defensive typing, vastly improving its matchups against Pokemon that rely on Ground-type coverage such as Dragonite, Baxcalibur, and Garchomp. It also provides a useful Freeze-Dry resistance against Iron Bundle.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy guards against fearsome powerful Dark, Dragon, and Fighting attacks that Rotom-W can have trouble handling and lets it use Tera Blast to hit Dragonite and Chien-Pao hard.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost offers Rotom-W a vast array of immunities with Levitate, enabling it to defeat certain Dragonite sets and do much better against Iron Hands and Iron Valiant when Rotom-W lacks Will-O-Wisp. Being a Ghost-type also prevents Rotom-W from getting trapped, letting it escape faster trappers without Volt Switch.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry will turn many powerful, unboosted attacks such as Jolly Life Orb Chien-Pao's Crunch, Dragonite's Outrage and Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush into 3HKOs. Just make sure to run an even HP stat so that Sitrus Berry activates with one use of Ruination.

  • Leftovers: If Sitrus Berry is already in use, Leftovers is a reasonable alternative.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet's extra chip damage can make Rotom-W a less passive pivot.

Nasty Plot.description:
• With a great typing, ability, and good bulk, Rotom-W makes for an effective user of Nasty Plot.

  • Fairy Tera Blast: This move is essential for getting past Dragon-types like Dragapult and Roaring Moon. Even when not Terastallized, it's a decent coverage move.

  • Hydro Pump versus Substitute: Hydro Pump is by far Rotom-W's strongest STAB, but it can be worth sacrificing for Substitute, which lets Rotom-W effectively defeat most Garganacl and defensive Dondozo.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While this Rotom-W can sweep on its own, Terastallization can prevent revenge kills from the likes of Iron Bundle.
  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Rotom-W can turn the tables on its Dragon-type adversaries, as well as catch Crunch Chien-Pao off guard.

Items

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry lets Rotom-W easily set up on Hippowdon, and avoid getting put to sleep by Dondozo.

  • Sitrus Berry: If Sleep isn't a big issue, Rotom-W appreciates the burst recovery Sitrus Berry provides. Make sure to run an even HP stat so it activates after Rotom-W gets hit by Ruination once.

  • Covert Cloak: If using Hydro Pump, this is Rotom-W's best way around Garganacl.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe: Maximizing Speed with a Timid nature gives Rotom-W the jump on Gholdengo. If Gholdengo isn't an issue, a Modest nature will still outspeed Jolly Breloom.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with Modest: Rotom-W's good bulk can be maximized instead of outspeeding Breloom; this spread avoids the 2HKO from Timid Gholdengo's Shadow Ball.

  • 244 HP / 180 Def / 84 SpA with Bold: This Sitrus Berry optimized spread avoids a 2HKO from Jolly Life Orb Chien-Pao and Timid Flutter Mane.

Defensive Pivot.description: Rotom-W is an excellent defensive pivot that can take on dangerous attackers such as Palafin, Scizor, and Iron Treads and generate momentum with Volt Switch. While Scald offers more PP and reliability, Steam Eruption OHKOes Great Tusk after Stealth Rock and improves Rotom-W's overall offensive presence. Will-O-Wisp hinders physical attackers more reliably than Scald. Alternatively, Apple Acid breaks down defensive Pokemon such as Garganacl, while Haze neutralizes slow setup sweepers such as Scizor and Freeze-Dry hits Dragon-types like Dragonite and Garchomp super effectively. Roost provides consistent recovery, while Strength Sap makes Rotom-W more effective against physical attackers such as Great Tusk, but leaves it unable to recover against Gholdengo. The given Speed EVs allow Rotom-W to outspeed uninvested Great Tusk, but more Speed can be run to handle certain threats; 224 Speed outspeeds Palafin, while 240 Speed with a Timid nature outpaces Gholdengo. Tera Steel allows Rotom-W to more easily pivot into Toxapex and take on Dragon-types such as Garchomp. Alternatively, Tera Electric strengthens Volt Switch and makes Rotom-W less vulnerable to Salt Cure. Rotom-W appreciates partners that can pivot such as Ting-Lu, Slither Wing, and Corviknight. Physical walls like Garganacl and Skeledirge after Terastallizing can take on many of the physical attackers that Rotom-W cannot handle. Powerful offensive Pokemon such as Iron Valiant, and Iron Treads appreciate Rotom-W's ability to pivot them into battle.

Bulky Pivot (Electric).description: With its access to Levitate, Rotom-W is nearly mandatory on all Electric teams. Its Ground immunity and Water-type resistance make Pokemon like Mega Swampert unable to bother it; it also has access to Hydro Pump to hit annoying Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Hippowdon. Rotom-W is also a really good blanket check to Ice- and Fire-types like Mamoswine, Victini, and Galarian Darmanitan. Volt Switch provides great momentum, which is needed in hyper offense teams. In addition to providing momentum, Rotom-W has access to Will-O-Wisp and Toxic, crippling foes such as Mega Garchomp and Mimikyu with Will-O-Wisp, while Toxic punishes switch-ins such as Gastrodon and Kyurem. Defog lets Rotom-W compress roles, freeing up Zapdos to run Choice Specs, while Rotom-W prevents hazards from hurting teammates. Pain Split is another option, as it massively improves Rotom-W's longevity; however, this requires Zapdos to run Defog. The 44 invested Speed EVs ensure Rotom-W outspeeds Jolly Azumarill so that it can punish Azumarill for setting up Belly Drum with Will-O-Wisp or Volt Switch. Zapdos covers Rotom-W's weakness to Grass-types with access to Hurricane and Heat Wave, being able to OHKO the likes of Mega Venusaur and Ferrothorn, respectively, while also being immune to Mold Breaker Excadrill's Earthquake. Regieleki can be used as a Rapid Spinner, removing pressure from Rotom-W to function as the only hazard removal while also luring in Ground-types that Rotom-W can punish such as Iron Treads or Great Tusk. With access to Taunt and having an amazing Speed tier, Zeraora can prevent hazards from coming up and allow Rotom-W to switch in freely and get off a strong Hydro Pump or gain a lot of momentum and Volt Switch into one of its offensive teammates. Zeraora also pressures Hydreigon and Gholdengo, which can use Rotom-W as setup fodder. Iron Hands provides the coverage and bulk against Pokemon like Dragon Dance Dragonite, Volcarona, and SubRoost Kyurem that Rotom-W can't deal with while also putting a lot of pressure on Normal teams, as Rotom-W can Volt Switch against Blissey into Iron Hands and force Blissey to tank a hit or switch out. Alolan Raichu gives Rotom-W's slow Volt Switch a lot of value as it is strong but frail, being able to deal with Ice-types like Baxcalibut with Focus Blast and Poison-types like Mega Venusaur and Clodsire with Psyshock. Magnezone provides a valuable Poison immunity while also checking other threats like Tapu Lele, Meowscarada, and Alolan Ninetales.

Nasty Plot.description: Nasty Plot Rotom-W provides a unique blend of defensive utility and wallbreaking potential thanks to its great combination of typing and ability in addition to its versatile move pool. Discharge has a chance to paralyze and cripple bulky switch-ins like Serperior, Tapu Lele, and Dragonite. Substitute keeps Rotom-W safe from status moves like Toxic and generates free turns for it to set up, turning many common utility Pokemon such as Landorus-T, Alomomola, and Heatran into Rotom-W's setup fodder. Volt Switch and Will-O-Wisp can be used as an alternative combination, the former helping Rotom-W keep up the momentum and the latter helping to cripple threats such as Dragonite and Garchomp. However, this combination is less effective for wallbreaking because it makes Rotom-W vulnerable to status moves and forces it to switch out if it needs to use its Electric-type STAB move, losing the boost from Nasty Plot. Tera Ghost combined with Levitate counters several popular Ground-type threats like Ursaluna, Sword Dance Gliscor, and Great Tusk, while Tera Steel and Tera Poison complement Levitate well and let Rotom-W effectively wall utility variants of Gliscor, the former improving its matchup into Tapu Lele and the latter granting it a resistance to common Fighting-type attacks from Zamazenta, Iron Valiant, and Urshifu-R. 44 Speed EVs allow Rotom-W to outspeed uninvested Landorus-T so it can set up Substitute first and dodge Toxic, while the rest of the EVs are dumped into bulk so it can check the aforementioned physical threats better. With most Rotom-W sets being pure utility, this set can often come across as a surprise to the would-be bulky checks to it such as Clefable, Zapdos, and Galarian Slowking, and it can also disrupt the opponent's pace by setting up Substitute and boost with Nasty Plot. However, both of its STAB moves are resisted by Grass-types and Dragon-types, which means it loses to the likes of Ferrothorn and Raging Bolt even after boosting. Serperior and Kyurem especially prey on this set because they both can use it as setup fodder.

Choice Scarf.description: A Choice Scarf and a great movepool to cripple foes give Rotom-W the luxury of annoying teams with its status moves and create huge vacuums of momentum thanks to Volt Switch, letting it function as a fast pivot. Hydro Pump discourages Ground-types such as Landorus-T and Ursaluna-B from coming in and blocking Volt Switch. Trick neutralizes setup threats such as Iron Defense Garganacl as well as walls such as Toxapex and Ferrothorn, greatly assisting offensive cores in breaking through. Thunder Wave cripples offensive threats such as Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, making them much easier to revenge kill and neutering the impact they have for the remainder of the game. Slower offensive Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny and Ogerpon-W enjoy being able to outspeed and threaten said threats that would previously be an issue. However, Will-O-Wisp is another great alternative, stopping foes such as Mega Lopunny and Urshifu-R from freely breaking through teams while helping their checks such as Toxapex and Alomomola stay healthier and ease the burden of checking them continuously throughout the game. Finally, Pain Split can be used, keeping Rotom-W healthy versus bulkier teams and being a huge thorn on walls after using Trick. Entry hazard removers such as Great Tusk and Tornadus-T are also useful teammates for it, preventing Rotom-W from taking Stealth Rock chip and preserving its longevity. The given EV spread and a Timid nature maximizes its bulk and Speed, helping it be as bulky and fast as possible as effectively as possible. Tera Steel helps it sponge hits like Iron Valiant's Moonblast and Baxcalibur's Scale Shot and cripple said threats, while Tera Ghost lets Rotom-W check Sneasler and wall Great Tusk.

Choice Item.description: Rotom-W can act as a good offensive pivot and revenge killer with Choice Scarf or as a wallbreaker with Choice Specs, as its formidable typing allows it to threaten a plethora of Pokemon including Ground-types such as Iron Treads, Landorus-T, and Garchomp with its Water-type moves while dealing with Desolate Land users such as Heatran, Skeledirge, and Ceruledge with its Electric-type moves. Hadron Engine boosts Rotom-W's Special Attack and Electric-type moves, while Primordial Sea provides an immunity to Fire-type moves and makes Thunder perfectly accurate. Will-O-Wisp and Trick provide good utility and cripple switch-ins such as Garchomp and Hisuian Goodra for teammates by burning them or removing their Assault Vest. However, Rotom-W can get worn out quickly due to entry hazards, so hazard removal options such as Iron Treads and Corviknight are good teammates. These two also provide slow pivoting support to Rotom-W. Similarly, hazard setters such as Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire are good teammates, as Rotom-W can take advantage of chipped foes such as Garchomp and RegenVest users such as Meloetta, Goodra, and Hisuian Goodra. Rotom-W struggles a lot against specially defensive walls such as Goodra, Meloetta, and Hisuian Goodra, so threats to them in physical attackers such as Chien-Pao, Slither Wing, and Galarian Zapdos are good teammates, with the latter two also forming a good VoltTurn core with Rotom-W to put pressure on each other's checks.

Offensive Pivot.description:
Rotom-F is a premier wallbreaker in the PU tier thanks to its decent Speed and great offensive and utility options, allowing it to become a great nuisance for most teams. Its unresisted STAB combination hits the entire tier for at least neutral damage, and its typing in conjunction with Levitate allows it to come in on weaker Pokemon such as defensive Misdreavus, Whiscash, and Gogoat. Will-O-Wisp cripples defensive Pokemon such as Tinkatuff and Perrserker, though Discharge is another option that trades Thunderbolt's damage output for a 30% paralysis chance, which can support a late-game cleaner such as Alolan Persian. Lastly, Volt Switch grants Rotom-F the ability to pivot out of unfavorable matchups such as against Carbink and Crabominable. Substitute can be utilized instead since Rotom-Frost is normally able to force out switch-ins rather efficiently due to its great offensive typing, becoming a terrifying sweeper with the addition of Terastallization. Tera Electric grants Rotom-F an even higher damage output on its main STAB move. Tera Ghost and Tera Water remove its weaknesses to Fighting and Fire-types such as Crabominable and Charizard, respectively.

Thanks to its multitude of options and offensive potential, Rotom-F functions best on offensive and balance teams that appreciate a wallbreaker that’s able to cripple special walls for a late-game cleaner. Alolan Persian and Haunter appreciate Rotom-F’s ability to break through, weaken, or cripple walls such as Gogoat and Carbink. Whiscash is a great defensive teammate for Rotom-F, able to switch in on threats such as Pyroar, Charizard, and Alolan Dugtrio. In return, Rotom-F threatens Grass-types such as Gogoat and Leafeon. Frail wallbreakers such as Basculin and Dugtrio appreciate being brought in safely through Rotom-F's Volt Switch. VoltTurn cores with Perrserker and Honchkrow should also be considered due to the great offensive synergy these Pokemon provide against common defensive cores.

Choice Scarf.description:
Choice Scarf Rotom-F's good Speed stat allows it to outspeed common threats and Choice Scarf users such as +1 Masquerain and Lycanroc-N. Its coveted BoltBeam STAB combination, fast Volt Switch, and Spikes immunity make it one of the most potent revenge killers in the tier. Trick allows Rotom-F to cripple specially defensive walls that would otherwise check it such as Tinkatuff, as well as Pokemon that rely on Heavy-Duty Boots to be effective, such as Masquerain. Rotom-F has many options for its third moveslot. Discharge can be used as an Electric-type STAB without needing to switch out while also being able to fish for paralysis, Will-O-Wisp can spread burn to physical attackers such as Gogoat and Skuntank, and Nasty Plot can allow Rotom-F to become a terrifying setup sweeper after using Trick. Rotom-F also has many viable Tera type options, with Electric being the most common, to boost its power while shedding Ice-type's annoying weaknesses to common Rock, Fire, and Fighting moves. However, Tera Ghost can be used to be immune to common Fighting-type attacks such as Carbink's Body Press and Crabominable's Close Combat, while Tera Water gives a valuable resistance to Fire-type attacks while generally being a good defensive typing.

Rotom-F's weakness to Stealth Rock can be an issue, so entry hazard control from Pokemon such as Dartrix and Quaxwell can be useful. Water- and Ground-types such as Whiscash, Gabite, and Camerupt can switch into the Fire- and Rock-types such as Charizard and Carbink that can otherwise threaten out Rotom-F. Pokemon such as Carbink and Tinkatuff can switch into foes that Rotom-F would otherwise have a hard time breaking through on its own, such as Tera Steel Dachsbun, opposing Tinkatuff, and Ampharos. Wish users such as Leafeon and Dachsbun can use Wish before switcihing to Rotom-F, allowing it to alleviate Stealth Rock damage. Dachsbun can also dissuade Fire-types from clicking Fire-type moves thanks to Well-Baked Body and can check Carbink depending on Carbink's moveset. Gogoat can check Whiscash and Raichu, allowing Rotom-F to use Volt Switch more easily while Rotom-F can pressure or cripple Gogoat's checks, such as Misdreavus. U-turn users such as Alolan Persian, Perrserker, and Flapple can form a VoltTurn combination with Rotom-F. Perrserker can also provide entry hazards with Stealth Rock, making it harder for Rotom-F's checks to switch in safely, and can threaten out Pokemon such as Carbink and Tinkatuff that would otherwise annoy Rotom-F.

Choice Specs (Grass).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Setup Sweeper.description:
Substitute allows for easier setup against passive foes like Sandaconda. Thunderbolt offers strong neutral coverage and stops Steel-types like Registeel and Alolan Sandslash from walling Mesprit. Shadow Ball is weaker than Thunderbolt but hits Bronzong super effectively. Mesprit should only use Grassy Seed if it's being paired with Thwackey.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

Offensive Setup.description:
Mesprit is an amazing setup sweeper because it has great coverage and Substitute to shield it from crippling utility moves like Toxic, Thunder Wave, and Trick. Nasty Plot allows Mesprit to be more immediately threatening, while Calm Mind lets it tank more special attacks and take advantage of Substitute and Stored Power more. Even though Dazzling Gleam is stronger than Draining Kiss, the latter is preferred for longevity, but Dazzling Gleam 2HKOes Appletun, Umbreon, and, with Tera Fairy, Hisuian Qwilfish at +2 after Stealth Rock. Stored Power lets Mesprit be even more threatening over time as you amass more boosts, but Mystical Power gives it a decent attacking move right off the bat that can help you steamroll teams by just attacking. Psyshock helps beat special walls like Articuno, Blissey, and Muk more easily as well as setup sweepers like Vivillon and Lilligant that can boost Special Defense. Tera Fairy lets Mesprit turn would-be checks in Dark-types such as Umbreon and Bombirdier into setup fodder, even letting it use Substitute on their attacks.

Mesprit is checked by special walls and Dark-types alike, so checks such as Bombirdier, Toxicroak, and Scyther pair greatly alongside it. Because faster physical attackers like Bruxish and Scyther easily threaten Mesprit out, physical walls like Lurantis, Avalugg, and Sandaconda work as amazing partners. Encore from Sableye, Cacturne, or Alolan Raichu can be quite annoying for Mesprit to deal with, as these Pokemon can lock Mesprit into a non-damaging move and then whittle it down. To combat this, Dark-types to beat them like Bombirdier and Hisuian Qwilfish are good teammates that can also cripple the opposing team with Knock Off, entry hazards, and status conditions.

Choice Scarf.description:
After donning a Choice Scarf, Mesprit becomes an excellent revenge killer that beats common threats like Samurott, Toxicroak, and Hisuian Sneasel. Psyshock 2HKOes Cryogonal while also letting Mesprit beat down special walls that love to come in on it, while Psychic can be used instead to let you take care of Pokemon like Sandaconda and Avalugg. Mystical Power with Choice Scarf is a powerful combination on Mesprit, letting it become a revenge killer that can easily spiral out of control and beat weakened teams. Trick helps with crippling walls like Blissey and Articuno that Mesprit draws in and helps it check bulky setup sweepers like Ursaring and Eelektross. Healing Wish can be used instead to help bring a teammate that has longevity issues back to full or give a setup sweeper another chance like Assault Vest Eelektross, Tauros, or Bruxish. Tera Fairy helps Mesprit revenge kill Toxicroak and Cacturne more safely, as it then resists Sucker Punch. Also, STAB Dazzling Gleam lets Mesprit muscle past Dark-types far more consistently.

Hisuian Qwilfish is the best Mesprit answer in the tier, so Pokemon like Bruxish, Froslass, and Appletun that can draw it in and force meaningful damage onto it are important teammates to have. Choice Scarf Mesprit pairs nicely with Choice Band wallbreakers like Hisuian Sneasel and Medicham because, with U-turn, Mesprit can pivot them in versus special walls and Dark-types. All of Mesprit's checks heavily rely on their items, like Blissey, Hisuian Qwilfish, and Eelektross, so Knock Off from teammates such as Samurott, Bombirdier, and Sableye especially helps it to clean late-game. Healing Wish pairs well with Life Orb Samurott, Tauros, and Choice Band Bruxish, as they tend to have poor longevity—a second chance for a setup sweepers like Eelektross and Swords Dance Hisuian Sneasel is also highly appreciated.

Thanks to Azelf's great Speed tier, expansive movepool, and extremely spammable STAB move under Psychic Surge in Expanding Force, it is one of AAA's most dangerous offensive pivots and cleaners. U-turn allows Azelf to generate momentum for its team while also providing solid damage into Pokemon like Roaring Moon and Chien-Pao as well as pivoting on RegenVest users like Swampert and Hisuian Goodra. The final two moveslots are very flexible. Knock Off debilitates switch-ins like Swampert, Manaphy, and Hisiuan Goodra. Dazzling Gleam threatens to OHKO offensive Roaring Moon and does good damage to Mandibuzz and Chien-Pao, while Flamethrower allows Azelf to still hit the latter while having coverage into Corviknight and non-Well-Baked Body Gholdengo. Trick can punish switch-ins like Hisuian Goodra and Manaphy while also debilitating other walls like Deoxys-D, but it makes Azelf a less reliable form of Speed control. Defensive pivots like Corviknight and Swampert give Azelf a Pokemon to fall back on and a slow pivot to get it in safely, while offensive pivots like Barraskewda and Roaring Moon appreciate Azelf setting up Psychic Terrain to get rid of their weakness to priority moves. Depending on its coverage, Azelf can struggle breaking through Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon like Hisuian Goodra and Mandibuzz as well as bulky special walls like Swampert and the rare Blissey, so wallbreakers like Great Tusk and Galarian Zapdos make excellent partners, as they can deal with these Pokemon, and the former also removes entry hazards Azelf can struggle against. Other offensive Pokemon that are weak to priority moves like Ogerpon-W, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao also make excellent partners with Azelf due to the Psychic Terrain it sets up.

Entry Hazard Lead.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Utility.description: Dialga-O is a useful defensive presence and pivot. Its typing gives it an excellent matchup into Miraidon, which it can threaten to OHKO with Draco Meteor, and allows it to soft check a large portion of the tier and pivot into an ally with a better matchup. Revelation Dance offers general-purpose damage and can instantly threaten Normalize users, while Doom Desire can set up a KO for an ally like Kartana. Teleport is used to underspeed opposing slow pivots like RegenVest Mega Steelix, Primal Kyogre, and Celesteela, allowing Dialga-O to bring in teammates largely without fear of utility moves like Knock Off and Mortal Spin. Fur Coat allows Dialga-O to switch in on more attackers, notably allowing it to wall Kartana, while Magic Guard makes it more effective into slower teams reliant on passive damage from entry hazards and moves like Salt Cure to gain the advantage. Adamant Crystal can't be removed with Knock Off and provides a useful damage increase, while Covert Cloak allows Fur Coat sets to navigate Salt Cure. Dialga-O's best fit is on balance teams with dangerous attackers that need as many attacking windows as possible to make progress, such as Choice Band users like Kartana. Outside of Kartana, Dialga-O has a pretty poor matchup into common physical attackers like Mega Mewtwo X and Kyurem-B, so it needs extra support from an ally like Imposter Chansey or a second Fur Coat user like Arceus-Ghost, Arceus-Poison, or Arceus-Fairy to help out. An offensive teammate like Steely Spirit Kartana enjoys the presence of Doom Desire to pick up instant KOes on targets like Fur Coat Arceus-Poison. Imposter-proof Dialga-O with something that can deny Strength Sap healing, like Chansey or a Magic Bounce user; these can also opt to use Teleport themselves to underspeed the Imposter user and gain the switch advantage against them.

Wallbreaker.description: Palkia-O's high Speed, outstanding power, and good movepool make it an excellent offensive threat and one of Ubers UU's top Pokemon. Fire Blast lets Palkia-O more easily KO certain Fire-weak Pokemon, such as Magearna and Solgaleo, though it doesn't do significantly more damage than Hydro Pump without Tera Fire. Earth Power is a perfectly accurate, albeit slightly weaker, alternative to its STAB moves against foes like Dialga and Solgaleo. Substitute helps Palkia-O take advantage of switches it forces and eases prediction against Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Thunder Wave ruins Arceus formes Palkia-O Speed ties with and faster attackers like Mewtwo and Zacian. Tera Fire lets Fire Blast OHKO foes like Kingambit and non-specially defensive Magearna and 2HKO Solgaleo in addition to making Palkia-O better at taking on Fairy-types like Zacian and Dragon-types like opposing Palkia-O and Choice Scarf Kyurem-W. However, it does give Palkia-O a Stealth Rock weakness. Tera Fairy lets Palkia-O take Dragon-type moves with no fear while also improving its matchup against Fairy-types. Tera Ground should generally be used with Earth Power to 2HKO Dialga and Solgaleo, OHKO Kingambit, and OHKO Magearna with Spikes support; it also helps Palkia-O beat opposing Dragon-types and Magearna, gives it a resistance to Stealth Rock, and gives it an immunity to Thunder Wave. Palkia-O best fits on offense and balance teams looking for a potent wallbreaker, paring nicely with sweepers like Zacian and Kingambit. Palkia-O appreciates Steel-type pivots such as Solgaleo, Magearna, and Corviknight, which switch into the foes that beat it such as Zacian and maintain momentum. Solgaleo has the added benefit of checking many other foes that outspeed Palkia-O, like Mewtwo, while Magearna can set up Spikes to help Palkia-O put foes like Kingambit and opposing Magearna into its KO range. Corviknight and other forms of entry hazard control such as Great Tusk and Mandibuzz are helpful at keeping Palkia-O healthy given its vulnerability to hazards, especially if it's running Tera Fire.

Nasty Plot Sweeper.description: Nasty Plot Palkia-O is a terrifying sweeper thanks to its brutally powerful STAB combination and good Speed. A Timid nature guarantees that Palkia-O outspeeds and threatens to OHKO almost all Arceus. Steam Eruption provides more consistent damage output and a potential burn, while Water Spout has potentially higher damage, won't miss, and can OHKO Ice Scales Arceus-Fairy after Nasty Plot and Spikes. Strength Sap is necessary to keep Dragon Energy and Water Spout's damage high as well as to allow Palkia-O greater freedom to switch in. Tera Dragon allows Dragon Energy to OHKO Dondozo and +4 Dragon Energy to OHKO Ice Scales Dialga-O, while Tera Water lets Palkia-O withstand Fairy-type attacks from users like Arceus-Fairy and Zacian. Palkia-O's best fit is on offense teams that can maximize the opportunities it gets and can easily pressure faster threats like Koraidon. Prankster and Ice Scales Chansey are complete counters for Palkia-O, as they are never threatened by its attacks and make Strength Sap worthless; as such, mixed attacking teammates like Enamorus and Triple Arrows Arceus-Ghost are highly recommended. Imposter-proof Palkia-O with a Desolate Land Arceus-Fairy or Ice Scales Chansey.

Specially Defensive (Steel).description:
Specially defensive Heatran is an invaluable part of any Steel team. It is a fantastic check to many metagame staples that Steel would greatly struggle to otherwise deal with, such as Volcarona, Corviknight, Skeledirge, Zapdos, and Iron Moth. It serves Steel teams consistently well even outside of these problem matchups due to its great natural bulk, plethora of useful resistances including a crucial immunity to Fire via Flash Fire, and utility for its team through its access to Stealth Rock and capacity to spread burns.

Lava Plume is Heatran’s primary attacking move, which not only hits neutral targets hard due to Heatran’s naturally good Special Attack but also has a 30% chance to burn foes. Fire’s nature as an attacking type that has no natural immunities means Heatran can use Lava Plume many times throughout the course of a game to generate progress with minimal risk. The burn chance of Lava Plume makes Heatran incredibly risky for foes to switch into, as physical attackers such as Great Tusk that could threaten a KO on Heatran do not want to risk the possibility of being burned and having their offensive power crippled. Furthermore, walls such as Toxapex also fear being burned, as the passive damage will affect their longevity over the course of a game. Earth Power is the only coverage necessary for Heatran, giving it the capability to easily break through foes such as Skeledirge and Iron Moth. It is notable that an EV spread including 56 Special Attack EVs will allow Heatran to OHKO offensive opposing Heatran with Earth Power. Heatran serves as an excellent setter of Stealth Rock due to its propensity to easily force switches against Pokemon such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Amoonguss. Protect rounds out Heatran’s moveset, not only giving it the chance to extend its longevity via Leftovers and accumulate burn damage on foes but also the capability to scout foes’ movesets, which can be especially useful when facing off against foes using Choice items. One should be careful when using Protect not to fall into predictable patterns and give foes the chance to set up on Heatran, however. Magma Storm can be used instead of Lava Plume to trap and eliminate foes such as Toxapex and force damage against bulky threats such as Iron Hands; the passive damage synergizes well with Protect, but Magma Storm's low PP and accuracy makes it less consistent throughout longer games. Taunt is an option that can be used place of Stealth Rock that synergizes particularly well with Magma Storm, preventing foes from using recovery moves, getting entry hazards up, or setting up on Heatran. However, a lack of Speed investment means it will have somewhat limited utility. As another option to Stealth Rock, Power Gem easily OHKOes Moltres, which walls Heatran otherwise, and prevents bulky Volcarona sets from outlasting Heatran. Alternatively, Will-O-Wisp can be used over Stealth Rock in conjunction with an investment of 40 Speed EVs to allow Heatran to outspeed and burn maximum Speed Adamant Kingambit. If desired, it is also possible to run one of the aforementioned alternative options of Taunt, Power Gem, or Will-O-Wisp instead of Protect, but this comes at the cost of significantly impacting Heatran's longevity and foregoing Protect's scouting utility.

Heatran serves as one of the three pillars of Steel’s “immunity trinity” along with Corviknight and Gholdengo; combined, these three offer immunities to Steel’s core weaknesses of Fire, Ground, and Fighting, forming an excellent defensive backbone for any Steel team. Corviknight is Heatran’s most important partner, being able to nullify Ground moves targeted at Heatran while Heatran in turn blocks Fire moves aimed at Corviknight. Furthermore, Corviknight can also threaten prominent Fighting-types in the metagame such as Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Sneasler with its STAB Brave Bird. With a physically defensive pivot set, Corviknight further synergizes with specially defensive Heatran by being able to soak up physical hits while Heatran takes special ones, having the ability to remove opposing Stealth Rock and Spikes to prevent Heatran from being worn down by entry hazards over the course of a game and providing Heatran with opportunities to switch in safely via U-turn. Bulk Up Corviknight appreciates Heatran too, as Stealth Rock and burn support can increase its sweeping potential. Gholdengo completes the immunity trinity by voiding Fighting moves aimed at Heatran. Gholdengo can further support Heatran by blocking Corrosion Toxic from Glimmora thanks to Good as Gold; this ability combined with Gholdengo's Ghost typing also lets it completely prevent the removal of Heatran's Stealth Rock, as Gholdengo blocks both Rapid Spin and Defog. With an Air Balloon, Gholdengo can block Ground-type moves and use Nasty Plot to break through walls, both of which Heatran appreciates. Alternatively, using a Choice Scarf, Gholdengo can switch into Enamorus and outspeed and OHKO it in return, and it can use Trick to cripple opposing special walls such as Toxapex and Blissey or lock sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragonite into setup moves to prevent them from exploiting Heatran. Outside of the immunity trinity, Hisuian Goodra also makes a good pairing with Heatran due to its unique Water resistance on Steel and capacity to threaten opposing Water-types such as Basculegion-F and Greninja with Thunderbolt. Hisuian Goodra can also check Hydreigon and Walking Wake, which both wall and exploit Heatran. Moreover, Hisuian Goodra can act as a switch-in to opposing Heatran and threaten it with Earthquake, and it is able to survive an Earth Power from Landorus and OHKO it in return with Ice Beam if necessary. Iron Treads can spin away hazards for Heatran without removing Heatran’s Stealth Rock, set Stealth Rock itself to free Heatran to use other moves if desired, and serve as an offensive check to Sandy Shocks with its STAB Earthquake as well as Landorus with Ice Spinner, which Heatran’s other teammates can struggle to handle. Physical sweepers such as Kingambit and Scizor are grateful for Heatran’s ability to absorb Will-O-Wisp for them, and they can clean up teams Heatran has worn down with Stealth Rock and chip damage. Klefki can complement Heatran's Stealth Rock with its own Spikes while taking advantage of Heatran's Fire immunity, which can help break down opposing teams faster as they switch around to deal with the immunity trinity. It should be noted that this is by no means an exhaustive list of potential teammates for Heatran; all Steel-type Pokemon in the metagame appreciate Heatran’s Fire immunity, and no Pokemon currently competes with Heatran in this regard.
