Knock Off support from the likes of Mega Vensaur, Clefable, and Thundurus-T is appreciated to help Hydreigon break through Pokemon like Celesteela, Tapu Fini, and Assault Vest Tangrowth. Setup sweepers like Tapu Fini and Galarian Moltres benefit from Hydreigon's longevity and ability to pressure their checks such as Mega Venusaur and Mega Tyranitar, respectively, allowing them to become wincons late-game; fast teammates such as Choice Scarf Enamorus and Keldeo also appreciate Hydreigon for this reason, with it being able to pressure their switch-ins such as Slowking and Assault Vest Tangrowth, which can open the way for them to clean late-game. Hydreigon can also easily be revenge killed by faster Pokemon such as Hawlucha, Latios, and Enamorus; Skarmory can deal with Hawlucha while providing Spikes support, and Slowking can deal with Latios and Enamorus.

Nasty Plot (Dragon).description:
Hydreigon's great stats, unresisted coverage, and useful ability let it serve as an excellent wallbreaker on Dragon teams, checking threats like Gholdengo, Iron Treads, and Toxapex. Dark Pulse targets Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Gholdengo, Gengar, and Armarouge. Flamethrower threatens Steel-types like Iron Treads, Corviknight, and Kingambit, while Earth Power aids in the Poison matchup, hitting Clodsire, Skuntank, and Toxapex. Alternatively, Flash Cannon may be used to threaten Fairy-types like Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Gardevoir behind Substitute. Substitute alongside Leftovers makes Hydreigon difficult to revenge kill and offers more setup opportunities against passive Pokemon such as Amoonguss, Klefki, and Forretress. Alternatively, Taunt prevents Ting-Lu from phazing Hydreigon with Whirlwind as well as obstructing Clodsire, Dondozo, and Gastrodon's recovery attempts. Draco Meteor is a niche option to OHKO opposing Dragon-types like Baxcalibur and Dragalge; however, Draco Meteor negates Nasty Plot boosts and requires Hydreigon to give up useful utility.

Hydreigon's ability to break past physical walls such as Quagsire, Skeledirge, and Dondozo is heavily appreciated by Baxcalibur and Dragonite. In return, Baxcalibur checks Clodsire, Dragonite, and opposing Hydreigon, while Dragonite threatens Quaquaval and Cinderace. Cyclizar sets up Shed Tail for non-Substitute Hydreigon, allowing for more setup opportunities and freeing up a moveslot for Hydreigon. Furthermore, Cyclizar removes Stealth Rock off the field with Rapid Spin, preserving Hydreigon's ability to set up. Dragapult combats Flutter Mane, Gallade, and opposing Dragon-types, while Hydreigon forces Kingambit off the field and switches into Shadow Sneak from Brambleghast and Ceruledge. Garchomp sets up entry hazards to enhance Hydreigon's wallbreaking capabilities and helps to take care of Clodsire and Volcarona. Dragalge is valued as a check to Fairy-types like Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant as well as an entry hazard setter, aiding in the Dark and Fairy matchups with Toxic Spikes.

Choice Scarf (Dragon).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Nasty Plot (Dark).description:
Due to Hydreigon's wonderful movepool, terrifying Special Attack stat, and useful ability, it's an easy-to-fit wallbreaker on Dark teams that is a huge asset in the Steel, Poison, Ground, and Water matchups. Draco Meteor provides nuclear power after a Nasty Plot, removing threats like Urshifu-R, Baxcalibur, and Great Tusk, while Dark Pulse is a great alternative due to its accuracy, good Base Power, and synergy with Flamethrower or Earth Power. Flamethrower hits Steel-types like Corviknight, Kingambit, and Iron Treads; however, Earth Power hits Hisuian Goodra, Toxapex, and Alolan Muk. Stealth Rock is appreciated to allow Ting-Lu to use Spikes while also capitalizing on the many switches Hydreigon forces. Alternatively, Substitute raises Hydreigon's potency as a wallbreaker, providing safety in front of passive Pokemon like Amoonguss, defensive Rotom-W, and Gastrodon as well as putting lots of pressure on more offensive types like Ground and opposing Dark teams.

Chien-Pao and Hydreigon form a formidable wallbreaking core due to Chien-Pao's ability to threaten Unaware Clodsire, Enamorus, and Roaring Moon. In return, Hydreigon uses Toxapex and Quagsire as setup fodder. Sableye provides a Fighting-type immunity and Will-O-Wisp support, discouraging Choice Scarf Great Tusk, Sneasler, and Quaquaval from using their STAB moves. Meowscarada and Greninja are great in the Grass and Water matchups, eliminating Quaquaval, Ice Beam Gastrodon, and Azumarill. Additionally, Meowscarada threatens Dragapult and Choice Scarf Gholdengo, while Greninja breaks (remove double space) past Unaware Clodsire. Kingambit checks Fairy-types like Hatterene and Flutter Mane while also picking off faster threats like Dragapult, Spectrier, and Barraskewda after a few Supreme Overlord boosts. In return, Kingambit values Hydreigon's ability to remove roadblocks like Great Tusk and Urshifu-R. Ting-Lu provides entry hazards and phazing with Whirlwind to wear down defensive checks, while Alolan Muk is an additional asset in the Fairy and Dragon matchup, taking on Enamorus, Iron Valiant, and Walking Wake. Choice Scarf Hoopa-U threatens Chien-Pao, Clodsire, and hinders Hydreigon's checks with Trick while appreciating Alolan Muk's removal in return.

vgc2023.overview:
• Hydreigon is a strong contender for the title of best Pokemon in the Series 1 metagame thanks to its diverse movepool and high damage output.

  • Terastallization proves to be a boon for Hydreigon, as it can get rid of its ever-burdening Fairy-type weakness by changing to much more beneficial types such as Steel.

  • Hydreigon has a good offensive typing, leaving few Pokemon able to switch in safely. It is one of the best checks to Gholdengo and also pairs well with it, forming a fundamentally powerful core when used with Tailwind support from Murkrow. Armarouge and Garchomp also synergize well with Hydreigon, covering for Steel-types, which it may not be able to damage effectively depending on its Tera type. Hydreigon can, however, struggle against damage reduction such as Snarl and Light Screen, with the latter coming especially from Grimmsnarl, which can easily take its STAB moves and OHKO it back with Spirit Break if Hydreigon is not Terastallized. Repeated usage of Draco Meteor can also make Hydreigon deal unimpressive amounts of damage, but this can be counteracted with Haze from Murkrow, allowing it to continue dealing devastating damage.

Life Orb.description:
• Tailwind allows Hydreigon to support allies such as Armarouge and Sylveon, forming strong offensive combinations. The third moveslot depends on Hydreigon's Tera Type and can be changed accordingly. Protect is utilized on teams with a different primary Tailwind setter such as Murkrow, but Hydreigon can still be kept as a secondary setter.

  • Life Orb lets Hydreigon dish out consistent damage without the need to set up.

  • The Steel Tera type synergizes wonderfully with Hydreigon's original typing and Levitate, allowing it to resist a plethora of common types such as Fairy, Ground, and, Dragon. This makes Hydreigon one of the best checks to Tera Ground Garchomp, which cannot hit Hydreigon with Earthquake and deals minimal damage to it with Dragon Claw and Rock Slide. A Fire Tera type allows Hydreigon to beat opposing Tera Steel Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Salamence. The Poison Tera type lets Hydreigon maintain the resistance to Fairy that Steel and Fire possess while also gaining an additional resistance to Fighting, crucial against the likes of Annihilape, Hariyama, and Close Combat Lycanroc. It is only left with Psychic as a relevant weakness, synergizing well with its original Dark typing. Tera Blast should be used instead of Flash Cannon for coverage against Fairy-types on sets that use Tera Poison.

Scope Lens.description:
• Heat Wave is a great coverage move to deal with Steel-types that can withstand Draco Meteor such as Gholdengo and Kingambit.

  • Scope Lens takes advantage of the +2 critical hit rate from Focus Energy, allowing Hydreigon to always critical hit, especially through Draco Meteor Special Attack drops and other means of damage reduction such as Light Screen.

  • A Timid nature lets Hydreigon speed tie other Hydreigon as the raw power it gains from having the ability to always critical hit is enough. A Modest nature can, however, be utilized on teams with good methods of speed control such as Tailwind from Murkrow.

  • The Fire Tera type powers up Hydreigon's Heat Wave, letting it OHKO Kingambit on a critical hit and nearly OHKO Amoonguss, and gives Hydreigon a Fairy resistance.

Assault Vest.description:
• Snarl is an immensely useful tool for reducing the damage dealt by strong special attackers such as Gholdengo, Psychic Terrain-boosted Expanding Force Armarouge, and opposing Hydreigon.

  • Flash Cannon in combination with the Steel Tera type is used as a way to keep Fairy-types such as Grimmsnarl and Sylveon in check. Heat Wave is used as coverage to hit opposing Steel-types, but Dark Pulse is usually preferred over it for its ability to deal consistent damage to most other types overall.

  • Assault Vest makes Hydreigon a very potent sponge against special moves when combined with its ability to use Snarl for further reduction, especially for its teammates. Its high Special Attack lets it deal respectable damage despite running a more support-oriented set.

  • The Speed EVs allow Hydreigon to outrun maximum Speed Timid Gholdengo, and as a result, Armarouge of all Speed investments, allowing it to immediately use Snarl and lower their damage output. The Special Attack EVs let it always 2HKO maximum HP and 4 Special Defense Armarouge and uninvested Gholdengo with Dark Pulse. The Special Defense EVs make -1 Modest maximum Special Attack Choice Specs Gholdengo's Shadow Ball only a possible 5HKO on Tera Steel Hydreigon, while Make It Rain rocks a petty chance to even 7HKO. -1 Armarouge Aura Sphere also only has about a 50% chance to 4HKO Hydreigon. Note that Hydreigon should not be Terastallized against Armarouge to maintain the Fire resistance and Psychic immunity, as it is still weak to Aura Sphere when Terastallized. Opposing Tera Fire Hydreigon never OHKOes Tera Steel Hydreigon with Life Orb Heat Wave when spread damage is accounted for, allowing Hydreigon to retaliate with Snarl. The physical bulk allows Hydreigon to never be 2HKOed by maximum Attack Adamant Annihilape Drain Punch and Jolly maximum Attack Garchomp Brick Break.

  • Steel Tera type is the best defensive type for Hydreigon, allowing it to hard check most special attackers such as Gholdengo and Sylveon while holding its own against Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl. Poison Tera type, on the other hand, lets Hydreigon maintain the Fairy resistance that Steel gives it while also awarding it an additional resistance to Fighting in the face of Pokemon such as Annihilape and Hariyama. Tera Blast should be used instead of Flash Cannon to hit Fairy-types on Tera Poison sets.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

HARBINGER (Choice Item).description:
• With access to the incredible Levitate, Hydreigon sets itself apart from Roaring Moon as a dangerous offensive force that effectively utilizes Terastallization.

  • Flash Cannon: This is Hydreigon's best option to hit Fairy-types such as Mimikyu and Flutter Mane.

  • Flamethrower versus Fire Blast: Flamethrower is usually good enough for hitting Steel-types such as Scizor and otherwise decent Dark Pulse switch-ins like Meowscarada. On the other hand, Choice Specs Fire Blast is capable of OHKOing bulky Gholdengo and Corviknight.

Items

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs Hydreigon is a nuclear wallbreaker that can pummel unsuspecting teams.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf patches up Hydreigon's somewhat lackluster Speed, allowing it to threaten a wider portion of the metagame with its high-powered attacks.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Hydreigon has a lot of competition from other Dragon-types, as well as having to face down strong Dark-resists like Chien-Pao. Terastallization is it's best way to flip these matchups when absolutely necessary.

  • Steel: Tera Steel can be used to get around the many Dragon and Fairy-types that try to revenge kill Hydreigon, though it is still vulnerable to Mach Punch from Breloom.

  • Poison: Tera Poison has great synergy with Hydreigon's former typing, making it do especially well against Great Tusk.

  • Fire: Tera Fire will grant Hydreigon a resistance to Fairy-types while removing its weakness to Fighting-types and powering up Flamethrower or Fire Blast. However, unlike Tera Steel it does not grant a resistance to Dragon, and it also gives Hydreigon a few new weaknesses.

  • Dark: Tera Dark boosts Dark Pulse into an absurdly powerful weapon, and when coupled with its flinch rate, Tera Dark Hydreigon can potentially muscle its way out of otherwise hopeless situations.

Versatile Attacker.description:
• Hydreigon's useful support movepool can add quite a bit of unpredictability to its offensive potential.

  • Note that this Hydreigon is fully capable of running three attacking moves with one support move.

  • Nasty Plot: Nasty Plot makes Hydreigon a surprisingly dangerous sweeper against slower teams and pairs particularly well with Substitute.

  • Substitute: Substitute is excellent for scouting Terastallization and punishes common status users such as Yawn Dondozo as well as Leech Seed Wo-Chien.

  • Taunt: Taunt can stop setup from defensive foes such as Hippowdon, Wo-Chien and Clodsire, and is especially dangerous if they lack coverage to hit back effectively.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Hydreigon sets of this kind normally prey on bulkier targets, using its support tools to overwhelm them. However, Hydreigon will likely still have to deal with its Dragon-type brethren, so Terastallization is sometimes necessary.

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type has fantastic synergy with Levitate, helping Hydreigon against Dragon- and Fairy-types without the dreaded Ground weakness.

  • Poison: With a Poison Tera type, Hydreigon can do well against Fairy-types without fear of powerful Fighting-type attacks. Thanks to Levitate, it also matches up well into Great Tusk.

  • Fire: When using Flamethrower, a Fire Tera type is handy for both the Fairy resistance and a better matchup against Kingambit.

Items

  • Leftovers: If using Substitute, Leftovers's extra bit of recovery helps reduce its risk.

  • Life Orb: A simple power boost still comes in handy, even if only using two attacks.

  • Black Glasses: If a teammate is already using Life Orb, Black Glasses is a good compromise.

Stealth Rock Support.description:
• Hydreigon's new access to Stealth Rock makes it a surprisingly effective offensive support Pokemon.

  • Taunt: Taunt effectively shuts down common support leads like Ting-Lu, Hippowdon, and Clodsire.

  • Thunder Wave: This is a powerful deterrent against offensive foes and can even stop sweepers in emergency situations when used with Focus Sash.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low / Medium: If running Focus Sash, Terastallization is generally not needed. For other items, Terastallization is sometimes more necessary.

  • Steel: Thanks to Levitate, a Steel Tera type is an incredible defensive typing for Hydreigon, giving it an advantage over Fairy- and Dragon-types.

  • Poison: Tera Poison is a good alternative to Steel, with fewer resistances but an important Fighting-type resistance for targets like Great Tusk and Iron Hands.

  • Fire: Fire-type Hydreigon is better against Kingambit and Fairy-types.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash makes setting up Stealth Rock a much easier task against offensive teams. Be warned that it doesn't stop Dragapult's Dragon Darts.

  • Leftovers: If using Taunt, Leftovers is the best choice for giving Hydreigon longevity against defensive foes such as Corviknight.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb lets Hydreigon be played more offensively if setting Stealth Rock isn't needed.

  • Dark Glasses: Dark Glasses work if a teammate is using Life Orb.

Nasty Plot (Dark).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Specs.description: Hydreigon carves a niche in National Dex courtesy of its powerful Choice Specs-boosted attacks and nearly unresisted STAB combo. Additionally, its useful typing allows it to pivot into common defensive Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Gholdengo, giving it opportunities of entry. Fire Blast complements Dark Pulse and Draco Meteor very well, hitting Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Kingambit. Flash Cannon allows Hydreigon to hit Fairy-types that would otherwise pivot into it, such as Mega Diancie and Iron Valiant, as well as hitting Mega Tyranitar moderately hard. U-turn is an alternative over the latter two moves that provides a more risk-free option to exploit Hydreigon's checks, giving Pokemon like Zamazenta and Mega Lopunny free entry. Tera Dark further boosts Hydreigon’s power, allowing its Dark Pulse to reliably 2HKO the likes of Toxapex and Heatran. Hydreigon fits best on bulky offense and offense teams that have reliable options to switch it in safely. Hydreigon pairs very well with pivots such as Mega Lopunny, Tornadus-T, and Landorus-T, as they can switch it in against opposing defensive Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Rotom-W. Assault Vest Tornadus-T pairs particularly well with Hydreigon, as it notably checks Dragapult, as well as providing insurance against foes such as Iron Valiant. Pokemon that can exploit common switch-ins to Hydreigon such as Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit pair well with Hydreigon, meaning the likes of Great Tusk and Zamazenta are good partners. Similarly, Pokemon that can lure or weaken the aforementioned switchins, such as Gholdengo and Dragapult, pair well with Hydreigon.

Fire Spin.description: With its solid natural bulk and good defensive typing in conjunction with Levitate, Hydreigon serves as a trapper that checks and eliminates Pokemon like Skeledirge and Mega Charizard Y lacking Focus Blast. Fire Spin traps and accumulates chip on a myriad of defensive Pokemon, such as Toxapex, Ting-Lu, Gastrodon, and Clodsire. Earth Power, in combination with Fire Spin, increases the damage that the aforementioned Pokemon take while also threatening Heatran. Alternatively, Dark Pulse can be used as a solid STAB move to hit airborne Pokemon such as Gliscor. Taunt prevents passive walls such as Toxapex and Gastrodon from healing while also preventing Hydreigon from being crippled by status from the aforementioned Pokemon as well. Tera Poison gives Hydreigon a Toxic immunity and a favorable defensive typing, allowing it to safely trap Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Iron Valiant. Offensive teammates like Mega Lopunny, Volcarona, and Dragapult appreciate Hydreigon trapping and removing walls like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu. Entry hazard setters such as Ferrothorn, Landorus-T, and Gastrodon support Hydreigon, as they heavily chip and pressure switch-ins like Kingambit in combination with Hydreigon's Fire Spin. Hydreigon is easily forced out by Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Mega Diancie, and Iron Valiant. As such, Pokemon that can handle the aforementioned threats such as Gholdengo, Clodsire, and Toxapex make great teammates for it.

The Clicker (Choice Specs).description: Utilizing its high Special Attack, Beads of Ruin, powerful STAB attacks, and solid coverage options, Hydreigon is a formidable wallbreaker that can tear down the tier’s most robust special walls like Hisuian Goodra, Meloetta, and Blissey over the course of a game. Focus Blast is a powerful option to muscle past Hisuian Goodra, Blissey and Zamazenta-C. U-turn allows Hydreigon to provide additional utility as a pivot, ease prediction, and maintain momentum against switch-ins like Blissey and Diancie, while Flash Cannon serves as an option to handle the Fairy-type switch-ins like Enamorus-T and Diancie that Hydreigon would otherwise struggle to beat. Hydreigon has unimpressive Speed and can be revenge killed quite easily by threats such as Slither Wing, Chien-Pao, and Pixilate Scream Tail, so walls that can handle these like RegenVest users, Corviknight, and Quaquaval are appreciated, with the latter two being able to pivot Hydreigon in. Powerful physical wallbreakers like Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing are appreciated, forming a potent VoltTurn core with Hydreigon if it opts for U-turn, handling the special walls that Hydreigon can struggle against, and pivoting in Hydreigon to break the physical walls they may struggle with.

Chilan Berry.description:
• Chilan Berry helps Volcarona defeat Chien-Pao, non-Power Gem Meowscarada, and Slaking.
  • Will-O-Wisp helps Volcarona defeat Avalugg and non-Stone Edge Ting-Lu.
  • Substitute prevents Soak and Fake Tears from Bellibolt and Sylveon, respectively, as well as beating Choice Band Donphan if it uses Head Smash.
  • Morning Sun allows Volcarona to defeat specially defensive Sylveon.
  • Overheat allows Volcarona to defeat Sylveon as well as Steel-types like Corviknight, Magnezone, and Kingambit.
  • The HP and Defense EVs let Volcarona survive Throat Chop from Choice Band Chien-Pao, while the Speed EVs let it outspeed Adamant Annihilape.
  • Will-O-Wisp + Morning Sun lets Volcarona defeat Iron Hands, while Will-O-Wisp + Overheat lets it beat Avalugg.
  • Against Sylveon, Volcarona should use Quiver Dance once, then use Overheat twice.
  • Against Slaking, Volcarona should Quiver Dance twice, then use Bug Buzz.

Passho Berry.description:
• Passho Berry helps Volcarona defeat Iron Bundle.
  • Will-O-Wisp allows Volcarona to defeat Avalugg, non-Stone Edge Ting-Lu, and non-Head Smash Donphan.
  • Substitute prevents Soak and Fake Tears from Bellibolt and Sylveon, respectively, as well as beating Choice Band Donphan if it uses Head Smash.
  • Morning Sun allows Volcarona to defeat specially defensive Sylveon and Iron Hands in combination with Will-O-Wisp.
  • Overheat OHKOes Iron Bundle. It also defeats Steel-types like Corviknight, Magnezone, and Kingambit, as well as Sylveon and Avalugg in combination with Will-O-Wisp.
  • The EVs allow Volcarona to survive Hydro Pump from Modest Choice Specs Iron Bundle and Psyshock from Choice Specs Sylveon twice. The Speed EVs outspeed maximum Speed Corviknight, and the remaining EVs are put in Special Attack.
  • Against Espathra, Volcarona should use Bug Buzz turn 1, then Quiver Dance, then Bug Buzz again to secure the win.
  • Against Choice Specs Sylveon, Volcarona should use Quiver Dance once, then Overheat twice.
  • Against Kingambit and Magnezone, Volcarona should use Bug Buzz and then Overheat to avoid losing to Metal Burst and Mirror Coat.
  • Be aware of Choice Specs Meowscarada, as Power Gem can OHKO Volcarona.

The Original Moth (Bug).description:
Volcarona performs as a solid late-game setup sweeper for Bug teams, threatening to sweep any unprepared team thanks to Quiver Dance. Flamethrower is the go-to STAB move for Volcarona, as it hits Steel- and Ice-types such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Chien-Pao. Optionally, Fiery Dance can be used over Flamethrower, which has an additional effect of boosting Special Attack, but Flamethrower is preferred due to a higher Base Power. Psychic primarily covers Poison-types like Toxapex, Glimmora, and Iron Moth, but it also hits Fighting-types such as Quaquaval and Great Tusk. Morning Sun provides reliable recovery, which allows Volcarona to further set up and threaten to sweep. Alternatively, Giga Drain targets Water- and Ground-type Pokemon such as Quagsire, Greninja, and Gastrodon. Bug Buzz can be used over Psychic to hit Dark- and Psychic-types such as Hydreigon, Ting-Lu, and Espathra. Heavy-Duty Boots keeps Volcarona safe from entry hazards, while Flame Body debilitates physical attackers. A Timid nature allows Volcarona to outspeed Choice Scarf Flamigo after a single Quiver Dance boost.

Volcarona and Scizor make a great pair, as Scizor—thanks to its Steel-typing—helps Volcarona by switching into Toxic from Clodsire, and it deals with Rock-types such as Tyranitar and Lycanroc thanks to Bullet Punch. Volcarona appreciates entry hazard support from Forretress, which pressures and wears down the opposing team. Choice Scarf Heracross helps against Steel- and Dark-types—such as Iron Treads and Kingambit—and Flying-types—like Kilowattrel—with Close Combat and Stone Edge, respectively; in return, Volcarona helps deal with Corviknight, which Heracross struggles to break. Slither Wing threatens Flying- and Water-types such as Iron Jugulis, Pelipper, and Greninja with Wild Charge, and threatens Corviknight with Flare Blitz. It can safely pivot in Volcarona, enabling its sweep. Both Slither Wing and Heracross pressure specially defensive walls such as Clodsire and Blissey, which Volcarona struggles to break. Lokix helps against Ghost-, Psychic- and Dark-types like Skeledirge, Espathra, Armarouge, Meowscarada, and Greninja thanks to First Impression, Throat Chop, and Sucker Punch. Volcarona appreciates Sticky Web support from Masquerain or Spidops to deal with Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Iron Treads and Iron Moth.

Bulky Quiver Dance (Bug).description: These are the sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Quiver Dance (Fire).description:
A potent offensive presence, Volcarona's access to Quiver Dance provides the backbone to its sweeping capabilities. Bug Buzz is Volcarona's main attacking option and can be combined with Swarm to increase damage as Volcarona loses HP while setting up, allowing Volcarona to OHKO checks like offensive Garchomp after one Quiver Dance. Psychic is essential, as it allows Volcarona to hit one of Fire's strongest checks, Toxapex, but also super effectively damages Poison-types and Fighting-types such as Glimmora and Quaquaval. The last slot is interchangeable, though generally Flamethrower is preferred as a STAB move that can also take advantage of sun support on Fire teams and is essential to for the Flying matchup, allowing it to hit Corviknight and Kilowattrel. Giga Drain can be used to give Volcarona a better chance of breaking through Water and Ground teams and give it a recovery option. Similarly, Morning Sun gives Volcarona more setup opportunities. Flame Body can also be used to threaten burns on Pokemon such as Kingambit and Dragonite, which oftentimes revenge kill Volcarona. Given its all-around solid defensive stats, Volcarona finds a myriad of opportunities to set up and takes advantage of the maximum Speed spread given to capitalize on the boosts as much as possible, outspeeding Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Great Tusk or Choice Scarf Dragapult after one or two Quiver Dance boosts, respectively.

Generally, Volcarona is best saved for mid- to late-game, when the opposing team has been chipped down and Volcarona has an opportunity to sweep after setting up. Utilizing its offensive teammates such as Scovillain, Ceruledge, Cinderace, and Paldean Tauros-F to slowly chip down defensive walls such as Dondozo, Ting-Lu, and Blissey provides better opportunity for Volcarona to sweep later in the game. Paldean Tauros-F is specifically useful with its ability to remove dual screens, preventing Volcarona's setup from being hindered. Rotom-H also provides excellent support, aiding in the Water matchup if Giga Drain is not used and providing pivot support to switch Volcarona in. Skeledirge and Talonflame provide defensive support to wear down offensive threats such as Dragonite. Torkoal providing sun support on Fire aids Volcarona, not only increasing Flamethrower's damage output, but giving Volcarona the opportunity to survive attacks like Choice Specs Greninja's Surf, giving it an opportunity to set up.

vgc2024.overview:
• Volcarona is a great setup Pokemon thanks to the superb Quiver Dance and great stats across the board. Volcarona can consistently set up in front of Rillaboom, Raging Bolt, Gholdengo, and, to an extent, Flutter Mane, thanks to its typing and a relatively fast Quiver Dance.

  • Volcarona appreciates redirection from Ogerpon-W and Amoonguss, Intimidate Pokemon such as Incineroar and Landorus-T, and Fake Out Pokemon like Rillaboom. All of these generate free turns for Volcarona to set up for a sweep. Rillaboom also provides it with Grassy Terrain recovery, which can make Volcarona extremely hard to bring down.

  • Volcarona struggles against Fire-type physical attackers like Incineroar, Entei, and Terastallized Ogerpon-H, which wall it and threaten it for massive damage without the fear of being burned. Urshifu-R and Ogerpon-W also force a Terastallization, though they can be handled if Volcarona sets up enough Quiver Dances.

Quiver Dance.description:
• Volcarona prefers Flamethrower as its Fire-type STAB move for the OHKO on Amoonguss at +1 and the OHKOs on Assault Vest Rillaboom and Kingambit when at +2. Giga Drain is Volcarona's choice of coverage to hit Urshifu-R, as well as the recovery helping it stick on the field longer.

  • Leftovers' recovery is most effective, as Volcarona is intended to stay on the field from start to finish, Giga Drain and common support enables this.

  • The EVs allow Volcarona to survive Ogerpon-W's Ivy Cudgel, and, when Terastallized and at +1 Special Defense, two Special Attack Booster Energy Flutter Mane Dazzling Gleams. The Speed investment allows for Volcarona to outspeed unboosted Iron Bundle after a Quiver Dance, and the remaining EVs are used to maximize damage.

  • Even when boosted, Volcarona will struggle against the aforementioned Fire-types, so Landorus and Urshifu-R make great teammates. Volcarona is a great answer to Flutter Mane and Rillaboom in return.

  • Volcarona runs Tera Dragon, as it synergizes with its original typing. This helps against Urshifu-R and resists both of Ogerpon-W's STAB moves, without bringing weaknesses to the Fire- and Flying-types it already struggles with. Volcarona's Fire typing handles the Fairy- and Ice- weaknesses, making Terastallization all the more safe.
124 Speed is to outspeed Deoxys at +1

Volcarona serves as a ferocious wallbreaker found on hyper offense teams, capable of denting large holes into specially defensive walls like Blissey and RegenVest Hisuian Goodra, allowing itself or its teammates to clean up late-game. Giga Drain chunks bulky Water-types like Swampert and Manaphy, while Psychic provides neutral coverage against foes that resist Fire- and Bug-type moves like Primordial Sea Zapdos and Ceruledge, and Bug Buzz acts as a more reliable secondary STAB move, sniping targets like Walking Wake and RegenVest Meloetta. While Sheer Force grants Volcarona stupefying levels of power, notably threatening an OHKO with Psychic against Zapdos, Turboblaze lets it melt Well-Baked Body Steel-types like Corviknight and Gholdengo into liquid metal. Life Orb is the preferred item, since Volcarona wants as much power as possible; however, Heavy-Duty Boots improves its longevity by allowing it to come in multiple times in a game without fear of being worn down by entry hazards. Teammates that appreciate Volcarona's wallbreaking capabilities like Walking Wake and Tail Glow Manaphy should be paired with it to clean up late-game. Offensive Bulk Up Great Tusk is an excellent partner for Volcarona on hyper offensive teams, notably clearing hazards that impede Volcarona's wallbreaking ability. Dual screens setters like Corviknight and Deoxys-S are great partners for Volcarona, allowing it to safely set up with Quiver Dance and survive a hit in a pinch. Revenge killers like Dragonite, Choice Band Barraskewda, and non-Dragon's Maw Choice Scarf Walking Wake threaten Volcarona, so having a teammate that can use them as setup fodder like Cresselia or Dragon Dance Roaring Moon is recommended.

Bulky Quiver Dance.description:
Volcarona makes great use of Quiver Dance and its solid defensive profile, checking Pokemon like Weavile, Meowscarada, and Iron Valiant, and it combines them with its decent longevity bolstered by Morning Sun to force switches and gain free opportunities to set up and sweep. The occasional Special Attack raises provided by Fiery Dance can add to Volcarona’s boosts and increase its sweeping potential, while Flamethrower is a more consistent and powerful alternative with more PP to assist in the long run. Tera Blast can be used as a surprise coverage move after Terastillizing but can also be used as a neutral move before Terastillizing for Fire-resistant Pokemon such as Gouging Fire. Tera Dragon gives Volcarona several powerful resistances, such as to Water, which helps against Barraskewda and rain, and Fire, which helps against Cinderace and opposing Volcarona; it also gives it a Tera Blast that hits most Pokemon neutrally and threatens Dragon-types like Kyurem, Dragonite, and Gouging Fire. Tera Fairy, in addition to being a solid defensive typing that also threatens Dragon-types, gives Volcarona a Dragon immunity to avoid attacks from Dragapult and Raging Bolt and resist Sucker Punch from Kingambit, as well as a way to solidly damage Ting-Lu. Tera Water is a powerful defensive option that gives Volcarona a threatening attack against the likes of Heatran and opposing Volcarona and a strong matchup against rain teams. Alternative Tera options are Ground, to improve Volcarona's matchup against Fire-types like Heatran and Poison-types like Clodsire, Toxapex, and Galarian Slowking and give it an immunity to Thunder Wave, and Grass, which is strong against bulky Water-types like Primarina and Hisuian Samurott. This set should run Giga Drain instead of Tera Blast for added longevity. Heavy-Duty Boots is a must-have for Volcarona to cover for its 4x weakness to Stealth Rock. 152 Speed EVs allow Volcarona to outspeed Great Tusk and Gholdengo as well as Zamazenta and Dragapult after a boost from Quiver Dance, while the remaining EVs are invested into HP and Defense to make Volcarona bulky enough to survive attacks from Pokemon like Raging Bolt, Enamorus, and Meowscarada that it otherwise couldn’t.

Volcarona’s ability to set up and sweep is always useful for helping teams make progress, but bulky Volcarona specifically is able to help its team by checking physical attackers throughout the game. Flame Body can cripple attackers like Kingambit and Dragonite on the switch in and can force them out from fear of being burned. This opens up teammates like Kyurem and Walking Wake to play more aggressively. Entry hazard setters like Glimmora and Great Tusk also appreciate Volcarona's ability to threaten Pokemon that try to use Rapid Spin with a burn. Dual screen setters like Deoxys-S and Alolan Ninetales are able to boost Volcarona's defenses significantly, giving it more opportunities to set up and sweep. Volcarona is also useful on sun teams, supporting Pokemon like Roaring Moon and Walking Wake with boosted Fire-type attacks as well as helping defensively against rain teams with Tera Water and picking off Deoxys-S and Iron Valiant with a sun-boosted Flamethrower. Volcarona is unable to make progress against special walls like Clodsire and Blissey; a Pokemon like Gholdengo are able to assist with Psyshock and immunity to moves like Toxic and Thunder Wave. Powerful physical cleaners like Weavile and Choice Band Meowscara are also useful for this purpose and synergize well with Volcarona. Other Unaware walls like Dondozo are also unaffected by Volcarona’s sweeping potential; wearing these threats down with hazards from Pokemon like Gliscor and Hisuian Samurott is extremely important in helping Volcarona sweep late-game. Weavile, Hisuian Samurott, and Meowscarda also help against Dondozo with Knock Off, discarding its Heavy-Duty Boots so that it can be worn down by entry hazards. Galarian Slowking is particularly difficult for Volcarona to deal with, especially if it's running Tera Fairy; powerful Pokemon that match up well against it like Kingambit, Roaring Moon, and Dragonite are important to chip it down and force it out.

Offensive Quiver Dance (Bug).description: Volcarona is one of Bug's strongest setup sweepers, with a respectable Speed stat, high Special Attack, and great coverage. In addition to being one of very few special attacking options on Bug, Volcarona helps apply pressure in a variety of matchups thanks to its strong STAB moves and coverage. Fire Blast can be used over Fiery Dance for more immediate damage output. Giga Drain deals with Water- and Ground-types, most notably Swampert, Gastrodon, and Rotom-Wash. Bug Buzz can be used instead for Volcarona to overwhelm types like Dragon, Dark, and Psychic with Quiver Dance-boosted STAB attacks. Hidden Power Ground hits Heatran, allowing Volcarona to break Steel's immunity-based defensive core that can otherwise give Bug teams problems. Alternatively, Psychic can be used to damage bulky Poison-types, like Toxapex and Mega Venusaur, that can wall physical attackers like Heracross and Buzzwole. These physical attackers, in addition to Lokix and Scizor, are able to break through specially defensive walls, like Chansey and Mantine, that Volcarona struggles against. Araquanid and Armaldo provide helpful entry hazards in Sticky Web and Stealth Rock, respectively, to make sweeping mid- or late-game much easier.

Offensive Quiver Dance (Fire).description: Volcarona is one of the top setup sweepers that Fire has access to, with Quiver Dance allowing it to become a dangerous threat to teams unequipped to deal with it defensively. Psychic allows Volcarona to pressure Fighting and Poison teams, especially after one Quiver Dance, which lets Volcarona outspeed and beat Keldeo, Glimmora, and Crobat. Similarly, Giga Drain does the same to Water and Ground teams after one Quiver Dance, threatening Tapu Fini, Gastrodon, and Hippowdon. Bug Buzz covers the Psychic and Dark matchups very well and allows it to hit Roaring Moon, Ting-Lu, and Latias, which would otherwise be a challenge to deal with. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Volcarona from being worn down by entry hazards, most notably Stealth Rock, which would otherwise stop Volcarona from being able to set up safely. Psychium Z lets Volcarona OHKO Toxapex with a +1 Shattered Psyche and beat otherwise troublesome threats like +1 Kommo-o, Iron Hands, and Clodsire. Cinderace and Mega Charizard X are especially good partners due to their ability to break through special walls such as Blissey, Clodsire, and Galarian Slowking with relative ease. Entry hazard removers such as Torkoal, Rotom-H, and Court Change Cinderace are near necessities if Volcarona is running Psychium Z. Torkoal and Rotom-H can also provide excellent utility in the form of Stealth Rock and dual screens, respectively, to help Volcarona sweep more easily. Volcanion is also an excellent partner for Volcarona that, thanks to its Water immunity, can act as a strong pivot into Pokemon like Azumarill and Mantine, which could revenge kill it or clear Quiver Dance boosts with Haze.

Offensive Quiver Dance.description: Volcarona is a highly threatening sweeper that can end the game on the spot if given the opportunity to set up a Quiver Dance while being able to force out major threats to the hyper offense teams that it finds itself on such as Swords Dance Mega Scizor. Flamethrower is Volcarona's Fire-type STAB move of choice thanks to its decent Base Power and consistent damage output, although Fire Blast can be used for the extra power, allowing Volcarona to notably have a very high chance to OHKO defensive Landorus-T and Tapu Lele after Stealth Rock and OHKO Gliscor after one Quiver Dance, while Flamethrower cannot. Giga Drain provides good coverage alongside Volcarona's Fire STAB move, allowing it to hit Water-types such as Alomomola and potentially forcing them to Terastallize. Finally, Hidden Power Ground allows Volcarona to hit unexpecting Heatran, which would otherwise be a hard counter to this set. Flame Body allows it to punish careless contact moves from Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny, Landorus-T, non-Protective Pads Meowscarada, and Mega Scizor. Tera Grass powers up Giga Drain while turning Volcarona's Water weakness into a resistance, allowing it to safely take on threats such as Ogerpon-W and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R. Alternatively, Tera Ground allows Volcarona to dodge revenge killing attempts from the likes of Iron Boulder while powering up Hidden Power Ground to let it potentially OHKO Gouging Fire at +1. Due to Volcarona's high threat level, common attempts to check it involve using Terastallization on a defensive Pokemon, such as Heatran or Alomomola; as such, partners like Raging Bolt and Kyurem appreciate Volcarona forcing those Pokemon to Terastallize. Grass-types like Serperior are also great partners, as they can bait in Heatran for Volcarona while being able to switch in situationally on Water-types like Ogerpon-W and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R that threaten it out. Serperior can also force progress with Glare on threats like Gouging Fire or setting up with Leaf Storm while chipping checks like Raging Bolt. Dual screens setters like Grimmsnarl are also good teammates to allow Volcarona to set up far more easily and win games quickly.

Bulky Quiver Dance.description: Due to its typing, ability, and the combination of Quiver Dance and Roost, Defensive Quiver Dance Volcarona is a powerful late-game sweeper and a decent pivot against Fairy- and Fighting-type moves such as Iron Valiant's Moonblast as well as Mega Lopunny and Zamazenta's Close Combat. Hidden Power Ground is an alternative to hit foes like Heatran, Garganacl, Mega Diancie, and Raging Bolt. Giga Drain can be paired with Tera Grass to provide coverage against Rock-types like Garganacl and Mega Diancie, as well as Water-types like Ogerpon-W, Alomomola, and Mega Swampert, and it helps to keep Volcarona healthy without sacking momentum to use Roost. Roost makes sure that Volcarona can check foes like Iron Valiant and Mega Lopunny in the long run and win the 1v1 against Tapu Lele and Darkrai without being chipped severely. Tera Grass gives Giga Drain a STAB boost and removes Volcarona's weakness to Water-types, which can be useful against offensive threats like Ogerpon-W and rain. Tera Steel allows Volcarona to turn walls relying on Toxic to make progress into its setup fodder, examples of which are Alomomola and Blissey. It also provides Volcarona with better matchups against the likes of Mega Tyranitar and Mega Diancie. The above EVs make sure that Volcarona can survive the damage from Stealth Rock twice and outspeed Zamazenta at +1. Teammates like Urshifu-R and Ogerpon-W can lure in walls like Ferrothorn and provide Volcarona with great opportunities to set up. They can also handle specially defensive foes like Heatran and Galarian Slowking for Volcarona when it's not equipped with Hidden Power Ground. Since it heavily relies on Heavy-Duty Boots to prevent entry hazard damage, Volcarona appreciates teammates like Gliscor and Mega Tyranitar to absorb Knock Off from foes like Landorus-T. It also benefits from teammates like Ferrothorn and Landorus-T checking Dragonite. Great Tusk and Landorus-T can relieve Volcarona of pressure from Stealth Rock by using Rapid Spin and Defog respectively when Volcarona loses its Heavy-Duty Boots.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Bulkarona.description:
• With recovery and massive investments in bulk, Volcarona is capable of setting up multiple Quiver Dances, making it a potent sweeper.

  • Tera Blast: Even before Terastallization, Tera Blast can come in handy for hitting Chi-Yu and Roaring Moon

  • Giga Drain: Giga Drain is Volcarona's best shot at beating Water-types such as Rotom-W and Palafin; note that Dondozo is not 2HKOed.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Burning foes is great for letting Volcarona set up against powerful foes like Chien-Pao and Great Tusk.

  • Substitute: Though it can be difficult to fit-in, Substitute allows Volcarona to punish users of status moves, such as sleep moves from Breloom and Gholdengo's Thunder Wave.

Other Options

  • Bug Buzz: This is Volcarona's best tool against foes behind a Substitute like Wo-Chien, and it hits physically defensive Ting-Lu hard.

  • Psychic: Psychic 2HKOs Toxapex, who can otherwise be problematic with Haze, and it hits Iron Moth hard.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While the massive Rock-type weakness often pressures Volcarona to Terastallize, Volcarona's useful resistances to Fighting and Fairy mean this isn't always the right play.

  • Grass: With a Grass Tera type, Volcarona can now 2HKO most Dondozo with Giga Drain and is better insulated against revenge kills from Water-types like Azumarill and Palafin-H.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type lets Volcarona take on powerful Dark and Dragon attacks from the likes of Chien-Pao and Choice Band Dragonite, and gives it powerful coverage against them with Tera Blast.

  • Water: Besides removing all of Volcarona's old weaknesses, a Water Tera type also massively improves the match up against Chi-Yu, Iron Moth, and Skeledirge with Tera Blast.

  • Flying: While a Flying Tera Type isn't a huge help defensively, the immunity to Fissure makes Volcarona better equipped to handle Dondozo.

  • Fire: A Fire Tera type simply gives Fiery Dance more power, and makes sense if not using Tera Blast.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Stealth Rock is common enough that this is the safest item for Volcarona to hold.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry gives Volcarona more durability against teams that lack hazards, and with an even HP stat, it'll eat Sitrus Berry right away after switching into Sealth Rock.

  • Lum Berry: This allows Volcarona to recover from status once against threats like Spore Breloom, Yawn Dondozo, and Thunder Wave Dragonite.

  • Covert Cloak: If Terastallized against Garganacl, Covert Cloak stops it from beating Volcarona with Salt Cure.

  • Safety Goggles: This allows Volcarona to handle Spore from Breloom, Brute Bonnet, and Amoonguss without Terastallizing.

EV Spreads

  • All of the given EV spreads except for the last one will outspeed offensive Iron Bundle and OHKO it with Fiery Dance after one Quiver Dance. If using Giga Drain, feel free to redistribute the SpA EV's.

  • Odd HP versus Even HP: Volcarona will usually prefer an odd HP stat to take less residual damage, with Stealth Rock no longer 2HKOing being the most important. However, if using Sitrus Berry, move 8 Defense EV's to HP so that one hit from Ruination or Stealth Rock activates it.

  • 244 HP / 204 Def / 12 SpA / 4 SpD / 44 Spe with Timid: This EV spread is the standard for outspeeding Iron Bundle after Quiver Dance, while simultaneously maximizing Volcarona's bulk.

  • 244 HP / 188 Def / 76 Spe with Timid: This EV spread sacrifices some physical bulk for being able to outspeed Dragapult after one Quiver Dance. If 8 Def EV's are moved to HP for the Sitrus Berry variant, this EV spread guarantees that Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Crunch triggers Sitrus Berry, always avoiding a 2HKO.

  • 244 HP / 236 Def / 28 Spe with Bold: This EV spread outspeeds Iron Valiant after Quiver Dance, and gives Volcarona a very strong chance of avoiding a 2HKO from Jolly Focus Sash Chien-Pao even without Sitrus Berry.

Offensive Quiver Dance.description:
• This far speedier approach to sweeping with Volcarona is more risky, but can catch more passive teams by surprise with its greater coverage.

  • Giga Drain: Giga Drain is the best coverage option for Volcarona, as it helps it deal with Water-type Pokémon, as well as recover a good amount of HP.

  • Bug Buzz versus Psychic: Bug Buzz's ability to ignore Substitute and hit Ting-Lu and Roaring Moon hard make it a reasonable consideration. Psychic's coverage isn't amazing, but it does help Volcarona deal with Iron Moth and Toxapex.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: This Volcarona is heavily pressured to start sweeping after it sets up, so Terastallization can widen the opportunities to do so.

  • Water: Terastallizing into the Water typing nullifies Volcarona's most common weakness in Rock-type, and Water-type Tera Blast is also the best option Volcarona has to hit Chi-Yu, Iron Moth, Skeledirge.

  • Grass: The Grass typing strengthens Giga Drain and nullifies Volcarona's weakness to Water-types, most notably helping against Dondozo, Azumarill, and Palafin-H.

  • Rock: Tera Rock is Volcarona's at covering Chi-Yu, Dragonite, Iron Moth, and Skeledirge with one move, especially with the useful Extreme Speed resistance. When used with Hippowdon's Sand Stream, it also makes Volcarona quite specially bulky.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy is a big help against powerful Dragon-type attacks such as Choice Band Dragonite's Outrage, and it gives Volcarona good coverage against it too.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: It is the best option on Volcarona, as it circumvents its crippling Stealth Rock weakness.

  • Lum Berry: This Volcarona's more offensive nature makes it especially vulnerable to status moves from the likes of Dragonite and Focus Sash Breloom, so Lum Berry is a reasonable way around this.

  • Sitrus Berry: If used with an even HP stat, Sitrus Berry will restore Volcarona's health the moment it switches into either Stealth Rock or gets hit by Ruination.

Swords Dance (Rock).description:
Upper Hand lets Terrakion circumvent Scizor's Bullet Punch and Breloom's Mach Punch.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Rock).description: Terrakion is the ideal Choice Scarf user for Rock teams due to its high Speed stat and access to powerful coverage moves in Earthquake and Close Combat. Close Combat provides coverage against Steel-, Normal-, and Dark-types such as Heatran, Mega Lopunny, and Greninja. Earthquake does heavy damage against Electric-types such as Zeraora and Tapu Koko as well as against Poison-types like Toxapex and Clodsire. Poison Jab is able to pressure Grass- and Fairy-types that Rock teams struggle to deal with, being able to OHKO Tapu Bulu and Whimsicott as well as deal high amounts of damage to Azumarill and Tapu Lele. Choice Scarf allows Terrakion to be an amazing revenge killer, outspeeding threats like Mega Lopunny and Zeraora. Terrakion pairs well with Shuckle, as its Stealth Rock and Sticky Web support allows Terrakion to net more KOs and outspeed faster Pokemon like Regieleki, Choice Scarf Meowscarada, and Adamant Barraskewda under rain. Terrakion also pairs well with Mega Diancie, which softens the likes of Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Toxapex for Terrakion thanks to its coverage. Alolan Golem helps Terrakion with the Steel matchup by trapping Pokemon such as Mega Scizor, Corviknight, and Celesteela with its ability Magnet Pull. Nihilego is able to help with the Fairy matchup with Sludge Wave dealing big damage to Pokemon such as Tapu Fini and Clefable. Tyranitar helps Terrakion by setting up sand, which boosts Terrakion's Special Defense stat, allowing it to survive Surf from Choice Scarf Greninja and Dazzling Gleam from Tapu Koko. Tyranitar also provides Pursuit support against faster Choice Scarf users such as Latias while also being able to break walls for Terrakion, allowing it to clean teams more easily.

Swords Dance.description:
Stone Edge can be used instead of Zen Headbutt to nail Flying-types like Articuno and Charizard; it also hits foes like Decidueye and Vikavolt harder. However, without Zen Headbutt, Virizion is helpless against defensive Poison-types like Vileplume and Tera Poison users like Wo-Chien.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

vgc2024.overview:
• Tornadus is one of the strongest support Pokemon bearing a great toolkit, including Tailwind, Taunt, Rain Dance, and Sunny Day. Prankster provides great speed and weather control. It has a great matchup against Rillaboom and Amoonguss, thanks to Bleakwind Storm, a great spread move which gives it a field presence, and Taunt.

  • Tornadus has amazing synergy with Urshifu-R and fast Pokemon like Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Landorus, which define the archetype of tailwind hyper offense.

  • Tornadus can become vulnerable to certain threats like Urshifu-R, Chien-Pao, and opposing Taunt Tornadus depending on its item choice. Focus Sash struggles against Urshifu-R, and items like Covert Cloak and Mental Herb struggle against Chien-Pao. Rocky Helmet matches poorly into Fake Out and Taunt pressure.

  • Tornadus struggles to create field pressure as a singular Pokemon. It cannot Taunt Pokemon like Farigiraf and Indeedee due to their respective abilities blocking priority. Chien-Pao, Raging Bolt, Iron Hands and Archaludon are bad matchups for it because of their ability to quickly remove it from the field.

Bulky Tailwind.description:
• Bleakwind Storm provides good damage into Rillaboom and Ogerpon-W. Tailwind is the most effective speed control Tornadus has access to. Taunt helps shut down Amoonguss and helps to manage certain Trick Room Pokemon like Porygon2 and Dusclops, but Protect can be run instead to ensure Tailwind goes up. Rain Dance and Sunny Day serve as weather control, which enables your sweepers and disables opposing weather-based sweepers. Rain Dance pairs well with Urshifu-R and Ogerpon-W while Sunny Day powers up Chi-Yu and Flutter Mane.

  • This given EV spread focuses on bulk, surviving Mystic Water Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R and Tera Fairy Choice Specs Moonblast from Flutter Mane. The low Speed investment ensures that Tornadus sets up its own weather.

  • Rocky Helmet helps against Urshifu-R mirrors and provides good chip into opposing physical attackers making contact. Covert Cloak prevents Fake Out flinches from Incineroar and Rillaboom. It also negates any secondary effects from moves like Rock Slide and Icy Wind. This ensures that Tailwind goes up. Mental Herb helps to shrug off one Taunt.

  • Tera Dark provides an immunity to Prankster Taunt, guaranteeing Tailwind. Tera Steel provides useful resistance to Chien-Pao and Flutter Mane's STAB moves. Both Tera types improve matchups into Psyspam and against Electric-type moves from Pokemon like Raging Bolt, Iron Hands and Archaludon.

Offensive Tailwind.description:
• Focus Sash ensures Tornadus survives one attack and set up Tailwind. Protect becomes important to avoid Fake Out without committing the Tera early.

  • Tornadus rarely Terastallizes, but Tera Ghost can ensure that it can more reliably set up Tailwind by negating Fake Out from Pokemon like Incineroar and Rillaboom, and Extreme Speed from Pokemon like Dragonite and Entei. Tera Flying increases its offensive pressure.

• Tornadus is an incredibly effective Tailwind user in DOU thanks to Prankster and its high Speed stat, ensuring that it can give its team a speed boost on demand. It pairs best with mid-speed attackers, such as Gholdengo and Landorus, which appreciate the immediate speed boost to knock out fast threats before they can respond with their own attacks.

  • Bleakwind Storm is Tornadus's best attack, dealing relatively consistent damage to both opponents. While it won't win any awards for damage output, it allows Tornadus to stay on the field without losing too much momentum after using Tailwind.

  • Taunt is used primarily to stop Pokemon like Cresselia and Diancie from setting up Trick Room. It can also prevent Protect, most entry hazards, setup moves, and redirection from the likes of Amoonguss, allowing you to make the most of Tailwind's limited duration.

  • Protect lets Tornadus avoid powerful attacks that might KO it or faster moves like Fake Out or an opposing Taunt that would stop it from using Tailwind. Protect can also be used to stall out field effects like weather and Trick Room.

  • Focus Sash is Tornadus's go-to item and lets it survive any one hit in spite of its mediocre bulk. Covert Cloak can be used instead to set Tailwind against Fake Out users.

  • Tera Ghost grants Tornadus an immunity to both Fake Out and Dragonite's Extreme Speed, which both have higher priority than Tornadus's Prankster-boosted moves and can prevent Tailwind from going up. However, Tornadus should usually not Terastallize, as it is unlikely to represent a game-ending threat. Tornadus should only Terastallize when it will directly lead to winning a game.

  • Tornadus has several other options over Taunt in the third moveslot. Rain Dance and Sunny Day can help support Pokemon like Palafin and Flutter Mane, respectively. Icy Wind, meanwhile, can double down on speed control while dealing some chip damage and is very helpful against opposing Tailwind teams.

Assault Vest.description:
216 Speed EVs lets Tornadus-T outspeed Iron Valiant.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Nasty Plot Wallbreaker.description: A colorful movepool, a great Speed tier, and Regenerator make Tornadus-T one of Flying's best wallbreakers. Bleakwind Storm can be used if Tornadus-T is paired with Mega Charizard Y, as its accuracy is not affected by sun. Focus Blast grants Tornadus-T excellent neutral coverage and is able to hit most Steel- and Rock-types, like Heatran and Tyranitar, hard. Heat Wave, however, has the benefit of nailing Jirachi, Gholdengo, and Corviknight, which makes it a better option against Psychic, Ghost, and, if using Knock Off, Steel teams. In the last slot, Taunt is preferred, so Tornadus-T can safely set up on walls like Toxapex and Ting-Lu, but Knock Off's ability to cripple the likes of defensive Heatran and Galarian Slowking is worth considering. Tornadus-T has a very poor matchup against Electric-types, so Pokemon that can deal with them, such as Landorus-T and Gliscor, are must-haves. They're also able to lay down Stealth Rock and have access to Defog, making them incredible teammates. Similarly, Corviknight and Celesteela stomach most Ice-type attacks aimed at Tornadus-T, thanks to their bulk and Steel typing. Mega Charizard Y forms a terrifying wallbreaking duo alongside Tornadus-T that breaks down shared checks such as Heatran and Blissey. Setup sweepers like Dragon Dance Dragonite and Agility Thundurus-T greatly appreciate Tornadus-T weakening or removing walls for them. 88 HP and 8 Special Defense EVs can be used over Special Attack to ensure Tornadus-T lives an Ice Beam from Choice Scarf Greninja from full health.

Nasty Plot (Electric).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Nasty Plot.description: Thundurus is a good setup sweeper and wallbreaker on offensive teams thanks to its great Special Attack and good offensive movepool, which can make it threatening even after one boost. It can be used over Thundurus-T due to its higher Speed, outspeeding foes like Iron Moth, Keldeo, and Enamorus. Thunderbolt helps against the plethora of bulky Water- and Flying-types, 2HKOing Celesteela, Tapu Fini, and Slowbro. It can also threaten 2HKOs on bulky foes like Magic Guard Clefable and Mega Sableye at +2. Focus Blast helps against the tier's numerous Dark- and Steel-types, OHKOing Tyranitar and Excadrill and having good odds to OHKO Hydreigon and Mega Tyranitar after Stealth Rock. Hidden Power Ice hits Dragon-types that resist Thunderbolt, 2HKOing Latios, Mega Altaria, and unboosted Mega Latias at +2, its also more spammable against Grass-types than Focus Blast and can hit Pokemon like Amoonguss super effectively. Psychic is an alternative that helps against Poison- and Fighting-types, 2HKOing foes like Choice Band Iron Hands, Amoonguss, and Buzzwole. Fightinium Z can provide Thundurus a way to OHKO targets like Mega Tyranitar, help break through neutral targets like Gastrodon, and bypass Focus Blast's accuracy. Thundurus can have a hard time breaking through specially defensive Pokemon, notably Mega Latias, which can set up on it even if Thundurus uses Nasty Plot, as well as Tapu Bulu and Mega Venusaur when lacking Hidden Power Ice or Psychic; it pairs well with other offensive Pokemon like Hydreigon and Iron Moth that can threaten these foes. In return, Thundurus can help to deal with their checks like bulky Scizor, Tapu Fini, and Iron Hands. Thundurus can pair well with pivots like Victini, which can bring it in against Water-types it threatens like Tapu Fini as well as help against Pokemon that wall it like Mega Venusaur. Due to Thundurus's Stealth Rock weakness that can make it harder for it sweep, hazard removers like Tapu Fini, Excadrill, and Hydreigon make for good teammates. Thundurus can also pair well with entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu, Mega Tyranitar, and Skarmory, which can help it to guarantee an OHKO on foes like Hydreigon and Tyranitar. In return, Thundurus can threaten out common hazard removal options like Tapu Fini and Excadrill, and it can even set up on some of them like Tapu Fini. Thundurus is very prone to getting revenge killed by faster foes like Mega Aerodactyl, Alakazam, and Choice Scarf Galarian Zapdos, so it pairs well with bulky partners like Slowbro, Celesteela, and Clefable.

Thundurus's excellent Special Attack, good Speed and coverage, and access to Nasty Plot allow it to function as a great wallbreaker. Focus Blast threatens RegenVest Roaring Moon, Hisuian Goodra, and Volt Absorb Empoleon. Psychic threatens Kommo-o, Great Tusk, and Iron Moth, while Sludge Bomb threatens Scream Tail. Sheer Force offers more power, letting Thundurus OHKO Garganacl with Focus Blast. Magic Guard lets Thundurus avoid chip damage and lets Sludge Bomb potentially poison switch-ins such as Kommo-o, specially defensive Garchomp, and Volt Absorb Mandibuzz; however, the drop in power significantly compromises its ability as a wallbreaker in exchange for utility. Fast cleaners like Meowscarada and Roaring Moon appreciate Thundurus being able to pressure their walls like Corviknight and Great Tusk, opening up the way for them to sweep late-game. Thundurus appreciates entry hazard support from the likes of Empoleon, Garchomp, and Sandy Shocks, as the chip damage from hazards allows Thundurus to secure OHKOs against Pokemon such as Hisuian Goodra and specially defensive Garchomp after a Nasty Plot, as well as Kommo-o, Iron Moth, and Volt Absorb Empoleon. Thundurus's poor bulk means it's OHKOed by most Pokemon faster than it, so walls such as Corviknight and Manaphy that can take hits for it and pivot it in are appreciated. Thundurus is prone to being worn down by Stealth Rock if not running Magic Guard, so entry hazard removers such as Great Tusk and the aforementioned Corviknight are appreciated.
Only use Tera Blast with Tera Flying

Pivot.description: These are sample set(s) as we wait for the metagame to settle before working on new analyses. They will be updated as the metagame continues to develop, so stay tuned!

Offensive Pivot.description: Thundurus-T functions as a powerful offensive pivot, able to capitalize off the forced switches it generates by bringing in its teammates with Volt Switch. Volt Switch threatens Flying-types like Celesteela and Galarian Zapdos while allowing Thundurus-T to pivot out of problematic matchups such as Tangrowth and Mega Altaria. Grass Knot threatens Ground-types like Hippowdon and Gastrodon. Knock Off hinders switch-ins like Clefable, Blissey, and Chansey. Psychic 2HKOes Iron Hands and would-be walls like Mega Venusaur and Amoonguss, while Focus Blast threatens Dark-types like Mega Tyranitar and Hydreigon as well as Steel-types like Excadrill. Thunderbolt better pressures Celesteela, Slowking, Mega Sableye, and Scizor while also providing Thundurus-T a STAB move that doesn't force it out. Special wallbreakers like Latios, Enamorus, and Keldeo appreciate Thundurus-T being able to threaten their switch-ins, such as Mega Tyranitar for the former and Slowking for the latter two. The aforementioned wallbreakers also benefit from Thundurus-T luring in bulkier Pokemon they can deal with, such as Amoonguss, Mega Latias, and Blissey, respectively, in addition to Knock Off's removal of Heavy-Duty Boots and Assault Vest from the likes of Skeledirge and Tangrowth. Thundurus-T is susceptible to being revenge killed by faster threats like Latios and Choice Scarf Hydreigon, so teammates that can check them such as Alakazam and Mega Altaria are appreciated. Entry hazard support from the likes of Ting-Lu and Iron Moth is also appreciated due to the forced switches Thundurus-T generates, letting it better pressure foes like Clefable; in return, it can aid its teammates by using Knock Off to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from foes such as Skeledirge and Amoonguss.

Nasty Plot.description: With a sky-high Special Attack stat and access to Nasty Plot, Thundurus-T is a powerful wallbreaker, able to threaten special walls like Mega Tyranitar, Celesteela, and Slowking. After a Nasty Plot boost, Thundurus-T can OHKO many bulkier Pokemon in the tier, including Mega Venusaur, Magic Guard Clefable, and Mega Sableye. Focus Blast hits Dark-types like Mega Tyranitar, Hydreigon, and Ting-Lu as well as Steel-types like Excadrill. Hidden Power Ice hits Dragon-types that resist Thunderbolt like Latios, Mega Latias, and Mega Altaria, while Psychic can 2HKO Iron Hands, Amoonguss, and Mega Venusaur. Fightinium Z turns Focus Blast into All-Out Pummeling, bypassing Focus Blast's low accuracy in a pinch against threats like Tyranitar, OHKOing Hisuian Goodra and Blissey after a boost, and dealing significant damage to walls like Gastrodon and Hippowdon, potentially OHKOing them after slight chip damage. Fast special cleaners like Choice Scarf Hydreigon, Enamorus, and Speed Booster Energy Iron Moth appreciate Thundurus-T's ability to pressure their switch-ins, such as Celesteela, Slowking, and Mega Tyranitar, respectively, potentially allowing them to sweep late-game. Mega Altaria appreciates Thundurus-T's ability to check foes that threaten it, such as Scizor and Celesteela; in return, Mega Altaria can deal with Mega Latias, which outspeeds and 2HKOes Thundurus-T while avoiding a 2HKO from +2 Hidden Power Ice. Thundurus-T's middling Speed leaves it prone to being revenge killed by faster Pokemon like Latios and Mega Aerodactyl; Mega Tyranitar can switch into Latios and trap it with Pursuit, while Slowbro can deal with Mega Aerodactyl. Thundurus-T is also weak to Stealth Rock, so entry hazard removers like Tapu Fini and Hydreigon are beneficial.

battlestadiumsingles.overview: This Pokemon is a new addition to the Regulation D format! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

Pivot.description:
• Thanks to Volt Absorb, Thundurus-T is an excellent offensive pivot that makes masterful use of Terastallization!

  • Grass Knot: Grass Knot is highly recommended for dealing massive damage to Ground-types, such as Ting-Lu and Ursaluna, without Terastallizing in addition to being a secondary attack to hit Urshifu-R while Choice locked into an attack.

  • Focus Blast: Focus Blast has reliability issues, but it's Thundurus-T's best shot of dealing big damage to Hisuian Goodra and Wo-Chien.

  • Sludge Bomb: Sludge Bomb is a more niche option, giving Thundurus-T a more reliable way to deal damage to Wo-Chien and Meowscarada at the cost of doing nothing to Hisuian Goodra.

  • Timid versus Modest: Timid is the best nature, allowing Thundurus-T to outspeed key threats, such as Urshifu-R, and at least Speed tie with opposing Thundurus-T. Modest is usable with Choice Specs, allowing Thundurus-T to outspeed up to Jolly Baxcalibur and Great Tusk, and the extra power can be handy in some situations, such as usually 2HKOing specially defensive Clodsire with Tera Blast Flying.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While Thundurus-T is perfectly fine with its base typing, it makes such good use of Terastallization that it'll often Terastallize.

  • Flying: Tera Flying makes Tera Blast a powerful STAB option with very few resistances while gaining no extra weaknesses thanks to Volt Absorb.

  • Ice: Not only does Tera Ice give Thundurus-T powerful coverage against Ground- and Grass-types like Landorus-T and Wo-Chien, it also gives an important resistance to Iron Bundle's and Chien-Pao's Ice-type attacks.

  • Water: Tera Water is a fantastic defensive option, turning Thundurus-T into an excellent check against Regieleki and Zapdos while still giving it a good coverage option against Landorus-T. However, it still retains Thundurus-T's weakness to Freeze-Dry.

Items

  • Choice Specs versus Choice Scarf: Choice Specs makes Thundurus-T difficult to wall without an extremely sturdy special wall, with even Pokemon like Clodsire and Cresselia at risk of a 2HKO. Choice Scarf, on the other hand, allows Thundurus-T to double as a good revenge killer, outspeeding major threats like Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao.

  • Assault Vest: While Thundurus-T isn't known for its bulk, Volt Absorb means Assault Vest makes Thundurus-T more effective at checking other Electric-types, especially when using bulkier EV spreads.

Bulkier EV Spreads

  • 20 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 228 Spe with Timid: This Assault Vest spread outspeeds both Urshifu formes and takes 70% maximum from Timid Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry without sacrificing power.

  • 188 SpA / 68 SpD / 252 Spe with Timid or Modest**: This spread is optimized for Assault Vest, letting Thundurus-T survive Timid Choice Specs Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry without Terastallizing.

Minor Optimizations

  • 0-3 Attack IV: Foes that commonly run Foul Play such as Amoonguss and Rotom-W have more powerful moves to use against Thundurus-T, but there's no drawback to minimizing Foul Play's damage.

Nasty Plot.description:
• Thundurus-T's massive Special Attack stat and array of immunities make it a good user of Nasty Plot.

  • Grass Knot: Grass Knot is integral for potentially OHKOing physically defensive Ting-Lu after a boost and usually OHKOing offensive Ursaluna.

  • Life Orb versus Sitrus Berry: Life Orb is great for wallbreaking, allowing Thundurus-T to potentially OHKO Ting-Lu with a boosted Grass Knot. Sitrus Berry is still a good option, though allowing Thundurus-T to instantly restore some health after being hit by Ruination, as long as its maximum HP is an even number.

Other Options

  • Substitute: When paired with Tera Water, Substitute lets Thundurus-T set up on Garganacl.

  • Focus Blast: Focus Blast's unreliability makes it hard to recommend for most teams, but it's the only way Thundurus-T will break through Hisuian Goodra without Terastallization.

  • Taunt: Giving up coverage is risky, but Taunt shuts down a lot of defensive counterplay against Thundurus-T such as Whirlwind Ting-Lu and Toxic Clodsire.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Thundurus-T's typing is totally functional for sweeping and wallbreaking, but Terastallization makes it far harder to revenge kill thanks to Volt Absorb.

  • Flying: Tera Flying gives Thundurus-T a powerful STAB option, letting it cleave through specially bulky foes, like Water Absorb Clodsire, particularly easily.

  • Water: While Tera Water does leave Thundurus-T vulnerable to certain Pokemon, such as Water Absorb Clodsire and Hisuian Goodra, it's a fantastic defensive Tera type that lets it deal with other common Electric-types that Terastallize like Regieleki and Zapdos.

  • Ice: Tera Ice is a great offensive option, letting Thundurus-T cleave through most Ground-types that aren't weak to Grass such as Landorus-T and Clodsire. Thundurus-T even makes good defensive use of it, resisting Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry.

Bulkier EV Spreads

  • 108 HP / 4 Def / 140 SpA / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Timid: This EV spread lets Thundurus-T survive Timid Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry, if it doesn't have an offensive item, making it a good choice for more defensive items Thundurus-T may use such as Sitrus Berry.

Minor Optimizations

  • 0-3 Attack IV: Thundurus-T isn't getting hit by Foul Play that often, but a lower Attack IV is marginally useful regardless.

A sky-high Special Attack stat combined with powerful coverage moves boosted by Sheer Force and access to Nasty Plot makes Thundurus-T a dangerous wallbreaker, able to threaten many common special walls such as Empoleon, RegenVest Manaphy, and Roaring Moon. Focus Blast threatens an OHKO on Volt Absorb Empoleon and a 2HKO on Blissey, RegenVest Roaring Moon, and Hisuian Goodra. Psychic threatens an OHKO on Kommo-o, Great Tusk, and Iron Moth. Fast cleaners like Azelf and Hisuian Electrode appreciate Thundurus-T being able to pressure their walls like Empoleon and Hisuian Goodra, respectively, opening up the way for them to sweep late-game. Thundurus-T appreciates entry hazard support from the likes of Kommo-o, Garchomp, and Sandy Shocks letting it more reliably OHKO specially defensive Garchomp and Hisuian Goodra after a Nasty Plot. Thundurus-T is prone to being chipped down by Stealth Rock and put in KO range of strong priority moves from threats like Dragonite and Ceruledge, so hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight are appreciated. Thundurus-T is also easily revenge killed by most Pokemon that are faster than it like Chien-Pao and Meowscarada due to its low bulk and middling Speed, so walls such as Manaphy and the aforementioned Corviknight that can take a hit for it and safely pivot it in are appreciated.
