Battle Bond (Water).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Specs (Dark).description:
Greninja is a staple for Dark teams thanks to its blitzing Speed tier that outpaces Cinderace and Iron Valiant. Protean + Choice Specs allows it to take full advantage of its coverage moves to OHKO and 2HKO common threats. Hydro Pump 2HKOes specially defensive Corviknight after Stealth Rock; however, Surf is a safer option while still OHKOing Iron Valiant after Stealth Rock. Ice Beam targets threats such as Dragonite and Clodsire. Grass Knot can 2HKO Ting Lu and Gastrodon while OHKOing Dondozo after Stealth Rock. Extrasensory targets Poison- and Fighting-types such as Toxapex and Quaquaval.

Meowscarada forms a dual Protean core with Greninja to break each other's checks; Greninja can break Toxapex for Meowscarada, while Meowscarada can break Iron Hands for Greninja. Chien-Pao and Greninja form a dangerous core that shatters teams without a proper Ice-resistant Pokemon. Chien-Pao is also capable of breaking Steel-types such as Kingambit with Sacred Sword. Kingambit can take on Fairy-type Pokemon for Greninja, such as Flutter Mane and Hatterene, while it can break past physical walls such as Quagsire in return. Ting-Lu can stack Stealth Rock and Spikes allowing Greninja to more easily score OHKOs such as against Corviknight and Dondozo and take care of Hatterene and Flutter Mane with Heavy Slam for Greninja. Sableye switches into Fighting-type attacks such as Great Tusk's Close Combat; additionally, it can block Rapid Spin, keeping entry hazards up for Greninja. Skuntank is amazing in the Fairy matchup, as it can check threats such as Choice Scarf Iron Valiant and trap Klefki with Fire Spin. Skuntank also absorbs and sets Toxic Spikes for Greninja.

Choice Specs (Water).description:
Thanks to a wide array of coverage options alongside Protean, Choice Specs Greninja is a devastating special wallbreaker that can dismantle several types, including Grass, Ground, Water, and Poison. Its naturally high Speed tier is invaluable to outpace and threaten fast foes such as Iron Valiant and Sandy Shocks. Aside from hitting Psychic- and Ghost-types like Bronzong and Gholdengo, Dark Pulse's lack of immunities makes it a spammable attack that can be used to muscle past neutral Pokemon such as Corviknight with flinches. Ice Beam covers a large portion of the metagame, including Dragon, Ground, Grass, and Flying teams, decimating prominent foes like Hydreigon, Clodsire, Amoonguss, and Iron Jugulis. It's also Greninja's hardest hitting attack against Skuntank, which is important in the Poison matchup. Extrasensory pressures Poison- and Fighting-types like Toxapex and Assault Vest Iron Hands and prevents Greninja from being picked off by Breloom's Mach Punch. Grass Knot rounds out its coverage, significantly damaging Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Water-types such as Gastrodon and Dondozo.

Choice Specs Greninja appreciates being paired with other wallbreakers like Barraskewda and Quaquaval that can handle Normal and Steel teams. They break through bulky Pokemon like Blissey and Kingambit that Greninja struggles with; they are also potent late-game cleaners that enjoy Greninja's ability to threaten Storm Drain Gastrodon and their physically defensive checks like Amoonguss, Toxapex, Slowbro, and Dondozo. Moreover, Barraskewda under rain excels at tearing down fast offensive teams that Greninja can struggle with, as it can threaten out Meowscarada, boosted Volcarona, and Choice Scarf Iron Moth. Quaquaval can also run Rapid Spin to let Greninja enter the field multiple times to wallbreak without worry, preventing it from being chipped down into KO range of priority attacks like Dragonite's Extreme Speed, Scizor's Bullet Punch, and Baxcalibur's Ice Shard. Pivot support from Slowking is helpful to bring Greninja in safely on foes like Dragalge and Gastrodon, letting it fire off attacks freely. Defensive teammates such as Toxapex, Dondozo, Gastrodon, and Quagsire can switch into potential revenge killers like Meowscarada, Chien-Pao, Dragapult, and Slither Wing, respectively; notably, Gastrodon and Quagsire also provide entry hazards to take advantage of the countless switches that Greninja forces, putting the likes of Ting-Lu, Toxapex, and Assault Vest Iron Hands into Greninja's KO range, as well as switch into and check Electric-types such as Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks and Assault Vest Iron Hands.

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Greninja is a powerful offensive threat and pivot that uses its rain-boosted attacks to break past most neutral foes. Dark Pulse helps deal with common Desolate Land users like Iron Moth and Cinderace. Ice Beam provides coverage against Dragon-types like Goodra and Roaring Moon, while Surf lets Greninja clean up weakened teams without relying on the low PP and accuracy of Hydro Pump. U-turn lets Greninja switch out from its checks while still maintaining momentum, forming a VoltTurn core with physical wallbreakers like Galarian Zapdos and Cinderace that can threaten the specially defensive Pokemon that wall Greninja like Blissey and Hisuian Goodra. Greninja pairs well with entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu and Garchomp, which can help it wear down its checks. Greninja also appreciates hazard removal from Pokemon like Corviknight and Iron Treads to avoid getting worn down when switching in; these two Pokemon can also pivot in Greninja.

Sniper.description: Using its high Speed, synergistic offensive typing, and high offensive stats, Ash-Greninja becomes a strong wallbreaker. With Flower Trick, Ash-Greninja can dent Fur Coat Slowbro without activating Rocky Helmet, OHKO Mega Swampert, and 2HKO Imposter users. Frost Breath lets Ash-Greninja OHKO Mega Garchomp and severely weaken Fur Coat Miraidon and Yveltal. Physically strong Pokemon like Mega Grachomp, Mega Lucario, and Kyurem-B appreciate Ash-Greninja's presence, as it's able to help overwhelm their checks such as Fur Coat Arceus-Ghost, Ho-Oh, and Mega Slowbro; Mega Lucario is particularly useful thanks to its strong matchup against Fur Coat Fairy-types like Mega Audino, which otherwise completely wall Ash-Greninja thanks to Rocky Helmet. Ash-Greninja can struggle against faster Pokemon such as Flutter Mane and Miraidon, as these are are all able to revenge kill it, so having teammates like Mega Steelix, Ho-Oh, and Arceus-Ground helps. Ash-Greninja also benefits immensely from having teammates that can block Strength Sap such as Mega Audino, Blissey, and Mega Slowbro, as many of its defensive checks like Miraidon and Arceus-Fairy rely on this move for healing. Having slow pivots, such as Teleport users like Mega Audino or RegenVest users like Mega Swampert, is also helpful to account for its frailty. To Imposter-proof Ash-Greninja's, a Fur Coat + Rocky Helmet user like Mega Audino is ideal.

Choice Scarf (Water).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Band (Normal).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Defog (Fire).description:
128 Speed Evs lets Talonflame outspeed Ogerpon-W.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Magic Guard.description: Talonflame is a fast late-game sweeper that uses its good Speed tier, powerful Brave Bird, and bevy of utility options to pick and choose its counters. With Swords Dance, it's able to set up and clean up games while being able to and take on pokemon Pokemon that would normally take its Brave Bird like Corviknight, physically defensive Manaphy, and Ogerpon-C, while Flare Blitz can be used as a way to break through other foes that would otherwise take on its Brave Bird such as Fluffy Zapdos and Heatran. Taunt allows Talonflame to set up on Pokemon with Unaware that would usually slow it down or wall it with healing like Blissey, Scream Tail, and Cresselia, while Will-O-Wisp can be used to cripple switch-ins, support teammates, and wear down checks to Talonflame like Garganacl, Primordial Sea Zapdos, and Garchomp. Pivots such as Corviknight, Barraskewda, and Manaphy like being able to pivot into Talonflame for it to set up a sweep or to take down certain threats and walls for them like Ogerpon-H, Ogerpon-W, and Kommo-o. Talonflame is forced out by Pokemon that are faster than it or have strong priority such as Barraskewda, Chien-Pao, Dragonite, and Choice Scarf Azelf, which can be taken on with teammates like Corviknight, Scream Tail, and Gholdengo.

Quiver Dance.description:
Vivillon is a good choice for hyper offense teams, as the combination of Sleep Powder and Quiver Dance can easily wrest momentum from the opponent and potentially sweep outright, giving Vivillon a niche in NU as a dangerous setup sweeper. Sleep Powder enables Vivillon to cripple opposing Pokemon that may otherwise check it, such as Eelektross and Drifblim, and give it the free turn needed to set up a Quiver Dance. Substitute is an option to ease setup by helping Vivillon play around the uncertainty of sleep turns and dodge status. Bug Buzz targets Pokemon such as Umbreon and Hattrem, which can otherwise cut Vivillon's sweep short with Thunder Wave or Nuzzle. Finally, Tera Blast with Tera Ground does heavy damage to Muk and outright OHKOes Magneton. Vivillon's very poor overall bulk makes Focus Sash a good option, as it guarantees a Quiver Dance boost or the ability to put a foe to sleep. However, if your team lacks multiple forms of entry hazard removal, Heavy-Duty Boots is preferred. Compound Eyes boosts the otherwise shaky accuracy of Sleep Powder and Hurricane, making them far more reliable. A Timid nature is preferred over a Modest nature to outspeed Choice Scarf users such as Indeedee-F, Passimian, and Medicham after a Quiver Dance and outspeed and threaten an OHKO on offensive threats like Toxicroak and Mabosstiff unboosted. Tera Ground allows Vivillon to turn the tables on Volt Switch users such as Jolteon and Rotom and also helps it survive Accelerock from Lycanroc. Alternatively, Tera Ghost along with Substitute allows Vivillon to set up against Chansey, which would normally wall it, and Tera Flying can be used to power up Vivillon's Hurricane.

If Vivillon is running Focus Sash over Heavy-Duty Boots, strong hazard control is key, so Hattrem, which prevents opposing hazards through Magic Bounce, and other hazard removal options such as Drifblim and Lurantis are mandatory. Special walls such as Chansey and Eelektross are a serious obstacle for Vivillon to overcome, with the former's Natural Cure negating the effect of Sleep Powder, so physical wallbreakers that can take advantage of them like Toxicroak, Paldean Tauros, and Ursaring make for great partners. Trick users, such as Rotom and Zoroark, can also bait in these foes and cripple them by giving them a Choice item, with Rotom deserving special mention for inviting in Lurantis and Appletun, which gives a Vivillon relatively free setup opportunity. Spikes support from the likes of Qwilfish and Cacturne is also appreciated to help wear down answers to Vivillon over time. Strong setup sweepers like Veluza, Dudunsparce, and Lycanroc, which all appreciate foes being put to sleep, also make for powerful partners in conjunction with Vivillon.

Taunt Wallbreaker.description:
Pyroar's excellent Speed and solid movepool make it a great wallbreaker that checks setup sweepers. Taunt allows Pyroar to prevent bulky Pokemon like Blissey, Muk, and Ursaring from getting free switch-in to use their utility moves while also stopping setup sweepers such as Bulk Up Braviary, Coil Eelektross, and Nasty Plot Mesprit. Will-O-Wisp threatens Pyroar switch-ins like Samurott, Muk, and Assault Vest Eelektross. Tera Blast is most commonly run with Tera Grass, allowing Pyroar to destroy threats like Floatzel, Sandaconda, and Veluza. Endeavor can be used over Will-O-Wisp to severely weaken special walls like Blissey, Appletun, and Ursaring if they attempt to trade damage after Pyroar uses Taunt versus them. Tera Ghost allows Pyroar to turn the tables against common Fighting-types such as Toxicroak, Medicham, and Hisuian Sneasel that would usually destroy it. Alternatively, Tera Grass allows Pyroar to tank powerful Water- and Ground-type attacks from Bruxish, Floatzel, and Sandaconda.

Pyroar can't reliably defeat walls such as Blissey, Umbreon, and Appletun; it best pairs with physical wallbreakers like Toxicroak, Scyther, and Samurott that can deal with these threats. If Pyroar loses its Heavy-Duty Boots, it becomes susceptible to entry hazards, so hazard removers such as Avalugg, Drifblim, and Lurantis or a hazard deterrent like Hattrem are great partners. Grass-types like Cacturne, Appletun, and Lurantis appreciate Pyroar for checking threats such as Scyther, Avalugg, and Vivillon; in return, they check Water-types like Bruxish, Clawitzer, and Samurott. Fighting-types like Hisuian Sneasel and Choice Scarf Medicham can threaten out Pyroar, so it pairs best with Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Mesprit, Bruxish, and Drifblim.

Stall.description: Defense gives the best odds against opposing Chien-Pao.

Bulk Up.description:
Gogoat is an amazing defensive wincon, able to boost past special threats like Indeedee-F and Charizard late-game thanks to its great special bulk, usage of Terastallization, and recovery in Horn Leech and Milk Drink. It is also a solid switch-in to Water-types like Whiscash and Basculin, comfortably taking their STAB moves and threatening to OHKO them or set up. Bulk Up is what lets Gogoat become so threatening late-game, letting it take on physical attackers like Perserrker and Sawsbuck after a Bulk Up or two. Rock Slide is optimal coverage alongside Horn Leech, hitting Grass-type checks like Charizard, Honchkrow, and Articuno. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Gogoat ignore entry hazards, namely the otherwise debilitating Toxic Spikes. Water is the premier Tera type due to its overall defensive utility, reversing Gogoat's Fire weakness and making it take Flying- and Bug-type attacks more easily, which lets it set up on various foes it could not before such as Charizard, Rabsca, and Camerupt. However, Tera Rock gives Gogoat STAB on Rock Slide while still having it resist Fire and Flying, but it becomes vulnerable to Ground- and Steel-types like Gabite and Perrserker. Both Tera types keep Gogoat's usefulness as a Grass-type check due to Sap Sipper.

Before Terastallizing or setting up, Gogoat is threatened by common offensive Pokemon like Charizard, Pyroar, and Rotom-F, so additional special walls like Carbink and Ampharos are recommended as partners. Carbink can also set entry hazards to wear down Gogoat's checks like Gabite and Tinkatuff, while Ampharos can bring Gogoat in with Volt Switch. Pokemon like Basculin and Alolan Dugtrio appreciate having a Pokemon that can come in on Electric- and Grass-types like Raichu and Leafeon. Misdreavus is particularly annoying for Gogoat, able to cripple it with Will-O-Wisp + Hex and use it at setup bait, so ways to dispose of or significantly weaken Misdreavus are appreciated. Wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Skuntank, special Honchkrow, and Indeedee-F can threaten Misdreavus while not caring about Will-O-Wisp, while paralysis from Tinkatuff and Alolan Persian can help Gogoat brute force its way past Misdreavus.

SubToxic.description: Aegislash's valuable defensive profile and immense natural bulk in Shield forme make it perfectly capable of forcing out and setting up on passive Pokemon such as Slowking, Jirachi, and Amoonguss. Substitute allows Aegislash to take advantage of the aforementioned Pokemon's inability to deal sufficient damage to it while also protecting it from potential status moves from these Pokemon; it also allows it to safely land Toxic on incoming defensive walls such as Ting-Lu and Gastrodon, stalling them out in conjunction with King's Shield and recovery from Leftovers. Shadow Ball serves as Aegislash's main STAB move, and alongside Aegislash's naturally high Special Attack stat, is useful for putting pressure onto Toxic-immune Pokemon such as Iron Moth, Excadrill, and Mega Sableye. SubToxic Aegislash fits best on bulky offense and balance teams that appreciate its ability to safely set up on and wear down defensive Pokemon while also making use of its ability to simultaneously check offensive threats such as Galarian Zapdos and Latios. Due to Aegislash's fear of status moves, like Scald burns from the likes of Slowking, as well as Spore from Amoonguss, pivots such as Flip Turn Keldeo, U-turn Iron Moth, and Teleport Blissey are helpful to ensure that Aegislash finds safe opportunities against them. Other defensive Pokemon such as Buzzwole, Skarmory, and Clefable can form notable cores with Aegislash; the former two take advantage of Dark- and Ground-types such as Mega Tyranitar and Ting-Lu, while Clefable provides additional support in staving off the likes of Latios and Buzzwole, which can potentially nail Aegislash on the switch with Mystical Fire or Earthquake, respectively. Knock Off users such as the aforementioned Clefable and Assault Vest Tangrowth are also helpful, as they can remove items from checks to Aegislash like Leftovers from Celesteela and Heavy-Duty Boots from Iron Moth and Scizor, giving it an easier time breaking through them in the long-run.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance turns Aegislash into a potent wallbreaker and sweeper, using its fantastic neutral coverage and bulk in Shield forme to set up against and break through defensive cores. Close Combat is Aegislash's strongest move overall, and it threatens the many Dark-types that would otherwise resist its Ghost-type STAB moves, like Mega Tyranitar, Hydreigon, and Ting-Lu. Iron Head is an alternative option that still OHKOes the former two after a boost while also 2HKOing Unaware Clefable. Shadow Sneak is a crucial priority move which at +2 can finish off weakened offensive Pokemon that would normally outspeed and take it out, such as Iron Moth and Keldeo, while also being usable to pick off Latios and Alakazam without a boost. Ghostium Z is usually preferred to power up STAB Shadow Claw, which, when turned into Never Ending Nightmare, threatens to KO physically defensive Pokemon such as Skarmory and Amoonguss after Swords Dance. However, Air Balloon can be run instead if the team already has a different Z-Move user, and this also allows Aegislash to find free setup opportunities against Ground-types such as Excadrill and Hippowdon, potentially spinblocking the former. Aegislash fits best on more offensive teams that appreciate its defensive utility and ability to break open holes for its teammates early-game. Other sweepers such as Dragon Dance Mega Tyranitar can benefit from Ghostium-Z variants of Aegislash forcing in and eliminating Buzzwole, Hippowdon, and Tangrowth; in return, Mega Tyranitar can help Aegislash weaken certain walls like Slowbro and Mandibuzz early-game. Aegislash also suffers from having terrible bulk in Blade forme, so it is easily revenge killed after attacking, making entry hazard support from the likes of Mew, Ting-Lu, and Mega Tyranitar helpful at chipping down offensive threats like Excadrill into Shadow Sneak range while also pressuring other walls such as Tapu Fini.

Mixed Attacker.description: Mixed Aegislash makes the most out of its excellent offensive stats accentuated further by Spell Tag to serve as a terrifying early- or mid-game wallbreaker. Close Combat forms perfect neutral coverage with Shadow Ball, notably 2HKOing Blissey and OHKOing Mega Tyranitar after Stealth Rock. Shadow Sneak gives Aegislash additional utility in being able to pick off weakened offensive Pokemon such as Latios and Blacephalon when needed. King's Shield prevents Aegislash from being picked off by Pursuit users like Tyranitar and lets it scout Choice-locked revenge killers such as Keldeo and Hydreigon. 8 Attack EVs with a Mild nature are necessary for Aegislash to 2HKO Chansey with Close Combat after Stealth Rock. Mixed Aegislash commonly features on more offensive teams that appreciate its instant wallbreaking power combined with its utility. Stealth Rock support from Pokemon such as Mega Tyranitar can be very crucial in helping Aegislash secure 2HKOes against Pokemon such as Tapu Fini and Amoonguss on the switch. While Aegislash can find additional opportunities by pivoting directly into attackers such as Latios and Galarian Zapdos, it is often unable to preserve its HP to continue wallbreaking after doing so; as such, pivots like Galarian Zapdos are essential to let Aegislash enter the battlefield safely against Pokemon it would like to force out, such as Slowbro. Other setup Pokemon such as Nasty Plot Hydreigon can help overwhelm shared checks to this set, such as Ting-Lu; in return, Hydreigon benefits from Aegislash's ability to keep faster Pokemon like Latios and Alakazam in check.

Utility.description: 132 Speed EVs are to outrun uninvested Sylveon.

Choice Specs.description: 172 Speed EVs are to outrun uninvested Umbreon and Vaporeon.

Specially Defensive (Dragon).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

24 Speed IVs lets Dragalge underspeed Toxapex

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Specs.description:
Aura Sphere 2HKOes Cryogonal and threatens common Tera Steel users like Poliwrath and Appletun. Dark Pulse hits Pokemon like Farigiraf, Veluza, and Trevenant harder than Clawitzer's other moves while also being decent neutral coverage. A Modest nature is generally preferred to maximize Clawitzer’s damage output, but a Timid nature can be used to outspeed threats like defensive Articuno. Tera Dragon further powers up Dragon Pulse and helps against Grass- and Electric-types like Arboliva and Rotom.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

With Choice Specs and the unique Mega Launcher ability, Clawitzer uses its exceptional coverage to be one of the most devastating wallbreakers in NU. Tera Dragon not only maintains Clawitzer's Water and Fire resistances, but it also turns Clawitzer's Grass and Electric weaknesses into resistances. Further, it gives Clawitzer a more powerful STAB move in Dragon Pulse, which guarantees a 2HKO on common special walls like Umbreon and Assault Vest Eelektross after Stealth Rock. Aura Sphere hits Chansey and Steel-types like Perrserker and Tera Steel Eelektross. U-turn can be used in the fourth moveslot to bring in teammates like Passimian and Toxicroak, which better deal with healthy special walls like Chansey and Umbreon or Tera Fairy threats, allowing Clawitzer to use Dragon Pulse more freely. Flash Cannon can also be used to hit Tera Fairy Pokemon like Chansey, Umbreon, and Vaporeon, which are immune to Dragon Pulse and Water Pulse, in Vaporeon's case. Without Terastallizing, Electric-types like Rotom, Jolteon, and Magneton pose a threat to Clawitzer. Appletun and Electric immunities like Sandaconda and Jolteon work as partners to eat up their moves and restore any HP they lose.

Babiri Berry.description:
• Babiri Berry lets Sylveon survive Heavy Slam from Choice Band Great Tusk, Choice Band Iron Hands, and Choice Band Dondozo.
  • Hyper Voice allows Sylveon to bypass Substitute from Leech Seed Meowscarada, Dragapult, and Booster Energy Roaring Moon, and it's a spammable STAB option to beat Encore + Disable Iron Valiant.
  • Fake Tears is for non-Clear Amulet Bellibolt, maximizing Sylveon’s damage against it, and it synergizes with Calm Mind against non-Clear Amulet Espathra, non-Clear Amulet Dondozo, and Unaware Skeledirge.
  • The HP EVs let Sylveon survive two Hydro Pumps from Booster Energy Walking Wake by using Calm Mind. The Defense EVs let Sylveon survive Headlong Rush from Choice Band Great Tusk.

Weakness Policy.description:
• Charm helps Sylveon beat slower physical attackers like offensive Azumarill and Choice Band Ting-Lu.
  • Draining Kiss provides Sylveon enough recovery to beat Choice Band Donphan.
  • Fake Tears can be used to beat stall Azumarill, while Hyper Voice can be used to have a better matchup against Leech Seed Meowscarada.
  • The EVs allow Sylveon to outspeed Choice Band Donphan and survive its Gunk Shot twice by using Charm on turn 1, then using Draining Kiss twice to secure the win.
  • An alternate EV spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpA with a Bold nature can be used to have the best possible odds against Choice Band Meowscarada. This set should also use Hyper Voice to reliably win against Leech Seed sets. However, this set loses against Donphan, and Choice Band Meowscarada's Giga Impact still has a slight chance to OHKO Sylveon. It's also unreliable against Ting-Lu, as Choice Band Ting-Lu can outspeed and beat it with Heavy Slam.

Choice Specs.description:
• Hyper Beam OHKOes Ting-Lu, Dondozo, non-Assault Vest Azumarill, and non-specially defensive Bellibolt.
  • Hyper Voice allows Sylveon to bypass Substitute from Leech Seed Meowscarada, Dragapult, and Petaya Berry Espathra. Hyper Voice also has perfect Accuracy and lets Sylveon beat slower Sylveon variants.
  • Psyshock allows Sylveon to beat Clodsire and occasionally Life Orb Salazzle.
  • Shadow Ball 2HKOes Skeledirge.
  • The Speed EVs are for Sylveon to outspeed Pokemon with 50 base Speed unless if they use a Speed boosting nature.
  • Against Espathra, Sylveon should always use Hyper Voice for the best chance to win against most Espathra. Unlike other Sylveon sets, Choice Specs loses to Encore + Disable Iron Valiant.

Offensive.description:
• Tera Blast + Fire Tera type gives Sylveon a strong matchup against Steel-types like Gholdengo and Tera Steel Hydreigon. When not Terastallized, Tera Blast is boosted by Pixiliate and is still useful for dealing damage when faced by Wide Guard users like Armarouge. Fairy Tera type makes Sylveon's Hyper Voice even more powerful, letting it 2HKO even naturally bulky Pokemon like Kingambit and Hatterene; this can be used over Fire Tera type on teams that can afford the loss in effectiveness against Steel-types like Gholdengo. Ground Tera type is an option that lets Sylveon hit opposing Fire-types like Ceruledge and Armarouge hard, retain good damage against Steel-types, and avoid a burdensome weakness to Garchomp, though Sylveon strongly values the resistance to Steel that a Fire Tera type grants.

  • Substitute is good for blocking Amoonguss's Spore, preventing its Clear Smog from resetting Sylveon's stat boosts, and taking advantage of defensive play. Quick Attack is an option that can prove particularly useful against Tailwind teams, picking off Pokemon brought down to their Focus Sash like Murkrow and Kilowattrel, as well as other weakened Pokemon.

  • Calm Mind is an option that can be particularly potent on bulkier teams with damage mitigation from Pokemon like Gyarados and Grimmsnarl to help Sylveon set up.

  • Throat Spray is a no-drawback way of improving Sylveon's offense; a +1 Hyper Voice will 2HKO most offensive Pokemon that do not resist Fairy. Life Orb lets Sylveon immediately 2HKO or nearly 2HKO most offensive Pokemon at the cost of recoil that could put it in range of attacks like Tera Ground Garchomp's Earthquake. Leftovers is good alongside Calm Mind on bulkier teams where Sylveon wants to stick around longer. Safety Goggles grants Sylveon immunity to Amoonguss's Spore.

  • On Tailwind teams Sylveon can run 212 Speed EVs, taken from its HP stat, to outpace Dragapult.

Choice Specs.description:
• Choice Specs is Sylveon's most immediately powerful set, it can 2HKO most offensive Pokemon that do not resist Fairy. It's much more immediately powerful than Throat Spray Sylveon and a bit stronger than Life Orb Sylveon without wearing itself down with recoil, helping it stay out of range of attacks like Tera Ground Garchomp's Earthquake.

  • Tera Blast + a Fire Tera Type lets Sylveon hit Fairy-resistant foes like Gholdengo and Amoonguss hard, and the typing is defensively useful against the former. Tera Blast is also useful by itself in the face of Wide Guard, giving Sylveon an option besides Hyper Beam, which has a turn of recharge, for a single target Fairy-type attack.

  • Shadow Ball hits Armarouge, Ceruledge, and Skeledirge, which resist Fairy, and is a strong option against Gholdengo and Gengar if Terastallizing is off the table.

  • Hyper Beam OHKOes bulky Pokemon like Rotom-W and Kingambit that can take Hyper Voice.

  • 212 Speed EVs, taken from Sylveon's HP stat, let it outpace Dragapult on Tailwind teams.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Offensive.description:
• With its good natural bulk, Sylveon can serve as a potent special attacker and decent revenge killer.

  • Tera Blast: Tera Blast serves as a good alternate STAB attack once Sylveon has Terastallized, providing highly valuable coverage against the Steel-types that could otherwise exploit it, like Scizor. It also gets around potential users of Throat Chop before Terastallization, such as Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon.

  • Psyshock: This is Sylveon's best shot of dealing with Iron Moth.

  • Shadow Ball: Shadow Ball hits foes such as Mimikyu, Flutter Mane, and Gholdengo super effectively, and it means Sylveon does not have to Terastallize to hit Gholdengo for good damage.

  • Quick Attack: Though it is weak, Quick Attack gives valuable priority for picking off weakened threats, and thanks to Pixilate, surprise users of Tera Ghost aren't able to absorb it. A Quiet nature can be used to increase its power, though this risks Sylveon getting outsped by Kingambit.

Other Options

  • Psychic: Psychic deals more damage to physically defensive Toxapex and Amoonguss, but its lower damage output against Iron Moth makes it disappointing if not using Tera Ground.

  • Hyper Beam: Despite the serious risks from the recharge turn, Hyper Beam's extreme power makes it a good filler move.

Items

  • Assault Vest: Assault Vest lets even offensive Sylveon be specially resilient.

  • Choice Specs: With the boost from Choice Specs, Sylveon is a surprisingly potent wallbreaker, making the most out of its many opportunities to switch in.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA: This spread capitalizes on Sylveon's good natural bulk while maximizing its power.

  • 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe: While no bulk investment makes Sylveon more difficult to safely get in, Speed investment allows it to outrun and threaten a wider range of foes, such as Scizor and Corviknight.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: Sylveon suffers coverage issues on its own, so its heavily reliant on either Tera Blast or the sheer power of Tera Fairy Hyper Voice to break past them.

  • Fire: Tera Fire allows Sylveon to break past troublesome Steel-types, like Gholdengo and Kingambit, and gives it a key resistance to Ice and Fire attacks from Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu respectively.

  • Water: Tera Water gives good coverage against Fire-types like Iron Moth and Skeledirge, in addition to surprising Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu by resisting their strongest STAB attacks.

  • Ground: Tera Ground doesn't match up quite as well against Steel-types as Tera Fire, but it lets Sylveon turn the tables on Iron Moth, and deal massive damage to Toxapex and Skeledirge.

  • Fairy: Getting an extra boost on Hyper Voice and Hyper Beam makes Choice Specs Sylveon far more difficult to wall, with even resists such as Gholdengo and physically defensive Skeledirge getting 2HKOed by Hyper Voice!

Items

  • Assault Vest: Giving Sylveon extra special bulk lets it take on powerful threats like Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle more reliably.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs turns Sylveon into a surprising wallbreaker, especially if using Tera Fairy.

  • Throat Spray: With Hyper Voice activating Throat Spray, Sylveon could potentially break apart slower foes in the late-game, though it only gets one shot at this Special Attack boost. This is best used with Tera Blast to give Sylveon an alternative STAB attack that doesn't activate Throat Spray.

CUTESY CRUSADER (Defensive).description:
• With its good bulk and Special Attack and a reasonable healing move in Wish, Sylveon is a good choice for a bulky Fairy-type.

  • Hyper Voice: Hyper Voice gives Sylveon a reliable STAB even when Terastallized, and hits through common Substitute users like Iron Bundle and Wo-Chien. While It's possible to drop this attack for Tera Blast in an attempt to run more coverage, this seriously worsens Sylveon's matchup against Chien-Pao and Ting-Lu.

  • Tera Blast: Beyond just Terastallization, Tera Blast is still impacted by Pixilate, making it a good move to use against foes that sometimes carry Throat Chop, like Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon.

  • Protect: Protect pairs excellently with Leftovers, and makes Wish a more reliable recovery move.

  • Yawn: Sylveon's good bulk makes it a great choice for phazing with Yawn.

  • Psyshock: Psyshock is Sylveon's best hope for Iron Moth switch-ins.

  • Shadow Ball: Shadow Ball offers important coverage on Gholdengo without demanding that Sylveon Terastallize.

  • Leftovers versus Sitrus Berry: Leftovers is the preferred recovery item for its synergy with Protect and Wish, but Sitrus Berry is a reasonable alternative if Protect isn't wanted, or if another teammate needs Leftovers more.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Sylveon's coverage issues are much easier to deal with when using Terastallization, but this set can still be used well defensively without it.

  • Fire: A Fire Tera type grants Sylveon resistances to Steel and Fairy, allowing it to take on foes it would otherwise have to run from, such as Gholdengo, and a good STAB to hit Chien-Pao hard with if not using Hyper Voice. It also works against Scizor, but note that Tera Water is common on that foe. Tera Fire also makes Sylveon far more vulnerable to Ting-Lu.

  • Water: Tera Water is a great mono-attacking option, making it ideal if only running Tera Blast to do decently well against Steel-types. It also gives Sylveon a better matchup against Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu, and is a safer option against Ting-Lu and Tera Water Scizor.

  • Fairy: If not using Tera Blast, Fairy becomes a reasonable option for boosting Hyper Voice's damage output. Note that Tera Blast is not needed to justify a different Tera Type.

  • Ground: Tera Ground worsens Sylveon's matchup with Chien-Pao, but it does let it deal big damage to Iron Moth, Gholdengo, and Toxapex.

Swords Dance.description: Thanks to its good STAB combination and great ability, Hawlucha functions as a powerful Swords Dance sweeper on offense teams. Its above-average Speed also enables it to outspeed all prominent Choice Scarf users like Hydreigon, Galarian Zapdos, and Sandy Shocks after Unburden. Acrobatics pairs really well with Unburden and is Hawlucha's best move due to its power, notably helping deal with the plethora of Fighting- and Grass-types, 2HKOing Okidogi, Mega Venusaur, and Amoonguss and OHKOing Buzzwole. Close Combat hits Steel-types that resist Acrobatics like Celesteela, Skarmory, and Excadrill, as well as OHKOing Dark-types like Mega Tyranitar, Bisharp, and Hydreigon. Taunt prevents Pokemon like Mega Venusaur, Okidogi, and Mew from using recovery, setup, and status moves, while Roost lets Hawlucha set up in front of defensive Pokemon like Tangrowth, Buzzwole, and Hippowdon. Grassy Seed is used on teams with Tapu Bulu boosting its Defense, while Misty Seed is used on teams with Tapu Fini boosting its Special Defense. The first EV spread lets Hawlucha avoid an OHKO from defensive Clefable's Moonblast and should be run alongside Grassy Seed. The second EV spread is used to let it survive a Moonblast from defensive Clefable after Misty Seed is activated. 124 Speed EVs are used to outspeed Sand Rush Excadrill. Hawlucha functions as a do-or-die sweeper on offense teams. Tapu Bulu and Tapu Fini are mandatory teammates for Hawlucha, as they can allow it to immediately use up its item and active Unburden; offensive variants are perferred when using Hawlucha, helping to threaten targets like Slowbro and Mega Sableye respectively. Hawlucha can have a hard time breaking through Fairy- and Ghost-types like Tapu Fini, Mega Altaria, and Mega Sableye, as well as Skeledirge, which deserves a special mention because of its typing, ability, and good physical bulk. Hawlucha pairs well with general offensive partners like Thundurus, Celesteela, and Enamorus, which can help threaten the aforementioned foes out and can also help against generally physically bulky Pokemon like Slowbro; in return, Hawlucha can help to break Mega Venusaur, Chansey, and Blissey. Hawlucha appreciates entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Mega Tyranitar and notably dedicated hyper offense leads like Excadrill, which can also help keep off Stealth Rock. Entry hazard chip which can be useful to help 2HKO bulky Scizor and Mega Altaria. Hawlucha pairs well with pivots like Slowbro, Sandy Shocks, and Galarian Zapdos, which can help to bring it in against foes like Buzzwole, Amoonguss, and Skarmory.

Unburden Sweeper.description: Hawlucha is a terrifying setup sweeper with a stellar Speed tier alongside Unburden to instantly outspeed the entire metagame, including boosted foes like Iron Valiant, +2 Mega Gyarados, and weather sweepers such as Mega Swampert and—with the given Speed EVs—Excadrill. Its high-powered STAB moves—which can be boosted further by Swords Dance—hit almost the entire metagame neutrally; Acrobatics grants Hawlucha strong neutral coverage against the likes of Tornadus-T, Dragapult, and Tapu Lele, which is backed up by Close Combat to decimate Flying-resistant Pokemon like Kingambit, Garganacl, and Mega Tyranitar. Its item instantly activates Unburden under the corresponding Terrain and grants it setup opportunities from the Defense boost, especially in conjunction with Roost. Electric Seed helps against Kingambit, Zamazenta, and Great Tusk and prevents revenge killing attempts from Dragonite's Extreme Speed, Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch, and Weavile's Ice Shard, while Psychic Seed helps against Gholdengo, Volcarona, and Choice-locked Dragapult. Taunt or Substitute deals with problematic walls, ignoring status like Toxapex's Toxic and Skeledirge's Will-O-Wisp; Taunt also prevents their recovery and phazing as well as Defense-boosting attempts such as from Skarmory or Tera Water Buzzwole, while Substitute blocks Landorus-T's Intimidate and punishes the use of weak attacks like its U-turn, Garganacl's Salt Cure, and Alomomola's Scald. The bulk investment allows Hawlucha to survive Clefable's Moonblast, which is unnecessary if running Psychic Seed. 176 Speed EVs can be used instead to revenge kill +1 Dragon Dance Dragapult. Tera Flying boosts Hawlucha's Acrobatics, potentially OHKOing Clefable at +2 and letting it set up against defensive Tornadus-T if necessary. The corresponding Alolan Guardian is a mandatory teammate to reliably activate Hawlucha's Unburden; Tapu Koko provides dual screens and brings Hawlucha in safely on Tangrowth and Ferrothorn with U-turn, while Tapu Lele pressures Toxapex and overwhelms Gholdengo. Offensive Pokemon on hyper offense teams such as Iron Valiant, Volcarona, Dragonite, and Mega Gyarados help maintain offensive pressure against the opposition; notably, they can force damage onto shared checks like Gholdengo, Skeledirge, Zapdos, and Toxapex, respectively, for Hawlucha to sweep more easily.

Swords Dance (Fighting).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Stealth Rock.description:
Carving out a niche for itself as an entry hazard setter with good matchups against common threats such as Charizard and Articuno, Carbink is easily able to exploit the fact that many common offensive Pokemon will struggle to OHKO it, making entry hazards on the opponent's side of the field nearly guaranteed. Body Press further takes advantage of Carbink's naturally high Defense by allowing it to deal modest damage, especially to frail attackers such as Pyroar or Steel-types that may try to switch in, such as Perrserker or Alolan Dugtrio, although its reliance on Body Press to not be immensely passive can invite in opposing Misdreavus or other Pokemon that may choose to utilize Tera Ghost. Power Gem allows for Carbink to target common Pokemon in the tier that have a large Rock weakness, such as Charizard, Articuno, Masquerain, and Vespiquen, while also insuring that it is not entirely helpless against the aforementioned Misdreavus. Spikes allows Carbink to be of greater assistance to more fast-paced offensive teams, further exploiting its natural bulk to apply even more pressure to the opponent in the form of entry hazards. Rest allows for Carbink to somewhat make up for its lack of recovery, which helps it to still be a threat later in the game and to set hazards back up if they are removed. Lastly, Iron Defense allows Carbink to become a threatening sweeper by making it even more difficult to break through while also greatly increasing the damage done by Body Press. Heavy-Duty Boots helps Carbink by making it immune to opposing hazards, greatly increasing its longevity, while Leftovers allows for a small amount of passive recovery. Tera Fighting increases the damage of Body Press even further, while Tera Ghost allows for Carbink to block attempts at using Rapid Spin to clear away hazards. A more physically defensive spread of 248 HP / 252 Def / 8 SpD with a Bold nature is also viable to improve Carbink's matchup against threats such as Gogoat and Dugtrio.

Carbink's high success rate when it comes to setting up entry hazards is greatly appreciated by almost all teams, especially those that make use of setup sweepers like Dragon Dance Charizard or powerful breakers like Zangoose, which greatly benefit from the extra chip damage that Carbink provides. In addition, Grass-types such as Gogoat and Thwackey appreciate Carbink's ability to take hits from the multitude of powerful Fire-types in the tier. Thwackey is also one of the few Pokemon in PU with access to Knock Off, which is valuable for removing Heavy-Duty Boots from opponents and making Carbink's hazards much more difficult to manage. Furthermore, Grassy Terrain lessens the damage dealt by Earthquake and provides Carbink with passive recovery, which is especially beneficial should it choose to run Heavy-Duty Boots. In return, these Pokemon are strong answers to Water-types such as Whiscash and Golduck that can solidly threaten Carbink with super effective attacks. Carbink also appreciates strong Ground- and Fire-types, such as Dugtrio, Charizard, and Pyroar, that can handle threatening Steel-types such as Perrserker and Alolan Dugtrio for it. Due to Carbink being extremely slow and vulnerable to moves such as Taunt and Encore, fast teammates such as the aforementioned Dugtrio, as well as Alolan Persian and Raichu, are also appreciated to handle attempts to stifle Carbink alongside providing much-needed speed control.

Iron Defense.description:
Iron Defense Carbink is an incredibly terrifying defensive setup sweeper with incredible stats, making really hard to stop even for some of the most threatening physical attackers like Crabominable, and Lycanroc-N, especially after it starts boosting with Iron Defense. Body Press hits most of the tier for neutral or super effective damage, making its switch-ins very limited after a boost. Most of these switch-ins like Charizard and Masquerain also have to be wary of Power Gem. Carbink could choose to run Moonblast instead, hitting the likes of Drakloak and Spiritomb. Rock Polish is an option in the last slot to boost past Pokemon that could normally pick it off at low health like offensive Perrserker, Klawf, and Gabite. Carbink can also opt to run RestTalk alongside Iron Defense and Body Press to function better as a late-game sweeper once opposing Ghost-types and bulky Pokemon that resist its attacks are removed. Clear Body helps with many aspects, like avoiding defensive drops from moves like Misdreavus's Shadow Ball or Quaxwell's Liquidation, blocking Alolan Persian's Parting Shot, and ignoring Sticky Web's Speed drop. Tera Fighting is used to boost Body Press's power, helping Carbink pick up the 2HKO on Gogoat, Skuntank, and Whiscash. A defensive Tera like Ghost or Water also work well with helping Carbink get by various foes. Ghost drops all of its weaknesses, allowing it to tank hits with greater ease, but it makes enemies like Misdreavus, Banette, and Haunter more problematic. Water is a great option for stuffing the likes of Golduck, Basculin, and Lumineon, though Carbink then has to be wary of Rotom-F and Raichu in addition to being a generally good defensive typing that also allows it to shrug off hits from Steel-type moves that would usually obliterate it. Carbink can opt to run a more specially defensive spread of 248 HP / 8 Def / 252 SpD with a Calm nature to better take hits from Whiscash, Lumineon, and Raichu for an easier time setting up on them. However, you do miss out on initial Body Press power.

Carbink works great on balance or bulky offensive teams looking for an endgame sweeper. It does great at supporting the likes of Misdreavus, Haunter, and Indeedee-F since it can wall Dark-types like Honchkrow, Alolan Persian, and Spiritomb. Carbink also isn't bothered by the likes of Houndoom, Pyroar, and Charizard which teammates like Gogoat, Rotom-F, and Rabsca really appreciate. It also fits the role of a Knock Off absorber, being able to take the hit when switching in and either immediately deal damage back or start setting up on Banette, Tinkatuff, and Klawf. While Carbink's defensive capabilities make it a great teammate, it also can break through bulky teams that rely on the likes of Hisuian Sliggoo and Chansey, which special attackers such as Haunter, Persian and Rotom-F enjoy having removed. Grass-types such as Gogoat, Dartrix, and Flapple really help Carbink find multiple opportunities to come back in to set up since they can help take hits from the likes of Whiscash, Basculin, and Sawsbuck. Carbink also really appreciates having a partner that can help with its 4x weakness to Steel, specifically against Perrserker and Alolan Dugtrio, like defensive Misdreavus, Lumineon, and RestTalk Gabite.

Special Tank.description:
Acid Spray can be used instead of Dragon Pulse to help Hisuian Sliggoo take on specially bulky foes like Chansey, Gogoat, and Calm Mind Misdreavus. Thunderbolt and Ice Beam are other options that offer Hisuian Sliggoo great coverage and deal more damage to Pokemon like Charizard and Gogoat, respectively.

Sample set. Stay tuned for updates!

RegenVest.description: Goodra serves as a solid special wall, leveraging its massive bulk and pure Dragon typing to properly check dangerous threats like Hadron Engine Sandy Shocks, and Sheer Force Thundurus and Gengar its Hisuian counterpart falters against. Knock Off provides utility and a reliable way to threaten Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Gengar, and Dragon Tail enables Goodra to accumulate chip damage and force out threatening setup sweepers like Volcarona and Manaphy. Draco Meteor provides a powerful neutral STAB move, Ice Beam allows Goodra to better threaten Zapdos and both Thundurus formes, and Scald provides an option to spread chip damage and potential burns to dissuade switch-ins. Thunderbolt allows Goodra to threaten Corviknight directly, while Earthquake allows it to OHKO Iron Moth and Heatran. Goodra suffers from having low physical bulk, meaning physically defensive teammates like Corviknight and Intimidate Quaquaval are recommended to handle them; these teammates also provide entry hazard removal, which is greatly beneficial for its survivability. Goodra also fails to check Walking Wake and Enamorus-T as a special wall, meaning it pairs well with teammates like Empoleon and Well-Baked Body or Earth Eater Gholdengo to handle these threats.

Assault Vest.description: These are sample set(s) as we wait for the metagame to settle before working on new analyses. They will be updated as the metagame continues to develop, so stay tuned!

RestoChesto (Dragon).description:
Due to its exceptional bulk and Steel typing, Hisuian Goodra is a staple on Dragon teams, being able to take on Fairy-, Dragon-, and Ice-type threats. Heavy Slam checks Fairy-types like Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Hatterene while also hitting Dragapult and other Dragon-types neutrally. Body Press, further enhanced by Acid Armor, threatens Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Hydreigon, as well as deals considerable damage to opposing Hisuian Goodra and Walking Wake after Defense boosts. Rest, in conjunction with Chesto Berry, provides instant recovery, allowing Hisuian Goodra to preserve Acid Armor boosts while remaining healthy, severely threatening Dragon and hyper offensive Dark teams. The given EV spread provides enough Defense to OHKO Chien-Pao with an unboosted Body Press while retaining as much Special Defense as possible to improve the Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Walking Wake matchups. Shell Armor prevents foes from breaking through Acid Armor boosts with a critical hit.

Baxcalibur is a great teammate in the Ground and Flying matchups, threatening Landorus, Sandy Shocks, and Corviknight. Garchomp provides entry hazards to wear down wallbreakers like Sneasler, Sandy Shocks, and Urshifu-R, as well as deals with walls such as Clodsire, Skeledirge, and Iron Hands. Dragapult offers a Fighting-type immunity to combat Sneasler, Zamazenta, and Urshifu-R. Dragonite and Hydreigon switch into Ground-type attacks from Iron Treads, Great Tusk, and Ting-Lu and also aid in the Steel and Poison matchups. Walking Wake is a huge asset in the Ground matchup and threatens Gholdengo and Skeledirge. Cyclizar removes entry hazards for Hisuian Goodra to improve its longevity and provides it a safe switch in against threats like Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant with Shed Tail.

Specially Defensive (Dragon).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Specially Defensive (Steel).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Outspeeds Adamant Azumarill.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This Pokemon is a new addition to the Regulation D format! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, vist the format page!

Assault Vest.description:
• Hisuian Goodra's incredible special bulk, typing, and useful immunity to Spore via Sap Sipper make it one of the prime choices for Assault Vest!

  • Flash Cannon versus Heavy Slam: Flash Cannon has great synergy with Acid Spray and is a reliable STAB move in general. While Heavy Slam isn't very useful against heavy targets, it's worth using for OHKOing offensive Flutter Mane, one of the biggest threats in the metagame.

  • Draco Meteor versus Ice Beam: Draco Meteor's power makes switching offensive threats like Urshifu-R into Hisuian Goodra tricky, and it is notable for 2HKOing Dondozo. Ice Beam lets Hisuian Goodra punish important Ground-types.

  • Acid Spray: Acid Spray is a useful wallbreaking tool, capable of making even specially bulky foes like Clodsire risk taking massive damage after the Special Defense drop.

  • Thunderbolt: Thunderbolt is another way to 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo and OHKO offensive Urshifu-R and pairs very well with Ice Beam in terms of coverage.

  • Earthquake: While not particularly strong, Earthquake is highly recommended for 2HKOing Heatran and 3HKOing opposing Assault Vest Hisuian Goodra, as both of these will wall this set otherwise.

  • Flamethrower: For other Steel-types like Gholdengo and Scizor, Flamethrower will deal much more damage than Earthquake.

  • Modest versus Quiet: The importance of mirror matches makes Modest an appealing option for Hisuian Goodra, but Quiet will ensure that all but the bulkiest Flutter Mane will need to Terastallize to avoid an OHKO from Heavy Slam.

Other Options

  • Surf: Surf is a decent option to hit Ground-types and Heatran with one attack, but Surf will, at best, usually only 3HKO Heatran.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Despite Hisuian Goodra's superb typing, its common weaknesses to Ground and Fighting make Terastallization a valuable route for it.

  • Flying: Tera Flying covers Hisuian Goodra's former weaknesses fantastically, even giving it an out against Fissure Dondozo. This comes at the cost of doing much worse against Iron Bundle, Thundurus-T, Zapdos, and Rotom-W though.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy still gives Hisuian Goodra a vital Fighting resistance, as well as being a good defensive typing in general.

  • Water: Tera Water has good synergy with Sap Sipper, giving Hisuian Goodra a sole weakness to Electric, in addition to gaining a useful Ice resistance against Chien-Pao, at the cost of doing worse against Iron Bundle.

Minor Optimizations

  • Female Gender: If using Heavy Slam, there is a a chance that Hisuian Goodra can become infatuated by the very rare Cute Charm Enamorus, making a female gender very slightly superior.

Armor Press.description:
• Hisuian Goodra's bulk lends itself naturally to boosting its Defense for Body Press, especially with a useful immunity to critical hits that gives it a great matchup against Urshifu formes after Terastallization.

  • Heavy Slam: As Flutter Mane is the most dangerous Special Attacker in the format, Heavy Slam is the best Steel-type STAB move, OHKOing all but the most defensive Flutter Mane if they don't Terastallize.

  • Protect: Protect has good synergy with Leftovers for extra healing, though Urshifu formes can ignore it.

  • Draco Meteor versus Ice Beam: If using a Sassy or Relaxed nature, Draco Meteor can threaten to 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo. Ice Beam, on the other hand, is a safer and stronger option against Landorus-T and Garchomp.

Other Options

  • Rest and Chesto Berry: Rest and Chesto Berry combine to give Hisuian Goodra a great way to restore health, though the combination is only reliable once.

  • Life Dew: Life Dew doesn't restore much health even with Leftovers, but it can help Hisuian Goodra last longer against some physical threats after setting up.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Hisuian Goodra's fantastic typing doesn't make Terastallization a requirement, but it does make setting up against major physical threats like Urshifu-R and Landorus-T much more feasible.

  • Flying: Tera Flying not only covers all of Hisuian Goodra's former weaknesses, but it also means Fissure is no longer an option to break through its boosts from the likes of Dondozo or Ting-Lu. The new weaknesses to Electric and Ice can harm it though, since Electric- and Ice-type coverage moves are commonly special.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Hisuian Goodra shielding from both Urshifu formes without giving it the harmful Electric and Ice weaknesses that Flying does, though it can harm mirror matches against Assault Vest Hisuian Goodra.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful or Sassy: This specially defensive spread is Hisuian Goodra's best shot at avoiding a 2HKO from Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Tera Fairy Moonblast, assuming extra Leftovers recovery from Protect.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish or Relaxed: Maximum physical bulk means Hisuian Goodra won't check Flutter Mane nearly as well, but it let will let Body Press become a better sweeping tool.

Minor Optimizations

  • Acid Armor: Acid Armor is the best option for boosting Defense due to its higher PP, but it requires Hisuian Sligoo to evolve while knowing the move in either Scarlet or Violet, as it's not able to be relearned by Hisuian Goodra. Shelter is still a viable, albeit strictly inferior, option.

  • Female Gender: While very rare, Heavy Slam being a contact move means Hisuian Goodra does risk of activating Enamorus's Cute Charm, making a female gender a marginally better choice.

RegenVest.description: RegenVest Hisuian Goodra is a great defensive Pokemon with access to strong STAB moves, phazing, and a wide range of coverage, making it capable of switching into special attackers such as Gholdengo, Iron Moth, and Walking Wake while not being entirely passive. Dragon Tail lets Hisuian Goodra force out setup sweepers such as Gholdengo and Manaphy, as well as racking up chip damage. Knock Off is a great option against Gholdengo, and it also cripples switch-ins such as RegenVest Manaphy, Swampert, and Meloetta. Hisuian Goodra has many options to fill the last two moveslots based on its team's needs: Earthquake hits Ceruledge, Heatran, and opposing Hisuian Goodra, while Flamethrower hits Corviknight and does more damage to non-Well Baked Body Gholdengo than Knock Off when its item has been removed already. Thunderbolt hits non-Volt Absorb Corviknight and Manaphy, Ice Beam threatens Great Tusk and Dragonite, and Draco Meteor is a strong STAB move that can OHKO Walking Wake and does significant damage to Roaring Moon. Hisuian Goodra lacks pivoting unlike other RegenVest users such as Manaphy and Meloetta, so it finds its place on bulkier teams that can afford hard switching. Hisuian Goodra pairs well with strong but frail offensive threats such as Galarian Zapdos, wearing down the opponent's team and giving these threats the opportunity to clean up. Entry hazard removers such as Corviknight are great partners for Hisuian Goodra, allowing it to make full use of Regenerator. It also pairs well with hazard setters such as Deoxys-S thanks to Knock Off's ability to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from foes and Dragon Tail's phazing. Hisuian Goodra heavily relies on its item to function, so it dislikes being hit by Knock Off from Roaring Moon and Walking Wake; it also struggles against physical attackers such as Iron Boulder and Galarian Zapdos, so physically defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight and Deoxys-D are great partners, as they can take hits for it, with the former also being able to absorb Knock Off.

Demon (Steel).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Dual Screens (Fairy).description:
Klefki is a popular choice for Fairy-type teams due to Prankster, dual screens, and Spikes. This set excels at enabling setup sweepers such as Mimikyu and Azumarill providing them with boosted bulk and chipping the opposing team thanks to Spikes. With maximum HP and Defense EVs and Foul Play, Klefki efficiently counters opposing Swords Dance and Dragon Dance sweepers such as Scizor and Dragonite. Alternatively, it can use Thunder Wave to cripple fast threats like Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant. Klefki’s Steel typing also provides a useful immunity against Poison-type teams and blocks Glimmora's Mortal Spin, ensuring that entry hazards remain on the opposing field.

Belly Drum Azumarill is an excellent partner for Klefki, as the dual screens greatly facilitate setting up with Belly Drum and sweeping opposing teams. Additionally, Spikes provide some chip damage to ensure OHKOs on foes like Meowscarada. Choice Specs Flutter Mane can also take advantage of the chip damage from Klefki's Spikes to power through teams and more easily defeat walls such as Toxapex, Quagsire, and Amoonguss. Calm Mind Flutter Mane benefits both dual screens to set up and sweep and from Thunder Wave slowing down threats like Barraskewda. Iron Valiant appreciates Klefki slowing down faster foes like Flutter Mane, Cinderace, and Dragapult with Thunder Wave, allowing it to defeat them. Iron Valiant also provides a much-needed offensive pressure against Steel-types like Kingambit and works as a devastating offensive core when paired with Flutter Mane. Hatterene and Klefki form a strong defensive core, with the former’s Magic Bounce punishing any attempt from Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Forretress to set entry hazards, while the latter can come in on Poison-type moves, potentially forcing a switch on a Choice locked Pokemon like Greninja in the process. The additional bulk that Hatterene receives from the dual screens even allows it to take a stand against foes such as Glimmora, Clodsire, and Toxapex, preventing them from setting their hazards while countering them.

Dual Screens (Steel).description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Screen Setter (Fairy).description: Klefki is the ideal dual screens setter on Fairy due to its Steel typing, which negates Poison-type attacks from Nihilego and Alolan Muk and ability to fend off threats like Mega Scizor with Foul Play. Klefki is a better option than Grimmsnarl due to its typing and ability to set up Spikes, which, like its screens, go up quickly with Prankster. This support allows for Pokemon like Tapu Bulu and Azumarill from setting up and sweeping, teams. Foul Play prevents Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Mimikyu to set up and sweep while Thunder Wave cripples foes and allows Mega Diancie to outspeed threats such as +1 Mega Charizard X and Nihilego, which will normally beat Klefki one on one. Setting up Spikes creates solid chip damage on Alolan Muk and Gholdengo, allowing for late-game sweeping from its teammates Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Mega Diancie punishes opponents trying to set up entry hazards against Klefki and beats Fire-types such as Heatran and Mega Charizard Y. Tapu Bulu helps Klefki with Grassy Terrain, which halves the damage it takes from Earthquake, making Pokemon such as Iron Treads and Mamoswine not hit as hard.

Rapid Spin.description:
Mirror Coat can be used over Body Press with Sturdy to allow Avalugg to live a special attack from full HP and OHKO its foe in return.

This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Sturdy Support.description:
• With incredible Defense and the ability Sturdy, Avalugg finds a niche on stall-based teams as a physical wall that prevents fishing for OHKOs.

  • Icicle Crash versus Avalanche: While Avalanche has bigger damage potential when Avalugg is attacked head on, its defensive profile normally forces switches. This makes Icicle Crash the more consistent option for overall damage.

  • Toxic Support Partners: Even though Avalugg stops foes such as Dondozo from using Fissure, it lacks the power to cleanly beat these targets on its own. Common stall teammates such as Toxapex and Clodsire can bring Toxic or Toxic Spikes to spread status, allowing Avalugg to simply stall while poison wears down the opposition.

  • EV Spread: Full investment into HP and Defense give Avalugg insane physical bulk. Even Choice Band Chien-Pao’s Sacred Sword isn’t a reliable 2HKO!

Other Options

  • Mirror Coat: Combined with Sturdy, Mirror Coat is a tempting last resort against the special attackers that Avalugg can’t wall. However, this almost assuredly destroys Avalugg’s survivability afterwards, which can compromise the defensive cycle of its team.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Situational: Most commonly a member of stall-based teams, Avalugg’s bad matchups are supposed to be covered by the team’s defensive cycle. Tera is normally only used if it is necessary to prevent the collapse of said defensive cycle.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting balances offense and defense, making dealing with physical Fighting- and Rock-type attacks much more manageable and giving a sizable boost to Avalugg’s best attack in Body Press.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost lets Avalugg escape from precarious situations against trapping moves and Gothitelle. It also outright walls Close Combat from the likes of Iron Hands and Iron Valiant, although the new Dark-type weakness significantly worsens its matchup with Chien-Pao.

  • Poison: Tera Poison is another option for weakening Fighting-type moves directed at Avalugg while also blocking Toxic and allowing for Toxic Spikes absorption later in the match.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Since Avalugg can expect to do a lot of switching, removing its vulnerability to Stealth Rock damage is extremely important for its longevity and preservation of Sturdy.

  • Rocky Helmet: Avalugg can punish many physical attackers it switches into with Rocky Helmet chip, slowly wearing them down without having to be offensively involved.

Offensive Pivot.description: Investment in defense helps it stomach a hit from Choice Scarf Zarude. Can go max max offensive too.

Fur Coat.description: Fur Coat Yveltal is an effective wall capable of checking threatening physical and mixed wallbreakers like Mega Garchomp, Magic Guard Mega Mewtwo X, and No Retreat Ghost-types. Knock Off is a reasonably strong STAB attack and provides useful utility, while Revelation Dance hits Arceus-Ghost harder and allows Yveltal to check Normalize users. Haze and Parting Shot are useful against No Retreat Arceus-Ghost, with Parting Shot also providing pivoting but matching up worse against Nasty Plot Arceus-Ghost. Calm Mind is an option in tandem with Revelation Dance to also check Arceus-Ghost effectively, although all Fairy-types must be removed before attempting to sweep with it. Yveltal's powerful Dark-type STAB moves deter Ghost-types, making it an effective user of Rapid Spin. If entry hazard removal is not needed, Will-O-Wisp and Nuzzle act as options for neutering threats like Mega Mewtwo X. Ability Shield is an alternative to Heavy-Duty Boots to offer a much better matchup against Teravolt Kartana and Mega Mewtwo X, but Yveltal then requires strong hazard removal and still falls prey to Sword of Ruin variants. Yveltal is susceptible to threats like Mega Diancie and Kyurem-B, so Steel- and Fire-types like Solgaleo, Zacian-C, and Victini are good teammates, and they can also provide a degree of scouting against Choice Band Mega Mewtwo X. Aforementioned offensive threats like Magic Guard Mega Mewtwo X can be Imposter-proofed by Yveltal. Knock Off variants can be Imposter-proofed by Arceus formes, while Revelation Dance sets can be Imposter-proofed by Chansey.

Mixed Wallbreaker (Rock).description: Mega Diancie is the ideal Mega Evolution for Rock teams due to its ability to check Dragon-types like Kommo-o, punish passive Pokemon and entry hazard setters such as Toxapex and Klefki with Magic Bounce, and be a mixed wallbreaker that threatens Great Tusk and Galarian Slowking. Diamond Storm does considerable damage to special walls like Blissey and Alolan Muk and can also provide a Defense boost. Psychic heavily damages Mega Venusaur, Toxapex, and Nidoking, which eases the matchup against Poison teams. Earth Power deals heavy damage to Steel-type Pokemon like Heatran and Iron Treads and is paired nicely with Mystical Fire to damage Skarmory and Corviknight. On a hyper offensive team, Mega Diancie runs four attacks for coverage. With Shuckle's Sticky Web up, its good Speed tier becomes more devastating and outspeeds Pokemon like Mega Gallade and Zeraora. Mega Diancie also pairs well with Omastar and Terrakion, as Omastar takes care of the Ground matchup with a well-timed Shell Smash, while Terrakion's access to Earthquake and Close Combat takes care of most Steel-types. On bulky offense, Mega Diancie prefers to run Spikes, as the chip damage sets up a potential late-game cleanup from more offensive Pokemon on the team like Terrakion and Nihilego. Garganacl pairs well with Spikes, as Salt Cure forces a lot of Pokemon to switch out and take additional chip damage.

Mixed Wallbreaker (Fairy).description: Mega Diancie is a valuable asset to Fairy teams, featuring Magic Bounce to deflect entry hazards and status, wide coverage, and strong offensive capabilities with its high Speed. Diamond Storm often increases Mega Diancie's bulk and threatens foes like Enamorus and Mega Charizard Y. Moonblast handles threats like Mega Sableye and Latias. Earth Power can be used to counter Steel teams, OHKOing Heatran, Excadrill, and Magnezone, while dealing heavy damage to the likes of Skeledirge and Garganacl. Mystical Fire targets Steel-types that don't mind Earth Power, such as Ferrothorn, Celesteela, and Mega Scizor under Psychic Terrain. Alternatively, Mega Diancie can run Nature Power and use the various terrains set by its teammates to expand its wallbreaking abilities. Stealth Rock can be used to allow Mega Diancie to set its own hazard, but four attacks are recommended given Mega Diancie's wide coverage. Klefki provides Spikes and dual screens support which allows Mega Diancie to OHKO threats like Gholdengo, and it can also carry Thunder Wave to let Mega Diancie outspeed and take out threats like Mega Gallade and Mega Aerodactyl. Tapu Koko takes on Water-types and aids in the Steel matchup by forcing out Corviknight and Celesteela. Tapu Bulu counters Ground- and Water-types like Great Tusk and Urshifu-R, while Tapu Lele takes on Poison-types and prevents priority moves from Azumarill and Mega Scizor. Iron Valiant is a great partner for the Steel matchup, but it also benefits from Tapu Koko's Electric Terrain to outspeed and take out faster threats such as Zeraora and Greninja. All of these teammates appreciate Mega Diancie's ability to bounce hazards back to the opponent, as Fairy teams do not possess entry hazard removal.

Mixed Wallbreaker.description: Mega Diancie cements itself as an excellent mixed attacker, capable of punching through defensive cores with its superb STAB moves and coverage. Mystical Fire punishes Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor for attempting to switch into and take advantage of it. Alternatively, Earth Power significantly dents or OHKOes Heatran and hits Gholdengo and Clodsire harder. Mega Diancie acts as an excellent entry hazard stacker, as it takes advantage of the switches it forces and threatens out common entry hazard removers such as Tornadus-T and Great Tusk. Mega Diancie can use Spikes or Stealth Rock to weaken checks such as Mega Scizor and Heatran, depending on its coverage move, while punishing them for attempting to pivot into it. A Naive nature is preferred, as it allows Mega Diancie to take less damage from common priority moves in Kingambit's Sucker Punch and Mega Lopunny's Fake Out. However, Mega Diancie can also use Hasty in order to sponge Hurricane from Tornadus-T. Mega Diancie fits best on bulky offense and offense teams, which appreciate its early- or mid-game wallbreaking and ability to set entry hazards. Pokemon that appreciate Mega Diancie weakening common Steel-types such as Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Dragapult pair well with it, using their higher Speed tiers to clean late-game. Additionally, Mega Diancie pairs well with Knock Off users like Tornadus-T and Kingambit, as they make Mega Diancie's entry hazards more effective and force checks such as Toxapex and Clodsire to succumb to them. Mega Diancie can struggle with entering the field given its relative frailty and poor defensive typing, which also gives it a tendency to be revenge killed by Pokemon like Mega Swampert and Zamazenta. As such, pivots that can bring it in safely such as Tornadus-T, Rotom-W, and Landorus-T make for good partners.

Trick Room Sweeper.description:
• Diancie is an effective offensive Trick Room setter due to its low Speed and high Attack, allowing it to punch holes in the opposing team. Its high defensive stats make it very difficult to take out in a single attack and demands whittling it down with multiple neutral attacks instead of super effective attacks, out of fear of activating Weakness Policy.

  • Diamond Storm hits a lot of top threats, notably 2HKOing Chien-Pao, Dragonite, and Volcanion. Gaining Defense boosts from it also helps Diancie against physical attackers such as Rillaboom and Palafin.

  • Body Press synergizes very well with Defense boosts from Diamond Storm, giving Diancie useful coverage to hit foes it would normally have a tough matchup against such as Kingambit and Hisuian Goodra.

  • Trick Room allows Diancie to support itself and its teammates such as Iron Hands and Torkoal by turning their low Speed into an advantage. Diancie is an effective Trick Room setter as it is hard to remove and, unlike other Trick Room setters such as Cresselia, has the offensive capabilities to make the most of it.

  • Foes must always be wary of Weakness Policy, as activating it turns Diancie into a fearsome sweeper. As such, Diancie forces opponents to either OHKO it or whittle it down with multiple neutral attacks, as a weak super effective attack into the bulky Diancie will put it in a commanding position. This is especially effective once Diancie has accrued enough Defense boosts, as even Rillaboom's Wood Hammer and Palafin's Wave Crash may not OHKO it anymore. Diancie can also use Mental Herb to guarantee it sets up Trick Room once against Taunt users such as Tornadus and Landorus-T.

  • Tera Grass allows Diancie to resist the Grass-, Water-, and Ground-type attacks that would otherwise OHKO it before a before a Defense boost such as Rillaboom's Wood Hammer, Palafin's Wave Crash, and Landorus's Earth Power. It also removes Diancie's 4x Steel-type weakness, which helps it matchup better against Steel-type foes like Heatran and Gholdengo and Pokemon with Steel-type coverage such as Iron Hands. Tera Grass also grants Diancie an immunity to powder moves, preventing Amoonguss's Spore from affecting it and circumventing Rage Powder.

  • Clear Body notably makes Diancie immune to Landorus-T's Intimidate and Grimmsnarl's Parting Shot, allowing Diancie to maintain a constant offensive presence on the field during its valuable Trick Room turns.

  • A Sassy Nature and maximum HP investment allow Diancie to survive a Steam Eruption from Volcanion. 24 Defense EVs allow Diancie to survive a Jolly Ogerpon-Wellspring Ivy Cudgel.

  • Diancie enables Trick Room attackers like Kingambit, Torkoal, and Glastrier to sweep alongside it. Diancie wants Fake Out support to help set up Trick Room more easily. Rillaboom is a Fake Out user that can eliminate Palafin and provide Grassy Terrain recovery , while Iron Hands functions better under Trick Room specifically and deals with Volcanion and Kingambit better. Amoonguss also acts as a great partner for Diancie, with its Rage Powder and Spore protecting it from the Ground, Water, and Steel attacks that would threaten it. Pollen Puff also helps to increase its longevity.

Special Wallbreaker.description: Hoopa is a passable wallbreaker that fits on offensive teams, particularly when paired with Sticky Web support from Masquerain and Spidops and teammates that can pivot it in safely. Psyshock allows Hoopa to hit special walls like Blissey on their weaker physical bulk, while Knock Off cripples RegenVest users like Alolan Muk and Meloetta that can otherwise take a hit and threaten a KO or pivot out to a faster offensive threat like Chien-Pao. Focus Blast 2HKOes Hisuian Goodra and KOes Kingambit that would attempt to switch in. Defensive pivots that can take a hit and pivot out like Corviknight and Meloetta can get Hoopa in safely. Dual screens setters like Prankster Corviknight and Mew also make for a good partner, as they allow Hoopa to have an easier time setting up with Nasty Plot or tank a hit in a pinch and retaliate. Offensive pivots like Slither Wing and Galarian Zapdos pair well with Hoopa with their ability to bait in and pivot out on checks like Corviknight and defensive Zapdos, allowing Hoopa to set up and threaten a KO; faster offensive threats like Chien-Pao and Barraskewda also pair well with it by making up for its lackluster Speed while Hoopa threatens out their checks like defensive Quaquaval.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Hoopa-U is an extremely strong physical wallbreaker that can be very threatening to more balanced and defensive teams due to its massive Attack stat and reliable STAB move in Hyperspace Fury, which is capable of impressive feats such as 2HKOing physically defensive Corviknight and Toxapex the majority of the time and always 2HKOing physically defensive Rotom-W. Zen Headbutt is a nice complementary STAB move, allowing Hoopa-U to smack prominent Fighting-types like Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Iron Valiant that may try to switch in on a predicted Hyperspace Fury. Drain Punch hits Dark-types like Kingambit and Ting-Lu, while Gunk Shot offers coverage against Fairy-types like Enamorus and Azumarill, as well as Tera Fairy Moltres, Garganacl, Kingambit, and Baxcalibur. A Jolly nature allows Hoopa-U to outspeed Pokemon like Timid Heatran, Modest Gholdengo, and Timid Volcanion, while an Adamant nature allows Hoopa-U to hit even harder, 2HKOing Garganacl the majority of the time. Tera Dark boosts the power of Hyperspace Fury even further, 2HKOing physically defensive Dondozo; Tera Dark also offers the additional benefit of making Hoopa-U resist other Dark-type attacks, which can be crucial against Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Hoopa-U fits well on bulky offense teams that are in need of a physical wallbreaker. Physical setup sweepers like Kingambit, Baxcalibur, and Dragonite appreciate Hoopa-U's presence on a team, as Hoopa-U is able to break through or dent physically defensive Pokemon that could stand in their way, like Dondozo, Great Tusk, and Rotom-W. One of Hoopa-U's biggest challenges is safely getting on the field due to its frail physical defense and quadruple weakness to U-turn, so it pairs well with pivots such as Chilly Reception Galarian Slowking, U-turn Dragapult, and Volt Switch Zapdos. Hoopa-U is also held back by its middling Speed, which tends to exacerbate Hoopa-U's physical frailty, so it appreciates paralysis support from partners like Rotom-W and Substitute Dragapult. Static Zapdos is a particularly notable partner for Hoopa-U, because it is able to switch in and potentially paralyze faster Pokemon like Cinderace and Dragapult, rendering those Pokemon no longer threatening to Hoopa-U. Pokemon that can set entry hazards like Ting-Lu, Heatran, and Landorus-T help facilitate with Hoopa-U breaking through its switch-ins. Opposing physical Dark-types, such as Kingambit, Hisuian Samurott, and Roaring Moon, typically force Hoopa-U out, especially after a Defense drop.
