However, Tera Water does the same, exchanging a bad matchup against Dragon-types such as Gabite for one against Electric- and Grass-types such as Raichu, Electrode, and Flapple.

Perrserker's best teammates are ones that appreciate having Stealth Rock set up and being able to enter the game safely. As such, strong sweepers that struggle to switch in safely otherwise such as Quiver Dance Masquerain, Swords Dance Charizard, and Zangoose are excellent partners. Fire- and Ground-type switch-ins such as Carbink, the aforementioned Charizard, and Gabite are also good partners. Electric-types such as Ampharos, Raichu, and Electrode can create a threatening VoltTurn combination with Perrserker. Pokemon such as Gabite and Pyroar appreciate having Perrserker come in on Pokemon that would normally threaten them out, such as Articuno, Lycanroc-N Choice-locked into Stone Edge, and Dachsbun, and force them to switch out while setting Stealth Rock to support the rest of its teammates.

Assault Vest Pivot.description: Perrserker's Steel typing and access to U-turn make it an excellent defensive pivot. With an Assault Vest, Perrserker can sponge a hit from special attackers like Appletun, Jolteon, and Zoroark and retaliate back with Tough Claws-boosted moves. Close Combat hits staples like Chansey and Jolteon, as well as Tera Steel users like Appletun and Eelektross. Seed Bomb hits Sandaconda without worrying about Rocky Helmet, as well as Water-types like Bruxish and Vaporeon. Tough Claws-boosted Fake Out is a great contingency against setup sweepers, allowing Perrserker to get free damage against them by pivoting in and out until Fake Out KOes. Perrserker uses Tera Ghost to turn the tables on Fighting-types like Passimian and Toxicroak, but Tera Fighting or Grass can be used to boost its coverage move. Perrserker's ability to pivot effectively means powerful breakers that appreciate free entry like Bruxish and Clawitzer make for great partners; these two in particular also greatly threaten common Perrserker checks like Sandaconda and Oricorio-F. Perrserker also works effectively with other pivots like Rotom and Scyther to create strong VoltTurn cores.

Quiver Dance (Bug).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Normal

Shadow ball can be run instead of Trick to hit Gholdengo and Ceruledge, helping in the Ghost matchup. Doing so will lose Indeedee the ability to Choice-lock walls like Corviknight and Ting-Lu, which can be a pain to break through.

Choice Scarf (Normal).description:
Indeedee is a good Choice Scarf user on Normal teams due to its decent Speed stat, being able to outspeed threats like Zamazenta and Okidogi. Thanks to its part-Psychic typing, it is able to take out foes like Iron Valiant and Urshifu-R with Expanding Force. Combining Psychic Surge with Expanding Force allows Indeedee to take out threats like Zamazenta, Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Toxapex. Dazzling Gleam lets Indeedee pressure Dark-, Fighting-, and Dragon-types like Choice Specs Greninja, Scrafty, and Hydreigon. Trick can punish common walls like Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and Empoleon, while Healing Wish provides support for the team.

Choice Specs Hisuian Zoroark is a nice teammate for Indeedee, being able to check Ghost-, Steel- and Psychic-types like Ceruledge, Archaludon, and Metagross. Hisuian Zoroark also provides help by using Trick to Choice-lock walls like Alolan Muk and Assault Vest Iron Hands. Indeedee returns the favor by taking out bulky foes like Clodsire and Toxapex and providing immunity against Sucker Punch Kingambit while the Psychic Terrain from its ability remains active. Ditto helps Indeedee as a late-game wincon by transforming into Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Gouging Fire in the Dark, Dragon, and Fire matchups, respectively, reverse sweeping when possible. Smeargle is a nice entry hazard setter, providing Spikes and Sticky Web for Indeedee to slow down fast Choice Scarf users like Sneasler, Urshifu-R, and Roaring Moon. Calm Mind Ursaluna-B deals with specially defensive Pokemon that Indeedee can't break like Alolan Muk, Hisuian Goodra, and Tyranitar. In return, Indeedee takes out Iron Valiant and Urshifu-R without Choice Scarf for Ursaluna-B and Smeargle. Blissey is a nice teammate that can tank special hits from foes like Greninja and Flutter Mane while also setting Stealth Rock and spreading paralysis with Thunder Wave. Porygon2 is a good defensive wall that is able to tank hits from Ogerpon formes, Gouging Fire, and Ceruledge while also checking them with Foul Play. Porygon2 also pressures Flying-types like Corviknight, Dragonite, and Mandibuzz with Discharge and Ice Beam. Indeedee doesn't like hazards, so Braviary is a great option that can remove hazards with Defog while taking out foes like Lokix and Hisuian Samurott with Brave Bird and Close Combat, respectively. Terapagos is another option due to its colorful moveset, including BoltBeam coverage that can take out Skarmory, Garchomp, and Landorus, and it can also remove hazards for the team with Rapid Spin. Terapagos's signature move Tera Starstorm allows Terapagos to dent bulky Pokemon. Loaded Dice Cinccino can be a physical sweeper and hazard remover with Tidy Up. Cinccino also has great coverage, including moves that can deal with Ground-, Water-, Flying-, Dragon-, and Ice-types with Bullet Seed, Triple Axel, and Rock Blast.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to Battle Stadium Singles Regulation F! This Pokemon has been updated to reflect the new Pokemon that The Indigo Disk has brought!

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Terrain Setter.description:
• Indeedee's Psychic Surge sets up powerful allies like Psychic Seed Sneasler and Expanding Force Iron Crown.

  • Dazzling Gleam: While generally weak, Dazzling Gleam is the best way to pressure Dark-types like Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon that are immune to Expanding Force.

  • Encore: Encore helps prevent Indeedee from getting set up on while also creating openings for its teammates.

  • Shadow Ball: Shadow Ball is almost exclusively for hitting Gholdengo, which can otherwise be troublesome for common Indeedee cores.

  • Healing Wish: Healing Wish is used less for its healing and more for its ability to pivot teammates in safely though at the cost of Indeedee itself.

  • Terrain Preservation: Targets such as Ice Spinner Urshifu-R and Grassy Surge Rillaboom can remove Indeedee's terrain. For this reason, it is sometimes better to lead with a teammate that can scout for these threats.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Common partners like Sneasler tend to be far more Terastallization hungry than Indeedee, so it should be preserved outside of fringe cases.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy turns Indeedee's Dark- and Bug-type weaknesses into resistances while giving Dazzling Gleam a nice boost.

  • Psychic: Tera Psychic is a simple offensive option, pushing Expanding Force's power even farther.

  • Stellar: Tera Stellar lets Indeedee diversify its offensive profile, such as making it easier to 2HKO semi-bulky Gholdengo with Shadow Ball.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 76 Def / 180 Spe with Timid: This bulky EV spread survives Ursaluna-B's Blood Moon and almost always survives Adamant Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash and Adamant Landorus-T's Earthquake. The Speed EVs outspeed Adamant Urshifu formes and Modest Iron Crown.

  • 12 HP / 44 Def / 196 SpA / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Timid: This offensive EV spread avoids the OHKO from defensive Landorus-T's Earthquake. It goes less bulky, however, because it wants to be OHKOed by Jolly Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash; this helps secure the most turns of Psychic Terrain possible for teammates.

Choice Scarf Support.description:
• This set's write-up has not started yet, but here's some basic info to get you started!

  • Support Moves: Encore is generally best used if also using Trick. It's even possible to use all 3 support moves at the cost of a decent matchup against Urshifu-S.

Choice.description:
Indeedee-F's combination of a solid Speed tier with Choice Scarf, synergistic ability in Psychic Surge allowing it to block priotity moves and boosting its Psychic-type attacks, and a strong STAB combination allow it to become one of PU's best revenge killers and wallbreakers. Trick allows Indeedee-F to debilitate walls that would otherwise wall it, such as Tinkatuff and Misdreavus. Psyshock hits Special Walls such as Articuno and Lumineon harder due to their weaker physical bulk, but Psychic can be used instead, as it does more damage to more physically bulky Pokemon such as Perrserker and Gabite. Indeedee-F's last two moveslots are very flexible; Hyper Voice provides a strong alternative STAB move which also allows Indeedee-F to damage Dark-types such as Houndoom. Tera Blast provides a STAB move before Terastallizing and can be used with a Ground or Fairy Tera to allow Indeedee-F to hit Steel-types and Dark-types that would normally check it such as Perrserker, Tinkatuff, and Skuntank; however, it is weaker than Hyper Voice. Healing Wish can sacrificially and allow a partner Pokemon to come back in healthy after it has been damaged, building momentum. Indeedee-F can also viably run Tera Psychic, boosting up its Psychic-type attacks even further. Indeedee-F's preferred item is Choice Scarf, which allows it to act as a solid revenge killer against threats such as Alolan Persian and Zangoose, aswell as outspeeding other Choice Scarf users such as Skuntank, Lycanroc-N, and Honchkrow. Alternatively, Indeedee-F can opt for a Choice Specs set that allows it to be very powerful, enabling to OHKO or 2HKO the majority of the tier.

Indeedee-F's main flaws are having issues breaking through common Steel- and Dark-types such as Tinkatuff and Skuntank if it does not want to Terastallize, or a teammate had previously Terastillized and it's difficult to get in safely. As such, Pokemon like Dugtrio, Charizard, and Carbink are excellent partners. Dugtrio in particular is an excellent partner, as with Indeedee's Psychic Terrain it does not fear getting revenged killed from priority from Basculin's Aqua Jet and Zangoose's Quick Attack. U-turn and Volt Switch from Pokemon such as Articuno and Ampharos can give Indeedee-F a free switch in the battle. Sticky Web Masquerain can be used with Choice Specs variants to help with the lackluster speed. Pokemon that struggle against walls, like Golduck, appreciate Choice Specs Indeedee-F breaking through bulkier foes like Articuno and Gogoat. Pokemon normally easily revenged killed by priority such as Pyroar and the aforementioned Dugtrio appreciate having Indeedee-F help keep their HP high with Healing Wish as well as setting up Psychic Terrian.

Redirection Support.description: • The given EV Spread survives a Rillaboom Wood Hammer in Grassy Terrain.

Slush Rush (Ice).description:
A Naughty nature lets Arctozolt OHKO Physically Defensive Toxapex with Bolt Beak after Stealth Rock damage and should be in tandem with Freeze-Dry to fully threaten Water teams as it deals with Swampert. On the other hand, a Naive nature lets Arctozolt outspeed Zeraora and Choice Scarf Excadrill under Snow, making Stomping Tantrum a better choice if using the aforementioned nature.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Snow Sweeper.description: Arctozolt carves itself a niche as a snow sweeper and wallbreaker thanks to Slush Rush and its powerful offensive STAB moves, hitting foes such as Landorus-T, Toxapex, and Slowbro. Slush Rush lets Arctozolt outspeed the entire unboosted metagame under snow, including foes such as Dragapult and Weavile, though its inability to outspeed boosted foes such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and its pitiful Speed outside of snow hinders its sweeping potential. Freeze-Dry is an alternative to Blizzard that lets Arctozolt break through foes such as Gastrodon and Mega Swampert, but the lack of consistency outside of these matchups makes it a less desirable choice. Low Kick provides coverage for foes such as Ferrothorn, Kingambit, and Mega Tyranitar. Substitute takes advantage of forced switches against foes such as the aforementioned Toxapex and Tornadus-T to ease prediction and avoid potential revenge killers such as the aforementioned Tapu Lele, Mega Scizor, and Mega Lopunny. The Defense boost from snow also helps preserve Arctozolt's Substitute, granting it more safe turns. Heavy-Duty Boots alleviates Arctozolt's major Stealth Rock weakness, granting it more opportunities to wallbreak. Alternatively, Leftovers can be used with entry hazard control to improve Arctozolt's longevity and grant more opportunities to use Substitute. Tera Electric is used to boost Bolt Beak's power and remove Arctozolt's weakness to Stealth Rock, but it loses the Defense boost from snow. Slowking is a mandatory teammate to support Arctozolt, setting snow and acting as a slow pivot to grant it safe entry. Mega Diancie provides entry hazard support to weaken foes such as Ferrothorn and helps deny opposing entry hazards for Arctozolt. Arctozolt struggles against revenge killers such as Mega Scizor and Choice Scarf Kartana, so it appreciates teammates such as Heatran and Tornadus-T handling them. Tornadus-T also provides reliable entry hazard removal so Arctozolt can use Leftovers.

Boots Pivot.description:
Dragapult is one of OU's best pivots, with its massive base Speed stat allowing it to dance around slower threats, spread status and deal significant damage over the course of a game. Dragon Darts is a strong STAB option that hits key targets in the tier such as Roaring Moon, Raging Bolt, and Dragonite, with the given spread running enough Attack investment to OHKO Kyurem after Stealth Rock damage. Alternatively, Draco Meteor can be used with an EV spread fully invested into Special Attack that lets it secure an OHKO into Walking Wake and Gouging Fire while also giving Dragapult a more powerful Hex to 2HKO even max HP Gholdengo, but the Special Attack drop from Draco Meteor leaves it vulnerable to being used as setup fodder, and this set is also weaker into sweepers that boost their Special Defense such as Raging Bolt and Volcarona. Both Will-O-Wisp and Thunder Wave are great options that synergize with the rest of Dragapult's toolkit by doubling the power of Hex; Will-O-Wisp turns Dragapult into a great fast check that can outrun and neutralize physical threats such as Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and Kingambit while also forcing chip on Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Clodsire that try to switch in, while Thunder Wave slows down targets like Volcarona to help teammates deal with them more easily. Tera Fairy is a great defensive option that flips Dragapult's Dragon weakness into an immunity while also granting a Dark resistance to resist hits from Kingambit and Darkrai, whereas Tera Ghost powers up Hex while still dropping its weaknesses to Fairy and Dragon to help block revenge killing attempts by Enamorus.

Heavy-Duty Boots Dragapult is a fantastic pick on balance teams, synergizing well with durable hazard setters such as Skarmory, Gliscor, and Ting-Lu that can assist in chipping down the switch-ins that it forces. In return, Dragapult helps to patch up bulkier teams' lack of speed control while not minding the hazards that they often allow on both sides of the field. Knock Off users such as Meowscarada and Weavile are solid pairings with Dragapult on these balance structures, removing Heavy-Duty Boots from opposing Pokemon to make the switches that Dragapult forces more meaningful while giving Dragapult opportunities to come in for free on their own checks, allowing these teams to better pressure opposing Skarmory and Corviknight. Bulkier offense teams also benefit from the presence of Dragapult as a form of speed control that wears down defensive cores with both damage and status effects; Kingambit in particular is a terrifying late-game sweeper that appreciates Dragapult's ability to weaken a team for it to clean through, with Will-O-Wisp Dragapult able to neuter its physical checks like Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Skarmory, while Thunder Wave variants can slow down threats that would otherwise outspeed Kingambit such as Volcarona, Cinderace, and Heatran. In turn, Dragapult often invites in opposing Kingambit, which resists its STAB options and is only threatened by its status moves, so solid switch-ins for this like Skarmory and Great Tusk are usually appreciated to prevent it from getting too many free turns. Raging Bolt in particular is a strong partner to pivot Dragapult on bulky offense teams that enjoy its support to help break through Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and specially defensive Gliscor. Heavy-Duty Boots Dragapult also struggles to muscle past bulkier checks like Toxapex and Clefable alone, so partners that can take advantage of them for setup opportunities such as Kingambit and Gholdengo are great picks. As Dragapult's Speed tier is almost unmatched in the OU metagame, Booster Energy users like Iron Boulder and Iron Valiant along with the even faster Deoxys-S are frequently forced in to revenge kill it, so more defensive teammates that can handle these threats are valued; Galarian Slowking is a good bulky pivot that takes on the latter two and can use Chilly Reception to bring in Dragapult for free after taking a hit, while both Gliscor and Skarmory are solid Iron Boulder checks that can either beat it or force it to switch out and lose its Speed boost, allowing Dragapult to outspeed it later.

Choice Specs.description:
Dragapult is an amazing source of immediate power due to its near unresisted STAB combination, solid Special Attack, and excellent Speed tier, which outspeeds the majority of the unboosted metagame except Deoxys-S. Equipping Choice Specs allows Dragapult to break through Pokemon such as Gliscor and Zamazenta with its STAB moves. Flamethrower threatens Kingambit. U-turn allows Dragapult to keep the momentum for its team and hit Dark-types like Ting-Lu and Roaring Moon. Infiltrator allows Dragapult to be a great check to dual screens teams and Substitute sweepers such as Iron Defense Zamazenta. Tera Ghost powers up its most spammable STAB attack in Shadow Ball, allowing Dragapult to further dent Galarian Slowking and secure the OHKO on Iron Valiant and Skeledirge. This also improves its matchup into Iron Valiant and Enamorus, as it takes much less damage from Moonblast, allowing it to survive a hit and KO them back. Tera Dragon raises Draco Meteor to nuclear levels, OHKOing Gliscor, Dondozo, and defensive Landorus-T, and it also improves Dragapult's matchup into Darkrai and Gholdengo, as it removes it weakness to Dark Pulse and Shadow Ball, respectively. A Modest nature can be run instead of Timid to forego outspeeding Zamazenta, Weavile, and Darkrai for higher damage output, such as OHKOing Gliscor and Serperior with Draco Meteor.

Dragapult fits well on offensive teams due to its excellent ability to break down walls such as Toxapex, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire. Therefore, Dragapult is able to benefit sweepers like Gholdengo, Raging Bolt, and Volcarona that appreciate walls being worn down. Dark- and Fairy-types like Kingambit, Roaring Moon, and Clefable are threats to Dragapult, as they are able to switch in and force it out. Therefore, checks to these such as Iron Valiant, Great Tusk, and Zamazenta make for good partners. The latter two help with Kingambit, which is Dragapult's biggest check due to resisting both of its STAB moves. Dragapult benefits from entry hazards on the opposing side of the field. Therefore, entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Gliscor are good partners for it. Knock Off support from the likes of Weavile, Roaring Moon, and Meowscarada are able to be brought in by Dragapult's U-turn, removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Kyurem and Darkrai. Meowscarada especially is a great partner, since it’s able to bring Dragapult in with its own U-turn after removing Heavy-Duty Boots, allowing Dragapult to better pressure its checks. Dragapult is not very good at switching into attacks, as it is relatively frail, so slow pivots like Galarian Slowking and Alomomola are amazing teammates. Entry hazards wear down Dragapult over time, limiting the number of times it can switch onto the field; therefore, hazard control from Great Tusk and Cinderace can help Dragapult. Deoxys-S and Booster Energy Pokemon with a Speed Boost such as Roaring Moon and Iron Valiant are able to outspeed and threaten to KO Dragapult, so speed control like Rillaboom, Raging Bolt and Kingambit make for good teammates.

Choice Band.description:
• Outrage is Dragapult's strongest move. It can defeat foes like Meowscarada and deal great damage against neutral enemies, such as Arcanine and Bellibolt.
  • Dragon Darts handles foes that may use Haban Berry, like Salamence and Garchomp.
  • Phantom Force defeats some Ghost-types like Skeledirge.
  • U-turn defeats Booster Energy Brute Bonnet, unless it raises Attack with Booster Energy.
  • Infiltrator enables Dragapult to win against Espathra.
  • Clear Body allows Dragapult to win against stall Azumarill, bulky Salamence, and stall Arcanine.
  • Being Adamant enables Dragapult to defeat Air Balloon and Booster Energy Iron Hands, the latter if it raises Attack with Booster Energy.
  • If running Jolly, Dragapult can outspeed Booster Energy Iron Bundle if it does not raise its Speed with Booster Energy.
  • Usually Dragapult should use its strongest move against the foe, but in the Annihilape matchup, Dragapult can win against some sets if it uses Outrage on the first turn, instead of Phantom Force, and Annihilape uses Bulk Up.

Choice Specs.description:
• Neutral targets that lose to Dragapult's STAB attacks include non-Speed Booster Energy Iron Bundle, Meowscarada, Donphan, and Rotom-W.
  • Fire Blast OHKOes Scizor.
  • Hydro Pump is for non-Speed Booster Energy variants of Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Sandy Shocks.
  • Thunderbolt is for non-Choice Band Dondozo and Corviknight.
  • Clear Body ensures that Dragapult's Special Attack isn't lowered by Bellibolt's Eerie Impulse. Infiltrator lets Dragapult bypass Substitute from Volcarona and Espathra.
  • Dragapult should try to avoid possible matchups against faster Pokemon such as Speed Booster Energy Walking Wake, and Iron Bundle and Choice Scarf Meowscarada, as their set versatility is high and potential matchups sometimes won't be in Dragapult's favor.

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Dragon

Spell Tag lets Dragapult OHKO Iron Valiant after it has been inflicted with status, which can be crucial in the Fighting matchup. However, Dragapult becomes much easier to wear down and will have a harder time overcoming bulkier types like Water or Poison. U-turn can be used over Substitute or Thunder Wave if using Heavy-Duty Boots to pivot in its teammates like Walking Wake to take advantage of switch-ins like Ursaluna-B and Heatran, but not having Substitute means Dragapult cannot stallbreak as well.

Hex (Dragon).description:
Hex Dragapult serves as great offensive support for Dragon teams, catching common switch-ins to Choice Specs Dragapult, such as Alolan Muk and Iron Hands, off guard by incapacitating them with Will-O-Wisp. With Substitute, Dragapult acts as a stallbreaker against types like Water, Poison, and Ground lacking Ursaluna-B, as burned defensive pivots like Clodsire will be unable to break its Substitute, allowing Dragapult to fire off powerful moves in Hex in conjunction with status ailments and Dragon Darts. Will-O-Wisp also punishes Sucker Punch users like Kingambit, granting Dragon a bit more breathing room against these threats, as well as bulky setup sweepers like Zamazenta and Corviknight. Thunder Wave can be considered if Shed Tail support from Cyclizar is available, as this allows Dragapult to neutralize threats like Iron Valiant, Volcarona, and special Choice Scarf users like Flutter Mane and Enamorus, which do not mind being burned. With 148 SpA EVs, Dragapult OHKOes Flutter Mane with Hex after it is statused, while the remaining EVs are invested in Attack and Speed to maximize the potency of Dragon Darts to make Dragapult as threatening as possible in the Dragon matchup. Infiltrator lets Dragapult OHKO statused Flutter Mane regardless, even behind Light Screen, revenge kill Frosmoth and Baxcalibur behind Substitute, and also inflict burns on Iron Defense Zamazenta behind Substitute.

Since Hex Dragapult weakens the offensive capabilities of bulky walls such as Corviknight, Alolan Muk, and Iron Hands, teammates like Dragon Dance Baxcalibur, Clangorous Soul Kommo-o, and Dragon Dance Dragonite can capitalize on these openings to set up and tear through opposing Flying-, Dark-, and Fighting-type teams. Baxcalibur also helps in breaking down bulkier types like Flying, Ground, and Poison, cleans up types like Dragon late-game, and picks off Choice Scarf Enamorus and Meowscarada with Ice Shard. Kommo-o provides powerful priority in Vacuum Wave to deal with Chien-Pao and Kingambit and has the ability to clean types such as Ice and Dark after a Clangorous Soul boost. Wallbreakers like Choice Specs Walking Wake and Choice Band Roaring Moon help Dragapult overwhelm threats such as Alolan Muk, Iron Hands, and Gholdengo, which can be hard to take down for Dragon teams. Alternatively, these teammates can don a Choice Scarf, allowing Walking Wake to deal with Chien-Pao and boosted Baxcalibur and Roaring Moon to obliterate Flutter Mane and opposing Dragapult. Entry hazard support from Grachomp and Dragalge are also great, as they make Dragapult more punishing to swap into, and Dragalge's Toxic Spikes are able to status Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant, which lets Dragapult spam Hex and prioritize getting a Substitute up in matchups like Fairy and Fighting. Garchomp also punishes prospective Knock Offs against Dragapult from Roaring Moon, Empoleon, and Iron Treads, thanks to Rough Skin and its typing to punish these threats back. Cyclizar can Shed Tail into Dragapult, enabling it to use another status move. In return, Dragapult dissuades Fighting-type attacks by its mere presence on teams, allowing Cyclizar to more safely enter the field. Cyclizar itself also supports Dragapult by providing a Ghost immunity, which is useful in dealing with foes such as Ceruledge and Gengar, and provides hazard removal to prevent Dragapult from being chipped down and let it more freely set up Substitutes. Hisuian Goodra is a great special wall that is able to take on Choice Scarf Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant for Dragapult. In return, Dragapult burns and wears down opposing defensive pieces like Iron Hands for it.

Choice Specs (Dragon).description:
As the fastest unboosted Pokemon in the Monotype metagame, Choice Specs Dragapult is an excellent offensive threat that deals with Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Greninja for Dragon teams. Draco Meteor and Shadow Ball are helpful against a variety of types lacking the necessary immunities and can be used to decimate types such as Dark, Flying, Fairy, and Ghost. Flamethrower roasts Steel-types such as Corviknight and Scizor without the risk of getting stalled by Pressure, and Thunderbolt nails Toxapex and Dondozo and cleans Water teams late-game. Alternatively, U-turn brings in team mates like Baxcalibur, Garchomp, and Hydreigon, which take advantage of common switch-ins such as Ting Lu, Clodsire, and Kingambit. Infiltrator lets Dragapult bypass dual screens, which is sorely needed to properly deal with Flutter Mane.

Since Dragapult excels at cleaning teams with its natural speed, wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Hydreigon, Baxcalibur, and Choice Band Haxorus, as well as entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Dragalge are excellent teammates. Dragonite loves Dragapult's ability to wear down or outright remove Steel-, Water-, and Ghost-types such as Klefki, Toxapex, and Skeledirge, allowing it to clean up types such as Fairy, Water, and Fire with a Dragon Dance or Choice Band set. Choice Scarf users like Baxcalibur, Hydreigon, and Roaring Moon are appreciated, as these deal with opposing Choice Scarf users such as Gallade and Gholdengo, which revenge kill Dragapult with ease. Cyclizar provides entry hazard removal and can pass a Shed Tail to Dragapult, allowing it to get in the field safely.

Choice Scarf (Dragon).description: This is a sample set as we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Hex (Ghost).description:
Dragapult carries a plethora of utility options in its movepool to hinder the opposition. It leverages its high Speed to outspeed and threaten Zamazenta, Flutter Mane, and Chien-Pao with status for its teammates. Heavy-Duty Boots also enables Dragapult to switch in much more often. Will-O-Wisp weakens physical attackers that pose a threat to Ghost teams, such as Great Tusk, Urshifu-R, and Kingambit, while Thunder Wave disrupts faster opposition such as Choice Scarf Hisuian Samurott, Ogerpon-H, and Zamazenta. Hex is also a great choice for beating Gliscor and other Pokemon affected by Dragapult spreading status. U-turn is another great form of support as it lets Dragapult, scout switches and bring in its teammates safely. Dragapult's ability, Infiltrator, also grants it the capability to hinder the likes of Substitute Zamazenta and Enamorus, and ignore dual screens set up by Klefki in the Fairy matchup. The given EV spread allows Dragapult to guarantee a 2HKO against Hatterene after recovery from Leftovers and always outspeed Zamazenta.

Flutter Mane is the biggest beneficiary of Dragapult's services, as it can outspeed Choice Scarf users crippled by Thunder Wave or live a few physical attacks from foes burned by Will-O-Wisp such as Earthquake from Landorus-T and Dire Claw from Sneasler. Flutter Mane repays Dragapult by blasting through Dark-types that give Ghost teams trouble such as Greninja, Choice Scarf Darkrai, and, if using a Choice Scarf, Chien-Pao. Spectrier is another great teammate for taking advantage of the status spread by Dragapult by threatening to win games with Hex. Dragapult's status also allows Spectrier to freely run Substitute and Nasty Plot together without needing to run Will-O-Wisp. Dragapult also safely pivots both Flutter Mane and Spectrier in, which is useful as both are quite frail. Gholdengo is an excellent choice, as with a Hex set, it is able to use the status spread by Dragapult to great effect and enhance its power, while with a Choice Scarf, it can threaten Chien-Pao, poses a threat to Dragapult with its priority moves. Skeledirge is a good choice as well, as it can withstand hits and reply back with a boosting Torch Song while also posing a threat to Heatran with Earth Power. Skeledirge also threatens Ice-types such as Alolan Ninetales and Frosmoth. Hisuian Zoroark is a much appreciated Ghost immunity that can deceive opponents into thinking it may be Dragapult or its vulnerable teammates, then take advantage of that to unleash powerful attacks against opposing Spectrier and Ceruledge or cripple walls such as Toxapex and Empoleon with Knock Off. Substitute Sinistcha is another choice to take care of one of Ghost's biggest problems in Ursaluna-B. Dragapult's spreading of status also allows for Mimikyu and Ceruledge to set up much more easily to threaten Fighting-types like Iron Hands and Steel-types like Corviknight, respectively. Mimikyu is also a one-time check to Chien-Pao and Kingambit with Disguise, both of which greatly threaten Ghost teams. Brambleghast can set up Spikes, which can wear down the opposition quickly in conjunction with burns from Dragapult's Will-O-Wisp, while Gengar can set up Toxic Spikes, letting Dragapult and Spectrier use Hex much more often.

Dragon Dance (Ghost).description:
Dragon Dance gives Dragapult the ability to not just boost its fantastic Speed to new heights, allowing it to outspeed fast Choice Scarf users such as Meowscarada and Roaring Moon, but also beef up its decent Attack stat. Dragon Darts is a reliable, hard-hitting Dragon-type STAB move that allows Dragapult to break Breloom's Focus Sash and Dragonite's Multiscale. Phantom Force is Dragapult's best choice for Ghost-tpye STAB move, as otherwise it is walled by any Fairy- or Steel-type, while Disable can disrupt Choice-locked Pokemon from potentially breaking its Substitute or attacking Dragapult in general. Substitute allows Dragapult to ease prediction and also adds a layer of protection against status moves, allowing it to set up on more passive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Amoonguss. It also synergizes well with Disable, allowing Dragapult to set up with ease. Will-O-Wisp is another option over Disable to allow Clodsire and Quagsire to become setup bait, while also crippling Kingambit and Ting-Lu; however, Disable is more consistent. Leftovers allows Dragapult to use Substitute multiple times throughout a game and be more annoying overall with Disable, while Dragon Fang is a good choice to boost Dragon Darts.

Skeledirge is a fantastic partner, as it can wall Fairy-types such as Choice Scarf Iron Valiant and Hatterene while also threatening foes like Kingambit that can easily take out Dragapult with their STAB priority moves. Gholdengo is another fantastic partner that can threaten Fairy-types like Klefki and Flutter Mane, if Gholdengo uses a Choice Scarf, and take care of physical walls such as opposing Skeledirge. Brambleghast is another good partner, as it can keep entry hazards off of the field, allowing Dragapult to come in multiple times, as well as providing Spikes support to soften up Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Iron Treads. Hisuian Zoroark provides the team with not just a Ghost immunity, but also can easily use Illusion to disguise itself as Dragapult and lure in foes that would normally threaten it, such as Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and opposing Dragapult, to open up for a potential Dragapult sweep. Flutter Mane is another great partner thanks to its ability to handle opposing Dragon-types such as Baxcalibur, Roaring Moon, and Walking Wake. It can also provide immediate speed control if need be to take care of other Choice Scarf users that could revenge kill Dragapult before it gets a Dragon Dance up. Mimikyu is an amazing wallbreaker that can either help wear down physical walls for Dragapult to clean up or can take advantage of Dragapult punching holes in the opponent's team to clean up itself. Mimikyu can also heavily threaten opposing Ghost-types for Dragapult like Choice Scarf Flutter Mane, Dragapult, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo thanks to its STAB priority in Shadow Sneak. It also provides a one-time check to setup sweepers such as Chien-Pao and Kingambit thanks to its ability Disguise.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Physical Attacker.description:
• Dragapult's blistering Speed makes it a very effective hit-and-run attacker.

  • Phantom Force: This is risky due to the two turns making Dragapult vulnerable to Normal-types and surprise Terastallization, but it still makes an effective late-game cleaning move.

  • Sucker Punch: Despite Dragapult's dynamite Speed stat, Sucker Punch still makes sense to pick off common Choice Scarf holders like Gholdengo, and play around priority from other foes.

  • Shadow Ball: With a Naive nature, Shadow Ball is an easy way to 2HKO Gholdengo, Flutter Mane, and incoming Skeledirge.

Other Options

  • Dragon Dance: Dragon Dance is fairly difficult to set up without Focus Sash, and it can lead to coverage issues. That being said, outspeeding Pokemon that commonly have their Speed boosted via an item, such as Flutter Mane, Gholdengo, and Iron Bundle, can lead to surprising win conditions.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Dragapult's cleaning capabilities are improved quite a bit by Terastallization, though it doesn't need to rely on it to be functional.

  • Dragon: Boosting the power of Dragon Darts makes Dragapult very effective at shredding through Focus Sash Pokemon such as Chien-Pao, in addition to removing the annoying Sucker Punch weakness.

  • Steel: Steel has a fantastic synergy with Dragapult's former typing, giving it a far better match-up against foes such as Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Mimikyu.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost is notable for letting Dragapult use a less risky STAB move in Tera Blast.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives a valuable Fairy-type resistance and is a more powerful tool against Steel-types at the cost of a Stealth Rock weakness.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy's Dragon-type immunity can help win Tera wars against foes like Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting vastly improves Dragapult's match-up against Kingambit, Chi-Yu, Chien-Pao, and Choice Scarf Meowscarada.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band guarantees that Breloom is OHKOed through its Focus Sash with Dragon Darts, and gives a 75% shot to the same happening to Chien-Pao.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb makes Sucker Punch a less risky option.

  • Focus Sash: Dragaoult's bulk isn't terrible, but Focus Sash will save it from the huge amount of top tier Pokemon that are capable of OHKOing it, such as Chien-Pao, Chi-Yu, and Gholdengo.

  • Choice Scarf: This may seem like overkill, but Choice Scarf gives Dragapult the edge over Booster Energy users such as Iron Bundle, Roaring Moon, and Flutter Mane, and other Choice Scarf foes such Gholdengo.

Special Attacker.description:
• Despite the lower offensive stat, the higher base power of Dragapult's special attacks makes it a serious threat.

  • Thunderbolt: Thunderbolt is the recommended coverage move for hitting Corviknight and Dondozo hard.

  • U-turn: Even though it's weak, U-turn is a reasonable consideration for pivoting and breaking Mimikyu's Disguise.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Dragapult can use Terastallization to surprise its checks, the high power of Draco Meteor and good coverage Shadow Ball provides mean it isn't reliant on it to function.

  • Dragon: Tera Dragon makes Draco Meteor nearly impossible to wall without a resistance, with even specially defensive Ting-Lu taking nearly 50% from it!

  • Fire: The Fairy-type resistance and powerful Flamethrower can make the Stealth Rock weakness worth it.

  • Steel: Tera Steel covers much of Dragapult's common weaknesses, and gives it a good Tera Blast to use against Fairy-types.

  • Ghost: Powering up Shadow Ball is perfect for cleaning up late-game, with only Normal-types and bulky resistances such as Ting-Lu, Wo-Chien, and Garganacl taking it well.

  • Fighting: The resistance to Sucker Punch Tera Fighting provides can be key in stopping Chien-Pao and Kingambit.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy improves Dragapult's match-up against other Dragon-types, Great Tusk, and resists Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch.

Bulky Status.description:
• With usable bulk bolstered by Will-O-Wisp, this Dragapult can severely punish its weaker offensive checks, and surprise common users of Sucker Punch such as Kingambit and Chien-Pao.

  • Disable and Substitute: Disable makes Dragapult rely on Will-O-Wisp for Normal-types, but when combined with Substitute, it defeats Choice-locked foes and those that rely on one specific move to beat Dragapult.

  • Draco Meteor: Draco Meteor improves Dragapult against other Dragon-types, such as Dragonite and Garchomp.

  • Flamethrower: This lets Dragapult deal decent unconditional damage to Steel-types, with Kingambit being the biggest target.

  • Dragon Darts: With a Naive nature, Dragon Darts gives Dragapult a consequence-free Dragon-type attack and decent mixed attacking potential.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Dragapult's typing gives it a lot of weaknesses, so Terastallization can help it stick around much longer, though the lack of good recovery means this isn't always the correct choice.

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Dragapult preforms better against Dark-types it may still struggle with after Will-O-Wisp, such as Chien-Pao and Ting-Lu.

  • Steel: Steel Tera type is great for general defense and Fairy-types such as Azumarill and Mimikyu.

Dual Screens.description:
• Dragapult's high Speed combined with Reflect and Light Screen make it an effective dual screens lead.

  • Curse: Curse reduces Dragapult's HP to get it off the field quickly once it has set up screens. It also forces opponents to use recovery moves or switch out, allowing Dragapult's teammates to get in and set up safely. Curse is Dragapult’s best option to bypass Substitute, Protect, and Mimikyu.

  • Shadow Ball: This breaks Focus Sash, hits Ghosts like Gholdengo and Flutter Mane that normally threaten it, and breaks Mimikyu's Disguise. Notably Gholdengo stops Curse with Good as Gold, making Dragapult totally helpless against it if it does not carry Shadow Ball.

  • Dragon Darts: Dragon Darts can be used for more power to make Dragapult more self-sufficient when it has to stay on the field, and breaks Focus Sash as well. Its dual-hit nature makes it bypass most Substitutes.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Will-O-Wisp can be used to cripple physical attackers. In tandem with Reflect, this can be a potent strategy to allow the next Pokemon to set up nearly risk-free.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Very Situational: As a dual screens lead, Terastallizing can compromise its teammates sweeping abilities, so it should only be done in emergencies.

  • Ghost / Dragon: If you are in a bad spot, Ghost and Dragon power up its STAB move of choice.

  • Steel: A defensive typing like Steel can allow Dragapult to survive certain moves like Iron Bundle's Ice Beam, boosted Cloyster's Icicle Spear, and boosted Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush and retaliate.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type is useful for enemy Infiltrator Dragapult's Dragon Darts.

Items

  • Focus Sash: While Light Clay is standard, Focus Sash nearly guarantees setting at least one screen without having to Terastallize, in the event Dragapult leads off against Choice Scarf users like Gholdengo, Hydreigon, and Meowscarada.

Swords Dance.description: Zacian is one of Ubers UU's best late-game cleaners and wallbreakers thanks to Intrepid Sword, its good Attack and Speed, decent bulk for an offensive threat, and its deep coverage movepool. Close Combat targets Pokemon like Zamazenta-C and Dialga. Zacian's last moveslot is relatively flexible; Tera Blast is generally preferred with either Tera Fire or Ground to hit Pokemon like Magearna, Solgaleo, Arceus-Fire, and Skarmory, although if they are not an issue, Psychic Fangs to hit Arceus-Poison and Toxapex without having to Terstallize and Crunch to hit Deoxys and Mewtwo are viable options. Tera Fire and Ground also provide immunities to burns and Thunder Wave, respectively. If Zacian is running Crunch, Tera Dark can be used to boost said move and provide an immunity to Psychic-type attacks from the likes of Deoxys and Mewtwo. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Zacian to stay healthy and be great in the Sticky Web matchup. Zacian best fits on offensive teams looking for a solid late-game cleaner. Zacian struggles against bulkier, physically defensive Pokemon like Magearna, Skarmory, and Toxapex, so Pokemon like Chi-Yu, Deoxys, and Arceus-Dark that can handle these threats are helpful to have. Zacian has four-moveslot syndrome, so it also appreciates support from teammates like Landorus-T and Chi-Yu that can deal with the Pokemon that Zacian can't hit, like Arceus-Fire and Skarmory. Pokemon like Choice Specs Kyurem-W, Mewtwo, and Giratina like having Zacian threaten out Pokemon they struggle against like Palkia-O and Kingambit. Entry hazard support from the likes of Deoxys and Dialga helps wear down Zacian's checks, allowing it to function as a more threatening cleaner; in return, Zacian removes Pokemon they have problems with like Kingambit, Palkia-O, and Arceus-Dark for them. Pivoting from the likes of Magearna, Landorus-T, Solgaleo, and Cyclizar gives Zacian a safe opportunity to set up Swords Dance; the later can also potentially pass Zacian a free Substitute with Shed Tail.

Wallbreaker.description: Zacian's excellent Speed and power make it both a fantastic revenge killer and wallbreaker. Close Combat helps cover Steel-types switching in, dealing super effective damage to Pokemon like Dialga and Zamazenta-C and hitting Magearna neutrally. Crunch helps remove key targets like Gholdengo, Solgaleo, Mewtwo, and Galarian Slowking. Psychic Fangs is occasionally used to beat Poison-types like Toxapex and Arceus-Poison it otherwise has trouble removing, while Wild Charge allows Zacian to hit Corviknight, Skarmory, and Dondozo. Tera Fighting can boost Close Combat to extreme levels, allowing it to break through Pokemon like Magearna and Solgaleo. Tera Ground is notable for providing an immunity to Thunder Wave and a powerful option to break through checks like Toxapex, Magearna, and Solgaleo in Tera Blast Ground. Zacian best fits as a wallbreaker on bulky offense and balance teams. Great Tusk and Landorus-T are excellent partners for Zacian, being able to set up Stealth Rock to chip down foes and also threaten the Steel- and Poison-type Pokemon like Magearna and Arceus-Poison that it is weak to. Late-game cleaners like Arceus-Fire, Sneasler, and Arceus-Grass enjoy the gaps Zacian creates in defensive cores providing them with opportunities to set up and sweep weakened teams.

Ice Scales.description: Ice Scales Zacian is an effective special wall against prominent special attackers like Palkia-O and Arceus-Ghost. Spirit Break dissuades setup from Arceus formes, Eternatus, and Palkia-O, though Magical Torque is a stronger alternative. While seemingly counter-productive with Spirit Break, Haze is the best option to neuter Nasty Plot Palkia-O and Arceus-Ghost, and it also ensures Zacian beats No Retreat Arceus-Ghost. Spikes provides support for the team and makes progress against Strength Sap users. Spirit Shackle traps Imposter users, preventing them from recovering health for free on Zacian. Toxic punishes most setup special attackers like Calm Mind Arceus formes. Covert Cloak prevents burns from Palkia-O's Steam Eruption and protects against status conditions inflicted by Nuzzle and Mortal Spin. Alternatively, Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers help mitigate entry hazard damage and keep Zacian healthy. Ability Shield is useful against Normalize users like Dragapult and Mold Breaker users like Palkia-O. Zacian pairs very well with a secondary specially defensive pivot like RegenVest Ting-Lu or Dialga-O, as they can scout for moves from Choice Specs users while not being chipped down by Volt Switch. In return, Zacian provides a switch-in to strong Dragon-type moves while also checking setup Pokemon like Palkia-O and Nasty Plot Flutter Mane. Imposter-proofs for Spikes variants include Fur Coat Groudon and Arceus-Ground, while Toxic variants can be Imposter-proofed by Arceus-Poison and Corviknight. Tera Steel provides a resistance to Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane's Boomburst while retaining a Dragon resistance, as well as providing a Toxic immunity.

Fur Coat.description: Fur Coat Zacian differentiates itself from other Fur Coat users with its high Speed, outspeeding dangerous physical threats like Koraidon and threatening them with Knock Off or Will-O-Wisp. Spirit Break is a weaker alternative to Magical Torque that offers more PP and a useful secondary effect, preventing Calm Mind Arceus formes and Torch Song Eternatus from freely setting up. Knock Off removes important items like Choice Band and Assault Vest from Pokemon like Groudon and Ting-Lu, respectively, as well as removing Imposter Chansey's Eviolite. Will-O-Wisp neutralizes most physical attackers like Koraidon. Spirit Shackle threatens to trap and eliminate Imposter users and physical threats walled by Zacian. Toxic cripples Imposter users and most Fur Coat users. Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers help mitigate entry hazard damage, allowing Zacian to check physical threats more reliably, while Covert Cloak provides protection against status conditions from Nuzzle and Mortal Spin. Zacian can struggle to handle extremely powerful physical wallbreakers like Groudon and Mold Breaker Koraidon by itself, so secondary physical walls like Fur Coat Arceus formes are appreciated as teammates; they can also Imposter-proof Zacian. Despite outspeeding threats like Palkia-O and Flutter Mane, Zacian cannot switch in, so a special wall like Ice Scales Dialga-O or Chansey can help pivot Zacian in. Tera Water grants a resistance to V-create and Gigaton Hammer, the latterof which Koraidon commonly uses to threaten Zacian.

Pixilate.description: Pixilate Zacian is a powerful cleaner. Pixilate boosted Population Bomb is an incredibly strong STAB move, 2HKOing defensive behemoths like Fur Coat Dondozo at +2. Coil + Protective Pads and Swords Dance + Wide Lens both increase Population Bomb's power and accuracy, with the former bypassing Rocky Helmet and the latter providing a stronger boost, notably letting Zacian boost past Strength Sap. Rapid Spin with Pixilate provides unblockable entry hazard removal in a pinch, while Precipice Blades targets Fairy-resistant Pokemon like Arceus-Poison and Arceus-Fire. Spirit Shackle is an option with Coil to trap and eliminate Imposter users, which are otherwise problematic. Knock Off users like Ting-Lu and Groudon are mandatory for Wide Lens sets to remove Rocky Helmet. While Zacian can remove hazards with Rapid Spin, hazard setters often carry moves that can heavily cripple it like Nuzzle and Knock Off, making another hazard remover like Tidy Up Groudon or Mortal Spin Ting-Lu a good choice. Groudon notably also pressures Fairy-resistant Pokemon like Arceus-Poison and Arceus-Fire well. Imposter users serve as a strong check to this set, so having a sturdy Imposter-proofing teammate is necessary, with Rocky Helmet + Fur Coat users or Corviknight being good candidates.

Iron Defense.description:
Iron Defense Zamazenta is a fast sweeper for offense that also happens to blanket check most of the physical metagame with great matchups into key threats such as Kingambit, Great Tusk, and Weavile. It acts as a strong form of role compression that can make use of its great bulk, a Defense boost from Dauntless Shield, and its high Speed stat to find opportunities to use Iron Defense to not only bolster its survivability but also strengthen the power of its Body Press. Crunch is a necessity to hit Ghost- and Psychic-types like Gholdengo, Skeledirge, and Galarian Slowking that aren't threatened by Body Press, while its last moveslot is more flexible; Heavy Slam gives Zamazenta super effective coverage into Fairy-types that otherwise would wall it such as Clefable, Enamorus, and Iron Valiant, while Substitute allows Zamazenta to dodge status moves from the likes of Gliscor, Galarian Slowking, and Toxapex along with helping to block revenge killing attempts from faster Pokemon such as Booster Energy Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Gholdengo. Stone Edge is an alternative that gives Zamazenta a non-contact option to hit Volcarona and Zapdos while still giving it coverage to hit Enamorus, at the expense of losing its ability to hit other Fairy-types and the benefit of Substitute's status and revenge killing protection. 168 EVs in Speed allow Zamazenta to outrun Adamant Dragonite after a Dragon Dance while also outrunning key threats like Weavile and Darkrai. Zamazenta can then choose to invest EVs into HP for better overall bulk or into Attack for stronger coverage moves; notably, maximum HP investment ensures that Zamazenta will survive Choice Scarf Enamorus's Moonblast from full while also avoiding a 2HKO from Clefable. Choosing to maximize Attack gives Zamazenta a clean 2HKO on offensive Gholdengo with Crunch and on both Clefable and Hatterene with Heavy Slam. The remaining EVs are invested in Defense to improve Zamazenta's bulk and give it a stronger Body Press. Tera Steel is one of Zamazenta's best options, defensively flipping the matchup into Fairy-, Psychic-, and Flying-type attacks from foes like Enamorus, Galarian Slowking, Deoxys-S, and Dragon Dance Roaring Moon while also powering up Heavy Slam to OHKO both Enamorus and Iron Valiant even without Attack investment. Tera Steel also gives Zamazenta a crucial immunity to Toxic from Gliscor and Toxapex. Tera Fire serves to grant Zamazenta a key Fairy resistance without making it weak to Fighting-type moves from Iron Valiant, but the primary draw of this Tera type is an immunity to burn, a particularly important quality against Dragapult and Skeledirge, the former of which being able to burn even Substitute variants of Zamazenta with Infiltrator. Tera Fairy is another solid defensive typing for Zamazenta, granting it a great defensive profile that includes a resistance to Fighting-type attacks that helps out immensely in the Iron Defense mirror matchup against both Zamazenta and Skarmory, as well as an immunity to Dragapult's Draco Meteor and a retained resistance to Dark-type attacks that allows you to still check Weavile and Roaring Moon; Tera Ghost is an option that leans even heavier into beating opposing Iron Defense users at the expense of granting little defensive value.

Zamazenta is a great fit on both bulky offense and hyper offense teams that need a fast offensive piece with good matchups into the tier's physical threats, in particular providing a crucial Kingambit check to a team. However, to be able to fully leverage its defensive value, it appreciates entry hazard removal to allow it to switch in without taking chip damage on entry and potentially being neutered entirely by Toxic Spikes. Hatterene is a particularly good partner in this regard, as it not only blocks entry hazards but can also be used to weaken shared checks like Gholdengo, Galarian Slowking, and Skeledirge, and Great Tusk can clear hazards from the field along with helping to wear down Gliscor and force in and chip down Gholdengo attempting to block Rapid Spin. Rillaboom also serves as a great pairing that helps to bolster Zamazenta's longevity, with the additional healing from Grassy Terrain making Zamazenta much more difficult to remove from the field. Zamazenta's ability to check the tier's offensive Dark-types is also a valuable quality for hyper offense teams that opt to run a hazard lead like Glimmora or Deoxys-S, as these builds often use Gholdengo to block hazard removal; this will often give threats like Kingambit, Weavile, and Hisuian Samurott free attacks that necessitate an offensive switch-in that Zamazenta provides. Zamazenta is then able to take advantage of these Pokemon by using them as setup fodder. Gholdengo itself is a strong partner to Zamazenta, able to switch into Fairy- and Psychic-type attacks from Enamorus, Iron Valiant, and Hatterene while also taking advantage of Zamazenta's defensive checks like Galarian Slowking and Clefable being unable to touch it. Zamazenta's relatively low wallbreaking power unfortunately leaves it struggling to muscle through Unaware walls like Dondozo, Skeledirge, and Clodsire, while its inability to boost the strength of its coverage moves makes bulkier Pokemon that don't fear Body Press like defensive Gholdengo and Galarian Slowking hard to break through; Zamazenta matches up best into opposing offense teams, and so balance breakers and stallbreakers are appreciated to support it in its other matchups. One strong offensive pairing with Zamazenta is Dragon Dance Roaring Moon, as it can weaken Skarmory and remove its Rocky Helmet to allow Zamazenta to later break through it. In particular, Roaring Moon's ability to chunk Dondozo and force it to take hazard damage with Knock Off is much appreciated to help Zamazenta make progress against it. Kingambit is another excellent teammate for Zamazenta, loading well into bulkier teams and heavily pressuring Dondozo while also being able to switch into Dragapult, Gholdengo and Hatterene that may come in to force Zamazenta out. A great partner to Zamazenta on hyper offensive teams is Booster Energy Iron Valiant, able to weaken shared checks like Gholdengo, Galarian Slowking, and Skeledirge for Zamazenta to later break through. Iron Valiant also provides hyper offensive teams with a temporary form of speed control that can outrun Dragapult and Deoxys-S, both of which outspeed and can threaten Zamazenta with strong special attacks, or, in Dragapult's case, debilitating status with Will-O-Wisp.

All-Out Attacker.description: With four attacks, Zamazenta wields an array of colorful coverage alongside the tier's highest unboosted Speed stat, threatening a majority of the metagame. Its natural bulk and Dauntless Shield give it opportunities to wallbreak via its prowess in offensively checking Mega Lopunny, Hisuian Samurott, and Ogerpon-W. Stone Edge pairs fantastically with Zamazenta's STAB, nailing Volcarona, Zapdos, Moltres, and Tornadus-T while avoiding adverse contact effects from the former three. Ice Fang is Zamazenta's only option to break through Gliscor and Landorus-T and its strongest attack against Dragonite. Heavy Slam is the preferred last coverage move to hit Clefable and render Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant incapable of soft checking Zamazenta, while Crunch threatens Psychic-types in Galarian Slowking, Slowbro, and Mega Latias. Wild Charge is Zamazenta's strongest attack against Toxapex but deals pitiful damage regardless without a Choice Band and can still be easily pivoted against even with the boost. Heavy-Duty Boots increase Zamazenta's longevity, allowing it to switch in and threaten opposing teams more often, whereas Choice Band provides more immediate power, albeit at the cost of being incredibly prediction-reliant to break through most teams carrying multiple Fighting-resistant foes. Rockium Z is a niche alternative that reduces difficulties in KOing Zapdos by minimizing the need for prior chip damage mitigating and Stone Edge's meager accuracy. It also helps in breaking through Fighting-resistant Pokemon such as Clefable and Galarian Slowking without the correct coverage move once properly chipped. Tera Fighting is preferred to boost Close Combat's power against neutral targets such as Ogerpon-W and Alomomola, with chances to OHKO and 2HKO them, respectively, without Choice Band and muscle through checks such as Tornadus-T. Alternatively, Tera Steel flips the tables against Choice Scarf Tapu Lele's revenge killing attempts and secures the KO on Clefable after minimal chip. Zamazenta can fit on more defensive teams as speed control that forces out offensive terrors such as Ogerpon-W to supplement a defensive core, or it can be used on offensive teams supported by other wallbreakers while helping check threats to such teams such as Mega Lopunny with its natural bulk and Dauntless Shield. Regardless, its best support remains Future Sight from Tapu Lele, Galarian Slowking, or Slowbro, as Zamazenta is most often handled by switching between Pokemon that resist its moves and physically bulky pivots such as Galarian Slowking, Landorus-T, and Alomomola or stopped in its tracks by Toxapex. Future Sight punishes these situations by dealing massive damage, particularly against Toxapex. Similarly, Pursuit support from Mega Tyranitar and Weavile weakens or removes pivots such as Galarian Slowking, Mega Latias, and Zapdos.

Howl.description: These sets are currently up for reservation for a revamp; please check out the C&C thread for more information!

Iron Defense + Body Press.description: Boasting extraordinary physical bulk and the highest unboosted Speed in the tier, Zamazenta can use Iron Defense and Body Press to become a powerful setup sweeper and cleaner. Substitute allows Zamazenta to set up on Pokemon such as Gliscor and Alomomola that heavily rely on Toxic for their offensive pressure and to be unthreatened by Knock Off from the likes of Mega Tyranitar and Hisuian Samurott, while Heavy Slam allows Zamazenta to immediately threaten Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant, both of which commonly use Choice Scarf and Booster Energy respectively to outspeed Zamazenta and have enough bulk coupled with a Fighting resistance to take a Body Press and threaten Zamazenta immediately. Alternatively, Crunch can be used to deal with Galarian Slowking and is also stronger than Heavy Slam against Pokemon such as Ferrothorn that commonly Terastallize into the Ghost typing, and Stone Edge is another option that threatens Volcarona and Zapdos while avoiding Flame Body and Static, respectively, and allows Zamazenta to deal with Tornadus-T without the need to Terastallize. Zamazenta struggles to break through Pokemon such as Galarian Slowking, Zapdos, and Toxapex that have the bulk to take multiple boosted Body Press and either threaten it back directly or can use Haze to remove Zamazenta's boosts. Therefore, teammates such as Mega Tyranitar that can Pursuit trap and wear down these Pokemon are invaluable. Other options such as Calm Mind Iron Valiant can also trade for heavy damage against most of these Pokemon, clearing the way for Zamazenta to sweep. Tera Electric allows Zamazenta to turn Zapdos into a setup opportunity, resisting both of its STAB attacks and being unafraid of Static, while Tera Steel allows Zamazenta to set up on Choice-locked Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant as well as turning Heavy Slam into an OHKO on both.

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band: Zamazenta is able to run Stone Edge to hit opposing Flying-type targets such as Zapdos harder than with Ice Fang or Wild Charge, and it is especially noteworthy for OHKOing Articuno, Moltres and Volcarona. However, its lower accuracy makes it an inconsistent choice. Choice Band Zamazenta can also opt to run Play Rough to target Sableye, which typically can switch into Zamazenta's attacks safely.

Iron Defense: Crunch provides good coverage against Ghost-types such as Hisuian Zoroark and Dragapult that otherwise would be able to wall Zamazenta. However, Crunch is mostly useless against Ghost-types with recovery such as bulky Gholdengo and Skeledirge. Stone Edge is able to take care of Zapdos and Moltres, which can cripple Zamazenta otherwise with Static and Flame Body respectively, as well as other Flying-types such as Tornadus-T. An alternative EV spread of 212 HP / 56 Def / 240 Spe can be used to ensure that Quagsire's Earthquake will not break Zamazenta's Substitute while still outspeeding Barraskewda.

Choice Band.description:
Choice Band Zamazenta is a solid wallbreaker on Fighting teams since it is one of the fastest and strongest Pokemon in the tier, outspeeding swift offensive threats like Chien-Pao and Flutter Mane while utilizing its coverage to break a multitude of defensive Pokemon in the metagame. Heavy Slam is key to targeting opposing Fairy-type Pokemon like Hatterene and the aforementioned Flutter Mane. Ice Fang is able to OHKO specially defensive Gliscor, which Fighting teams have difficulty taking down. Moreover, it is also Zamazenta's best move to target the Landorus formes. Alternatively, Psychic Fangs allows Zamazenta to target opposing Poison-types, letting it OHKO Sneasler and Okidogi, as well as 2HKO mixed Toxapex and Galarian Weezing. Wild Charge is yet another coverage option that OHKOes Pelipper, has a chance to 2HKO Toxapex, and threatens various Flying-type Pokemon such as Articuno and Moltres. Finally, Crunch targets opposing Ghost-types such as Spectrier and Gholdengo. 8 HP EVs in conjunction with 32 Special Defense EVs prevent Zamazenta from being OHKOed by Choice Scarf Flutter Mane's Moonblast, allowing Zamazenta to revenge kill it with Heavy Slam.

Choice Band Zamazenta appreciates Great Tusk's ability to remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin so it is not chipped down over time by Spikes. Great Tusk is also able to assist Zamazenta by setting Stealth Rock so Zamazenta has an easier time securing OHKOs against Pokemon such as Gliscor. Choice Scarf Sneasler pairs well with Zamazenta due to its ability to dispatch opposing Fairy-type Pokemon like Enamorus and Azumarill. Sneasler can also use Switcheroo to disrupt defensive walls such as Toxapex by removing their items and locking them into a status move, allowing Zamazenta to eventually wear them down. Iron Valiant is a beneficial partner for Zamazenta, being able to threaten Sableye and Mandibuzz as well as other physical walls such as Toxapex and Gliscor, which can be useful depending on Zamazenta's choice of coverage moves. With a Choice Scarf, Iron Valiant can further threaten Dragapult and opposing Zamazenta, and cripple defensive walls with Trick. Assault Vest Iron Hands can act as a switch-in to opposing Fairy-type Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Enamorus and Flutter Mane and threaten them back with Heavy Slam. Iron Hands is also useful in handling opposing Flying-types like Corviknight, Articuno, and Gliscor thanks to its Electric and Ice coverage, and can further provide Zamazenta with a safe switch in thanks to Volt Switch. Kommo-o can block Gholdengo's Shadow Ball with Bulletproof and threaten it in return with Flamethrower, which is useful as this is a foe Zamazenta struggles to deal with. Kommo-o finds extra utility as a switch-in to Skeledirge, and can force it out if opting to run Choice Specs. In return, Zamazenta can outspeed non-Choice Scarf Fairy-types like Flutter Mane and threaten them with Heavy Slam, which otherwise stop Kommo-o easily. Hisuian Lilligant pairs well with Zamazenta, taking on defensive Gliscor, Clodsire, and Dragonite with its Hustle-boosted Ice Spinner. It is also able to use its Grass-type STAB moves to threaten bulky Water-types that can switch into Zamazenta such as Dondozo and Azumarill. Gallade threatens opposing Poison-type Pokemon like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Amoonguss; in exchange, Gallade appreciates Zamazenta's ability to punish Landorus-T with Ice Fang. Okidogi, like Sneasler, can threaten Fairy-types like Azumarill and Iron Valiant. In addition, Okidogi's use of Taunt + Bulk Up can stallbreak Zamazenta's defensive checks like Toxapex and Corviknight. Urshifu-R is another excellent teammate to Zamazenta, with its Surging Strikes proving deadly to many of Zamazenta's most troublesome foes such as Gliscor, Skeledirge, Ceruledge, and Volcarona.

Iron Defense.description:
Zamazenta excels in matchups that Fighting typically struggles against, such as the Fighting mirror, Ground, and Fairy, since it is able to outspeed threats such as Iron Valiant and Flutter Mane, set up Iron Defense on physical attackers, and punish more passive Pokemon. Substitute allows Zamazenta to take advantage of passive foes such as Gliscor, Clodsire, and Amoonguss that can't break its Substitute in one hit, allowing it to start setting up Iron Defense and preventing it from being hindered by status. Heavy Slam is important, as Zamazenta outspeeds big Fairy-type threats such as non-Choice Scarf Enamorus and Flutter Mane. Heavy Slam also prevents Zamazenta from being walled by Iron Valiant in the Fighting mirror matchup. 252 Speed EVs allow Zamazenta to outspeed Jolly Barraskewda outside of rain and Flutter Mane, while 248 HP EVs allow it to set up four Substitutes.

Iron Hands, with its great special bulk paired with Assault Vest, complements Zamazenta's physical bulk well, being able to take hits from threatening Pokemon such as Flutter Mane and Hatterene while also being a big help in the Flying matchup with its access to Ice Punch and Thunder Punch to hit Zapdos and Enamorus-T. Great Tusk provides great physical bulk alongside Zamazenta and is also able to bring wallbreaking potential, with access to Ice Spinner to hit Flying-types such as Gliscor and Headlong Rush to hit Poison-types such as Unaware Clodsire and Toxapex, which are both hindrances for Zamazenta. Great Tusk is also able to remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin to prevent passive chip on Zamazenta while also running Knock Off to prevent Ghost-types from spinblocking. Iron Valiant provides the special offense Fighting desperately needs in order to break physical walls such as Dondozo and Slowbro that Zamazenta struggles against, and is also able to hit Ghost-types that can wall Zamazenta, such as Skeledirge and Sinistcha, with Shadow Ball. Iron Valiant can also run Trick to disable Toxapex and Clodsire and stop them from stalling out Zamazenta. Sneasler provides great coverage against Fairy-types, with Dire Claw being able to hit threats such as Enamorus. Additionally, Choice Scarf Sneasler outspeeds Choice Specs Flutter Mane while also being able to set up Toxic Spikes to cripple more defensive Pokemon such as Scream Tail. Sneasler also can run Switcheroo to hinder Toxapex and Clodsire, similarly to Iron Valiant. It also offers great pivot potential with U-turn, and can put Pokemon like Unaware Quagsire, which normally walls Zamazenta, on a timer when paired with Poison Touch. Hisuian Lilligant is a great setup threat with its access to Victory Dance and is able to threaten Flying- and Water-types such as Azumarill, Zapdos, and Toxapex with Ice Spinner and Leaf Blade at +1. Hisuian Lilligant also has access to Healing Wish as support for Zamazenta. Choice Band Galarian Zapdos is a great wallbreaker, 2HKOing Toxapex and Sinistcha. Another great wallbreaker is Urshifu-R, which helps with the Ghost matchup because it can deal with Gholdengo and Skeledirge if it is using a Choice Band or after a Swords Dance boost. Gallade is a niche Pokemon to use but helps with the Poison matchup that Zamazenta struggles with, thanks to its access to Sharpness-boosted Psycho Cut. It's also able to run Assault Vest to lure and remove Enamorus's Choice Scarf with Knock Off, which allows Zamazenta to use Heavy Slam against it. Assault Vest also lets Gallade deal with Quagsire and Toxapex instead of forcing a prediction.

IronPress.description: With its combination of robust defenses and good Attack, Zamazenta-C is an excellent mid- or late-game sweeper for bulkier teams. Body Press synergizes well with Iron Defense and Dauntless Shield, and when combined with Zamazenta-C's brilliant natural bulk, it can quickly clean up weakened teams. Behemoth Bash or Heavy Slam lets it Zamazenta-C answer Fairy-types, like Zacian and Tera Fairy Arceus-Dark, and Crunch lets it tackle Psychic- and Ghost-types, like Mewtwo, Giratina, Lugia, and Deoxys. 200 Speed EVs with a Jolly Nature allow it to outspeed Cyclizar, 112 Attack EVs let it have a favorable roll to 2HKO Mewtwo, and the rest of the EVs go into Defense to maximize Body Press's damage. Tera Water lets Zamazenta-C stay in on more opponents foes like Arceus-Fire, Palafin, Chi-Yu, and Kyurem-W, and Tera Flying lets you it resist Fighting-type moves from the likes of Mewtwo, Zacian, and Deoxys and be immune to Ground-type moves from Great Tusk, Landorus, and Ursaluna, though a weakness to Stealth Rock is added. Being able to check Magearna, Zacian, Dialga, Ursaluna-B, Arceus-Dark, Palafin, and Palkia-O, Zamazenta-C is appreciated by Giratina, Chi-Yu, Palkia-O, Arceus-Dark and Mewtwo. Zamazenta-C suffers from being worn down by entry hazards, so a hazard remover like Great Tusk or Giratina is needed. It also appreciates hazard support of its own from setters like Magearna and Dialga. Fighting-, Ground-, and Fire-resistant Pokemon like Arceus-Poison, Rillaboom, and Giratina are also a boon to Zamazenta-C, as they can stomach whatever hits come at it.

Zamazenta-C leverages its high bulk and Speed to be an excellent setup sweeper with Iron Defense + Body Press while also being able to check many of the tier's dangerous offensive threats with its excellent defensive typing. Zamazenta-C can only use Dauntless Shield, which increases its potency as a setup sweeper while boosting Body Press. Stone Edge threatens an OHKO on Iron Moth while 2HKOing Dragonite, Ceruledge, and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Substitute can be used to block status and phazing moves, notably surviving a Scald from defensive Manaphy and a Dragon Tail from Garchomp, as well as pivoting moves from defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight, Empoleon, Mandibuzz, and Manaphy. Special wallbreakers such as Gengar, Azelf, and Walking Wake appreciate Zamazenta-C being able to threaten switch-ins to them such as Empoleon, Hisuian Goodra, and RegenVest Roaring Moon, as well as offensive checks such as Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Ogerpon-C, as the aforementioned teammates are otherwise forced out by the threat of an OHKO; in return, they can remove Zamazenta-C's checks, such as defensive Kommo-o and Zapdos. Zamazenta-C struggles with physically defensive Pokemon that can counter it by setting up on their own, such as Iron Defense Kommo-o and Corviknight, as well as Bulk Up Great Tusk, so teammates that can check them such as Zapdos and Scream Tail are appreciated, with the latter being able to pass Wishes to Zamazenta-C. Zamazenta-C is also weak to entry hazards, so teammates that can remove hazards such as Corviknight and Great Tusk are appreciated.

Offensive.description: With its great defensive typing, sky high Special Attack stat, and good STAB combination, Eternatus acts as one of Mix and Mega's most threatening special wallbreakers. Fire Blast gives coverage into Steel-types like Solgaleo, Magearna, and Sablenite Corviknight; Flamethrower is a more consistent alternative, but the drop in power makes it lose out on damage thresholds like OHKOing Sablenite Corviknight after Stealth Rock. Recover increases Eternatus's survivability and lets it offset Life Orb recoil and other chip damage. Life Orb Eternatus is typically seen on more offensive teams looking for a solid wallbreaker. Pokemon that hard wall Eternatus like Blissey and Blue Orb Magearna and Pokemon that can use it as setup fodder like Iron Boulder and Calm Mind Venusaurite Solgaleo can give it a tough time. As a result, Pokemon like Great Tusk and Arceus-Ground that can deal with these threats are good teammates. Naturally faster threats like Weavile and Walking Wake and priority from Arceus can directly threaten Eternatus; this makes Pokemon that can handle these threats like Arceus-Fairy, Galarian Slowking, and Sablenite Corviknight good partners.

Meteor Beam.description: Eternatus acts as a terrifying cleaner and setup sweeper, using its good natural bulk and typing to have an easier time against revenge killers. Meteor Beam allows Eternatus to lure in and OHKO Ho-Oh while providing extra firepower, and Fire Blast threatens Steel-types like Corviknight, Magearna, and Solgaleo, whereas Flamethrower is a weaker but more consistent alternative. Sludge Bomb nails Fairy-types like Arceus-Fairy, Altarianite Dragonite, and Hisuian Arcanine, while Recover provides longevity, allowing Eternatus to have an easier time against revenge killers like Altarianite Regieleki and Metagrossite Urshifu-R. Meteor Beam and Power Herb's single-use nature requires Eternatus to be used with offensive pivots that can wear down the opposing team like Altarianite Regieleki, Red Orb Raikou, and Metagrossite Urshifu-R; in return, it can clean up the opposing team. Entry hazard users like Arceus formes, Hisuian Arcanine, and Hisuian Samurott make for great partners, wearing down Eternatus's checks like Galarian Slowking, Arceus-Ground, and non-Heavy-Duty Boots Lunala throughout the course of the game.

Specially Defensive.description:
• Specially defensive Eternatus functions as a good check to Kyogre and Calm Mind or Taunt Arceus formes thanks to Toxic, its high Speed and bulk, and reliable recovery.
  • Dynamax Cannon always does enough damage to break Kyogre's Substitute, allowing Eternatus to Toxic it on the next turn.
  • Flamethrower gives good neutral coverage with Dynamax Cannon, hits Zacian-C and Corviknight, and can fish for burns. Dragon Tail is an option to force out Arceus formes that Tera Poison or Steel to avoid Toxic, and it can annoy Clodsire. Toxic Spikes can be useful to pressure the opposing team, especially with smart double switches. In either case, the loss of Flamethrower leaves Eternatus more passive generally.
  • Sludge Bomb is much less reliable at setting poison than Toxic is; however, it allows Eternatus to have a chance against Calm Mind Tera Fairy Kyogre sets, which may otherwise use Substitute to block Toxic.
  • The given EV spread allows Eternatus to outspeed base 120 Speed Pokemon like Arceus and Palkia-O, with the rest of the EVs dumped into bulk.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots is optimal on teams lacking entry hazard removal, while Leftovers works better when Eternatus is paired with Giratina-O or Corviknight.
  • Tera Fairy is used, as its Dragon-type immunity is useful against Koraidon and Miraidon, and it provides a neutrality to Ice. Tera Water provides Eternatus with a resistance to Ice, making it much more reliable against Kyogre sets lacking Thunder, and a resistance to Zacian-C's Behemoth Blade.
  • Eternatus is very difficult to switch into generally, since it has strong neutral coverage and can poison most switch-ins. Its most reliable checks are Clodsire, Blissey, and Arceus-Poison, all of which don't care about being poisoned and can use Eternatus as a free setup opportunity. Exerting enough offensive pressure helps deal with these threats.
  • Eternatus works well as a third or fourth pokemon on defensive cores, since it absorbs Toxic Spikes and takes on the aforementioned Arceus formes and Kyogre. Ting-Lu makes for a fantastic partner as a result.
  • On teams lacking entry hazard removal, Skeledirge is a great partner, since both Pokemon can use Heavy-Duty Boots and have reliable recovery.
  • Switch-ins to Ground-types are much appreciated such as Corviknight, Giratina-O, and Landorus-T. Arceus-Ground makes for a good partner to pressure opposing Ground-types offensively.
  • While it can't switch in on Toxic, Mewtwo is a great annoyance, as it tends to be faster than Eternatus and can hit it with a super effective Psystrike. As such, pivots into Psystrike such as Corviknight or Ting-Lu are ideal teammates.

Agility Sweeper.description:
• Agility Eternatus leverages its fantastic bulk, speed, and offensive output to become one of the most threatening late-game sweepers.
  • 32 Speed EVs let Eternatus outspeed the entire metagame at +2, including +1 Koraidon. The rest of its EVs are invested in HP to help it survive hits while setting up. The given HP investment allows Eternatus to survive Choice Scarf Koraidon's Dragon Claw from full HP without Terastallizing, allowing it to bait in and remove Koraidon for the benefit of a teammate like Kyogre.
  • Flamethrower gives Eternatus consistent Fire-type coverage, but Fire Blast can somewhat alleviate Eternatus's power issues. In sun, Tera Fire-boosted Fire Blast is guaranteed to 3HKO Ting-Lu and is favored 2HKO Clodsire.
  • Tera Dragon allows Dynamax Cannon to 2HKO Toxapex and specially defensive Gliscor regardless of Eternatus's item while 2HKOing Clodsire and OHKOing Gliscor after Stealth Rock with Draco Plate or Life Orb.
  • Tera Fire strengthens Eternatus’ chosen Fire-type move, helping against Pokemon like Zacian-C and Kingambit. It is also a valuable defensive typing for Eternatus, notably giving it a resistance to Zacian-C's STAB moves, as well as a neutrality to Koraidon's Dragon Claw.
