Flower Trick cuts through bulky threats such as Dondozo, Great Tusk, and Primarina, even ignoring the former two's potential Defense boosts, while Triple Axel gives Meowscarada a crucial Ice-type STAB move that allows it to nail common Pokemon such as Clodsire, Gliscor, Raging Bolt, and Roaring Moon. U-turn could be used in the last slot for keeping momentum while chipping switch-ins such as Kingambit and Hatterene. Alternatively, Meowscarada can run Low Kick to smack some of the tier's most threatening staples such as Archaludon, Kingambit, and Kyurem. Heavy-Duty Boots is practically a requirement on this set, as Meowscarada will frequently be switching in and out of combat and is otherwise quite weak to hazards. Tera Grass and Dark enhance Flower Trick and Knock Off while Tera Fire grants Meowscarada some crucial resistances to Fairy, Ice, and Steel-type attacks such as those from Enamorus, Gouging Fire, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo. Tera Electric is an additional option that allows Meowscarada to feast on Zapdos more effectively thanks to a newly gained Static immunity and resistance to both of its STAB moves.

Meowscarada fits best on balance teams that need a way to force hazard chip along with Knock Off spam to whittle down or outright threaten Pokemon that otherwise don't mind Knock Off such as Gliscor. Meowscarada's frailty courtesy of its pitiful bulk is sometimes hard to work around and limits its switch in opportunities, especially with common weaknesses courtesy of its exploitable defensive typing and a nasty 4x weakness to U-turn. Furthermore, Meowscarada, while being quite fast, is still outsped by monsters such as Darkrai, Dragapult, Weavile, and Zamazenta, the latter of which happens to be one of Meowscarada's best checks. Weavile's offensive tenacity combined with deadly Speed makes it a potent threat, which is why Rocky Helmet Skarmory is one of Meowscarada's best partner options on balance teams, as it punishes Triple Axel spam and shrugs off Weavile's hits comparatively easily. Meowscarada's role as an offensive pivot helps chip away at opposing cores while also bringing some of their key defensive threats into OHKO range for some frail teammates like Darkrai, Iron Boulder, and Gholdengo. Dragapult is another great partner for Meowscarada; it can blank Fighting-type attacks and follow up with a fast Will-O-Wisp to neuter Zamazenta as well. Meowscarada's defensive woes can be covered by bulky teammates that don't mind taking coverage moves from faster threats. On the physical side, Gouging Fire and Great Tusk are both excellent partners whose typings complement Meowscarada's. Gouging Fire acts as a great Will-O-Wisp absorber, while Great Tusk's role as a physically bulky offensive spinner with synergistic typing opens up multiple opportunities to clear hazards. On the special side, Clodsire and Galarian Slowking are both impressive partners thanks to their longevity and fantastic defensive profiles, with the former being able to blank setup sweepers like Darkrai and the latter being able to continue Meowscarada's momentum chain by using a slow Chilly Reception to take a hit or scout a switch, allowing Meowscarada to come in safely. Additionally, Galarian Slowking also threatens Pokemon that would commonly switch into Meowscarada like Iron Defense Zamazenta with Future Sight.

Choice Item.description:
Choice Item Meowscarada distinguishes itself as an amazing wallbreaker and offensive pivot of the tier thanks to its great Attack and Speed stats and fantastic coverage options alongside Protean, capable of dismantling common defensive picks such as Dondozo, Galarian Slowking, and Ting-Lu. Choice Band boosts its wallbreaking prowess to nuclear levels, whereas Choice Scarf makes it a great revenge killer capable of outspeeding foes like +1 Iron Valiant, Deoxys-S, and +1 Roaring Moon. Triple Axel functions as an incredible coverage move, hitting foes like Gliscor, Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Enamorus super effectively. U-turn allows Meowscarada to gain momentum against common switch-ins like Kingambit, Skarmory, and Corviknight. Trick can also be used over Flower Trick to cripple checks like Skarmory and bulky setup sweepers like Hatterene to hamper their effectiveness and giving Meowscarada more flexibility with moves. Tera Dark boosts the power of its Knock Off, notably allowing Choice Scarf Meowscarada to OHKO Galarian Slowking and Choice Band Meowscarada to OHKO offensive Volcarona and Cinderace. Tera Fire makes Meowscarada resistant to Ice, Fairy, and Fire, helping it against foes like Kyurem, Enamorus, Gouging Fire, and Volcarona while also making it immune to Will-O-Wisp from the likes of Dragapult and Volcarona's Flame Body, though it still struggles against Gouging Fire, as losing Protean means it fails to nail the 2HKO. In addition, Choice Scarf Meowscarada no longer OHKOes Gliscor, Roaring Moon, and Rillaboom, while Choice Band variants lose the OHKO on Raging Bolt. Finally, Tera Grass allows Meowscarada's Flower Trick to reach new heights of power, enabling Choice Scarf variants to secure an OHKO on bulky Calm Mind Primarina and Choice Band variants to OHKO maximum HP Great Tusk.

Choice Item Meowscarada fits well on bulky offense structures that appreciate its ability to pivot and remove items from opposing Pokemon, especially defensive ones, with Knock Off. Teammates such as Gholdengo and Volcarona appreciate Meowscarada pivoting against switch-ins like Skarmory and Corviknight, giving them opportunities to set up and clean. Other setup sweepers like Iron Defense Zamazenta also appreciate Meowscarada's ability to revenge kill foes like Gholdengo and non-Choice Scarf Enamorus for them to set up and sweep with minimum hindrance. Entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu, Skarmory, and Gliscor also appreciate Meowscarada using Knock Off to remove Heavy-Duty Boots, which makes foes like Volcarona take hazard damage. Special wallbreakers like Kyurem and Enamorus also appreciate Meowscarada threatening special walls like Primarina and Galarian Slowking. Meowscarada struggles against Steel-types like Skarmory, Archaludon, and Kingambit. Thus, teammates that threaten them, such as Dragapult and the aforementioned Gholdengo and Volcarona for Skarmory, and Pokemon like Zamazenta and Great Tusk for Kingambit, are appreciated. Zamazenta itself is also a threat to Meowscarada, so teammates that check it such as the aforementioned Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Enamorus should be acknowledged. Galarian Slowking also deserves a special mention as a teammate, as its Future Sight has excellent synergy with Meowscarada and helps it deal with Zamazenta as well as other Fighting-types like Iron Valiant by making Meowscarada's moves, especially Knock Off, harder to switch into with these Pokemon. In addition, it also forms a strong pivoting core with Meowscarada. Due to the risk of being Choice-locked into the wrong move, Meowscarada is also quite prediction reliant when facing structures with Pokemon like Gliscor and Dondozo. Therefore, Pokemon that pressure such cores, like Raging Bolt and Dragapult, are excellent partners. Meowscarada also doesn't like taking chip damage from hazards, as it repeatedly wants to pivot in and out of the field. Thus, it appreciates hazard control from teammates such as Great Tusk.

Offensive Pivot.description: Meowscarada is a powerful offensive pivot that utilizes its good Attack, high Speed, and great coverage to support teammates like Landorus-T. Triple Axel helps against Flying-types like Zapdos and Tornadus-T, and it can OHKO Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Garchomp. Toxic Spikes, when paired with Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Landorus-T that pressure Toxic Spikes absorbers such as Toxapex and Galarian Slowking, can be hard to deal with and put setup sweepers like Iron Boulder on a timer. Spikes can be used to chip down foes like Ferrothorn and Toxapex after they have had their Heavy-Duty Boots removed. U-turn pivots out Meowscarda from its checks like Toxapex and Ferrothorn and brings in wallbreakers like Urshifu-R and Zamazenta against them. Protective Pads protects Meowscarada from the abilities of Garchomp, Ferrothorn, and Zapdos and Rocky Helmet Pokemon like on Landorus-T, while Heavy-Duty Boots lets it avoid getting worn down by entry hazards. Tera Grass can help Meowscarada survive moves like Moonblast from Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Aqua Jet from Urshifu-R, if Protean has changed its type. Entry hazard setters like Garganacl, Landorus-T, and Gliscor appreciate having Meowscarada as a teammate, as it can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from foes such as Toxapex and Zapdos, making their hazards more potent. Meowscarada's mediocre defenses and weaknesses to Fighting-, Fire-, and Flying-type attacks mean it appreciates defensive teammates like Clefable, Alomomola, and Ferrothorn that resist or are neutral to those attacks. Meowscarada can pair well with other pivots like Landrous-T and Iron Crown, forming a VoltTurn core to help it deal with its checks like Toxapex. Meowscarada also pairs well with wallbreakers like Urshifu-R and Zamazenta, which can help break through checks like Ferrothorn.

Choice Band.description:
• Flower Trick is for non-Choice Band Dondozo, Gastrodon, and non-Weakness Policy Ting-Lu.
  • Knock Off is for Espathra, Sableye, and Magnezone.
  • Giga Impact is for non-Chilan Berry Volcarona and offensive Sylveon.
  • Play Rough beats non-Counter Annihilape and Special Attack Booster Energy Walking Wake, while Thunder Punch beats Corviknight.
  • Trick and Shadow Claw can be used for matchups against Bellibolt and Counter Annihilape but are generally not too reliable, as Bellibolt can 2HKO Meowscarada with Thunder after Trick, while Annihilape can use Rage Fist to beat Shadow Claw Meowscarada instead of Counter.
  • Protean can force opponents to guess what move Meowscarada will use. For example, non-Choice Band Iron Hands has to choose between Close Combat and Wild Charge to beat either Flower Trick or Play Rough from Meowscarada. Choosing incorrectly, however, allows Meowscarada to 2HKO Iron Hands.
  • An Adamant nature allows Meowscarada to have a better chance to beat more defensive Sylveon sets and Iron Defense Corviknight. A Timid nature allows Meowscarada to outspeed Iron Moth, Hisuian Zoroark, and non-Speed Booster Energy Walking Wake.

Choice Scarf.description:
• Flower Trick OHKOes non-defensive Azumarill and Sandy Shocks and beats Rotom-W.
  • Knock Off OHKOes Dragapult and defeats Espathra, Iron Leaves, and non-Metal Burst Sableye.
  • Play Rough hits Iron Valiant, Roaring Moon, and opposing Meowscarada.
  • Low Kick OHKOes Chien-Pao, Tyranitar, and non-Chople Berry Kingambit.
  • Giga Impact OHKOes non-defensive Volcarona and Iron Moth.
  • Trick can potentially catch bulky Pokemon like Endeavor Donphan and Corviknight off guard by locking them into a useless move.
  • Choice Scarf Meowscarada should be used against fast and frail Pokemon it can OHKO with a super effective move, like Dragapult, Espathra, and Hisuian Zoroark, or Pokemon it can 2HKO and survive a hit from with Protean's type change, like Iron Valiant and Walking Wake.

Choice Specs.description:
• Frenzy Plant OHKOes Dondozo, Rotom-W, non-Sap Sipper Azumarill, and some Ting-Lu variants.
  • Dark Pulse beats most Espathra variants, beats non-Metal Burst Sableye, and has a high chance to OHKO Farigiraf.
  • Chilling Water 2HKOes Donphan and usually 2HKOes specially defensive Skeledirge. It also allows Meowscarada to transform into a Water-type and survive Torch Song and Blast Burn from Skeledirge.
  • Power Gem beats Volcarona, Torkoal, and non-Speed Booster Energy Iron Jugulis.
  • Pollen Puff OHKOes Iron Leaves, Wo-Chien, and opposing Meowscarada.
  • While using Dark Pulse beats most Prankster Sableye, using it against Metal Burst Sableye leads to Meowscarada losing, so it should use Frenzy Plant instead.

SubSeed.description:
• Alternating between Substitute and Protect after setting up Leech Seed allows Meowscarada to slowly gain HP if it is not OHKOed by the foe. It is a potent Speed trap, meaning most weaker, slower foes lose to it.
  • With Protean, Meowscarada can gain a more useful defensive typing, such as Normal, Water, or Fairy, for the entire battle.
  • Chilling Water allows Meowscarada to defeat Arcanine and Skeledirge.
  • Charm nets wins against non-Choice Band Iron Hands and Garchomp.
  • Mental Herb gives Meowscarada better matchups against Taunt users like Annihilape, Corviknight, and Kingambit, as well as Encore users like Gardevoir.
  • Alternatively, Chople Berry + Leaf Storm defeats most Great Tusk variants. After Protect, Chople Berry also comes in handy versus other Pokemon with Fighting-type coverage like Arcanine.
  • The Defense and HP investment allows Meowscarada to defeat Choice Band Donphan. With low HP investment, Meowscarada also gains relatively more from Leech Seed. Maximum Speed allows Meowscarada to set up Leech Seed against as many Pokemon as possible.
  • When using four status moves, use a Jolly nature to maximize Struggle damage. With Chilling Water or Leaf Storm, use a Timid nature instead.
  • Using Protect before using Leech Seed against the likes of Donphan and Talonflame allows Meowscarada to survive Gunk Shot, Brave Bird, and Flare Blitz.
  • Use Leech Seed turn 1 to stay a Grass-type against foes like Azumarill, Bellibolt, and Dondozo.
  • Use Taunt turn 1 to maintain positive matchups against Espathra and Prankster Sableye.

Choice Scarf (Dark).description:
Meowscarada is a fantastic revenge killer for any Dark team due to its great Speed, coverage moves, and ability in Protean. Flower Trick makes Meowscarada a great late-game cleaner against Ground and Water teams, or just in general, taking out threats such as Great Tusk, Greninja, and Flutter Mane. Knock Off can target Ghost- and Psychic-type Pokemon, such as Gholdengo and Espathra, while removing items from walls such as Toxapex's Black Sludge, Klefki's Light Clay, and Skeledirge's Heavy-Duty Boots. Play Rough allows Meowscarada to clean through weakened Dragon teams, and it's a useful move late-game against other Dark teams. Alternatively, Meowscarada can run Toxic Spikes to cripple foes such as Great Tusk. U-turn picks up momentum for its team on forced switches, for example against Greninja. Choice Scarf plus its Speed and Protean allows it to take on threats such as Greninja, Choice Scarf Great Tusk, and Choice Specs Flutter Mane.

Greninja and Meowscarada can break through each other's checks: Greninja can beat Toxapex and Corviknight for Meowscarada, while Choice Scarf Meowscarada can revenge kill Flutter Mane for Greninja. Chien-Pao can prevent walls such as Toxapex from healing with Taunt, allowing Meowscarada to better pressure Water teams; it can also pressure Flying- and Dragon-types for Meowscarada, beating threats such as Dragonite. Chien-Pao can also break past walls such as Clodsire and Amoonguss for Meowscarada. Kingambit is an incredible late-game sweeper, picking off faster threats like Choice Scarf Flutter Mane with Sucker Punch, and it beats down Fairy-types such as Hatterene for Meowscarada. In return, Meowscarada can pick off Iron Valiant, allowing Kingambit to better pressure Fairy teams. Ting-Lu sets Stealth Rock and Spikes, allowing Meowscarada to clean more easily late-game. Additionally, it can check slower Pokemon such as Toxapex, Corviknight, and Clodsire with Taunt alongside Earthquake or Ruination. It can also stomach strong special attacks such as Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast, OHKOing Flutter Mane in return with Heavy Slam. Sableye can switch into Fighting-type attacks for Meowscarada, such as Great Tusk's Close Combat, and either cripple their users with Prankster Will-O-Wisp or force them to switch with Prankster Encore. Sableye can also prevent Pokemon like Clodsire and Brambleghast from setting entry hazards thanks to Prankster Taunt. Skuntank can ease the Fairy matchup by beating Hatterene one-on-one, which lets Meowscarada set Toxic Spikes safely. It can also trap Klefki with Fire Spin, preventing dual screens from staying on the field for too long. Finally, Hydreigon can take on walls such as Toxapex for Meowscarada with Substitute + Nasty Plot, safely setting up and overpowering them.

Choice Scarf (Grass).description:
Meowscarada finds itself as the best revenge killer to threatening setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Hydreigon, and Armarouge available to Grass teams thanks to its good offensive stats paired with a strong ability in Protean. This is further supported by a great Speed tier, which allows it to serve as a strong cleaner in multiple matchups such as versus Water, Fighting, Dark and Ghost teams with a Choice Scarf. Flower Trick enables Meowscarada to break through Defense boosted Pokemon such as Curse Dondozo, as well as Pokemon behind dual screens such as Flutter Mane. Play Rough provides the Fairy coverage that enables Meowscarada to threaten Fighting, Dragon, and Dark teams. U-turn is used to allow Meowscarada to pivot out against checks to it, such as Toxapex and Skeledirge, to bring in a teammate that can break through it, such as Breloom and Toedscruel, while also maintaining momentum.

While Meowscarada is an effective cleaner, it cannot exactly break through certain Pokemon by itself. Choice Band Breloom is a great teammate for Meowscarada, as it can break through Meowscarada's checks such as Toxapex, Kingambit, and Clodsire. Meowscarada is also vulnerable to Pokemon with strong priority and revenge killers faster than it such as Breloom and Choice Scarf Flutter Mane. Defensive walls such as Amoonguss and Wo-Chien can switch into said priority attacks and revenge killing attempts for Meowscarada. Amoonguss in particular also removes Toxic Spikes, which can be useful for Meowscarada and its teammates. Brambleghast and Toedscruel provide entry hazard removal in Rapid Spin, while also setting up hazards of their own in Spikes. Abomasnow gives an important Ice neutrality to Grass teams, which in tandem with the Defense boost provided by Snow allows it to serve as an answer to Ice-type threats such as Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur. Swords Dance Iron Leaves and Rotom-C provide counterplay to Corviknight that Grass teams otherwise lack, with the former appreciating Meowscarada pivoting out to it when facing Poison-types such as Dragalge and Toxapex, threatening Poison teams in general with its Psychic-type STAB moves and Fighting-type coverage attacks, while the latter forms a pivoting core with Meowscarada.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to Battle Stadium Singles Regulation F! This Pokemon has been updated to reflect the new Pokemon that The Indigo Disk has brought!

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Focus Sash.description:
• With its good Speed and wide movepool, Meowscarada makes for a potent lead.

  • Triple Axel: Triple Axel prevents Meowscarada from getting set-up on by Dragonite, and deals massive damage to Landorus-T and Roaring Moon.

  • Sucker Punch: Sucker Punch allows Meowscarada to better handle fast and priority using foes such as Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Bullet Punch Metagross.

  • Toxic Spikes: Meowscarada is an excellent offensive choice to lay Toxic Spikes, since it puts immense pressure on Ting-Lu, Urshifu-R, and Ursaluna-B leads.

  • Taunt: Thanks to its good Speed, Meowscarada makes particularly excellent use of Taunt, shutting down other entry hazard leads such as Ting-Lu and Hippowdon. It's also the best Meowscarada can muster against Archaludon, though beware of Body Press.

  • Protean versus Overgrow: Protean offers the most offensive flexibility, and is especially useful on Triple Axel sets to put Tera Flying Choice Scarf Landorus-T into Sucker Punch's KO range. For more supportive sets with Toxic Spikes, Overgrow is preferred to keep STAB on its attacks after it uses its support moves.

Other Options

  • Play Rough: While Triple Axel deals with most Dragon-types better, Play Rough can be a huge upset against Urshifu-S!

  • Low Kick versus Brick Break: Low Kick is worth considering if your team struggles with Kingambit, but Brick Break will deal far more damage to Chi-Yu.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: This Meowscarada has very little use for Terastallization, only using it in late-game situations where it can sweep.

  • Grass: When paired with an Overgrow boost, Tera Grass lets Flower Trick deal a huge amount of damage.

  • Stellar: Tera Stellar is the more flexible option for late-game sweeping. Just remember that moves only get the double BP boost if they match Meowscarada's current typing.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost saves Meowscarada from Normal-type priority, which can flip the match on unsuspecting Dragonite, Ogerpon-H, or Entei!

CRITTY CAT.description:
• With its good Attack, Speed, and access to Flower Trick and Knock Off, Meowscarada is a potent cleaner that is also hard to switch into.

  • Flower Trick: With its guaranteed critical hit, Flower Trick is a dangerous cleaning move once resistances to it have been sufficiently chipped.

  • U-turn: If using Protean, Meowscarada is a pivot that does far more damage than most users of U-turn, and helps Choice Scarf Meowscarada get out of some tricky early-game situations such as Chien-Pao leads.

  • Triple Axel versus Play Rough: Triple Axel may not be the most reliable move out there, but it strikes fear into the heart of Dragonite and Landorus-T, who can both be big offensive issues for Meowscarda. Play Rough isn't nearly as good at handling Dragon-types besides Roaring Moon, but it does blast through Urshifu-S.

  • Jolly versus Adamant: Jolly is usually preferred for outspeeding fast threats like Roaring Moon and Iron Valiant, but Adamant 's extra power can be justified on Choice Scarf since it still outspeeds Choice Scarf Garchomp.

  • Protean versus Overgrow: Protean’s type-shifting allows Meowscarada to make the most of its colorful movepool, particularly on Choice-locked sets, where the limitation to only changing types once is effectively nullified. f you intend to make use of a Tera type other than Grass or Stellar, Overgrow is worth considering, as it allows Meowscarada more flexibility with its moves by not changing type and removing STAB from Flower Trick or Knock Off.

Other Options

  • Low Kick versus Brick Break: Low Kick OHKOs Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, if using Protean, as well as Tera Normal Ursaluna-B if using Choice Band, but Brick Break deals far more damage against Chi-Yu. Both however, can face competition with Meowscarada's other coverage moves.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: With the Speed offered via Choice Scarf, Meowscarada can threaten otherwise faster foes, such as Chien-Pao and Flutter Mane, potentially putting more pressure on offensive teams.

  • Choice Band: Choice Band boosted Meowscarada hits incredibly hard, and with its naturally high Speed it can serve as a cleaner and a potential wallbreaker.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Terastallization overriding Protean means Meowscarada should usually only Terastallize to clean a weakened team late-game.

  • Grass: While Terastallizing does override Protean, Tera Grass Meowscarada can be used to power through teams ill-prepared for it. Dual screens teams in particular are especially vulnerable to the sheer power of Choice Band-boosted Tera Grass Flower Trick.

  • Dark: Tera Dark boosted Knock Off isn't as reliable at sweeping as Flower Trick, but it can surprise bulky Steel-types such as Scizor and Archaludon.

  • Stellar: Tera Stellar's one-time boost per attack can give Meowscarada more flexible cleaning options. If Meowscarada Terastallizes after using Protean, the type it currently is will get the double base power boost, which can lead to unexpectedly powerful coverage moves!

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives Meowscarada a Will-O-Wisp immunity and an Ice resistance that can surprise Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle.

Alternate EV Spreads

  • 76 HP / 244 Atk / 108 Def / 4 SpD / 76 Speed with Jolly: This spread allows Meowscarada to outspeed timid Chi-Yu while avoiding an OHKO from Breloom's Mach Punch, Chien-Pao's Ice Shard and Choice Band Dragonite's Extreme Speed.

Minor Optimizations

  • Trick And Neutral Natures: Trick can help Choice-locked sets incapacitate an annoying wall, such as Dondozo or Wo-Chien, by locking them into a single move. Make sure to use a neutral nature and use a Jolly Mint on Meowscarada, so it won't get confused by eating any Berry after Trick.

Choice Item.description: Meowscarada serves as a strong pivot and revenge killer that leverages its excellent STAB combination to threaten some of the tier's strongest physical walls like Quaquaval, Great Tusk, and Garganacl. U-turn allows Meowscarada to pivot out on its switch-ins like Corviknight and defensive Kommo-o. With Choice Band, Low Kick OHKOes Zamazenta-C on the switch and forces out Hiusian Goodra, Play Rough threatens to OHKO Kommo-o while chipping Sap Sipper Great Tusk, and Lash Out punishes chipped Intimidate Corviknight switching in. Choice Scarf is an option over Choice Band that trades the ability to OHKO defensive Kommo-o and 2HKO Scream Tail and Sap Sipper Great Tusk for being an exceptional Speed control option and having the ability to revenge kill slower Choice Scarf users like Azelf and Roaring Moon, as well as unboosted, naturally faster targets like Barraskewda and Hisuian Electrode. Meowscarada's ability to force out special walls like Hisuian Goodra, RegenVest Manaphy, and Roaring Moon is greatly appreciated by special wallbreakers and pivots like Walking Wake, Iron Moth, and Choice Specs Azelf, which in return force out the physical walls that wall Meowscarada like Corviknight and defensive Zapdos. Meowscarada is vulnerable to revenge killers like Dragonite, Zamazenta-C, and Chien-Pao, so teammates that can switch into these threats like Corviknight and Quaquaval make good partners.

Choice Scarf (Dark).description: Thanks to its fantastic movepool and Protean, Choice Scarf Meowscarada is the best revenge killer available for Dark teams, outrunning the likes of Regieleki, Speed-boosted Kommo-o, and Mega Swampert under rain. Flower Trick is Meowscarada's most powerful move, picking off weakened foes such as Tapu Lele and Terrakion. Play Rough is essential, as it deals with many threats to Dark teams like Galarian Zapdos, Mega Gallade, and Iron Valiant. U-turn allows Meowscarada to switch out of unfavorable situations, pivoting into powerful teammates such as Galarian Moltres and Mega Tyranitar while keeping momentum for the team. Knock Off cripples defensive switch-ins—such as Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Clefable—as well as offensive Pokemon like Zeraora and Iron Treads. Toxic Spikes can be run instead to better pressure Normal, Fairy, and Fighting teams. Meowscarada's teammates appreciate its ability to check a myriad of threats as well as its revenge killing capabilities. Wallbreakers like Galarian Moltres and Hydreigon are great partners to deal with physical walls like Celesteela and Mega Venusaur. Ting-Lu and Tyranitar provide entry hazard support for Meowscarada—ensuring it is able to net more KO's—and are great defensive pivots for it to fall back upon. Similarly, Mega Sableye provides a Fighting immunity, bounces back status moves, and prevents entry hazards from going up, letting Meowscarada switch in unscathed.

Choice Scarf (Grass).description: Meowscarada is an excellent choice for Grass teams thanks to its high Speed and Protean, enabling it to be a threatening revenge killer that can outspeed common threats such as Choice Scarf Iron Valiant and Gholdengo. Flower Trick is Meowscarada's best STAB option and is capable of dealing with weakened Pokemon like Clodsire and Spectrier. Flower Trick's guaranteed critical hit is also very useful in the Fairy matchup and lets Meowscarada revenge kill Azumarill and a weakened Tapu Lele behind Reflect. U-turn allows Meowscarada to maintain an advantage against its defensive checks like Corviknight by being able to pivot into its teammates like Scovillain. Knock Off is a tool to cripple Meowscarada's defensive switch-ins like Toxapex and Klefki in addition to the aforementioned Corviknight. Play Rough is a strong coverage option to threaten opposing Dragon-type Pokemon like Kommo-o, Kyurem, and Latios, which Grass teams tend to struggle against. Low Kick is a less frequent option but lets Meowscarada OHKO Bisharp while threatening Heatran with a 2HKO; however, Play Rough is preferred to have an easier time against Dragon teams. Meowscarada has an easier time revenge killing foes with entry hazard support from Ferrothorn and Cradily. Ferrothorn appreciates Meowscarada's ability to check Fighting-types like Mega Gallade, Iron Valiant and Galarian Zapdos with STAB Play Rough. Hisuian Lilligant is also a fantastic offensive partner for Meowscarada. It is able to check the Flying-types that switch into Meowscarada like Celesteela and Landorus-T while also assisting in the Dragon matchup, outspeeding common Pokemon like Garchomp and Dragonite. Hisuian Lilligant also makes the Steel matchup easier for Grass; its ability to threaten Heatran is appreciated by Meowscarada, while Meowscarada can threaten Gholdengo with Knock Off, which Lilligant cannot beat. Mega Venusaur is also a mandatory defensive partner for Meowscarada; its Bug neutrality and bulk allows it to act as a consistent check to Mega Scizor, which easily switches into any move of Meowscarada, and Venusaur is able to check it with Hidden Power Fire. Mega Venusaur also checks opposing Fairy-types for Meowscarada like Tapu Koko, Mega Diancie, and Iron Valiant, while Meowscarada is able to threaten the Psychic-types that force out Mega Venusaur such as Latios, Mega Alakazam, and Victini. Whismicott is one of the best hazard removal options on Grass, and Meowscarada appreciates not having Stealth Rock and Spikes chip it down, because it comes in often to threaten a KO. Whimsicott's Fairy typing also allows Meowscarada and its teammates not to be overwhelmed by Dragon-types like Garchomp, and it can encore Calm Mind Mega Latias. Celebi with Nasty Plot and Groundium Z can break defensive Steel-types like Heatran and Hisuian Goodra while also being able to threaten opposing Poison-types like Alolan Muk and Toxapex.

Defensive.description:
• Skeledirge functions as a catch-all check to the strongest physical attackers in Ubers, notably taking on Koraidon, Zacian-C, and some variants of E-Killer Arceus.
  • Unaware fully prevents Swords Dance Koraidon and Zacian-C from breaking down Skeledirge through pure force, in contrast to other physical walls like Groudon and Toxapex. Unaware even lets Skeledirge have some use against special attackers like Calm Mind + Will-O-Wisp Arceus-Fairy.
  • Torch Song is a good STAB move that boosts Skeledirge's Special Attack each time it's used, making it a good way to force out foes and turning Skeledirge into a potential late-game wincon.
  • There are two options for the secondary attacking move. Hex pairs very well with Will-O-Wisp, becoming a 130-Base Power STAB move. On the other hand, Earth Power is very useful against Pokemon that use Tera Fire to avoid burns, such as Koraidon, and it also hits Miraidon and Eternatus switch-ins hard.
  • The combination of reliable recovery with Slack Off and Heavy-Duty Boots means that Skeledirge can easily stay healthy throughout the game and not worry about entry hazards.
  • Tera Fairy is useful against Choice Band Koraidon in particular, as it can break through Skeledirge with Dragon Claw or Outrage; the downside is that Tera Fairy makes Skeledirge vulnerable to Zacian-C's Behemoth Blade. Tera Flying gives Skeledirge an immunity to Ground-type moves, which can be helpful against Arceus-Ground and Stomping Tantrum Koraidon. Tera Water provides a good all-around neutral defensive type to use which maintains an Ice-type resistance for Chien-Pao and Calyrex-I.
  • Skeledirge offers a great deal of role compression to teams thanks to its ability to reliably check so many offensive threats.
  • Skeledirge's main flaw is that it can be passive and vulnerable to double switches, U-turn, and Taunt.
  • Koraidon can often take advantage of the predictable switch to Skeledirge to bring in deadly offensive threats such as Chi-Yu, Walking Wake, and Kyogre with U-turn. As a result, it may be advantageous to anticipate U-turn in these scenarios.
  • Taunt is often employed as a method to bypass Skeledirge's Will-O-Wisp, especially by Koraidon and E-Killer Arceus. If you expect the foe to use Taunt, taking advantage of the situation and gaining Special Attack boosts with Torch Song is a great way to limit their ability to wallbreak.
  • Ting-Lu and Clodsire are excellent teammates for Skeledirge, as they cover most of the special attackers that come in on it, especially Miraidon, while Skeledirge can in turn handle most physical threats. Together they form a solid defensive backbone.
  • Skeledirge is unable to take on Ground-type physical attackers like Arceus-Ground, Tera Ground Zacian-C, and Groudon without using Tera itself. As a result, Pokemon that resist or are immune to Ground like Corviknight, Giratina-O, Landorus-T, and Arceus-Grass make for good partners. Corviknight has the additional benefit of solidifying the matchup against E-Killer Arceus.
  • Arceus-Fairy is useful as a backup check to Koraidon, and it makes it much more difficult for Koraidon to get easy momentum with U-turn.

When it comes to Unaware Pokemon, Skeledirge is one of the best available; it has great physical bulk and a solid move in Torch Song, which boosts its already good Special Attack. These traits make it a hard-to-break physical wall and a potential wincon as well. Will-O-Wisp lets it cripple physical attackers such as Mega Tyranitar, Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T while also punishing Water-types such as Rotom-W. Combined with Will-O-Wisp, Hex helps it overwhelm passive checks in Toxapex, Gastrodon, and Clodsire while also allowing Skeledirge to sweep statused teams. While not as strong as Hex, Shadow Ball is a decent option as it's more consistent. Tera Water allows Skeledirge to beat rain teams by spreading burns against rain sweepers such as Mega Swampert, Barraskewda, and Floatzel. On the other hand, Tera Fairy allows it to counter Dragon Dance Dragapult and avoid Pursuit from Kingambit, Mega Tyranitar, and Weavile while also keeping a Fighting resistance, meaning it can still check Zamazenta. It also removes Skeledirge's Ground weakness, allowing it to comfortably burn Pokemon like Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T. Skeledirge struggles against Heatran and Garganacl, as it can't burn them nor deal significant damage to them. Therefore, Pokemon that pressure them like Garchomp and Rotom-W for the former and Cover Cloak Gholdengo for the latter make good partners. Skeledirge also hates losing its item, so Knock Off absorbers like Flyinium Z Tornadus-T and Gliscor make for good teammates. The former can also weaken Heatran for it while Skeledirge can burn Mega Tyranitar. Special sponges like Gastrodon, Clodsire, and Toxapex all appreciate Skeledirge's ability to cripple physical attackers such as Kartana, Mega Lopunny, and Kingambit, alleviating the pressure these Pokemon exert on them. In return, they can all handle special attackers like Gholdengo, Choice Specs Dragapult, and Mega Charizard Y.

Physically Defensive.description:
• Will-O-Wisp burns physical attackers like Iron Hands, Great Tusk, and Annihilape.
  • Torch Song provides consistent damage while also ignoring Substitute, which helps versus Espathra, Volcarona, and Corviknight.
  • Encore shuts down slower Pokemon that use status moves like Soak Bellibolt and Fake Tears Sylveon. It also stops foes like Choice item Gardevoir and Choice Scarf Sableye from using Trick freely.
  • Blast Burn allows Skeledirge to OHKO threats like Iron Treads and Kingambit.
  • The investment in HP and Defense allows Skeledirge to survive Knock Off from Choice Band Meowscarada and Headlong Rush from Attack Booster Energy Great Tusk.
  • In combination with Weakness Policy, Blaze allows Skeledirge to OHKO Meowscarada after Meowscarada transforms into a Rock-type and uses Power Gem.
  • Unaware helps versus setup Pokemon like Bulk Up Annihilape, non-Lumina Crash Espathra, Volcarona, and Swords Dance Iron Hands.
  • Sitrus Berry helps against physical attackers and acts as insurance in case Will-O-Wisp misses against threats like Iron Hands.
  • Mental Herb is useful against opposing Encore users like Annihilape and Gardevoir.
  • Air Balloon is helpful against Ground-types like Great Tusk and Donphan.

Physically Defensive (Fire).description:
Skeledirge is a great choice for Fire teams as a non-passive physically defensive wall. With Will-O-Wisp and Unaware, it can check physical set-up sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragonite or Belly Drum Azumarill that threaten Fire. Additionally, Torch Song lets Skeledirge fire back against these threats while raising its Special Attack and reducing passitivity. Hex pairs incredibly well with Will-O-Wisp, as it threatens large amounts of damage on burned foes, while Shadow Ball is a more consistent STAB option that hits opposing Skeledirge for more immediate damage. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Skeledirge avoid entry hazards chipping away at it whenever it switches in.

Volcarona is a great teammate for Skeledirge, as it can threaten Dark-types that annoy Skeledirge such as Ting-Lu and Kingambit. In return, Skeledirge can burn physical attackers, like Dragonite, giving Volcarona more setup opportunities. Paldean Tauros-F is also a good teammate, since it can threaten the aforementioned Dark-types with its Fighting STAB while also having Intimidate to help neutralize physical attackers that Skeledirge cannot handle on its own, such as Roaring Moon. Additionally, its Choice Scarf set can outspeed and KO Greninja. Torkoal pairs well with Skeledirge due to its ability to both remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin and set them up, all while also powering up Skeledirge's Torch Song. Cinderace is a fairly good partner as well due to High Jump Kick, letting it remove Dark-types aiming to threaten Skeledirge, while also being able to remove entry hazards with Court Change and hit Poison-types such as Clodsire and Toxapex with Zen Headbutt. Scovillain is a good partner, since it can remove Water-types such as Dondozo and Rotom-W with its Grass STAB. Both Talonflame and Air Balloon Iron Moth alleviate Skeledirge's weakness to threats such as Great Tusk and Ting-Lu.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Defensive Gator.description:
• Thanks to instant recovery, Unaware, and the snowballing potential of Torch Song, Skeledirge is a viable alternative to Dondozo.

  • Will-O-Wisp versus Yawn: Will-O-Wisp vastly improves Skeledirge's match-up against fearsome physical foes such as Kingambit, while Yawn works exceptionally well with Stealth Rock support.

  • Earth Power: If Iron Moth is particularly troubling, Earth Power is the best solution for it. It also hits Chi-Yu switch-ins hard.

  • Substitute: Substitute is a good way around status, especially Garganacl's Salt Cure. It also becomes effective when used on Toxic Spikes teams.

Other Options

  • Encore: When paired with Substitute, Skeledirge can seriously punish passive Pokemon, though at a serious cost in coverage.

  • Flame Charge: Despite Skeledirge's low Speed, stacking Flame Charge boosts can make it difficult to check, though it'll often need multiple boosts to outspeed threats without compromising its bulk.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: Skeledirge's defensive typing isn't without its merits, but the wide variety of weaknesses it has often forces Skeledirge to Terastallize to check major threats like Chien-Pao and Dragonite.

  • Fairy: Terastallizing into the Fairy typing removes Skeledirges glaring weakness to Dark and provides an overall superior defensive typing. making Chien-Pao and Ting-Lu far more reasonable to deal with. It also provides a neutral typing for the inevitable Shadow Balls that will be thrown at Skeledirge, like from Flutter Mane or Gholdengo.

  • Normal: While Tera Normal isn't fantastic defensively, it lets Skeledirge severely punish attempts from special attacking Ghost-types such as Flutter Mane and Gholdengo to check it.

  • Water: A Water Tera type lets Skeledirge take on opposing Water attacks, providing a valuable turn to burn foes like Azumarill and Palafin-H. It should be noted that Tera Water tends to be a safer option versus the common Gholdengo, as it does not often run Thunderbolt.

  • Fire: Despite the defensive nature of this set, Tera Fire's increased power for Torch Song is welcome, and it still helps Skeledirge against Chien-Pao.

Items

  • Leftovers versus Sitrus Berry: Residual recovery helps Skeledirge use Torch Song more freely. Leftovers is the best option since Skeledirge has instant recovery, but Sitrus Berry with an even HP stat can be used to restore some health after getting hit by Ruination.

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak ignores the secondary effects of Salt Cure and Acid Spray, improving Skeledirge's match-up against Garganacl, Iron Moth, and Bellibolt.

  • Safety Goggles: The immunity to Spore Skeledirge gains lets it check Breloom, Amoonguss, and Brute Bonnet far more effectively.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: This makes Skeledirge less pressured to Terastallize to rid itself of its Stealth Rock weakness.

Alternate EV Spreads

  • 220 HP / 76 Def / 212 SpD with Bold: This EV spread allows both Tera Fairy and Water Skeledirge to avoid a 2HKO from a plethora of offensive threats, such as Focus Sash Chien-Pao, Modest Gholdengo, Adamant Azumarill, and Choice Specs Dragapult, while still boasting significant physical bulk.

Blunder Song.description:
• With Blunder Policy, this Skeledirge provides a unique approach to offense: it'll either put important foes to sleep or threaten to snowball into a sweep with Speed and Special Attack boosts!

  • Shadow Ball: Even with Skeledirge's wide variety of viable Tera types, Shadow Ball is still an excellent secondary STAB attack for hitting Dragapult, Flutter Mane, and opposing Skeledirge.

  • Earth Power: Earth Power is Skeledirge's best option against Garganacl and Chi-Yu, and it makes checking Iron Moth feasible.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: Beyond the many weaknesses Skeledirge's typing has, it only has one shot of having +2 Speed, so Terastallizing is preferred over switching when possible.

  • Fairy: With this Skeledirge's more offensive nature, Tera Fairy's immunity to powerful Dragon-type attacks is a big help, and it makes Tera Blast an effective tool against bulky foes such as Ting-Lu, Baxcalibur, and Garchomp.

  • Water: Besides being a fantastic defensive typing, Tera Water gives Skeledirge the chance to pick off weakened Iron Bundle as they use Hydro Pump and gives it a good attack against Chi-Yu, Garganacl, and Iron Moth.

  • Fire: In addition to removing the troublesome Ghost-type weakness, Tera Fire makes sweeping with Torch Song require less setup.

  • Normal: Tera Normal gives Skeledirge a key Ghost-type immunity, taking advantage of common Choiced Ghost-types such as Gholdengo.

  • Grass: Tera Grass vastly improves Skeledirge's matchup against Breloom, Rotom-W, and Brute Bonnet.

EV Spreads

  • All EV spreads for this set should outspeed Dragapult after missing Sing.

  • 204 HP / 4 Def / 132 SpA / 4 SpD / 164 Spe with Modest: The HP investment in this spread lets Skeledirge survive one Earthquake from Garchomp or one Throat Chop from Jolly Focus Sash Chien-Pao when staying not Terastallizing, and one Choice Specs Hydro Pump from Iron Bundle when Tera Fairy or Tera Normal.

  • 92 HP / 252 SpA / 164 Spe with Modest: This spread sacrifices bulk for being able to OHKO Iron Bundle with Torch Song after Stealth Rock damage and doing the same to Kingambit with Tera Fire.

  • 164 HP / 180 Def / 164 Spe with Bold: This defensive spread allows Tera Skeledirge to always avoid a 2HKO from Jolly Choice Band Dragonite's Extreme Speed and avoids getting 2HKOed by Baxcalibur's 4-hit Icicle Spear when Tera Normal or Fairy.

  • 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Modest or Timid: A huge sacrifice in bulk makes it harder for Skeledirge to set up, but the Speed investment does allow it to outspeed several major Choice Scarf threats after missing Sing. Modest variants will outspeed up to Modest Choice Scarf Chi-Yu and Jolly Choice Scarf Annihilape, while Timid sets will Speed tie with +1 Espathra.

Offensive Gator.description: This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

Spinblocker.description: Thanks to its typing and good physical bulk, Skeledirge serves as an excellent spinblocker that can wall common spinners such as Iron Treads with Earth Eater and Quaquaval with Desolate Land. It also walls threats like Choice Band Cinderace and Zamazenta-C and, depending on its ability, Garchomp and Primordial Sea Zapdos. Skeledirge can then use Torch Song to set up on passive opponents like Scream Tail and non-Well-Baked Body Blissey or Will-O-Wisp to burn an incoming foe, including switch-ins like Hisuian Goodra and Alolan Muk. Hex alongside Will-O-Wisp does more damage, but Shadow Ball can be used for more consistent damage. Skeledirge pairs well with hazard setters such as Garchomp and Iron Treads, as it allows them to keep their hazards on the field, and they can in turn handle opposing Well-Baked Body Pokemon. Due to its middling Special Defense, Skeledirge appreciates specially defensive teammates like Blissey and Hisuian Goodra. Additionally, a teammate that covers the type that Skeledirge chooses not to be immune to, such as Quaquaval for Earth Eater variants and Corviknight for Desolate Land variants, helps form a strong defensive core. Dark-types like Meowscarada and Chien-Pao also OHKO Skeledirge with a bit of chip damage, so Pokemon like Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing that can threaten them are appreciated.

Physically Defensive (Ghost).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Defensive.description: Skeledirge is a good physical wall, acting as an important check to Koraidon, Zacian-C, and Extreme Killer Arceus. It can switch into these powerful Swords Dance sweepers, beating them or halting their sweep. Torch Song allows it to potentially sweep a weakened team late-game. Earth Power is an option that chips Miraidon and Eternatus as well as giving it a super effective hit against Tera Fire Zacian-C and Koraidon. Fairy is the ideal Tera type, giving Skeledirge an immunity to Koraidon's Dragon-type attacks and removing its weaknesses to Ground- and Ghost-type attacks from foes like Arceus-Ground, Calyrex-S, and Giratina-O. Tera Flying is a niche option that further improves its matchup against Arceus-Ground while avoiding super effective Behemoth Blade from Zacian-C. Skeledirge is a good fit on balance teams that appreciate it checking common setup threats and carrying teammates that make up for its shortcomings and bad matchups. Skeledirge is very vulnerable to Miraidon, Kyogre, Calyrex-S, and Arceus-Ground, so it appreciates teammates like Ting-Lu, Eternatus, Wo-Chien, and Giratina-O to handle these powerful attackers. Likewise, Skeledirge pairs well with fast attackers and priority users such as Calyrex-S, Choice Scarf Koraidon, and Extreme Killer Arceus, which can threaten the foes that force Skeledirge out and revenge kill Pokemon it checks if it is overwhelmed.

Rapid Spin.description: Quaxly is a notable Rapid Spin user in LC due to its access to reliable recovery and good matchup into entry hazard setters like Pawniard and Glimmet; it can also double as a capable sweeper thanks to Moxie. Aqua Cutter gives up some power compared to Liquidation but does not make contact, which avoids activating Greavard's Fluffy and Voltorb's Static, and removes the risk of activating Pawniard's Defiant with a Defense drop. Aqua Jet is STAB priority that OHKOs Hisuian Growlithe, while Brave Bird provides super effective coverage versus Grass- and Fighting-types like Toedscool and Foongus. Encore can lock opposing Pokemon into unfavorable moves, such as weak setup moves, gaining momentum for Quaxly's team. Quaxly can use Tera Grass for a better matchup versus Electric- and Grass-types as well as a valuable immunity to Spore from Foongus and Toedscool. Tera Flying can also be used with Brave Bird to turn Quaxly into a more potent offensive threat. Pokemon weak to Stealth Rock, such as Hisuian Growlithe, Wingull, and Nymble, are great partners for Quaxly, as they appreciate the removal of entry hazards to be used at their full potential. Foongus is another good partner, as it can safely switch into Grass-types and provides valuable Spore support. Pokemon such as Toedscool and Wattrel check Electric-types for Quaxly.

Choice Scarf (Fighting).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Rapid Spin (Water).description:
Quaquaval is a great pick for Water teams due to its unique access to Rapid Spin, threatening presence in the Steel and Dark matchups, and potential to snowball unsuspecting teams. Close Combat targets Steel- and Dark-types like Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and Hydreigon. Alternatively, Brick Break may be used to retain Quaquaval's defensive stats and clear dual screens in the Ice and Fairy matchups at the cost of extra damage. Aqua Step enables Quaquaval to function as a potential late-game cleaner and threatens Pokemon like Volcarona, Skeledirge, and Unaware Clodsire. Rapid Spin is used to clear entry hazards, aiding against entry hazard-stacking teams. The given EV spread allows Quaquaval to outpace Flutter Mane and Chien-Pao after a single Rapid Spin or Aqua Step boost, OHKO Flutter Mane after one Moxie boost, and better deal with priority moves from Breloom and Kingambit.

Greninja breaks past troublesome walls like Toxapex, Sableye, and Water Absorb Clodsire due to its wide range of coverage. Toxapex serves as an answer to threats like Meowscarada, Breloom, and Iron Valiant, sets up Toxic Spikes, and hinders Pokemon like Rotom-W, Dragonite, and Quagsire with Toxic. Gastrodon and Quagsire are valued for their Electric-type immunity against Pokemon like Rotom-W, Sandy Shocks, and Magnezon as well as their entry hazards, supporting Quaquaval as a cleaner. Pelipper can set rain to boost Quaquaval's Aqua Step and pressures Grass-types like Breloom, Infiltrator Brambleghast, and Meowscarada with Hurricane. Slowking can safely pivot into Quaquaval with Chilly Reception and aids in late-game cleaning with Future Sight.

(Regulation C) Moxie Sweeper.description:
• Aqua Step and Moxie give Quaquaval a niche as a late-game sweeper that doesn't always need a turn of setup.

  • Aqua Jet: Aqua Jet's ability to pick off weakened threats pairs very well with Moxie, giving it new potential win conditions.

  • Ice Spinner: This is Quaquaval's best way of dealing big damage to Dragonite and Garchomp.

  • Encore: Encore lets Quaquaval punish slower foes such as Corviknight by getting an easy setup opportunity or by simply forcing them to switch.

Other Options

  • Wave Crash: While Wave Crash is Quaquaval's strongest Water-type attack, the recoil can be problematic for Focus Sash sets.

  • Roost: Recovery might seem odd on such an offensive Pokemon, but it helps Quaquaval avoid getting worn down against bulkier teams.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: With Moxie and Aqua Step boosting its offensive output, Quaquaval doesn't always have to rely on Terastallization.

  • Water: Boosting Aqua Step's and Aqua Jet's power opens up new sweeping chances late-game.

  • Electric: Tera Electric lets Quaquaval deal massive damage to Azumarill and wear down Dondozo switch-ins with Tera Blast.

  • Steel: Tera Steel can let Quaquaval get the jump on Fairy- and Dragon-types such as Flutter Mane and Garchomp by resisting their attacks.

Items

  • Focus Sash: With Focus Sash, Quaquaval trades potential wallbreaking for getting surprise sweeps against more offensive teams.

  • Assault Vest: Even without defensive investment, Assault Vest can let Quaquaval take a super-effective hit against some naturally faster threats, such as Psychic Chi-Yu and Energy Ball Iron Moth.

  • Mystic Water: The power increase to Aqua Step and Aqua Jet makes sweeping easier, especially when paired with Tera Water.

(Regulation C) Bulky.description:
• While Quaquaval's bulk is only serviceable, having both Roost and a great support movepool makes it a reasonable defensive option that does particularly well against Kingambit.

  • Taunt and Bulk Up: Taunt pairs particularly well with Bulk Up, letting it set up on surprising foes such as Corviknight.

  • Substitute: Substitute lets Quaquaval stall out OHKO moves from the likes of Dondozo, and it protects it from Garganacl's Salt Cure.

  • Encore: Not only does Encore give Quaquaval new chances to set up, but it also punishes passive play from Unaware walls such as Skeledirge.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Setup Quaquaval will often have to use Terastallization to deal with the checks switching into it.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Quauqaval a better matchup against Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, who can be fairly problematic otherwise.

  • Flying: While it has very little defensive synergy with Quaquaval's previous typing, Tera Flying lets Quaquaval effectively stall out Dondozo if using Taunt, or Substitute and Encore together.

  • Grass: Tera Grass makes Quaquaval's match-up against Rotom-W much smoother.

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Quaquaval can set up against most defensive Garchomp thanks to the Dragon Tail immunity.

Items

  • Leftovers: The passive recovery from Leftovers works great with Substitute sets in particular.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet pairs well with Taunt and Tera Flying, letting Quaquaval easily play around Dondozo and Corviknight while setting up Bulk Up.

  • Covert Cloak: If running Substitute isn't possible, Covert Cloak is Quaquaval's best shot at defeating Garganacl.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 156 SpD / 100 Spe with Jolly: This EV spread allows Quaquaval to outspeed Meowscarada after an Aqua Step while raising its special bulk. If not using Bulk Up, running Defense EVs is also viable instead.

  • 244 HP / 4 Atk / 28 Def / 164 SpD / 68 Spe with Careful: The Special Defense investment and Careful nature let Quaquaval survive Timid Flutter Mane's unboosted Moonblast at full health, and the Speed lets it outspeed Garchomp after Aqua Step.

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: Maximizing Speed ensures that Quaquaval outspeeds Choice Scarf Gholdengo, Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult after using Aqua Step.

Physically Defensive.description: Due to its incredible utility moves in Rapid Spin and Knock Off, longevity from Roost, and good typing, Quaquaval functions incredibly as an entry hazard remover and pivot and checks Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Barraskewda. Quaquaval has a multitude of viable abilities, such as Scrappy to let Rapid Spin and Low Kick affect Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Ceruledge as well as Intimidate and Fluffy to further increase its bulk, allowing it to more safely switch in on top physical threats such as Roaring Moon and offensive Great Tusk. Thanks to U-turn, Quaquaval can allow frail attackers including Azelf and Meowscarada to safely switch in. Knock Off can be used for its general reliability and utility, while Low Kick wears down opposing Hisuian Goodra and Blissey. Quaquaval is quite vulnerable to special attackers such as Azelf, Deoxys-S, and Hisuian Electrode. To counter these significant threats, RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta can be used to safely switch in on most of their attacks and threaten to deal decent chip damage to them with Knock Off or U-turn. Some teammates that benefit from Quaquaval's presence include Roaring Moon and Deoxys-S, as they don't enjoy taking Spikes damage, so they appreciate its hazard removing capabilities.

Magic Guard.description: Quaquaval is a decent wallbreaker, using its strong STAB moves, and solid Attack stat to burst through bulky opponents foes like Great Tusk, Deoxys-D, and Skarmory. Brave Bird hits Desolate Land users such as Iron Moth, Volcarona, and Ceruledge on the switch-in, but Quaquaval can use Close Combat to help against Pokemon like Heatran and Manaphy, though this does have the drawback of making it easier to be revenge killed. Rapid Spin is used as not only entry hazard removal for Quaquaval and its teammates but also a way to let it outspeed and threaten foes like Hisuian Electrode, Galarian Zapdos, and Iron Boulder. Knock Off can be used to both remove items from Pokemon like Corviknight, Deoxys-D, and Mandibuzz, as well as hit Ghost-types such as Ceruledge and Gholdengo. U-turn is a less prominent option to be able to pivot on checks like Corviknight and Manaphy. Roost is used to keep Quaquaval healthy potentially allowing it to outlast its checks, while Swords Dance can be used as a way to let it end games by blasting through its checks like Corviknight, Gholdengo, and physically defensive Manaphy. Offensive Psychic-types such as Azelf, Iron Boulder, and Deoxys-S appreciate Quaquaval's presence, as it's able to take on Dark- and Steel-types such as Roaring Moon, Chien-Pao, and Gholdengo for them. Quaquaval is slow, and struggles to deal with faster foes such as Deoxys-S, Dragonite, and Latios, so it benefits from having teammates like Swampert, Corviknight, and Mandibuzz to help with checking them defensively and bringing it in safely.

All Out Attacker (Bug).description:
With access to nearly unresisted First Impression and U-turn due to Tinted Lens, Lokix is an amazing revenge killer for Bug teams. Its ability to scare out many common threats such as Espathra, Chien-Pao, and Dragapult is highly valuable. Lokix struggles to break past many physically defensive walls like Quagsire, Dondozo, and Corviknight; however, it can pivot in teammates—such as Vivillon and Volcarona—that can beat them. A Choice Band with an Adamant nature maximizes Lokix's damage output and can utilise Axe Kick to lure and defeat Steel-types like Kingambit and Iron Treads. Alternatively, Life Orb avoids a Choice lock and makes use of Sucker Punch to pick off threats that First Impression alone cannot such as Gholdengo and Flutter Mane. Throat Chop lets Lokix deal good unresisted STAB damage and prevents Skeledirge from using Torch Song, which is extremely valuable and one of the reasons Lokix is a necessity for Bug teams.

Lokix is highly susceptible to entry hazards and is often not quite strong enough to OHKO many Pokemon. Forretress is a great entry hazard remover and entry hazard setter, fixing both of those issues. Forretress also has a good defensive profile, acting as a sponge for absorbing damage, and it can even form a VoltTurn core with Lokix. Scizor removes Fairy-types that threaten Lokix such as Hatterene and Iron Valiant and allows Lokix to clean up after it has done enough damage. Volcarona takes care of Steel-types that don't fall to Axe Kick such as Corviknight and Scizor. Lokix can remove Ghost-types—such as Gholdengo, Dragapult, and Flutter Mane—to enable Slither Wing and Heracross, letting them spam their powerful Fighting-type moves and clean up after Lokix. Frosmoth can deal with many bulky Ground-types—such as Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Ting-Lu—and Vivillon improves the Fighting-type matchup by beating Great Tusk, Gallade, and Paldean Tauros-W and can answer Dondozo with the combination of Sleep Powder and Energy Ball. Masquerain can set up Sticky Web, which gives Lokix an amazing Speed advantage versus Iron Treads, Iron Moth, and Walking Wake, making Life Orb Lokix immensely threatening.

Swords Dance (Dark).description:
Excellent for the Dark mirror and revenge-kills threats such as Barraskewda.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

Tinted Offense.description:
• The combination of First Impression and Tinted Lens make Lokix one of the most threatening revenge killers in the format, able to outprioritize and KO foes regardless of resistance.

  • First Impression is Lokix's most important attack, but it can only be used as the first attack after it switches in.

  • U-turn can be punishing against offensive and slow teams as the lack of resists means Lokix can keep switching in and dealing big damage with First Impression, at the cost of making it vulnerable to hazards.

  • Leech Life is the strongest Bug-type move Lokix learns outside of First Impression, with the added benefit of healing recoil damage.

  • Sucker Punch is a powerful STAB priority move, enabling Lokix to outprioritize foes even after it has used First Impression.

  • Axe Kick is the only coverage move of note in Lokix's moveset due to its high Base Power. Be wary of the low accuracy and recoil that occurs should it miss.

  • Throat Chop is the most powerful Dark-type move Lokix learns. It also has the side benefit of disabling Roar from Hippowdon and Hyper Voice from Sylveon.

  • Swords Dance is an option to make Lokix a sweeper instead of a revenge killer.

Items

Life Orb: Life Orb enables easier revenge kills at the cost of recoil.

Silver Powder: Silver Powder raises the power of First Impression without the recoil from Life Orb, and it also frees up Life Orb for a teammate to use instead.

Tera Types

Bug: A Bug Tera Type increases the damage of First Impression, allowing Lokix to OHKO foes it could not otherwise, such as Dragapult.

Swords Dance (Bug).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

monotype.comments:
Other Options

Electric

All-out Attacker: Leppa Berry can be used over Punching Glove to allow Pawmot to use Revival Blessing twice in one game.

All-out Attacker (Electric).description:
Pawmot is a great wallbreaker on Electric teams, outspeeding foes like Garchomp, Landorus, and Sandy Shocks. Close Combat does not receive the benefits of Pawmot's ability and item, but it helps beat pesky foes like Ursaluna-B, Hisuian Goodra, and Baxcalibur, which are immune to or resist its Electric-type attacks. Close Combat is also a good move to beat foes like Ting-Lu and Kingambit which Pawmot's teammates might struggle against. Thunder Punch is an alternative STAB move, as it hits common walls like Corviknight and Toxapex while also threatening Pelipper on rain teams, thus preventing the opponent from setting up rain for Barraskewda repeatedly. Thunder Punch also helps versus Belly Drum Azumarill, preventing it from setting up. Mach Punch is Pawmot's preferred second STAB move, as it offers strong priority, securing an OHKO on foes like Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Greninja after a single layer of Spikes. Mach Punch also nullifies Kingambit's Sucker Punch by outspeeding it with priority. Revival Blessing is another alternative that can be used over Mach Punch, as it offers a unique and valuable type of utility by allowing a teammate to be revived. This may prove to be a huge benefit in some matchups like the Electric mirror, where Pawmot can revive teammates like Sandy Shocks after the opposing Rotom-W is low on HP or has already fainted. Ice Punch hits foes like the Landorus formes, Gliscor, Clodsire, and mixed Amoonguss. The last coverage move is Seed Bomb, as it hits Pokemon like Gastrodon, Quagsire, and Rotom-W, which can prove troublesome for Pawmot's teammates to break. Seed Bomb also compounds with Thunder Punch to hit every Water-type in the game for super effective damage, making Pawmot incredibly powerful in the Water matchup. Punching Glove helps Pawmot avoid chip damage from Rocky Helmet on foes like Rough Skin Garchomp while also avoiding status effects like burn from foes like Flame Body Volcarona, Moltres, and Talonflame.

Pawmot greatly benefits from teammates like Regieleki, which can use Rapid Spin to remove entry hazards for Pawmot and pivot well into other teammates with the help of Volt Switch. Regieleki's extremely high Speed tier also allows it to revenge kill foes like Enamorus, weakened Walking Wake, and, if using Magnet and Wild Charge, Flutter Mane. In return, Regieleki appreciates Pawmot dealing with Ground-type Pokemon, like Quagsire and Gliscor, with the help of Seed Bomb and Ice Punch due to Regieleki's lack of coverage moves. Iron Hands is another great teammate, as it allows Pawmot to run alternative sets, like Thunder Punch over Fighting-type STAB moves, since Iron Hands can run these moves in its stead. Assault Vest Iron Hands also has immense bulk and acts like a sponge for special attacks from foes like Choice Scarf Flutter Mane and Volcarona, which can cause great problems for Pawmot, since it is relatively frail. Iron Hands can also slow pivot into Pawmot with the help of Volt Switch. In return, Pawmot deals with walls like Quagsire and offensive Rotom-W, which Iron Hands may face difficulty in breaking. Sandy Shocks sets hazards like Stealth Rock and Spikes to boost Pawmot's wallbreaking potential by providing necessary chip on foes while also being able to provide a Ground immunity thanks to Air Balloon, thus behaving like a switch-in against foes like opposing Sandy Shocks, Choice Scarf Iron Treads, Gholdengo, and Skeledirge. In exchange, Pawmot helps break foes like the Landorus formes and Gliscor that wall Sandy Shocks completely. Pawmot also threatens foes like Baxcalibur, Dragonite, mixed Amoonguss, and Galarian Slowking, which can cause problems for Sandy Shocks. Rotom-W is an essential teammate for Pawmot, as it provides a much-needed Ground immunity while also offering great utility with its defensive sets that run Will-O-Wisp and Thunder Wave. Hydro Pump on Rotom-W deals with pesky Ground-types like Great Tusk and Mamoswine, which Pawmot struggles against. Defensive Rotom-W benefits from Pawmot's ability to take down foes like Water Absorb Clodsire and Gastrodon. Thus, together they form a strong core on Electric-type teams. Teammates like Thundurus, Thundurus-T and Zapdos provide a Ground immunity for Pawmot while also threatening strong Fighting-type foes like Zamazenta and Great Tusk. Zapdos can break these physically bulky Pokemon with the help of Hurricane, while Thundurus-T can use Psychic as a coverage move for Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and physically defensive Amoonguss. In return, they appreciate Pawmot's ability to break specially defensive walls that hinder Zapdos and Thundurus-T's wallbreaking capability. Thundurus provides great support with Prankster Thunder Wave, paralyzing fast foes like Dragapult and Flutter Mane and allowing Pawmot to outspeed them. Magnezone pairs well with Pawmot, as it can act like a sponge for Fairy-type moves from foes like Hatterene, Iron Valiant, and Flutter Mane and force them out with Flash Cannon. In return, Pawmot helps to break special walls like Galarian Slowking and Clodsire, which Magnezone can't break.

Choice Scarf (Electric).description:
Pawmot is a great Choice Scarf user on Electric teams by virtue of its coverage and utility, being able to deal with Chien-Pao and Flutter Mane. With Revival Blessing, Pawmot can give second chances to fallen offensive Pokemon such as Iron Hands and Choice Specs Zapdos to punch holes in opposing teams. Double Shock allows Pawmot to OHKO threats such as Flutter Mane and Azumarill as well as finishing off Iron Valiant, but this comes with the downside of Pawmot immediately being forced out after using the move. Ice Punch allows Pawmot to deal decent damage to Ground-types that resist both its STAB moves, notably OHKOing both Landorus formes as well as 2HKOing both Iron Leaves and Clodsire. Volt Switch allows Pawmot to pivot out of a check such as Amoonguss into one of its teammates to deal with it. Play Rough and Seed Bomb are usable alternatives, with Play Rough being able to 2HKO Sableye while still hitting Dragon-types and Seed Bomb dealing with Water/Ground types that most Electric-type Pokemon cannot handle efficiently. Notably, Seed Bomb OHKOes specially defensive Gastrodon and 2HKOes physically defensive Quagsire. Grass Knot can also be used, being able to 2HKO Quagsire as well as Great Tusk.

Sandy Shocks provides great hazard support to wear down incoming foes for Pawmot to take advantage of. Ground-immune Pokemon such as Zapdos and Rotom-W are appreciated by Pawmot, being able to switch into an anticipated Ground-type attack from the likes of Great Tusk and Landorus-T. Zapdos can also threaten Grass-types such as Amoonguss, while Rotom-W together with Pawmot can overwhelm Quagsire. In return, Pawmot can revive one of them so it can continue checking Ground-types when needed. Regieleki provides hazard removal and a fast pivot for Electric teams, and in return it appreciates Ground-types being lured in and removed by Seed Bomb Pawmot variants. Assault Vest Iron Hands is another great teammate, being able to switch into attacks that could OHKO Pawmot such as Dragapult's Draco Meteor and Enamorus's Moonblast. Iron Hands can also OHKO the latter when running Heavy Slam. In return, Pawmot can run Seed Bomb to handle Water/Ground types Iron Hands cannot efficiently threaten such as Quagsire, and Swords Dance variants of Iron Hands appreciate it removing Flutter Mane and wearing down Sableye. Magnezone is a great partner, being able to threaten the Fairy-types that can threaten Pawmot such as Hatterene and Flutter Mane.

Revival Blessing Support.description:
• Revival Blessing is an extremely invaluable tool that lets Pawmot revive crucial teammates such as Dondozo and Meowscarada, very likely turning the battle in the user's favor. It is Pawmot's most important move, but an attack is slotted first in case the timer forces Pawmot to use its first move. Double Shock is better here if Pawmot Terastallizes into the Electric typing, which lets it repeatedly use the move without drawback or failure. If running the Fighting Tera type or not Terastallized, Close Combat is better in this moveslot.

  • Focus Sash, in tandem with Pawmot's high Speed, ensures it gets at least two moves off if it is not double targeted.

  • Volt Absorb synergizes with Electric-weak teammates such as Dondozo, while Natural Cure allows Pawmot to brush off status moves such as Amoonguss's Spore.

  • Both the Electric and Fighting Tera types provide offensive benefits to Pawmot, turning an attack into a reliable source of damage against a plethora of common Pokemon such as Murkrow, Dondozo, and/or Hydreigon. The Electric Tera type lets it use Double Shock repeatedly, which avoids the drawback of Close Combat lowering its defenses, turning it into a potent cleaner.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

Offensive Utility.description:
• Pawmot separates itself from Iron Hands by having an excellent support movepool and a good Speed tier.

  • Double Shock and Close Combat: Double Shock and Close Combat are its most important attacks, but note that it can only use Double Shock once without Terastallizing. Once Terastillized, Pawmot you can use Double Shock continuously for big damage, even on foes that resist it.

  • Mach Punch: Priority allows Pawmot to revenge kill better, hitting Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Iron Bundle super effectively.

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch gives Pawmot coverage against Ground-types, most notably Great Tusk, Clodsire, and Garchomp, in addition to hitting Dragonite for lots of damage before it Terastallizes.

  • Revival Blessing: Revival Blessing's one shot of reviving a teammate gives Pawmot an extremely unique niche in turning battles around, though it doesn't fit all offensive teams.

  • Nuzzle: This is notably one of the few ways to inflict paralysis on Gholdengo. Nuzzle is best when used with a Focus Sash, as Pawmot can paralyze the foe and outspeed it the next turn, getting another move off before it faints.

  • Encore: Encore does a great job of punishing passive play, and prevents easy setup from slower defensive foes such as Garganacl.

Other Options

  • Fake Out: This can be used to get an edge against common Focus Sash leads such as Meowscarada.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Situational: Terastallizing is only needed if Pawmot is on the field long enough for repeated uses of Double Shock.

  • Electric: An Electric Tera Type allows Pawmot to continuously use Double Shock, making it an effective late-game cleaner.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash trades the damage boost from the other items for better opportunities to use support moves.

  • Life Orb: Life Orbs enables easier revenge kills at the cost of recoil.

  • Magnet: Magnet will power up Double Shock without the recoil from Life Orb, and it also frees up Life Orb for a teammate to use instead.

Abilities

  • Iron Fist: This boosts the power of Mach Punch and Ice Punch, giving Pawmot more powerful priority and coverage.

  • Volt Absorb: Volt Absorb's Electric immunity stops Magnezone, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H from using Volt Switch to create safe switch-ins.

  • Natural Cure: This allows Pawmot to take status moves more freely, such as Yawn from Dondozo or Will-O-Wisp from Skeledirge.

Offensive.description:
• Pawmot's good offensive stats and unique support movepool give it a good niche in the metagame.

  • Double Shock and Close Combat are its most important attacks, but note that it can only use Double Shock once without Terastallizing. Once Terastillized, Pawmot you can use Double Shock continuously for big damage, even on foes that resist it.

  • Mach Punch allows Pawmot to revenge kill better, hitting Meowscarada, Choice Scarf Hydreigon, and Tera Steel Dragapult super effectively.

  • Ice Punch gives Pawmot coverage against Ground-types, most notably Clodsire and Garchomp, in addition to hitting Dragapult for lots of damage.

  • Revival Blessing's one shot of reviving a teammate give Pawmot an extremely unique niche in turning battles around, though it doesn't fit all offensive teams.

  • Nuzzle paralyzes foes, and it's notably one of the few ways to inflict paralysis on Gholdengo. This move is best when used with a Focus Sash, as Pawmot can paralyze the foe and outspeed it the next turn, getting another move off before it faints.

  • Encore does a great job of punishing passive play, and prevents easy setup from slower defensive foes such as Garganacl.

  • Fake Out can be used to get an edge against common Focus Sash leads such as Meowscarada.

Abilities

  • Iron Fist: This boosts the power of Mach Punch and Ice Punch, giving Pawmot more powerful priority and coverage.

  • Volt Absorb: Volt Absorb's Electric immunity stops Magnezone, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H from using Volt Switch to create safe switch-ins.

  • Natural Cure: This allows Pawmot to take status moves more freely, such as Yawn from Dondozo or Will-o-Wisp from Skeledirge.

Items

  • Life Orb: Life Orbs enables easier revenge kills at the cost of recoil.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash trades the damage boost from the other items for better opportunities to use support moves.

  • Magnet: Magnet will power up Double Shock without the recoil from Life Orb, and it also frees up Life Orb for a teammate to use instead.

Tera Types

  • Electric: An Electric Tera Type allows Pawmot to continuously use Double Shock, making it an effective late-game cleaner.

Tidy Up.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Wish.description:
Dachsbun is the best Wish passer in PU. Its great typing and decent overall bulk give it ample opportunity to keep itself and its teammates healthy while checking threats like Gabite and Alolan Persian. Well-Baked Body also lets Dachsbun switch into Fire-types like Charizard and Houndoom as well as absorb Will-O-Wisp from Misdreavus and Charizard, all of which threaten other Wish passers like Leafeon. Body Press prevents Steel-types from walling Dachsbun and also gets stronger if Well-Baked Body has already been triggered. Play Rough is good coverage alongside Body Press and hits Misdreavus, but Roar can be used instead to force setup sweepers like Gogoat and Carbink out as well as rack up chip damage if entry hazards are up. Copycat can be used to copy entry hazards from Pokemon like Whiscash as well as beat certain setup sweepers like Iron Defense Carbink one-on-one. Tera Steel lets Dachsbun absorb Steel- and Poison-type attacks and gives it an edge against Pokemon such as Sludge Bomb Houndoom, Articuno, and Indeedee-F. Dachsbun can run 64 Speed EVs to outspeed neutral-natured Honchkrow at the cost of some bulk. Dachsbun can also opt for a physically defensive spread to better take on Pokemon like Lycanroc-N and, after Terastallizing, Zangoose.

Dachsbun fits best on balance teams in need of cleric support and a blanket check to various offensive threats. Pokemon like Gabite, Mareanie, and Tinkatuff can check Steel- and Poison-types like Alolan Dugtrio and Skuntank for Dachsbun, and they appreciate Dachsbun coming to their aid against foes such as Articuno and Pyroar. Charizard is another great partner that switches into Steel-types like Perrserker and non-Rock Slide Alolan Dugtrio and can do so repeatedly thanks to the Wishes Dachsbun passes. Setup sweepers like Rotom-F and Gogoat find it easier to boost multiple times in a game with Dachsbun keeping them healthy. Wish support also gives Gogoat an easier time preserving Milk Drink's limited PP, which allows it to play more recklessly early on against threats that Dachsbun baits in, such as Basculin. In return, these setup sweepers make up for Dachsbun's passivity and can threaten out nuisances like Vespiquen and Whiscash. Misdreavus can spread burns to give Dachsbun an easier time against physical attackers like Crabominable and slow opposing walls down with Taunt. Meanwhile, Dachsbun can stand up to Fire-types like non-Tera Steel Charizard, check Dark-types like Alolan Persian and Honchkrow, and reduce Misdreavus's reliance on Pain Split for recovery.

Choice Specs.description:
